MUMBAI: Indiabulls Housing Finance has said in a statement that it has a Rs 662-crore exposure to Yes Bank ’s additional tier-1 ( AT1 ) bonds.

These bonds are to be written off as proposed under the RBI ’s resolution plan for the troubled lender.

Indiabulls Housing Finance said that neither the company nor promoter Sameer Gehlaut have any loans outstanding from the failed bank.

Yes Bank issued Rs 10,000 crore of AT1 bonds , of which over Rs 8,900 crore is outstanding with mutual funds, insurance companies, and some individual investors as well.

Title: AIFUCTO, JFME back schoolteachers’ demand
Content:
PATNA: The ongoing indefinite strike by more than 4.5 lakh contractual secondary and higher secondary schoolteachers of the state has got support from the All India Federation of University and College Teachers’ Organisations ( AIFUCTO ) and the Joint Forum for Movement on Education (JFME).

The teachers have been on strike since February 17 in support of their demands, including equal pay for equal work and better service conditions. More than 74,000 schools of the state have reportedly become dysfunctional due to their strike. Moreover, they boycotted invigilation work in secondary and Intermediate examinations and were boycotting evaluation of answer books.

Expressing grave concern over the prolonged strike by schoolteachers, AIFUCTO secretary Arun Kumar said most of the schools in the state are run by contractual teachers and the fate of more than 60% students depends on their performance. If they withdraw their services from the system, the entire educational machinery of the state would go topsy-turvy, he said.

He appealed to the chief minister to intervene and save the careers of lakhs of innocent boys and girls by conceding to the genuine demands of striking teachers.

The JFME, at its national executive meeting held in New Delhi recently, also supported the demands of contractual teachers of Bihar and appealed to the state government to find an amicable settlement of their demands in the larger interest of school education.

Title: Expedite Smart City projects: PMC boss
Content:
PATNA: Patna Municipal Corporation (PMC) commissioner Himanshu Sharma on Sunday reviewed the progress of several projects undertaken by Patna Smart City Limited (PSCL) in the city, including construction of smart network roads, Bakarganj Nala and installation of a mega screen at Gandhi Maidan.

At Gandhi Maidan, Sharma asked the contractor involved in installation of the 72-foot-high mega screen to ensure that the equipment connected to the projector is not damaged at any stage. “If there is defect in any equipment, it will be the responsibility of the contractor to fix it without any delay. The mega screen will be the major attraction for the residents because of its location,” Sharma added.

The mega screen at Gandhi Maidan, which was used on a trial basis on February 1, will be officially launched this month.

Sharma, who is also the managing director of PSCL, inspected the drainage facility near Gandhi Maidan. Chief sanitary inspector of PMC told Sharma that rainwater from Gandhi Maidan and nearby is released into the Ganga through the Bakarganj drain.

The commissioner also inspected work on construction of ‘Jan Sewa Kendra’ (public service centre) in ward number 22 under Patliputra circle and asked the executive officer to complete the process of obtaining no-objection certificate from the departments concerned at the earliest.

Sharma inspected the progress of smart road network project along with additional municipal commissioner Devendra Prasad Tiwari and chief general manager of PSCL Sudhir Kumar Sahu. Under the project, 30 roads will be redesigned to ensure better mobility, utility and liveability in the city.

Title: Budget allocation for Telangana farm sector
Content:
Additional Rs2k cr for Rythu Bandhu

The Rythu Bandhu scheme also was in focus in this budget with an additional allocation of 2,000 over last year. The finance minister announced that in 2019-20, 12,000 crore was allocated in budget at 10,000 per acre per annum. “Due to issuance of new passbooks, the number of beneficiaries will increase in the ensuing year and correspondingly 2,000 crore of additional funds have been allocated. In this budget, under Rythu Bandhu Scheme, we are proposing an amount of 14,000 crore,” Rao said.

Good growth for crop sector

Finance minister T Harish Rao announced that a good estimated growth rate for crop sector, at 23.7% in 2019- 20. The livestock and fishing sectors are estimated to grow at 17.3% and 8.1% respectively. The services sector is estimated to grow at 14.1% in 2019-20 at current prices.

Rs1.1k cr allotted for Rythu Bima

The government allotted 1,141 crore for Rythu Bima Scheme in the new budget. Under this scheme, the government is paying insurance premium amount of 2,271.5 per farmer to the LIC regularly. Under this scheme, an insurance amount of 5 lakh will be paid in 10 days in case a farmer passes away.

Title: NDA united in Bihar, says LJP chief Chirag Paswan
Content:
LJP chief Chirag Paswan

PATNA: Lok Janshakti Party (LJP) chief Chirag Paswan on Sunday said the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) was united in the state and CM Nitish Kumar was like a “guardian” to him.

“My recent statements were misinterpreted. There is no misunderstanding between me and the CM,” Chirag, who had earlier questioned the state government over rise in crime in the state, said.

“There is no denying the fact that development has taken place in the state under the stewardship of the CM, but there is still a lot of scope for development,” he added.

Chirag, who had started his ‘Bihar First, Bihari First Yatra’ last month, has planned to cover all the districts in a phased manner before holding the state-level rally of the party in Patna on April 14 to mark the birth anniversary of Dr B R Ambedkar .

Title: Coronavirus in Kolkata: Private hospitals set up isolation wards after state directive
Content:
Several private hospitals in Kolkata have set up isolation wards following an instruction from the health depa... Read More

KOLKATA: Several private hospitals in Kolkata have set up isolation wards following an instruction from the health department. As many as five government hospitals across the state have now been identified as swab-collection centres for nCoV. They will also train health employees on how to collect swabs, which will then be sent for tests at NICED and SSKM Hospital.

The hospitals to serve as swab collection units include RG Kar Medical College and Hospital, Uttar Banga Medical College and Hospital, Malda Medical College and Hospital, Murshidabad Medical College and Hospital and Midnapore Medical College and Hospital. Isolation wards have also been set up at private hospitals like RN Tagore International Institute of Cardiac Sciences (RTIICS) and AMRI Hospitals.

“AMRI Hospitals will strictly follow the health department advisory regarding setting up isolation wards at all our units along with the other guidelines suggested in the letter we received from the health department. We have already set up a waiting lounge for patients who are coming in with flu-like symptoms so that other patients at the OPD are not infected in any way,” said AMRI Hospitals CEO Rupak Barua.

“A six-bed triaging and isolation ward has been set up at RTIICS, but the majority of patients showing symptoms will be advised home isolation and conservative management at home,” said RTIICS zonal director R Venkatesh.

“If patients require ICU care, we have two beds in an isolated intensive care. The unit has dedicated ventilators and monitors apart from all necessary protective equipment. Our preparedness and planning has been led jointly by the head of internal medicine, a pulmonologist and an emergency physician,” Venkatesh added.

AMRI has also adopted an SOP on how to handle the situation in case someone is found infected with nCoV. “We are educating our nurses and other caregivers who are directly involved in handling patients. We are also keeping an eye on their health and our infection control teams are taking stock of the situation regularly,” said Barua.

Title: Women steal the show on special day
Content:
PATNA: International Women’s Day was celebrated with full enthusiasm across the state on Sunday.

The women employees of Airports Authority of India (AAI) operated the air traffic control, communication navigation surveillance and engineering departments at Patna airport. Addressing the staff, Ranjana Negi, chairperson of Women Welfare Association of AAI-Patna said women are not behind men in any sector.

Women railway employees were given free hands to handle reservation counters and run passenger and goods trains independently as loco pilots. Shobha Kumari, Binita Kumari and Shradha Sharma piloted a goods train from Muzaffarpur to Sonepur while Babita Kumari was the guard on duty in the goods train.

According to East Central Railway (ECR) chief public relations officer Rajesh Kumar, operations at Gulzarbagh railway station were fully handled by women staff.

In Patna, women enjoyed free bus ride on all 14 routes. Around 27,800 women boarded city buses on Digha, Bihta, Boring Road, Bailey Road, Ashok Rajpath, Phulwarisharif and airport routes.

Anupriya, a resident of Gardanibagh, said the transport department took a positive initiative by making bus rides free for women on this special day.

The environment, forest and climate change department, on the other hand, gave free access to women in all parks. Patna zoo director Amit Kumar said over 8,500 people, including 4,000 women, visited the zoo on Sunday.

Eco Park, Buddha Smriti Park, Veer Kunwar Singh Park and S K Puri Park also witnessed footfall of a large number of women folks. Kiran Kumari, a student of JD Women’s College, spent her time with family and friends at Eco Park and enjoyed a long chat. Nitu Paswan, a resident of Ashiana Colony, said she spent the day with her husband and kids at Patna zoo.

Art, culture and youth affairs department and Bihar State Power Holding Company Limited (BSPHCL) felicitated their women employees for their exemplary work.

Altogether 21 women employees of electricity department were felicitated by former chief secretary of Bihar Anjani Kumar Singh at an event organised by BSPHCL. Singh said women have shown courage in every field, including sports and defence. BSPHCL managing director Pratyaya Amrit was also present on the occasion.

Women artists from state were felicitated by art, culture and youth affairs minister Pramod Kumar at an event held at Rajendra Nagar Bhawan in Motihari.

Meanwhile, CM Nitish Kumar greeted women on the occasion. “Women play an important role in the development of state and nation. Women empowerment is an integral part of the policies of the state government. I extend hearty congratulation and best wishes to all women on the occasion of International Women’s Day (sic),” he tweeted.

(With inputs from Kumod Verma)

CM congratulates Bina, Bhawana: CM Nitish Kumar on Sunday congratulated Bina Devi and Bhawana Kanth for receiving ‘Nari Shakti Puraskar 2019’ from President Ram Nath Kovind in New Delhi. He said the two made the state proud by winning the award.

Title: Hike in steel, cement prices hurting realtors
Content:
At a time when Visakhapatnam is preparing itself to host the executive capital of Andhra Pradesh, the realty sector of the region was anticipating a boom. However, the spike in prices of steel and cement has significantly affected the sector’s optimism. Realtors are of the opinion that if the prices continue to go up, they will be compelled to stop under-construction projects and wait for the prices to go down.

Speaking to TOI, Koteswara Rao, a city-based realtor said, “2019 was a bad year for us. With the new government implementing a fresh sand policy, the supply of sand went down and the price of sand increased in the black market. Many projects got stalled. But finally, when sand prices came down, the price of steel and cement is affecting our business.

While a 50kg bag of cement cost Rs 225 in January, the price went up to Rs 325 per bag in mid-February. Now, the price has gone up to Rs 400 per bag. Similarly, the price of steel has increased by nearly 60 per cent over the last six months, of which, a 30 per cent hike has occurred over the last three months.

“Generally, this is the peak season for construction business. The price of cement and steel remains competitive during this time of the year. But this year is an exception and manufacturers are hiking the price of steel and cement,” Rao added.

Suppliers claimed that the price hike for steel is due to rise in prices in the international market. “As far as we are aware, steel prices have gone up globally and it has had an effect on Indian steel prices also. Owing to a lack of demand, steel prices reduced from April to September last year. Now, the demand has increased and prices of steel have also gone up,” said N Nagendra Rao, a wholesaler.

On the rising price of cement, experts said while prices were stable in southern states till the end of 2019, the price in Visakhapatnam rose this year due to high real estate demand.

“Due to the new sand policy of the state government there was shortage of sand supply and owing to this many projects were stalled in the city. As supply of sand normalised in November, realtors restarted stalled projects and demand increased by leaps and bounds,” said Nagendra Rao.

Currently, more than 5,000 flats in large complexes and 2,000 in smaller complexes are up for sale in the city and its outskirts. Many of these are still under construction.

Realtors feel that while the price of real estate is increasing in Visakhapatnam with the executive capital proposal on the table, the increase in prices might actually lessen demand, thereby damaging the hopes for a realty sector boom.

Title: ‘Holika Dahan at new place won’t be allowed’
Content:
Varanasi: The city markets, on Sunday, remained flooded with people making purchases for the festival of colours falling on Tuesday. Markets were opened even on weekly closure day on Sunday and witnessed huge crowd till midnight

While the festive mood gripped the city with several shops selling vibrant colours, sprinklers and different kinds of masks and caps in the markets, the district administration and police remained on high alert to ensure proper security arrangements and keeping anti-social elemnest at bay.

The administration and the police made it clear that no new tradition will be allowed to start on the festival of Holi and only traditional Holikas, set up at over 1,100 places in the city, will be burnt on the eve of Holi.

ADM city VK Singh said that over 1,100 traditional Holikas are set up in the city limits. Holika Dahan at only these 1,100 places will be performed on Monday, he said adding that Holika at no new place will be allowed. Strict vigil will be maintained by the police personeel deployed at all Holikas, he added.

A series of meetings of peace committees was conducted by all the police stations while district magistrate Kaushal Raj Sharma and SSP Prabhakar Chawdhary also conducted a meeting with people of all communities at Town Hall ground on Saturday evening. During the meeting the officials appealed to people to maintain peace and harmony and said that that no hooliganism will be allowed in the name of celebration.

Police forces took out march in the markets and other localities. Extra alertness was evident in mixed populated areas.

Title: Bengal man dies after returning from Saudi Arabia with fever
Content:
Kolkata: A 33-year-old labourer from Murshidabad who had returned from Saudi Arabia on Saturday with cough, fever and breathing distress, and had been admitted to Murshidabad Medical College and Hospital, died on Sunday. The swab sample has been sent to NICED in Kolkata to find out if he had been suffering from Covid-19. The report is expected on Monday. Till now, no Covid-19 case has been detected in the state. Another Murshidabad resident, a 21-year-old youth who returned to Kolkata from Dubai on Sunday morning, was admitted to Beliaghata ID Hospital after being thermal screened at Kolkata airport and was found to have with fever, cough and cold.

Doctors said the 21-year-old youth worked as a sweeper in Saudi Arabia and had been suffering from fever and cold when he took a flight home. After being screened at the airport, he was handed over to workers from the health department who brought him to Beliaghata ID Hospital in a special ambulance around 11.15am. He was admitted in IB6 ward and doctors said his fluid sample would be sent for tests on Monday.

With the addition of the youth, two persons are now admitted to ID Hospital as coronavirus suspects. If their test reports are negative, they will be discharged but will be advised home isolation for four weeks.

The 33-year-old victim had reached Kolkata on Saturday morning with cough, fever, breathing distress and body ache. He travelled to Murshidabad and was admitted to a hospital early on Sunday morning. He passed away around 4pm, less than eight hours later. The chief medical officer, health, of Murshidabad, Prasanta Biswas, said the cause of death is yet to be determined. “We have sent his swab sample to Kolkata for a test. All superspecialty and other hospitals in the district have been put on alert after the death. We are taking all possible precautions and stepping up vigil,” he said.

According to his family, the Belepukur resident was a diabetes patient. When he started suffering from cough and cold and had difficulty breathing in Saudi Arabia, he panicked.

“He was scared and rushed back as soon as he could. Unfortunately, his symptoms worsened very quickly even though he was admitted to hospital within hours of his arrival,” said his cousin.

The health department is now considering an upgrade of the laboratory at IPGMER for testing swab samples of Covid-19 suspects. “The state has set up 163 beds in isolation facilities. The training will allow more personnel to collect swab and serum samples according to protocol,” an official said.

Title: Schools Closed in Gurgaon: Three schools suspend classes
Content: GURUGRAM: At least three schools in the city sent out advisories to parents in the past 24 hours, announcing suspension of classes as a precautionary measure in the wake of the coronavirus scare Heritage Xperiential Learning School (HXLS) said in its circular that the management had held multiple rounds of discussions with teachers and the safety committee, and decided to suspend classes from March 9 to 29 as attendance had dropped substantially. “On Sunday evening, we received a circular announcing the closure of school. However, Shiv Nadar School, where my daughter studies, hasn't announced anything like this,” said Tripti Singh, whose son studies in Heritage.Neena Kaul, the principal of HXLS, said, “The well-being of our community is essential to us. In the past few weeks, we have been closely assessing the situation. With the increasing number of suspected cases in Gurugram, we have decided to advance our session break and close the school from March 9 to 29. We will use this time to prepare ourselves better for providing virtual lessons to ensure a seamless a learning experience for our children.”Manav Rachna International School in Sector 46 sent out a notification to parents on Saturday, informing them that classes would be closed for toddlers to Class IV.“Keeping in mind the safety and security of our students in light of the COVID-19 scares, MIRS-46 has decided to close the session early for the toddlers to Grade IV with effect from March 9,” the circular sent out by the school read.“However, the examination for classes V to VIII will be conducted as scheduled and Grade X and XII will have their regular classes,” it added.The third school that announced closure of classes was Blue Bells, said sources in the know of things.There are more than 500 private schools in the city.

Title: Congress reminds RJD of one Rajya Sabha seat promise
Content:
Bihar Congress incharge Shaktisinh Gohil

PATNA: All, it seems, is not well with the two major constituents of Bihar Mahagathbandhan – Congress and RJD – as the former on Sunday reminded Lalu’s party of a “commitment” it had made during the last Lok Sabha elections to give one Rajya Sabha seat to it.

In a letter written on Sunday, Bihar Congress incharge Shaktisinh Gohil also ruled out the possibility of his candidature for the Rajya Sabha from Bihar. He, however, reminded ally RJD of its promise to give one seat to the Congress in Rajya Sabha.

“RJD leader Tejashwi Prasad Yadav had categorically said in the joint press conference of Mahagathbandhan during Lok Sabha polls that one seat from RJD quota in Rajya Sabha will be left for Congress. Hope RJD fulfils its promise,” Gohil wrote.

On speculations about his candidature, Gohil said, “If Congress gets the promised Rajya Sabha seat, its candidate will be a leader from Bihar only. Anyone like me, who is not a voter in Bihar, will not be candidate of Congress.”

Asked about Congress’s demand for one seat, RJD national vice-president Shivanand Tiwari said, “The RJD had not made any such commitment to Congress. RJD’s state president Jagdanand Singh had also made this clear. However, Lalu ji has been authorised to take decision on this matter,” he said.

Notification for the biennial election to Rajya Sabha was issued on March 6. According to sources, five vacancies will be created from Bihar in the Rajya Sabha following end of tenure for Harivansh, Kahkashan Perween and Ram Nath Thakur of JD(U), besides Dr C P Thakur and R K Sinha of BJP on April 9.

As per norms for election of members for Rajya Sabha, first preferential votes of 42 members of state legislative assembly are required for sending a candidate to the Upper House.

Sources said as per present strength of major political parties in Bihar assembly, BJP can send one member, while JD (U) and RJD can send two members each.

Though the Rajya Sabha biennial elections will be held on March 26, no major political party from Bihar has declared the names of its candidates so far.

Title: 22 of marriage party hurt as jeep collides with parked lorry in Nalanda
Content:
BIHARSHARIF: At least 22 persons of a marriage party sustained injuries on Sunday morning, when the jeep they were travelling in collided with a parked lorry near Jayprakashpur Bhedia village under Noorsarai police station area in Nalanda district .

The injured persons, including 17 women and three minor girls, were admitted to Noorsarai and Chandi primary health centres (PHCs). Two critically injured were sent to PMCH, a police officer at Noorsarai police station said. The two seriously injured were identified as Ram Pravesh Sao and Krishna Sao.

He said Ram Pravesh of Soradih under Harnaut police station was returning home with his relatives after attending his son’s wedding at a Biharsharif temple late Saturday night. “The driver of the jeep lost control and hit the parked lorry. He said the newlywed couple and some other relatives were safe as they travelled by separate vehicles,” he said.

Title: Flipkart probe: E-vendor group files caveat in Supreme Court
Content:
(File photo)

BENGALURU: Following the National Company Law Appellate Tribunal (NCLAT) order last week to begin a probe into Flipkart for abuse of its dominant position, the All India Online Vendors Association (AIOVA) has filed a caveat in the Supreme Court against the Walmart-owned e-tailer. The move by AIOVA , the group representing small e-vendors, comes in anticipation of Flipkart challenging the NCLAT order in the SC. TOI has reviewed the filing.

A caveat is a notice submitted in anticipation by a person or an entity, informing the court that another person or entity may file a lawsuit or application against them and that the court should give the caveator (the person who has filed the caveat) a fair hearing before deciding on the matter brought in front of the court.

Interestingly, soon after acquiring 77% stake in Flipkart in 2018, Walmart had also filed caveats in the Delhi HC against the RSS-affiliate Swadeshi Jagran Manch (SJM) and Confederation of All India Traders (CAIT), entities which had opposed the acquisition of the homegrown e-tailer by the US brick-and-mortar retailer.

An AIOVA spokesperson confirmed it filed the caveat on Saturday. Flipkart did not respond to a query emailed by TOI.

Title: 1,000 Jan Aushadhi outlets by 2024: Minister
Content:
PATNA: Union minister of state for health and family welfare Ashwini Kumar Choubey said here on Sunday that the number of PM Jan Aushadhi outlets in the state to provide medicines to the poor and lower middle class citizens at low prices would be increased to 1,000 by 2024.

Choubey said at present the state has only 66 such outlets. He hoped that the state government would accelerate the process of setting up more outlets in the government hospitals to derive benefits of the central government’s scheme.

The minister said altogether 6,200 Jan Aushadhi outlets were operational across the country. The number would be increased to 10,000 by the end of 2024. He pointed out that 1.25 crore people across the country were purchasing medicines from Jan Aushadhi outlets, which provided 900 kinds of medicines and 174 kinds of surgical items.

“The health ministry is planning to increase the number of medicines from 900 to 2000 and surgical items from 174 to 300 by the end of 2024,” Choubey said, adding that around 5.5 crore people belonging to economically backward and lower middle class were in debt due to high expenses on medicines and medicare in the country.

He said sanitary pads were being sold at Rs1 each at all Jan Aushadhi outlets. “PM Narendra Modi has kept the promise made,” he added.

Referring to Ramayan circuit, the BJP MP from Buxar said the Ramayan Express carrying around 350 people would reach Buxar on March 13. The travellers would get acquainted with the Rameshwaram temple at Ram Chaura Ghat in Buxar before departing for Sitamarhi and Janakpur (Nepal).

Title: Patna set to celebrate Holi with fun, frolic
Content:
Dry and organic Holi:

factor:

Skincare tips:

Food and delicacies:

PATNA: Residents of the city are all set to celebrate Holi , the festival of colours, with utmost zeal and enthusiasm. The two-day festival, which will begin with ‘Holika Dahan’ on Monday, marks the beginning of spring season. It is observed on the full-moon day of the Hindi month of Falgun.Holika Dahan will be celebrated on Monday on the eve of Holi when people will burn bonfires. As per city-based priest Shyam Upadhyay, a pyre is set up in an open area where two effigies – one of Holika and another of Prahlad – are placed. “While Holika’s effigy is made of combustible material, Prahlad’s effigy is made of non-combustible material. The day depicts the victory of good over evil as ‘Prahlad’ defeated his devil aunt ‘Holika’,” he said.Meanwhile, forest department principal secretary Dipak Kumar Singh has urged people to avoid burning non-combustible items, especially tyres and lubricants. “When burned, these non-combustible items release very toxic and harmful gases, which are bad for environment as well as health of people,” Singh said, adding people should also avoid burning bonfires near forest areas or areas surrounded by plants.In a bid to avoid wasting water, people now prefer playing dry Holi. Several communities and societies have started celebrating the festival without using water. Paltliputra Cooperative Society ’s secretary Rai Ajeet Prasad said Holi should be celebrated with fun and without harming nature. “We can only achieve a safe and harmless Holi by not using water and celebrating it with herbal and organic colours,” he said.Doctors at private and government healthcare centres have advised people to celebrate Holi without the fear of coronavirus. Patna civil surgeon Dr Raj Kishore said people don’t need to panic as there hasn’t been any confirmed case of coronavirus in the state so far. “Residents don’t need to avoid gatherings or Holi Milan events as it has nothing to do with coronavirus,” he added.From oiling the hair to applying petroleum jelly or moisturising lotion on the body, people follow several processes to protect their skin from harmful chemicals during Holi. “Some colours have very harmful chemicals which can result in breakouts, acne and even rashes. Hence it’s very important to cover the skin with a layer of moisturizer and sunscreen. Besides, coating the hair before playing Holi is very important as the colours can damage the hair,” said city-based dermatologist Ajay Kumar.The festival of colours is all about fun, rituals and mouth-watering dishes. Most people begin cooking traditional food items like ‘malpua’, ‘gujiya’, ‘ dahi vada ’ and ‘thandai’. Some start preparing Holi delicacies two-three days in advance. “Several people visit my house on the evening of Holi. Every year, apart from the traditional dishes, I try to treat them with a new food item. This time, I will serve chocolate ‘golgappa’ to my guests,” said Anita Sinha, a resident of Kankarbagh.Guv, CM greet people: Several prominent personalities extended their wishes to people on the occasion of Holi. In his message, governor Phagu Chauhan said, “I wish that the festival of colours brings prosperity, happiness, peace and joy in the lives of people across the state and a calm atmosphere prevails in the society. I also wish that the festival is celebrated with utmost brotherhood and communal harmony.”CM Nitish Kumar too hoped that the festival would bring happiness and prosperity in the lives of people. “Holi symbolises the victory of good over evil. The biggest speciality of this festival is that it is celebrated by everyone without any differences and with love and affection for each other. I appeal to people in the state to celebrate this festival with mutual love, brotherhood and social harmony,” Nitish said in a statement.Former CM Rabri Devi too extended her wishes. “Let us pledge to burn the evil inside us on Holika Dahan this year and put our lives in good deeds. May the festival of colours fill our lives with joy, peace and harmony,” she said.

Title: IMD forecasts thunderstorm on March 10 in Bihar
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

PATNA: Weather may play spoilsport on Holi as India Meteorological Department ( IMD ) has predicted thunderstorm with lightning and even hail over Bihar from March 10 to 12.

The IMD has attributed the weather condition to a confluence between westerly winds associated with a western disturbance and low-level easterly wind from the Bay of Bengal over central and east India.

IMD bulletin on Sunday said the aforementioned weather system is expected to lead to moderate to scattered rainfall with isolated thunderstorm or lightning or hail along with gusty winds (speed reaching 30-40kmph) over Bihar, Jharkhand, Odisha, Madhya Pradesh , Chattisgarh and Vidarbha during March 10 to 12.

It has also issued warning for thunderstorm accompanied with lightning and gusty winds at a few places in Bihar on March 11 and 12.

As per daily weather bulletin issued by Patna Meteorological Centre , only one or two places in south-west and east Bihar districts are likely to receive rain along with thundershowers on March 10. However, turbulent weather is likely at a few places in all the 38 districts on March 11 and 12.

A yellow colour warning has also been sounded for all 38 districts in the state for thunderstorm with lightning and gusty wind (30-40 kmph). A yellow colour weather alert stipulates the authorities to be watchful of the weather changes.

The Patna Met office stated that light to moderate rainfall occurred at one or two places over northern parts of Bihar during the past 24 hours. It predicted fall in night temperature by two to three notches over land area of the region during the next 72 hours.

Title: Ashwini Kumar Choubey: No coronavirus fatality in country yet;Union minister
Content: PATNA: Union minister of state for health and family welfare Ashwini Kumar Choubey on Sunday said 39 positive coronavirus cases have so far been reported in the country with zero fatallity.Choubey, who was here to attend the core committee meeting of the BJP to finalize the names for probable candidates for the Rajya Sabha seats falling vacant from Bihar, said 28,529 people were under the surveillance of medical experts in the country.He said altogether 34 laboratories were operational in the country. “The number of laboratories will be increased to 50 in a day or two. In addition, a team of medical experts has been sent to Iran to ensure that no Indian citizen tested positive could fly back to India,” he said.“The Indian citizens tested positive in Iran are being provided medical assistance by the team and a laboratory has been set up there for the purpose. However, those tested negative, including the ones from Siwan in Bihar, are being allowed to fly to India from Iran,” the minister said.Referring to the initiatives taken by the Centre to deal with coronavirus, Choubey said a rapid response team (RRT) has been set up to assist the states from where majority of the cases has been reported. Besides, a group of ministers set up by the central government is taking stock of the situation on a daily basis, he said.He said people coming to India from Nepal through Bihar are being properly screened. “The states have been asked to develop mechanism to gather reports from panchayat level so that the problem could be tackled properly,” he added. Isolation facilities identified in state: The state health department has identified isolation facilities in every district to accommodate coronavirus patients and suspects. People with a travel history to countries affected by the virus will be monitored in home isolation. “People with symptoms similar to the virus will be identified and put in isolation. Active door-to-door surveillance will be done by ASHA workers,” state surveillance officer Dr Ragini Mishra said, adding altogether 6,579 PRI members and 57,245 health workers have been appointed by the state health government for the purpose.

Title: Kolkatans gather for early-morning revelry on Happy Streets, this time in Lake Town
Content:
The Happy Streets crowd on Sunday

KOLKATA: The 2km-long service road stretch off VIP Road — between Lake Town and Golaghata — turned into a hub of activities on Sunday morning. Happy Streets, organized by The Times Of India in association with Bidhannagar Police, was held at Lake Town for the first time and the event was inaugurated by Bidhannagar MLA and state fire and emergency services minister Sujit Bose.

The overcast sky of Saturday night turned into a bright sunny morning as thousands poured in to soak in the fun at this year’s fifth Happy Streets.

“I congratulate everybody for being part of this wonderful initiative on Women’s Day. Enjoy and have fun with your friends and family,” Bose said.

The main stage hosted a zumba session by Zin Chandana, followed by BeatBoxing by Romit Dutta and Moitreya Chatterjee. There was also a number of activities led by anchor Saahil Agarwal.

There were multiple zones across the 2km-stretch, including a kids’ zone, sports zone, activity zone and a cycling zone. Fun on Wheels had kids learning to skate while Kolkata Gojukai Karate Do taught attendees some basic moves. The kids’ activities hosted by International School of Design (INSD), Kolkata and Sticky Bits kept the young ones busy. A lot of people also attended the yoga session held by Yoga Plus.

Many in the crowd who had attended some of the previous Happy Streets editions said it was a new experience altogether with the Lake Town clock tower in the backdrop. “The atmosphere is amazing. We want Happy Streets to continue and we will come again,” said a girl who had come from the nearby Bangur area.

There were also people playing football and badminton. Teens took advantage of an early morning outing and cycled along the stretch. Six-year-old Gaurika Gupta from Lake Town was excited to attend Happy Streets for the first time and promptly took to roller skating.

Several senior citizens out for their morning walk joined the Happy Streets crowd, saying it was a whole new experience.

Title: Mutual funds ask investors to change Yes Bank account mandate
Content:
(File photo)

MUMBAI: The mutual fund ( MF ) industry has stepped in to help investors who had linked their Yes Bank accounts for payment and receipt of funds with regards to their investments with the fund houses. The industry as a whole has suspended crediting all Yes Bank accounts in case of redemptions and dividend payouts.

MFs have also stopped all systematic investment plan (SIP) mandates from investors that were to come from Yes Bank accounts till an alternative account is provided, Association of Mutual Funds in India ( Amfi ) chairman Nilesh Shah said.

These decisions were taken by the fund houses soon after the RBI imposed restrictions on the private lender on Thursday evening. “All of us didn’t pay money to Yes Bank accounts for redemptions. We were able to allot NAVs against money collected from Yes Bank till Thursday. But for future SIPs, since money won’t come from Yes Bank, we won’t be able to give them NAVs,” Shah said.

NAV, or net asset value, is the price of each unit of an MF scheme at which an investor can either invest in the fund or redeem holdings. Although Sebi rules allow MFs to accept cash investments in their schemes for up to Rs 50,000 per year, given the extra administrative hassles for such inflows, all fund houses insist on investments either through cheques or electronic payments.

An email to investors from PPFAS MF said that all purchase transactions including SIPs involving Yes Bank have been disallowed for a temporary period (one to three months) from Friday and it may also be extended further. Or, “in case of any relaxation by the RBI, we may start processing SIP transaction as well as purchase transaction”. The fund house asked its investors to route all purchase transactions through a new bank account immediately, as this would help “in minimising the dislocation in SIP programme”.

PPFAS MF also said it was withholding all payments to Yes Bank account holders from its funds for the time being and asked its investors to provide a “change of bank mandate” for all future redemptions.

Title: UPI Payments: PhonePe, BharatPe in talks with multiple banks to support UPI
Content: BENGALURU/MUMBAI: After burning the midnight oil to migrate Yes Bank consumer IDs and merchant payments on the Unified Payments Interface (UPI) to ICICI Bank , both PhonePe and BharatPe (one of the largest merchant payments apps) said they restored operations fully over the weekend. These include peer-to-peer and merchant payments via UPI .Following the Yes Bank shocker, Bengaluru-based PhonePe has now initiated talks with State Bank of India (SBI) to have a multi-bank approach for UPI, two people aware of the matter said. Delhi-based BharatPe too is in talks with Kotak Mahindra Bank as well as SBI .After ICICI Bank came to the rescue on Friday, the Mumbai-based bank now is processing almost 60% of UPI transactions, as it was already working closely with Google Pay, one of the top apps on the platform. Sources also said that the National Payments Corporation of India ( NPCI ) played a critical role in emerging out of the Yes Bank crisis in 24 hours.“NPCI was constantly monitoring the situation. Yes Bank has given a no-objection certificate to migrate user UPI handles to ICICI Bank till the moratorium is in place. Changes were done after that,” a source said.PhonePe co-founder and CEO Sameer Nigam, as part of his reply to a comment, said on Twitter, “Just never imagined the bank itself going totally dark like this. Lesson learnt in the hardest possible way.” PhonePe also took a hit on its balance sheet as it had to settle payments with merchants via the new nodal account with ICICI Bank, as the money in Yes Bank nodal account remains stuck.The amount which PhonePe had used to settle with its merchants is not known, but it is one of the largest consumer-focused UPI apps, clocking 20 million daily transactions. Nigam, whose PhonePe was hit the most, had to fly down to Mumbai on Friday morning amid one of its worst crises so far.“All our QRs are active now. It was one of the fastest migrations ever done — NPCI was working with us overnight to get this done,” said BharatPe co-founder and CEO Ashneer Grover. BharatPe had 20-30% exposure to Yes Bank for its QR codes.ICICI Bank said that it could manage to respond to the crisis at PhonePe because the bank had an application programming interface, called APIs, ready and systems tested for high-volume transactions during ‘peacetime’, and it also has fraud analytics systems in place. “The bank put together a 40-strong team of legal, operations and technology to avoid having to obtain approvals sequentially. In future, if customers want, the handles would be revised to reflect ICICI Bank domain names,” said ICICI Bank ED Anup Bagchi.Currently, PhonePe users can transact using their existing UPI IDs of Yes Bank — @ybl, as TOI reported in its Saturday edition. Kotak Mahindra Bank’s chief digital officer Deepak Sharma said it is always on the lookout for “mutually beneficial partnerships” without commenting on talks with BharatPe. An email sent to SBI did not elicit any response till the time going to press.

Title: Avail central govt schemes, says Union minister Ravi Shankar Prasad
Content:
PATNA: Union minister Ravi Shankar Prasad said on Sunday that women engaged in various productive activities, including in the non-government sectors, startups and entrepreneurial ventures, have been giving new direction to their personal and family lives, besides contributing to the good of society.

The Patna Sahib MP was interacting with a group of women on the occasion of International Women’s Day. They also shared their experiences in such diverse fields and narrated the changes that they had brought about in their own lives and families and also in society by engaging in choice enterprising and entrepreneurial activities, as well as social service work.

Prasad gave the details of central schemes that PM Narendra Modi had introduced for the welfare of women and to also create opportunities for them for self-employment.

In this regard, he referred to the ‘Beti bachao, beti padhao’ and ‘Sukanya Samriddhi’ schemes. To give dignity to their lives, the central government had got constructed 11 crore toilets in the last five to six years, including for girl students in schools, he said and added that the central government had also facilitated opportunities for them to excel in such new areas as Indian Air Force by giving permission to allow women to become pilots and fly fighter or air defence planes.

That apart, the central government has also paid adequate attention to women’s health by promoting the manufacture and use of sanitary napkins, Prasad said, adding that the information technology had opened before them whole lot of opportunities for their own economic benefits and also of their families and people living even in villages. In this regard, he cited the cases of women working in common service centres in rural areas, where they have been helping village people.

On the occasion, a few women working in the common service centres also narrated their experiences, pointing out that it had not only brought their own economic well-being, but also improved the income of their families. Further, it had also given them a life of dignity and respect in the villages, they said.

Title: RJD man among 2 shot dead in Bihar
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

PATNA/ARA: Two people, including an RJD functionary, were killed in Siwan and Bhojpur districts on Sunday.

Sanjay Manjhi (35), an RJD functionary, was shot dead by armed criminals at his ancestral house at Molanpur village under the Mufassil police station area in Siwan district around 1am. The incident occurred when Manjhi was sleeping in his room. “Somebody knocked the door and requested him to open it. The assailants pumped three bullets into Manjhi’s body after he opened the door,” police said.

Manjhi was rushed to the sadar hospital at Siwan where the doctors declared him brought dead. As the news about the murder spread in the area, Manjhi’s supporters assembled at the hospital and shouted anti-police slogans.

The police faced a tough time dealing with the protesters. However, the situation was brought under control after the intervention of senior police officers. “An FIR has been lodged against unidentified persons on the statement of the deceased’s relative,” Siwan SDPO Jitendra Pandey said.

In Bhojpur district, one Ashok Kumar Mishra (38) was killed by unidentified criminals in a diara area of Sonbarsha village under Karnamepur police outpost. Police said the criminals fired at Mishra, a farmer, when he had gone to collect fodder for his cattle from diara.

The deceased’s father, Brij Kumar Mishra, a retired soldier, reported the incident to the police. Bhojpur SP Sushil Kumar said that the deceased had an altercation with some locals residents two days ago. “Raids are on to arrest the killers,” he added.

Title: Pushpam Chaudhary: London School of Economics alumna Pushpam Priya Chaudhary projects herself for Bihar CM’s post
Content:
Pushpam hails from a political family in Darbhanga.

Bihar needs pace, Bihar needs wings, Bihar needs change. Because Bihar deserves better and better is possible. Reje… https://t.co/l2kb4XMGHK — Pushpam Priya Choudhary (@pushpampc13) 1583627551000

PATNA: Newspaper readers in Bihar woke up to the launch of a new political platform,‘Plurals’, on Sunday, with London School of Economics alumna Pushpam Priya Chaudhary declaring herself to be the CM candidate in the state assembly elections slated to be held later this year.Coinciding with International Women’s Day, Pushpam’s campaign seemed a bit unorthodox as far as politics in Bihar is concerned. The newspapers advertisements and her social media handles had a message in English: “Love Bihar, Hate Politics? Join the most progressive political party. Plurals has arrived. Bihar deserves better and Better is possible.” It mentions Pushpam as “president, Plurals and CM candidate Bihar 2020”.Her letter in Hindi talks about making Bihar the most developed state by 2025 and making growth rate of Bihar equal to any European country by 2030. It asks people to preserve the letter as the oath-taking document, which she would read on being elected in the upcoming elections.Pushpam hails from a political family in Darbhanga. Her father Vinod Kumar Chaudhary was a JD(U) MLC from Darbhanga graduate constituency from 2008 to 2014. Her grandfather Uma Kant Chaudhary also unsuccessfully contested the assembly elections four times from erstwhile Samata Party.Vinod said he was also the state general secretary of JD(U), but presently contesting as an independent candidate from the same Darbhanga graduate constituency.He, however, feigned ignorance about Pushpam’s decision to launch herself as the CM candidate. “She never discussed with me with clarity about such a plan. We had a conversation around a month ago that some big multinational company was offering her a job with a package of Rs8 crore per annum in London. I asked her to take it up, but she told me that she wants to do something big. She told me that I’m getting old now and should look after my health and allow her to enter electoral politics,” Vinod told TOI on Sunday.Vinod, however, did not share her contact number saying Pushpam returned to India only a five days ago and had no local cellphone number yet. He said Pushpam, in her late 20s, did her schooling in Darbhanga and graduation from Symbiosis International University , Pune.Pushpam also worked as creative head in Bihar State Tourism Development Corporation for a brief period in 2012. “Later, she did MA in Development Studies from Institute of Development Studies, University of Sussex, United Kingdom (2016), followed by Master of Public Administration from London School of Economics and Political Science (2019),” Vinod said, adding that her sister Juhi is in the UK Civil Services.While Pushpam could not be contacted, she tweeted on Sunday: “Bihar needs pace, Bihar needs wings, Bihar needs change. Because Bihar deserves better and better is possible. Reject bullshit politics, join Plurals to make Bihar run and fly in 2020. #PluralsHasArrived #ProgressiveBihar2020.”In another tweet on March 6, she wrote: “Integrating Multiple Realities: My studies at LSE and IDS and also my experiences in Bihar have taught me that there cannot be a single model of development as every individual has a unique reality.”

Title: Sonbhadra: Bodies of woman, two daughters found in well
Content:
Representative image

VARANASI: Bodies of a woman and her two daughters were recovered from a well in Banauli village in Sonbhadra district on Saturday night, police said.

SP, Sonbhadra, Ashish Srivastava said, “The bodies have been sent for post-mortem examination. The cause of death will be ascertained after we receive the post-mortem report.”

Police said Mira (26) and her daughters, aged 2 and 5, went missing on Saturday evening after which their family members started searching for them and found their bodies inside a well behind their house.

Title: Villages in capital city region not to be part of local polls
Content:
Amaravati: In an interesting development, the state government has decided not to hold local body elections to villages in the capital city areas.

Citing the court cases regarding the merger of some of the villages into neighbouring municipal towns, the state government has requested the State Election Commission (SEC) to withdraw all the 29 villages in the capital city area from the notification list.

This is a big jolt to the principal opposition TDP as it wanted to consolidate its strength by winning the local body elections in Amaravati riding on the wave of agitations by the locals.

TDP wanted to show that people are backing Amaravati as single capital city by defeating YSRC in the area.

Interestingly, YSRC won both Tadikonda and Mangalagiri assembly constituencies spread over the capital city area in the elections held eight months ago. TDP national general secretary Nara Lokesh faced humiliating defeat in his first direct electoral battle from Mangalagiri constituency. TDP was looked determined to take revenge on YSRC by sweeping the local body elections. However, its hopes were shattered when the government deferred the elections to all the villages.

The state government had earlier decided to merge five villages that were part of the capital city area in Tadepalle and Mangalagiri municipal towns. Similarly, the government wanted to set up Amaravati Municipal Corporation by merging the remaining 24 villages of the capital city.

While the high court stayed the merger of Yerrabalem, Bethapudi and Nowluru in Mangalagiri municipality and Undavalli and Penumaka villages in Tadepalle municipality, the plans of creating new municipal corporation for Amaravati were also put on hold keeping in view of ongoing cases against the shifting of the capital city.

The elections to the Tadepalle and Mangalagiri municipal bodies have also been put on hold due to the pending cases. Meanwhile, the state government had finalized the reservations for mayor posts in municipal corporations and chairpersons for municipal towns in the state.

Title: Kolhapur: NAAC accreditation workshop by DKTE
Content:
Representative image

KOLHAPUR: A one-day workshop on ‘ NAAC accreditation ’ under ‘Paramarsh scheme’ of the University Grants Commission (UCG) was organized by the Ichalkaranji-based DKTE Textile and Engineering Institute.

The workshop was inaugurated in the presence of Dr. DK Kamble, assistant advisor, National Assessment and Accreditation Council (NAAC), Bengaluru, as chief guest and Dr. RG Allagi, former principal, Basaveshwar College , Bagalkot, among others.

Director Dr. P V Kadole addressed the workshop. It was followed by a speech of the chief guest who spoke about the significance and various norms of NAAC as guidelines to the representatives from various mentee Institutes.

Workshop at chemistry department of SUK

A two-day workshop on ‘Emerging trends in chemical and material sciences’ was conducted at the department of chemistry of the Shivaji University, Kolhapur, last week. Over 200 researchers participated in the workshop. The department has completed 54 years and has the unique distinction of publishing over 2,000 research papers. The department has also witnessed graduation of 100 M.Phil students and over 700 Ph.D students.

Women’s day celebrated at Vivekanand College

City-based Vivekanand College celebrated women’s day on Sunday. Shubhangi Gawade , secretary of the Shri Swami Vivekanand Shikshan Sanstha inaugurated the event. During the occasion, various events were organized for the participants.

Awareness on coronavirus at SUK

An awareness lecture on coronavirus was organized at the Shivaji University, Kolhapur (SUK), last week. Dr. V A Ranade, medical officer at the university’s health centre, guided administrative and faculty members about the safety measures to be taken to avoid the infection.

Title: Shed fear, ‘Police Didi’ & ‘Police Kaka’ will be there to help you
Content:
Nagpur: Aimed at enthusing confidence among women, girls and even young boys by ensuring their safety, director general of police (DGP) Subodh Kumar Jaiswal has, on the occasion of International Women’s Day on Sunday, issued orders to kick start ‘Police Didi’ (Sister Cop) and ‘Police Kaka’ (Uncle Cop) schemes across all police stations in the state.

‘Police Didi’ scheme, a brainchild of Rashmi Shukla, who is now commissioner of state intelligence, was first implemented while she was Pune CP a few years ago. Shortly after that, Shukla’s batchmate and then Nagpur police chief K Venkatesham had started ‘Buddy Cops’ programme in the city.

Under the ‘Police Didi’ scheme, a woman cop from every police station would be entrusted with the responsibility to visit women and girls hostels, education institutes and such places to befriend the inmates. The cop would also create a social media group with the women and girls as its members. The group members will be able to post their grievances, seek advise and also forward suggestions for local police stations to act.

An officer said the group members can also share their personal grievances with the woman constable. “If some personal issues are required to be addressed, our constable would be there to help,” said the officer. “This platform would shield many women and girls from becoming silent victim,” said the officer.

In similar fashion, ‘Police Kaka’ will be there to help young boys with whom they can share grievances and seek assistance in matters which they might be afraid to share with the family. “In today’s world, it’s not only women or girls, but many boys too fall victim to exploitation which they cannot share with parents or other family members,” he said.

Title: Priest accused of cheating seeks bail
Content:
Dr Prashant Upadhyay

Vadodara: Accused priest of Shri Baglamukhi Brahmastra Vidya Mandir, Dr Prashant Upadhyay, has once again sought bail from the sessions court in the case of cheating a businessman of Rs 21 lakh.

In his petition, Upadhyay has pleaded innocence in the case and claimed that the case was registered against him to tarnish his image in the society. The court took up Upadhyay’s bail plea for hearing on Saturday and asked the police to respond.

The investigating officer is likely to oppose his application through an affidavit in the next hearing which will be held on March 11.

Last month too the sessions court had denied anticipatory bail to Upadhyay, whose earlier bail application too claimed that businessman Devraj Pandya had filed a false case against him. He has also questioned the timing of the case as the offence had taken place between 2013 and 2015.

Pandya had alleged that Upadhyay had taken money for performing ceremonies at his home and factory for various reasons. Pandya had approached the priest when his business was going through difficult times. Even after taking this huge sum when Pandya’s business had not recovered, he filed a cheating case against Upadhyay.

Upadhyay is currently in Vadodara Central Jail as his custody with Gotri police ended on Saturday.

Gotri police had also arrested him after a woman had lodged a cheating plaint against him alleging that Upadhyay had taken Rs 10 lakh from her and her husband to settle their marital discord.

Title: Biomining will take 2 years to clear Kasba Bawda waste
Content:
Representative image

KOLHAPUR: The locals from Kasba Bawda , Kadamwadi have to wait for two more years to get rid of the 4 lakh tonnes of garbage at the dumping site .

The KMC is going to carry out the biomining of the garbage heap. The machinery to carry out the process has arrived and its parts will be installed soon to make it operative.

For many years, the locals have been affected by the garbage at the Kasba Bawda site, which gets approximately 160 tonnes per day. The filth and the frequent fires to the garbage mound has been the major health concerns of the locals.

The strays in the locality feed on the dumped waste and get violent many times causing fear among the locals. The locals expected the garbage mound cleared many years ago only, however, the Kolhapur Municipal Corporation ’s inability to find a feasible and sustainable solution has put them into an inconvenience for all these years.

A senior sanitation official of the KMC requesting anonymity said, “The machine is basically a segregator. The garbage will be segregated into the soil, inert waste and refuse waste. The solid will be provided to the farmers to enrich their farms as it contains high-quality nutrients. The inert waste will be dumped into the landfill sites which then will be capped. The refuse waste will be processed further and can be used as the fuel in sugar mills and other factories. We are going to spend around Rs 19.75 crore to the contractor appointed for the process. It will take around two years for biomining of the entire garbage.”

The officials claimed the application of the biosanitisers, which will help degrade the refuse waste into organic. Also, the biosanitisers will clear the filthy smell. “The contractor will make the payment as per the amount of waste cleared from the dumping site. Such a condition will ensure that the contractor carries out the work uninterruptedly. We are also going to upgrade the processing facility, set up the windrows and slurry plant to process all the daily waste collected from the city,” said the official.

Title: Sessions court’s opinion must for commutation of life sentence: Bombay HC
Content:
Representative image

AURANGABAD: The Aurangabad bench of the Bombay high court has ruled that a sessions court’s opinion is must for commutation of life sentence under the state government’s scheme for premature release of life convicts.

The observations and directives of the HC have come while hearing a criminal writ petition filed by a convict, whose application for commutation of sentence was pending for the past six years for the need for sessions court’s opinion.

The bench comprising T V Nalawade and Justice M G Sewlikar held on March 4, said, “Ordinarily the learned sessions judge should consider such matter and he should give an opinion in this regard” while disposing of a writ petition filed by the life convict in Nashik central jail whose commutation plea was pending.

In February 2015, superintendent of Nashik Central Prison had requested the sessions court in Jalgaon for an opinion on the convict Kishor Laxman Lonari ’s plea, under the premature release scheme on completion of 14 years behind bars.

The then sessions judge wrote back to the prison authority stating that no special or separate opinion was required and the convict’s plea had to be dealt according to law.

When this communication from the court was brought to the notice of the HC, it observed: communication made by the learned Ad-hoc District Judge-2 and Assistant Sessions Judge shows that the learned Judge was not aware of the purpose for which his opinion was sought. This Court wants to observe that in such cases, the learned Sessions Judge needs to look in to the matters personally as files with regard to such opinion are generally kept in the office of Sessions Judge. Only due to non-availability of that file, it can be said that the communication for aforesaid nature was made by the learned Ad-hoc District Judge-2 and Assistant Sessions Judge.’

The high court has now directed the prison authority to send the matter again to the sessions court with a specific request for opinion within seven days.

The division bench of the HC specifically ruled that ‘Consideration of such matter by the learned Sessions Judge does not require much time and we are sure that he/she hardly requires 5-10 minutes for forming opinion and for giving opinion as guidelines are already given by the State Government. On the basis of the nature of offence only opinion is required to be given as to in which category the prisoner can be placed. It appears that only due to aforesaid confusion, the matter of the present petitioner was not decided for more than 6 years.’

Title: Inadequate bus service keeps children away from school
Content:
Coimbatore: Unlike other students of the Government higher secondary school at Sundakkamuthur, M Manoj , 15 , has not been regular to school .

He misses classes at least twice or thrice a week as he does not manage to catch the 8’o clock government bus that plies between his house and school.

Manoj lives at the Tamil Nadu Slum Clearance Board’s housing unit at Malai Nagar in Kovaipudur in the city. There aren’t frequent buses connecting the spots.

“If I miss the 8’o clock bus, then I have to hire an auto, which charges exorbitant fare, wait for the next buses that reaches the housing unit an hour later or walk for a couple of kilometres to the nearest bus stop to catch a bus,” Manoj said.

“I cannot afford to hire an auto for a 7km ride and my teacher will make me kneel down in front of the entire class if I arrive late. So, I skip the school whenever I miss the bus,” he said.

Only six trips – four between 7.15am and 11.30am and two between 5.15pm and 6.45pm – are made to the housing unit.

While over 200 families are residing in the housing unit at Malai Nagar, close to 900 families are residing at Anna Nagar in Madukkarai that is located next to Malai Nagar.

Most of them are working as labourers and they catch the first bus to their workplace. Nagajothi, a resident, said most of the children skip the school upon missing the buses as they do not have anyone to drop at the school.

As the number of school dropouts was high in the region, a special school was started near the housing unit six months ago. More than 30 students are studying there, she added.

“Not just the students, even others are affected due to lack of transportation. Upon missing the buses, we have to walk to Arivozhi Nagar, which is about a kilometre away. Even though the service is better there, the number of trips is limited,” said Selvaraj, who had moved to the housing unit two years ago.

He said the situation is much worse during the evening hours as they do not have any bus service after 7pm. “Even though the nearest bus stand is just a kilometre away, the auto drivers charge a minimum of Rs 100 because of the deserted pathway. Most of us are labourers. How can we afford to pay Rs 100 just for a ride when we earn nothing more than Rs 200 to Rs 300 a day,” he said. “We are solely depended on the government bus services to go to hospitals and ration shop.”

Despite several attempts, officials of the Tamil Nadu State Transport Corporation (TNSTC) were not available for comment.

Title: Burglars scoff at police patrolling, target two houses
Content:
Vadodara: Despite claims of intense police patrolling, burglars continue to have a free run in the city. Two complaints of burglary were registered in the city in last 24 hours.

In the first complaint of burglary lodged with the Makarpura police station, resident of the area, Pragnesh Parmar, 31, told the police that there was a break-in at his house at Gold City in Tarsali sometime between March 2 and 4 when he was away. According to the police, the burglars broke into his house through the main door. They then opened the safe in the bedroom and stole gold ornaments worth Rs 1 lakh apart from Rs 15,000 in cash. The burglars also stole Parmar’s aadhaar card and RC book.

Another complaint of burglary was filed by 50-year-old Shilpa Patel, a resident of Vasna Road with Gotri police. Patel told the police that her house which was under lock, had been burgled on Saturday morning. The burglars broke open the safe and stole gold ornaments worth Rs 1.14 lakh including cash.

The city has been witnesses a spate of burglaries as the Sikhligar gang is allegedly getting active here. The cops have formed several teams to patrol different areas and are also checking vehicles at night to ensure that crime rates reduce in the city.

Title: Plans afoot to widen roads to bus terminal
Content:
Coimbatore: The city corporation is likely to conduct a meeting with stakeholders to develop access roads and other infrastructures around the integrated bus stand at Vellalore in the city.

“Based on the direction from district collector K Rajamani, the corporation would be conducting a meeting with the stakeholders, including officials from Tamil Nadu State Transport Corporation (TNSTC). Following the meeting, steps will be taken to widen the access roads,” a corporation source said.

But, ideally the corporation should have conducted the meeting before floating the tender or at least before commencing the construction work of the bus stand, city-based activists opined. About a couple of months ago, state municipal administration minister SP Velumani laid the foundation stone to start the construction work. The bus stand is coming up on 60 acres near the dump yard at the cost of Rs 164.81 crore.

K Kathirmathiyon of Coimbatore Consumer Cause said, “Ideally before constructing the bus stand, the corporation should have known the number of buses that would be shifted to the integrated bus stand and how viable it is to integrate all the bus stands. Because, the high court direction states that all the buses plying to locations within 55km should start only from Gandhipuram bus stand.”

Title: Kolhapur Municipal Transport’s budgetary promises for 2019-20 remains on paper
Content:
Representative image

KOLHAPUR: Several measures were announced in the Kolhapur Municipal Transport ( KMT ) budget for 2019-20. These measures included increasing the efficiency of the transport system and reducing losses. However, the promises remain on paper .

The budget mentioned setting up of a command and control centre at Shivaji Chowk to manage the trips of the KMT buses properly and ensure on-time arrival of the buses. Though the schedules for the buses are fixed, many times, passengers have to wait for half-an-hour for buses to arrive. This is one of the main reasons for commuters to opt for other modes of transport and, thereby resulting in lesser revenue generation of the municipal transport.

Most of the undertakings of major cities in the state have modern command and control centres. These centres help to monitor the transport service, real time tracking of the buses, improve security and safety of the passengers and manage the passenger strength to avoid congestion. At the same time, it also ensures that each bus carries sufficient number of passengers.

A senior KMT official, on the condition of anonymity, said, “Huge capital expenditure is required to set up the command and control centre. Only the idea was put up in the budget. This time, funds for the same will be allocated.”

For the centre, each bus should be equipped with the Global Positioning System (GPS) and hand-held devices connected to the main server should be provided to the ticket collectors to register the time and the number of passengers boarding in a particular bus. The centre can be upgraded further by using advanced technologies. The official said that the estimates for the all the components to be required to run the common and control centre will be worked out soon.

The KMT had also planned to increase the number of on-road buses to increase the number of passengers travelling every day. At present, around 97 buses ply on city roads every day. The assurance in the budget was to make at least 112 buses out of 121 operational on a daily basis. Currently, around 75,000 passengers travel by KMT buses which, according to the plan, was expected to touch 95,000. No special efforts were taken to increase the passenger flow this year.

Title: Chennai: ‘Yes, canal off Radial Road is encroached’
Content:
Encroachment of the canal made the 2015 floods worse in S Kolathur

CHENNAI: Revenue department officials have confirmed encroachments in S Kolathur , off Pallavaram-Thoraipakkam 200 Feet Radial Road, based on a survey they carried out three months ago, following complaints from residents. Residents had complained that access to the radial road was cut off due to encroachments.

In a letter to the St Thomas Mount block development officer (BDO) last week, Sholinganallur tahsildar confirmed that portions of an apartment complex in S Kolathur were built encroaching on a canal.

Sources said action will be taken against the encroachers after a round of talks. The encroached portions connect the residential neighbourhood to the radial road.

More than 1,000 families reside in S Kolathur and the only way for them to reach the Radial Road as of now is through Dr Ambedkar Salai.

The survey to identify encroachments is a result of more than two years of struggle by locals, according to a resident who filed the RTI. During the 2015 floods and rains in the subsequent years, the encroachments put them through a great ordeal, which spurred them to take the matter into their own hands. “In 2015, people had to jump walls to get to the 200 Feet Road to even get relief material,” recalled A Stephen of Raja Nagar, who has been residing in the neighbourhood for more than 15 years.

If the identified encroachments are cleared, two more routes to access the Radial Road will take shape, according to the residents.

In another relief to the residents, the public works department has begun constructing a retaining wall from Narayanapuram lake to Keelkattalai lake. Officials had promised them a comprehensive flood mitigation plan.

“The water from Keelkattalai lake passes through the surplus canal and excess water from the canal floods the neighbourhood. Even last year, when there was less rain, the canal was brimming,” said J Sankar, a resident who has been petitioning the authorities seeking action. Authorities said necessary action will be taken to stop sewage being let into the surplus canal.

Title: Cable operator arrested for repeatedly dodging warrant
Content:
Vadodara: A cable operator living in Ghadiyali Pol who repeatedly failed to appear in court during trial of a criminal case filed against him by a cable television distributor was finally arrested by the police.

A judicial magistrate’s court had issued a non-bailable warrant against Alpesh Shah as he was not appearing for trial. According to the complainant, the accused is one of the operators for distribution of cable television. When the distributor filed a criminal case against him in the court, Shah reached a settlement by assuring him of paying up the dues. However, even after giving assurances, Shah did not pay the amount and also did not appear in court for the trials. The court first issued summons to him and then a bailable warrant. However, when he still did not appear, a non-bailable warrant was issued by the court. Police went several times to his home to serve the warrant, but could not find him at home. Last week when the cops once went to his house, they found him and arrested him. The court will hear the case on March 12. tnn

Title: All-women crew ‘pilot’ three trains of equality
Content:
Varanasi: As Manduadih-Prayagraj Rambagh passenger train chugged out of Manduadih railway station at 6am on Sunday, it was a show of women power with senior assistant loco pilot Sunita Kumari leading from the front in a position traditionally held by men.

As part of Indian Railways campaign to promote gender equality and underscore the importance of women empowerment, an exclusive women crew operated three passenger trains on separate routes under Varanasi division of North Eastern Railway to commemorate International Women’s Day.

Similarly, Manduadih-Bhatni passenger train was led by senior assistant loco pilot Priyanka Rai and was flagged off from Manduadih railway station at 7.05am, followed by Chhapra-Bhatni passenger train, which was operated by senior assistant loco pilot Shweta Yadav. The all-women trains were flagged-off by divisional railway manager (NER Varanasi) Vijay Kumar Panjiar. From loco pilot and security guard to ticket examiners, these trailblazers were the show-stoppers, with the crew receiving an overwhelming response from passengers and railway officials.

As Chhapra-Bhatni train reached Manduadih, the staff including loco pilot Shweta, guard Sonali Kumari, ticket checking staff Mamta Kumari, Pratima Kumari, Nisha Kumari, RPF assistant sub-inspector Archana Upadhyaya, head constable Bindu, constable Binnu, Sugam and Garima were accorded a warm welcome.

An excited crowd waited for Manduadih-Bhatni passenger train at Mau railway station even as it arrived an hour late. As soon as the train reached the platform, loco pilot Priyanka Rai and women staff were greeted with powerful slogans like ‘Dhool hai chingari hai, yeh Bharat ki nari hai’ (Indian woman is a spark, not a sand grain). Priya was honoured with a bouquet and the entire crew was welcomed with sweets.

On the occasion, railway regional advisory committee member Sriram Jaiswal said that everyone felt honoured to see how women are now ready to accept all challenges and are handling all kind of responsibilities.

To mark the occasion, NDRF also organised a special health camp for women on its campus in Chowkaghat area. Apart from health check-up of over 120 women, they were also made aware about breast and cervical cancer. Senior consultants also shared a diet plan with participants. Women were also made aware about the necessary precautions to be taken against coronavirus.

Title: Thousands attend Poochorithal festival with religious fervour
Content:
Trichy: The Poochorithal festival in Arulmigu Samayapuram Mariamman temple near Trichy commenced with religious fervour on Sunday. Temple management and priests carried the first batch of flowers to adorn the sanctum sanctorum of the temple atop an elephant through the temple car streets at 7am.

The procession was followed by thousands of devotees with flowers to offer the deity. Poochorithal (showering flowers) festival is considered a significant festivals in Samayapuram temple. HR&CE sources claimed that during the 28-days-long fasting by the presiding deity Mariamman, celebrated as Poochorithal every year during the last Sunday of the Tamil month Masi (March), only liquid food such as buttermilk and tender coconut is offered to the chief deity.

“Samayapuram temple is considered the foremost of all Mariamman temples in the state. Usually, people fast for their betterment but here in Samayapuram, the deity itself sits on fast for the welfare of devotees,” said S Sakthivel, a flower vendor in Samayapuram.

People from adjoining villages will carry loads of flowers to adorn the deity on every Sunday next month. As thousands thronged the temple since morning, good Samaritans had established stalls to offer free buttermilk and water. Around 350 police personnel were deployed for monitoring the crowd while special arrangements including temporary bus stand and traffic diversions were introduced by the district administration. The town panchayat provided basic amenities such as mobile toilets and potable water tanks for the visitors near the temple streets.

Title: Karjan man files bail plea ‘by mistake’, fined Rs 5,000
Content:
Vadodara: Crying wolf cost this applicant dear for not only did he scorch his ears from the lashing he got from a miffed Karjan court, but also burned his pockets for wasting the court’s precious time by ‘abusing the process of law’!

It was a case of Dhanji Rathodiya jumping to conclusions and to pre-empt arrest, filing an anticipatory bail plea in an assault case, where he stated his innocence and expressed fears that the investigating officer may arrest him despite him not being involved in the crime.

The sessions court was shocked to learn that the case doesn’t even mention Rathodiya’s name as an accused and that the investigating officer has not even called him for questioning.

This got the court’s goat truly, and his petition seeking ‘stay on his possible arrest’ earned him the wrath of additional sessions judge A A Nanavati, who fined Rathodiya Rs5,000 for taking the court for a ride.

The case pertains to an incident of assault and criminal intimidation where three accused Jitesh Rathod, Pravin Rathod and Rajesh Vasava got into fight with Sumit Solanki and his two friends in Karjan town on February 20 over a petty issue. Jitesh and Pravin had sought anticipatory bail which was rejected by the same court on February 29. On March 2, Rathodiya sought anticipatory bail. On taking cognizance of the application, the court issued notice to the state to respond to Rathodiya’s plea on March 5.

The investigating cop – head constable Rajendrasinh Ramsinh – in an affidavit informed the court that neither Rathodiya has been named as an accused nor was he summoned for questioning as he had no connection with the case.

On hearing police’s stand, Rathodiya then requested the court to let him withdraw his bail plea stating that he had filed it by mistake.

Assistant government pleader Ramesh Gianchandani, however, objected to it and urged the court to impose heavy fine on Rathodiya.

“The court took note of the fact that Rathodiya’s application was a copy of the applications filed earlier by the two accused and his name was also handwritten with a pen on a blank space,” Gianchandani said.

The court in its order stated that Rathodiya had abused the process of law and put the entire machinery of dispensing justice into motion so it can hardly be accepted that he filed the application by mistake.

“Rathodiya is a relative of one of the accused so he may have assumed that he may also be arrested. But he had nothing to do with the case as he was not present at the time of the incident,” Rajendrasinh told TOI.

Title: Rs 36L gold recovered from 2 passengers
Content:
The Air Intelligent Unit (AIU) of customs department have recovered gold worth Rs 36.30 lakh from two passengers who arrived at Trichy airport on Saturday.
