According to customs authorities, the passenger had arrived here through Air India Express from Dubai during the night hours on Saturday. routine During a routine checking process, the customs officials grew suspicious over the activities of a passenger.

During the check, he was found that Shankar from Trichy had concealed 376g gold worth Rs 16.5 lakh. Subsequently, it was recovered.

Similarly, customs officials recovered 450g gold worth Rs 19.83 lakh concealed in a baggage of a passenger named Sathish from Pudukottai who arrived Trichy airport from Singapore by Scoot Air. The yellow metal concealed in various forms was recovered from the passenger. Further inquiries are on.tnn

Title: ‘U’khand treats only a third of total sewage generated in state’
Content:
The 10-km long sewage line in Rispana river

NAINITAL: Uttarakhand’s 24 sewage treatment plants (STPs) are treating only a third of the sewage that the urban areas of the hill state generate each day.

To a question raised in Parliament recently, the Union government quoted the above data, adding that the hill state has a treatment capacity of only 165 million litres of sewage under the National Mission for Clean Ganga (NMCG).

The data also mentions that the state generates 495 million litres of sewage each day and only 153 million litres of it gets treated.

While the reply, which cites data from the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB), does not say what happens to the untreated waste amounting to 343 million litres, environmentalists said that most of it ultimately ends into rivers like Ganga, Bhagirathi, Alaknanda and Rispana.

Nainital-based environmentalist and former professor of Kumaun University Ajay Singh Rawat said, “Uttarakhand is the source of major rivers in the country such as Ganga and Yamuna. These rivers feed most of the population of northern India and are a lifeline for almost half of the country’s population. However, as the data shows, the rivers are grossly polluted by untreated sewage, as hundreds of millions of litres of waste water is flowing into these rivers.”

Several other residents also echoed similar concerns. Manish Kumar , a resident of Kandoli area of Dehradun , said that though some parts of the colony have sewage facilities, most of the waste water generated from hundreds of homes in the locality is dumped in the Rispana (a tributary of Ganga). “This is true of almost all the colonies along the river in Dehradun. Even the sewage line that is there has been laid in the middle of the river further raising suspicion that some of it must be mixing with the river water,” he said.

When compared to other Himalayan states, especially neighbouring Himachal Pradesh, Uttarakhand’s performance is particularly dismal in the matter of treatment of sewage. While Himachal’s urban areas produce 110 million litres of sewage daily, the state has a treatment capacity of over 114 million litres.

Uttarakhand government officials meanwhile said that though it was true that the state needs to do a lot to increase its sewage treatment capacity, many new STPs have also been opened up. “The data shows that we need to do more but it is also true that many new STPs have become functional across the state. We are further working to create more such plants,” said urban development minister and government spokesperson Madan Kaushik.

He added that there is also a possibility that the data may be old.

Title: Avinashi Road caves in
Content:
Coimbatore: Hardly a month after the highways department relaid it, the Avinashi Road , one of the major roads in the city , has caved in near the office of Indian Chamber of Commerce and Industry.

“Workers of the city corporation had repaired a drinking water pipeline leak a few feet away just days ago. As the pothole is close to the T-junction, it is causing a huge inconvenience to the commuters,” said Surender, a commuter. “Just days after the leak was fixed, the road caved in without being able to bear the weight of heavy vehicles. This is the condition of all roads we are using.”

“To prevent accidents, traffic police have placed a barricade over the pothole. The highways department had relaid the road after it became unmotorable. I am not sure when will they fix this,” Surender said.

The road caved in because of the pipeline leak, said district road safety committee member K Kathirmathiyon. “Whenever water leaks through the underground pipeline, it loosens the soil. That portion gives away when a heavy vehicle passes over it,” he told TOI. “The highways department should find out the reason behind the damage and take immediate steps to rectify it.”

Highways department officials have promised to repair it.

Title: Contribution of women to GDP is only 18%: Expert
Content:
Trichy: India must be much closer to the $5 trillion economy if only ‘homemaking’ is considered for GDP calculation, said Jahanzeb Akhtar, principal commissioner of income tax, Chennai, on Sunday.

She was one of the chief guests for the talk on the role of women in making India a $5 trillion economy organised by Indian Institute of Management (IIM) Trichy.

Raising concern over dropping of female labour force participation, she said contribution of women to India’s GDP is at a mere 18%. She asked the audience to ponder over the fact that the ‘care economy’ is where women are largely engaged in our country.

Jahanzeb Akhtar urged the women students to value their feminine qualities and how they could indirectly help deal with issues of tax evasion and tax avoidance given women have characteristics that make them think of family and community and hence be less corrupt.

Quoting examples of many women workers who pioneered their fields, vice chancellor, Tamil Nadu National Law University, Trichy V S Elizabeth urged society to take care of women who belong to all strata of society and want to contribute to the economy.

She said the world should end violence against women and insisted that it was high time that people started looking at the world through eyes of women.

Station director Natarajan said all India Radio Trichy recalled all the sacrifices and hardships his mother went through and valued the deeds the women do to make a family stand tall.

IIM Trichy director Bhimaraya Metri motivated the female students in the gathering to take up leadership positions in the corporate world with examples of Indira Nooyi and Kiran Mazumdar Shaw.

Title: Jallikattu bull dies after coming out of Vadivasal
Content:
TRICHY: A ten-year-old Jallikattu bull which took part in the jallikattu event held at Avur of Pudukottai district died on Sunday.

The bull owner claim that the it died of electric shock after meeting with a live electric wire hanging from an electric post about one km from the Jallikattu venue.

However, district administration while ruling out electrocution said that the bull died out of injury after hitting an electric post.

According to its owner, U Anbarasan, 40 the bull entered a farmland in the Melapatti village and coming out of Vadivasal where it met with a live wire on the ground detached from an electric post and died on the spot.

The jallikattu event held at Avur witnessed over 800 bulls entering the vadivasal on Sunday, about 500bull tamers attempted to tame them.

The Jallikattu bull ‘Sevalai’ by name owned by U Anbarasan, 40 of Sengalakudi died minutes after coming out of Vadivasal.

Usually volunteers stationed in the bull collection area, a few hundred meters away from the Vadivasal, stop the bulls and facilitate owners to catch their respective bulls.

But in this case volunteers could not stop Sevalai which ran outside the Jallikattu arena and entered a farmland.

Anabarasan said that there were at least 10 persons went chasing Sevalai. Some of them could have also died if they had met the live wire. But they exercised caution see the bull falling near the electric poll in Melapatti.

Anbarasan questioned officials for not screening the 1 km radius of Jallikattu venue for potential danger. While this is the standard protocol, Anbu said this accident occurred merely 500 metres away from the jallikattu spot and it could have been avoided.

Villagers say that TANGEDCO officials were alerted about the damaged live wire about two days back. But it was not repaired.

Speaking to TOI, Pudukottai district collector P Uma Maheswari said that the bull’s death wasn’t due to electrocution but due to injuries that it sustained after hitting the electric post.

Title: Covid-19: Railway hospital sets up 12-bed isolation ward
Content:
Trichy: The health department of Trichy railway division has established an isolation ward with 12 beds at Golden Rock Railway hospital following instructions from the railway board after more coronavirus (Covid - 19) cases were reported from across the country.

Patients coming to the hospital with suspected cold and fever are admitted to the isolation ward before sending them to the government hospital for further medical examination and observation.

Medical officers in the railway division have been instructed to isolate people who have fever. For the purpose, every railway hospital should have isolation wards with necessary protective gear, chief medical superintendent Dr Soundarrajan said.

“As many as 500 to 600 outpatients visit the hospital every day. We have two non-touch thermometers to examine the patients who would arrive here with cold and fever. If anyone found with Covid-19 symptoms, they would be quarantined at the isolation ward for a brief time before sending them to the government hospital,” he said.

If any suspicious coronavirus cases are reported in any of the railway hospitals or health units in the division, that should be informed to the board immediately. However, as of now, they have not encountered any such cases for far, he said.

“As per the instruction, we are in constant touch with the district as well as state health authorities to obtain the guidelines on the subject in order to follow necessary measures,” Soundarrajan said.

To create awareness among the railway employees as well as commuters, flex boards bearing ‘Do’s and Don’ts’ would be fixed at all the railway stations tomorrow, the medical superintendent said.

Meanwhile, the number of medical staff who are engaged in the Covid-19 screening process in Trichy international airport has been increased to 22 from 15, as the passengers arriving from across the world at the airport are being screened, health officials from the airport said.

Airport health officer Dr Subin told TOI that since January 28, they have been screening passengers arriving from Singapore and via China. However, as the virus seemed intensified in India, they have started screening all passengers who arrive here from overseas destinations.

“We have commenced universal screening. Strength of our medical team would go up as state health department will send more medical staff,” he added.

Title: Farmers seek 200 days under MGNREGA
Content:
Trichy: Farmers’ associations from the delta districts have appealed to the state government to enhance the total working days of Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme to 200 days from 100.

The Union budget allocations for various schemes under the department of rural development have been already reduced. The funds allotted to employment guarantee scheme (MGNREGA) have come down in the budget, farmers alleged.

As per the budget, Rs 61,500 crore has been allocated for the NGNREGA scheme for the year 2020-21, a more than 13% decrease from the total estimated expenditure for 2019-20, which was Rs 71,000 crore, they said.

Total number of working days should be increased to 200 from 100, so that agriculture labourers could get more days’ wage. The Kerala government is utilizing MGNREGA workers for agriculture activities too. That should be followed in Tamil Nadu also, secretary of Thanjavur District Cauvery Farmers Protection Association Swamimalai S Vimalnathan said at a farmers’ consultative meeting on Union budget 2020-21 held here on Saturday.

“Already thousands of agriculture labourers have lost their income as there is no proper employment in farming. The employment guarantee scheme has been helping them to a certain extent. But, the government cut the allocation for MGNREGA. This is unfair,” he alleged.

Title: 20 kg rotten fish seized from shops in Pollachi destroyed
Content:
Coimbatore: Food safety officials and fisheries officials on Sunday destroyed 20 kilograms of rotten fish kept for sale at outlets in Pollachi.

The officials have been conducting inspections at fish stalls in the district to curb the sale of formalin-laced fish. On Sunday, they inspected 12 wholesale and retail fish outlets at Thernilayam, Market Road and New Scheme Road in the Pollachi taluk.

They seized 20 kilograms of rotten fish from four shops and destroyed it by pouring phenyl over it. The shopkeepers were served warning notices and were instructed to sell only fresh fish and to discard waste immediately.

The officials fined a shopkeeper 2,000 after finding banned single-use polythene carry bags in the shop.

However, they could not find formalin-laced fish.

Seventy kilograms of formalin-laced fish and 430 kilograms of stale fish were destroyed last week after the officials conducted a raid at the Ukkadam fish market in the city.

Title: Chennai: Saplings along Maduravoyal bypass under threat
Content:
Waste, which is also a fire hazard, hampers growth of sapling

CHENNAI: The forest department’s plans to make the Maduravoyal bypass road a shady avenue are being stunted like the saplings it has planted. A total of 22,000 saplings were planted on both sides of the road for a distance of 32.6km between Perungalathur and Puzhal in October and November.

Most of the saplings survived and thrived, for a while. Now they are being threatened by piles of garbage and wild undergrowth. Worse, the wire mesh of the tree guards that protect them has been stolen.

Social forestry division forest officer S Shanmugam told the TOI that the growth of the saplings had slowed because of these problems.

A visit to the area on Saturday revealed that besides these three problems, a host of other issues too posed a threat to the saplings. For example, there were several stretches blackened by fire, apparently caused by a carelessly thrown cigarette stub. Forest officials said people also dumped domestic waste packed in black bin bags, which caught fire easily.

Shanmugham says the problem on the Perungalathur to Maduravoyal strech is different. “Here it is the wild growth of bushes, which need to be cleared by the National Highways Authority of India . As the plants were raised on the edges of the highway, watering them and replacing a damaged sapling becomes a risky job,” he said.

Fires break out or are set off by vandals not only on the sides of the road, but also on the road median. The NHAI has no facility to extinguish these fires. Patrol vehicles of the NHAI carry water in plastic pots, which is not sufficient to put out a fire, said an official.

The NHAI should install awareness boards every half km along the entire stretch, where the saplings have been planted, said the official, adding that the patrol vehicles should be equipped with fire extinguishers and personnel trained to use them should be on duty.

Forest officials point that these trees will not only provide welcome shade when fully grown, but also cut pollution.

Title: Plea to regularise ad hoc staff at BDU constituent colleges
Content:
Trichy: The Association of University Teachers ( AUT ) observed a fast in Trichy on Sunday demanding regularisation of the services of teaching and non-teaching staff in Bharathidasan University’s 10 constituent colleges.

The AUT also demanded that the Tamil Nadu government and the BDU allow ad hoc teachers to pursue PhD and also to guide research scholars. The association demanded UGC pay scale for these teachers.

Only 31 regular teachers have been recruited since the establishment of these colleges, starting 2006. There are 10 constituent colleges including four recently converted into government colleges.

“UGC regulations mandates that not more than 20% of the sanctioned strength shall be filled with ad hoc teachers. However, all the six constituent colleges don’t have a single regular teacher and are run with only ad hoc teachers,” said N Pasupathy, AUT president.

He added that UGC guidelines fixes Rs 25,000 as monthly consolidated pay for ad hoc teachers, which was subsequently modified to Rs 50,000 in 7th UGC scales of pay.

The university has not adopted either so far while the university has chosen to appoint ‘hourly-basis lecturers’ to exploit them further.

“While they are entitled for UGC pay scale, 363 guest lecturers, 214 hourly-basis teachers and around 100 odd PTA teachers are running the college by getting a maximum salary of Rs 12,000. The salary starts at Rs 5,000,” said AUT general secretary M S Balamurugan.

Also, there was a delay on the part of the university to disburse the salary every month, he said. No service rules had been framed in the last 15 years to cater to the needs of the staff, he added.

Title: MSU starts homework to get respectable NAAC grading
Content:
Vadodara: M S University has started groundwork for the forthcoming third cycle of the National Assessment and Accreditation Council (NAAC) which is due in 2021-22.

The varsity was rated grade ‘A’ by NAAC in 2016. NAAC is an autonomous body funded by the University Grants Commission that assesses and accredits all higher education institutions in the country.

As part of preparations, university’s faculty of family and community sciences (FFCS) and Internal Quality Assurance Cell (IQAC) organized a workshop on Saturday titled ‘NAAC 2021-data analysis’ in which all teaching and non-teaching staff were involved.

The workshop aims to consolidate data of all the seven NAAC criteria and to check for any discrepancies. MSU vice-chancellor Prof Parimal Vyas emphasized on the seriousness of the workshop requesting attendance of all members.

He asked teachers to have at least two publications in a year in recognized journals while urging heads and senior teachers to guide the younger staff members.

“SCOPUS list of journals must be available with each teacher. We need to nurture a research culture,” he said, adding that the university needs to work six months in advance unlike the past where NAAC assessment remained overdue for 18 months.

Vyas further urged each teacher to be responsible for supplying relevant data.

“It is not just the responsibility of the IQAC or annual report team,” he added.

Title: Vadodara gets new district judge
Content:
Vadodara: Gujarat high court has appointed M R Mengdey, principal district and sessions judge (PDJ) of Mehsana, as new PDJ of Vadodara.

The post was lying vacant as the previous PDJ Dr A C Joshi was elevated as high court justice last week. U T Desai, the PDJ of Bharuch, will replace judge Mengdey in Mehsana. Along with judge Mengdey and judge Desai, the high court transferred 16 other judicial officers working in the cadre of district judge within the state.

Justice Joshi was appointed PDJ of Vadodara in May last year when he was serving as PDJ of Ahmedabad, according to a high court notification.

Title: Resurrecting Lucknow tehzeeb: Wait for book by ‘encyclopedia of Awadh’
Content:
LUCKNOW: The slow, silent decay of the Ganga-Jamuni tehzeeb , the Awadhi ethos upholding a distinctive, syncretic Hindu-Muslim culture, would soon be part of a new autobiography to be penned by Lucknow chronicler and Padma awardee Yogesh Parveen.

Often referred to as the ‘encyclopedia of Avadh’, Praveen will write about the soul of Lucknow, which has “lost its character due to politics of polarization”. “The city was once soaked in Ganga-Jamuni tehzeeb... Unity in diversity was its essence. Communal harmony was the soul of Lucknow,” Parveen told TOI on sidelines of an event in his honour, ‘Lucknow ke gaurav’.

He said: “Lucknow was the best cosmopolitan city of the world. A P Sen was a Bengali, while Amritlal Nagar was a Gujarati. They lived for Lucknow and died for Lucknow. Today, it's painful to see witness the city caught in a pluralistic phenomena, which is being badly misused. The younger generation is mehroom (deprived) from 'pehle-aap' (after you, please) culture, tehzeeb (etiquette) and the communal amity that once characterized the city... If people imbibe these values, all hostility and conflict would end.”

“Through my book, I will aim to change the mindset of the young generation, which is drawn towards commercialisation while spurning traditional religious beliefs and spirituality,” he said.

Talking about the Ganga-Jamuni tehzeeb, he said: “Be it India or Lucknow as a whole, communal harmony has lost its sheen. ‘Lucknow sisak raha hai, heritage tabah ho rahi hai, sauhard mar chuka hai' (Lucknow is crying, heritage is being destroyed and harmony exists no more). In the past, people respected each other’s religious sentiments... It's one of the basic fundamental principles. Secularism was the fulcrum. Unfortunately, ab who manobhaav nahi hai. (Now, those sentiments are absent) Everybody is self-centred and do not believe in brotherhood.”

“Ganga-Jamuni tehzeeb was an amalgamation of the rose of Persia and lotus of India. Be it during Partition or Babri demolition, Lucknow set an example of harmony. We never heard of communal riots in the city and people lived happily together. Now, leaders are polarising people and Lucknow is losing its character. This is the opposite of the idea of Lucknow we cherished," said Praveen, who has already penned 20 books on Lucknow and contributed to Bollywood films like Satyajit Ray’s 'Shatranj Ke Khiladi' and Shyam Benegal 's 'Junoon', which were shot in the state capital.

Title: Mafia’s new trick to fox cops: Liquor hidden behind junk
Content:
One of the trucks caryying illegal liquor seized by STF on March 7

PRAYAGRAJ: UP’s liquor mafia now has a new trick up its sleeve to dodge cops — hiding consignments in boxes of junk.

Police came to know about their modus operandi after Special Task Force (STF) recently seized a consignment of illegal liquor worth Rs 75 lakh in Amethi district .

Additional SP (STF) Neeraj Kumar Pandey said, “Liquor smugglers are focussing on delivering consignments from from Bhatinda in Punjab in Bihar after passing through UP. Cartons of liquor are hidden in junk to evade police suspicion.”

“During a checking drive on March 7, STF (Prayagraj unit) intercepted two trucks near Mohanganj in Amethi’s Jagdishpur Road. They were found to be loaded with junk,” he added.

However, as the police went though the junk, they were surprised to find illegal liquor hidden inside containers.

Police seized two trucks which were carrying 827 cartons of illegal liquor and arrested three truck drivers. The accused were identified as Lakhvinder Singh, Jagdish Singh and Pipal Singh.

Earlier while cracking down on liquor mafia, the STF had hit a wall after it failed to get information about Punjab-based smugglers. The truck drivers it arrested with illegal alcohol units weren’t told about the location of delivery.

“The truckers were given ‘code words’ and they were supposed to say them when their contact person would call them with information about the location. The drivers were told the location of delivery only if they knew the code word,” said police.

Title: Two from state get ‘Nari Shakti’ award from Prez
Content:
Patna: Bina Devi, who is popularly known as ‘Mushroom Mahila’ in Bihar, and Darbhanga-born Indian Air Force’s fighter pilot Bhawana Kanth received ‘Nari Shakti Puraskar 2019’ from President Ram Nath Kovind on International Women’s Day in Delhi on Sunday.

The two were among the 15 women who received this prestigious award for their extraordinary achievements. Bhawana was among the first three Indian Air Force’s women fighter pilots. She had conducted a solo flight in MIG-21 in 2018.

The 41-year-old Bina, who hails from Kilkari village in Tetia Bamber block of Munger district, popularized mushroom cultivation across the state. She trained farmers in mushroom (oyster and button) farming, organic farming, vermicompost production and organic insecticide preparation at home. She has generated self-employment for rural women in 220 households of her village and engaged many of them in dairy and goat farming.

Bina told this newspaper that the award motivated her to work harder in her endeavour. “I’m honoured that the state government selected my name for this honour. It was one of the best moments of my life. The appreciation always uplifts my willpower. Now, I’ll work harder to engage more women in farming,” she said.

Bina and her husband Krishna Kant have been engaged in mushroom farming for the last one decade after she joined Krishi Vigyan Kendra. She is now the master trainer at the centre.

“In one go, we cultivate around 200 bags of mushroom which we export across the state as well as to Kolkata. Usually, I grow oyster mushroom in summer and monsoon. Monsoon is the best time to grow oyster mushroom because of high humidity. It improves the quality. In winter time, we cultivate button mushroom,” Bina said.

She added: “Because of my work, I’m able to provide education to my kids. My elder son Himanshu is studying MCA in Delhi while Animesh is preparing for competitive exams after graduation. Pritam and Bhagyashre appeared for Intermediate exams this year.”

Bina has popularized mushroom production in 5 blocks and 105 neighbouring villages in Munger district, imparting training to 1,500 women in mushroom farming.

She had earlier received ‘Abhinav Kisan Puraskar’ in 2014 at Bihar Agriculture University, Sabour, by the then chief minister Jitan Ram Manjhi. She was also awarded ‘Best Farmer Award’ at Kisan Mela organized by the state government in 2019.

Title: Celebrating women in sanitation management
Content:
Trichy: The Tamil Nadu Urban Sanitation Support (TNUSSP) programme, a collaborative effort of the Tamil Nadu government and the Indian Institute of Human Settlements (IIHS) in sanitation development has launched a campaign promoting the stories of women in sanitation. Stories of Trichy-based seven women including a trans woman are being shared on social media platforms to encourage women to indulge in community development activities.

Celebrating the occasion of International Women’s Day on March 8, TNUSSP involved in septage management in Trichy, Coimbatore and Kanchipuram districts identified seven women for their exceptional contribution to urban sanitation development. Seven women from Trichy, Coimbatore and Kanchipuram, which include officers, Self-Help Group (SHG) women and sanitary worker, were featured in the series of ‘Women in Sanitation’ campaign.

T Saranya, S Kamala, D Kalpana, S Amuthavalli, Asha, Vijaya and Veni were the women featured in the videos. The women are working in various capacities. The interviews with the seven women involve the participants explaining the challenges they faced as women in the sanitation sector. Motivational messages were also shared in the videos released by TNUSSP in their social media handles.

“The objective of the campaign is to encourage women to play a role in sanitation management and community development. The women we featured in the videos have done exceptional work in fulfilling their responsibilities,” Sugantha Priscilla L, senior specialist, IIHS told TOI.

Trans-woman S Kamala told TOI that women should come forward in the field of sanitation, which will inspire the entire family to adapt hygienic practices. “Though I faced a lot of humiliations in the past, I was decided to indulge in community development. Such perseverance is the need of the hour,” said, Kamala who is managing a community toilet at Sangliyandapuram, Trichy. Coinciding with the Women’s Day, organisers said that such real stories of women in sanitation will inspire the women who hesitate to play a role in sanitation and menstrual hygiene.

Title: Man sedates, sexually assaults minor relative, held
Content:
Representative Image

TRICHY: A 34-year-old man was arrested under Protection of Children from Sexual Offences ( POCSO ) Act for sexually assaulting a 17-year-old school girl in Pudukottai district on Saturday.

The victim, a class XII student of a government school, is seven months pregnant.

The accused, according to the police, is a close relative of the victim. He had sexually assaulted her on several occasions for the last one year after sedating her.

The victim developed health issues, and a medical examination revealed her pregnancy. The shocked relatives learned that the accused had sexually assaulted her several times. He had also threatened her against revealing this to her parents.

Based on a complaint by the victim’s parents, police arrested the accused and booked him under section 328 for sedating her, 506 (i) for criminal intimidation. He was also booked under section 6 of POCSO Act for penetrative sexual assault.

Title: Signal woes put pedestrians at risk in Kolkata
Content:
TimesView Cops have come up with several result-oriented and targeted plans to control traffic. A little bit more of fine-tuning and constant monitoring are probably needed to yield even better results.

KOLKATA: Kolkata Police are now bringing even minor intersections within the ambit of traffic signals . On EM Bypass, advance traffic lights are also being installed ahead of crossings to give motorists adequate time to slam brake if the signal is red.Pedestrian signals, though, remain a sore point in Kolkata with some intersections without signals for those who walk.TOI did the rounds of pedestrian lights at randomly selected five intersections and discovered unique issues at each of them.

Title: PU moot court competition provides practical training to budding lawyers
Content:
The competition attended by legal luminaries was held on March 6-7

Vadodara: City-based Parul University (PU) provided a two-day practical training platform to budding lawyers by organizing the second edition of the state-level moot court competition on March 6 and 7.

The event held at the varsity’s faculty of law successfully brought together prominent legal luminaries from across the state, who adjudged and mentored the students in the various methods of litigation and petition filing. This occasion was graced by justice C K Buch, retired judge of the Gujarat High Court (HC) who presided over the final rounds of the competition.

Aasutos Raj Pathak, permanent secretary of district legal services authority, Vadodara inaugurated the moot court competition.

Sharing his experiences as the judge in HC, Justice Buch asked students various logical questions to evoke their legal acumen including linkage between the marginalised communities and their access to justice.

In addition to the senior judicial experts, students also got opportunity to learn under the guidance of prominent advocates of Baroda Bar Association, along with retired judges of the district court.

The final winners of the competition included GLS Law College, Ahmedabad, Siddharth Law College, Gandhinagar, Anand Institute of Legal Studies, Anand and AMP Law College, Rajkot.

The faculty had also hosted professor Kota Fukui, a senior professor at the graduate school of law and politics at Japan’s Osaka University.

PU will be hosting another talk session with retired justice C K Thakker of Supreme Court, who has been invited for a seminar on gender disparities in India to mark international women’s month.

“Our emphasis on practical training is in line with our focus towards producing the most skilled and capable human resources with the ability to effectively navigate the social, political and legal landscape of our nation,” said PU’s vice president Dr Parul Patel.

Title: Aurangabad: Trader arrested for sending hate content on messages
Content:
Representative image

AURANGABAD: The city police have arrested a 40-year-old trader for allegedly spreading communal hatred on a social media platform.

This is the second such arrest by the police in a week’s time after the man’s communally-charged comment went viral, which forced the cops to take action.

The trader has been identified as Shivnarayn Motilal Totla, who has a wholesale grocery business in the Old Mondha area of the city.

Authorities said the latest action by the City Chowk police station is on the lines of the standing orders issued by commissioner of police Chiranjeev Prasad. The commissioner had instructed the city police to deal with individuals posing threat to communal harmony and overall law and order situation.

Deputy commissioner of police (zone-I) Nikesh Khatmode Patil said, “Soon after registering an offence, we arrested the accused on Saturday night from his house. His statement has been recorded and the mobile phone has been seized and sent for forensic analysis.”

Police said that the accused claimed that he had received the objectionable photograph of a religious structure on a WhatsApp group ‘Vande Matram’ and he forwarded the same to another group ‘TGKMA’ — traders from the Old Mondha area are part of this group.

Detection branch’s police sub-inspector Pravin Kathkar said after the accused posted the alleged content in a group, the screenshots of the same went viral.

These were received by one of the citizens, who got a printout of the same and reached out to the City Chowk police station with a complaint.

Police said an offence under section 295 (for making destruction, damage, or defilement of a place of worship or an object held sacred, with intent to insult the religion of a class of persons) of the Indian Penal Code was registered on the accused.

He was sent to judicial custody by the court, following which, he applied for bail, which was granted.

Sensing trouble, the suspect deleted the post from the said group, before handing over the phone to the police, said a policeman privy to the probe.

Title: For a safe Holi, shun artificial colours: Doctors
Content:
A shopkeeper sells gulal ahead of Holi in Prayagraj on Sunday

PRAYAGRAJ: As the sale of substandard and artificial colours continues in the city, dermatologists have asked revelers to use natural colours to enjoy safe Holi .

Health department officials launched an awareness campaign in the city on Sunday and appealed people to avoid use of chemical-based colours.

Dr Shakti Basu , a dermatologist at Colvin Hospital, said: “Substandard colours may harm skin and eyes. Some colours are sold in the form of paste mixed with toxic compounds and substandard oil. Such colours may cause skin allergy and temporary blindness.”

District administration has failed to put effective curbs on the sale of artificial colours which are being sold in makeshift shops in Chowk, Rajapur, Sulemsarai, Bahadurganj, Johnstonganj , Leader road and Kothaparcha.

Last year, 110 patients were brought to different hospitals who complained of rashes, itching and skin problems due to Holi colours.

“If one is planning to play Holi with wet colours, one may apply body lotion or coconut oil all over the body, especially face, before going out,” he said.

According to eye specialists, arbitrary use of adulterated and synthetic colours can increase chances of injuries to eyes. Even ‘gulal’ and ‘abeer’ are known to have traces of asbestos which may cause corneal ulcer.

Additional chief medical officer Dr Anil Kumar said natural colours should be promoted and people should avoid unsafe colours.

Most of the colours sold at makeshift shops are oxidized metals or industrial dyes mixed with substandard oil.

Lead oxide (black), copper sulphate (green), aluminium bromide (silver) and mercury sulphite (red) are mostly used in colours which may cause allergy, temporary blindness, renal failure, skin cancer and paralysis.

“We are carrying out surprise raids in markets to tighten the noose around vendors selling substandard or artificial colours,” a senior district official said.

Title: Star cricketer Smriti Mandhana’s father was proud after India’s performance
Content:
File photo of Smriti Mandhana

KOLHAPUR: For the star cricketer Smriti Mandhana ’s father, Shriniwas Mandhana , Sunday started on a high note as India, for the first time, had reached the finals of ICC Women’s T20 World Cup held in Australia.

India was playing against the mighty Australian team. In the morning, he had a word with Smriti. “She was relaxed and confident,” said the 23-year-old’s father.

Shriniwas who owns SM-18 Café in Vishrambaug, Sangli said, “We all were confident. All our family members, relatives, and friends had come to SM-18 on Sunday morning. Looking at the team’s performance, we thought we would win. But this is sports, things like this happen.”

“Everyone would have loved a different result, but this was just not our day,” he said.

He said that after the loss it was business as usual in the cafe.

He said, “I am at SM-18 café, my wife is at home. We could not have any word with Smriti yet as their concluding ceremony was on. We might be able to talk to her at night.”

The stylish 23-year-old southpaw, who became ‘India’s latest heartthrob’ after her performance in the 2017 World Cup.

Shriniwas said that in the league matches, India performed extremely well, however, it was just one off day on the field.

“There’s a different kind of pressure playing in front of 80,000 spectators at Melbourne Cricket Ground and the players gave their best,” he said.

Talking about Smriti’s fondness of cricket, Shriniwas said that she used to follow her brother to his cricket practice sessions and got hooked on to it. She never enjoyed studying as much as cricket.

The Australian side defeated India by 85 runs for an unprecedented fifth T20 World Cup triumph on Sunday. Australia recorded 184 for four in 20 overs, while India crumbled to 99 all out.

The iconic Melbourne Cricket Ground saw a turnout of 86,174 people, which is a record in women’s cricket history.

Title: Delhi's Defence Colony residents join hands to fill potholes
Content:
Locals said that after the heavy rain last week, the condition of these roads worsened and vehicles kept getti... Read More

NEW DELHI: Residents of Defence Colony decided to take matters into their own hands after struggling with the pathetic condition of main road facing JCO Club Defence Colony and few internal roads in A-block. On Sunday, several truckloads of malba (debris) were arranged to fill the potholes on these stretches, as commuting had become a nightmare on these roads.

Locals claimed that after they initiated the drive, Delhi Jal Board came forward to assist them to fill craters on roads. The potholes had developed after work for laying sewer lines was carried out four months ago.

“After the civic agency laid down the lines in December, the dug-up areas were filled temporarily with soil and no repairing or restoration was done by DJB. The work kept delaying for several reasons, including the assembly elections,” said a resident.

After the rain last week, the condition of these stretches worsened, forcing the residents to address the issue. “After the heavy rain on Thursday and Friday, these stretches further caved in at several spots. Vehicles were getting stuck in these potholes. So, we pooled in money and arranged for debris,” said a resident.

The resident added that DJB has also arranged for two trucks of debris to fix the potholes, but they want a concrete solution.

On being questioned, area MLA Madan Lal accepted that the main road has been in a shambles, but claimed that the civic agency had made the arrangements on Sunday, not the residents. “After Holi, the roads in A-block will be repaired properly. We are not responsible for the condition of other stretches in the area,” Lal said.

A resident of C-block said that the situation was the same in his locality too. “This is a B-category area while paying property taxes, but you’d not realise this while looking at the state of these roads,” he said.

Maj (retd) Ranjit Singh, president of Defence Colony RWA ,said that the elected representatives were ignoring the problems. “Not just the roads, even the sewage lines in the area are overflowing. The authorities need to address these as soon as possible,” Singh said.

Title: Coronavirus in Kerala: Pathanamthitta on high alert, mass gatherings banned
Content: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Pathanamthitta district has been put under strict alert with the reporting of five positive cases of Covid-19 from Ranni . A massive search operation is on to track the people who have come into contact with these people who have been now tested positive.“We have taken up the massive exercise to track those who had direct contacts with these people. Not just the direct contact, the secondary and tertiary contact people will also have to be found out. This exercise is expected to complete by today evening itself,” said P B Nooh, district collector of Pathanamthitta.The worrying factor for the district administration is the fact that the three people who had come Italy had attended two weddings and also attended mass in two churches. It has also been found that they have travelled outside Pathanamthitta district. The people who had come to receive these three at Nedumbassery airport had come from Kottayam.The district administration has constituted eight medical teams with seven members each comprising two doctors to conduct a house-to-house visit in the areas where the five positive cases have visited. “We have asked the medical teams to immediately shift people to isolation wards if they show fever symptoms or came into contact with these positive cases,’’ said the collector.For this we have set up isolation wards in taluk and district hospitals. Medical teams from Alappuzha and Kottayam medical college hospitals have already reached Pathanamthitta to help the district administration.All private hospitals in the district have been asked to report if they come across any suspected cases. A meeting of private hospitals has been convened to review the situation, the collector said.The district administration has urged people, especially in the Ranni taluk, to avoid mass gatherings and public functions. It has also been decided to appeal to all political parties to avoid public functions in the district. “At present the situation is under control and there is no need to panic. All action plan is on to trace people. The district administration is doing its best,” the collector said.Five control rooms have been set up in the district by the health department and the disaster management officials to provide support in case any emergency.Control Room NumbersDMO: 0468-2228220Disaster Management Authority: 0468-2322515Toll Free No: 1077, 9188293118, 9188803119

Title: Surveillance intensified over Covid-19
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: The health department has intensified the surveillance in the wake of five positive cases of Covid-19 reported from the state. All health workers at the primary level have been asked to intensify their house-to-house monitoring, since the people who tested positive had direct contacts with several people.All hospitals have been asked to report any suspect cases immediately to the respective district health administration. The screening of passengers at airports will be intensified since there are reports of people getting out of the airport without reporting at the health desks.People coming from China, Hong Kong, Thailand, Singapore, Japan, South Korea, Vietnam, Nepal, Indonesia, Malaysia, Iran and Italy will be screened at the airports. Those who have travelled from these countries after February 10 and haven’t reported to the state health department, has been asked to immediately report the nearest health centre.Health minister K K Shailaja has urged all the people to support the government to prevent any spreading of the virus in the community. “Only through community participation can we succeed in tackling this issue. Hence, everyone who have travelled from the infected regions have to report immediately to the nearest health centre,” said the minister.Shailaja also warned of strict action against those who defy government orders. The government is closely monitoring the situation and all necessary arrangements have been made to prevent any epidemic-like situation.“At present the focus of the government is to save the lives of people who have tested positive. They are stable and the doctors have said there is nothing to worry. The second focus is on to prevent the spreading of the virus in the community. For this, we are taking measures,” said the minister.The number of hospitals with isolation wards have been increased in Pathanamthitta now. If situation demands, then there will be more isolation wards in other districts too. All doctors have been urged to strictly adhere to the treatment protocol issued by the health department.

Title: Coronavirus in Rajasthan: South Central Railway takes precautionary measures
Content: Aurangabad: South Central Railway (SCR) will create a separate isolation ward for handling suspected coronavirus cases at the Zonal Railway Hospital and all the six divisional hospitals, including Nanded.Regular public announcements at all important railway stations are being made to create awareness among the passengers and the employees about the preventive measures to stop the spread of coronavirus.SCR will put a separate Information Education and Communication (IEC) material on coronavirus, to be displayed at important locations in all stations written in local language.“Machinery has been put in place for monitoring any suspected cases at different railway stations at the zone and division-levels. Railway medical in-charges are in constant touch with state and district authorities to obtain guidelines on the subject and take necessary detective, preventive and curative measures suggested by them,” chief public relations officer of SCR, Ch Rakesh said.The Railway Board on March 6 held training for all zonal medical authorities involving experts explaining to them via video-conference. SCR authorities said that medical personnel are being trained to handle suspected patients of coronavirus.The authorities said a close watch is being kept on the website of the Ministry of Health Sciences to take notes of measures suggested by the central authorities.As per the official record, around over 12,000 passengers book unreserved tickets from Aurangabad railway station every day and the station witnesses footfall of over 34,000 passengers on any given day, including foreign tourists.

Title: Kalshetti suspends headmaster of Kolhapur Municipal Corporation school
Content:
Representative image

KOLHAPUR: Civic chief Mallinath Kalshetti on Sunday suspended a Kolhapur Municipal Corporation ( KMC ) school acting-headmaster for going on leave without taking prior permission from the seniors.

During his surprise visit on Saturday morning to Barrister Balasaheb Khardekar Vidyamandir, Kalshetti found acting headmaster Namdev Wagh absent without informing the administrative officer of the school board. He also found two other teachers absent, who are identified as Subhash Marathe and Kiran Padalkar , against whom the show-cause notices have been issued.

An official of the primary education committee of KMC requesting anonymity said, “Three teachers of the school are already on leave. In such a case, the acting headmaster should have been in the school on a full-time basis. We found no permission was taken by him. The absence of the senior teachers in the school may lead to indiscipline and loss of academic work. Civic chief has also ordered an internal enquiry over the indiscipline of the teachers and other staff of the KMC schools.”

In recent weeks, Kalshetti is on spree to suspend the officers and other staff for arriving late to the office or failing to do their duty. He has demanded a reply from the two teachers, failing to provide a satisfactory response will result in their suspension. During the suspension, the civic body staff only get a fraction of their salary.

Title: Gujarat: Four kill, burn snake, film it on TikTok
Content:
Video shows farm labourers dancing with the dead reptile

VADODARA: Four farm labourers from Mahisagar district were arrested on Sunday for killing a rat snake and then making a TikTok video of their act.

Forest department booked Jagdish Vaghela, Pravin Vaghela, Bharatsinh Vaghela and Vikram Vaghela under different sections of Wildlife Protection Act as the rat snake is a schedule II reptile specie.

According to forest department sources, the four labourers saw the snake escaping from a haystack in a farm where they were working on March 5 and ran behind it. They caught hold of it and then started playing with it. Soon, they started making a TikTok video with the reptile and in one of the videos they are seen hitting the snake with a wooden stick. “They hit the snake with a wooden stick and stones which ultimately killed the reptile,” said Balasinor range forest officer Daud Kokani.

The four made the videos even after killing the snake and then burnt the carcass. A day later, man from Rajkot saw the TikTok video and asked for their location. The accused told him that they are from Balasinor following which the man informed the forest department officials and also showed them the video. Kokani said that with the help of local informers, they could find all four farm labourers by Sunday.

“They were not aware that killing a snake is crime. They just wanted to have fun so they hit the snake for the videos,” Kokani said. On Sunday when they were asked why they had burnt the snake’s remains, they told foresters that they wanted to perform snake’s final rites. All four accused were sent to judicial custody on Sunday evening.



In Video: Gujarat: Four men kill and burn snake, film it on TikTok

Title: 221 drunk drivers arrested during weekend checks in Cyberabad
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

HYDERABAD: The Cyberabad traffic cops have arrested 221 persons for drunk driving during special checks conducted during the weekend. Of them, 119 persons are between the age group of 21-30 years and 66 are in the age group of 31-40 years.

The traffic cops said that 43 violators were designated drivers, 23 IT employees, 31 labourers, nine from agriculture and realty sectors. There were also 19 entrepreneurs, nine students, five security guards, one government employee.

While the permissible BAC (Blood Alcohol Concentration) limit is 30, 102 people were found to have between 51 and 100 BAC, while one person was found with BAC level above 300.

Title: 3 dumpers of plastic waste removed from Jayanthi nullah
Content:
Representative image

KOLHAPUR: The Kolhapur Municipal Corporation ( KMC ) has removed over three dumpers of plastic waste from Jayanthi nullah on Sunday’s Mahaswachhta Abhiyan.

Over 150 sanitation workers were deployed along the stretch of the nullah which covered areas near Lakshmipuri, pumping station and Hutatma Garden. The civic body appealed to the people to join the cause and accordingly, some of the locals and people connected to various organisations, college students attended the drive.

From the past few weeks, the KMC reported dumping of a large amount of plastic waste into the nullah. Subsequently, 30 people were fined on Saturday for dumping the waste.

R K Patil, deputy hydraulic engineer of KMC said, “Currently, we are organising the drive to confiscate the plastic carry bags from the traders and fine them as part of the implementation of the plastic ban. Those restoring to throw plastic in open are also fined. We have found a large number of plastic waste in the Jayanthi nullah which crosses the city’s important localities. We found the plastic waste floating and deployed the staff at those places. We collected over three dumpers of plastic which will be disposed of properly.”

The KMC is going to identify the manufacturers of the plastic carry bags found in large quantities in the nullah. The officials claimed that most of the plastic waste was used for making small milk pouches. The KMC is going to visit the milk suppliers from the localities and ask them to strictly buy-back the milk pouches. The officials maintained that the locals use plastic pouches to collect the regular household waste which is then together dumped in the nullah.

“We are going to address the concerns of the locals about an inadequate number of garbage containers and no regular visits of the ghantagadis to collect the waste from door to doors,” added Patil.

Title: Former intel chief AB Venkateswara Rao contends charges in letter to MHA
Content:
VIJAYAWADA: Former intelligence chief AB Venkateswara Rao has contended that the conformation of his suspension by the ministry of home affairs ( MHA ) was without considering his explanation.

In his explanation to MHA, Rao had said the allegations against him stemmed from due to his perceived closeness with the TDP government.

Rao said the inquiry by a DSP-rank official from CID was over two days after a memo was given by DGP on February 2, 2020 and the contents of the report are more or less same as in the memo with little extrapolations.

Rao said procurement of UAV and Aerostat was started in 2017 by the DGP’s office. A purchase order was issued by State Trading Corporation of India Limited (STCIL) with DGP’s approval but cancelled by DGP in December 2018.

He said while the intelligence department was the user agency for the equipment, the DGP’s office was the procuring agency. He was not a member of purchase committee or technical committee. The DGP’s office is answerable for any irregularity, and not ADG intelligence.

In his report to MHA, Rao said the memo by DGP on February 2 did not give any cause of action and reference to the source of suspicion.

He said in-house experts were involved in technology survey, product identification, demonstration, field visit, technical evaluation and licensing procedures. Rao said RFP and EOI were are not mandatory for every tender.

Rao said fixing technical evaluation criteria was not the job of the purchase committee and technical committee.

Rao said the purchase committee led by ADG C Dwaraka Tirumala Rao cut down the cost from Rs 44 crore to Rs 20 crore by scaling down five-year warranty and five-year annual maintenance to one year.

Rao said his son’s company did not give any demonstration on behalf of RT Inflatables. He said the chief secretary’s letter said the ‘demonstration of equipment is mandatory but not done’.

Rao said he was transferred on the very day the new government took charge. He was without a posting for more than eight months and an inquiry was initiated after his request for posting and salary.

The inquiry was over in two days and the government suspended a day after the report and it showed the malice in law, said Rao to MHA.

Title: Coronavirus in Maharashtra: Officials on alert ahead of Holi, Gudipadwa
Content: KOLHAPUR: The Maharashtra State Road Transport Corporation (MSRTC) is facing a unique challenge this holiday season. With the number of passengers expected rise, the corporation will also have the added responsibility of ensuring everyone’s safety by taking all necessary coronavirus-related precautions.According to Rohan Palange, the Kolhapur divisional controller of MSRTC, they are awaiting more instructions from the district administration.“So far, we have received general precautions like the importance of sanitization, avoiding crowded places, avoid touching face etc.. But whether to lower the number of trips or stop certain routes is yet to be announced,” he said.He added that the Kolhapur depot has around 800 buses that make around 6,000 trips in which around 3 lakh passengers commute daily on intra-city and inter-city routes. “And these are our buses, operating from our depot. If we added buses that arrive and operate from other depots, then the number of passengers and trips will be very high,” he said, adding that so far there has been no decision on the provision of masks to conductors or drivers.Sangli, Satara, and Kolhapur district administrations are on high alert ahead of Holi and Gudipadwa festivities. The collectors of the respective districts have requested people to refrain from mass gatherings and organising events on these occasions.Abhijeet Chaudhary, the Sangli collector, told TOI: “Citizens should avoid mass gatherings. Even though we have not received any request for social events, such events are not the need of the hour. We are making sure citizens get to know the dos and don’ts of controlling the infection.”He added that the posters and digital boards are being installed across the city for the citizens’ information.While the district health department officials from Satara said they have informed the hotels and resorts in the Mahabaleshwar and Panchgani to report any foreign tourists who have travel history from coronavirus-hit countries. Sanjay Salunkhe, district civil surgeon, Sangli, told TOI, that they had taken five swab samples earlier last week, all of which have tested negative. “People do not need to panic. Everything is under control,” he said.

Title: JNTU-H asks profs to submit 34 documents as proof of PhD
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

HYDERABAD: Professors, who have completed PhDs or work in colleges affiliated to the Jawaharlal Nehru Technological University Hyderabad (JNTU-H), are in a fix as they now have to submit several details along with more than 30 other documents to prove the ‘genuinity’ of their degrees. They have time till March 12 to upload as many as 34 documents to prove that their PhDs are not fake.

“I received my PhD from Sri Venkateswara University in 2014. I have the admission letter, pre-PhD course work, final thesis submission report, and the original degree with me. But where would I get the admission letter or name of the then Board of Studies (BoS) chairman along with proof, or a copy of the no objection certificate issued by the employer to pursue PhD while working?” asked M Vara Prasad Rao , a lecturer with 17 years of experience.

“I have submitted my certificates at least five times and appeared for physical verification more than 10 times. Except for collecting details, JNTU doesn’t analyse the data or release the results. We don’t know what their target is and why they are repeating this process every year,” Rao said.

President of Technical Institutions Employees Association V Balakrishna Reddy said, “Every year they have this verification drive in November or December, but never release the results. This is nothing but harassment.”

The professors said that the varsity can collect other details such as PhD registration number, name of the candidate, date of admission and date of degree awarded as well as the final thesis report and send these details to the respective universities for verification.

Meanwhile, varsity officials said that some of the documents have been made optional. “We asked for these documents as a few could not even give us their guide’s name. However, after the professors raised concerns, we made several of these documents optional,” said Ramamohan Reddy K, director (in-charge), Academic Audit Cell, JNTU-H.

Title: Delhi: 35 years on, 30 acquitted in transistor blasts case
Content: NEW DELHI: A Delhi court has acquitted 30 people in the 1985 transistor bomb blasts, which left 49 people dead and 127 injured, observing that a conviction could not happen on the basis of “such a faulty investigation”.Additional sessions judge Sandeep Yadav stated in his order: “The indisputable conclusion is that the investigation conducted in these cases was defective, lopsided, unfair and suffered from various lacunae. Accused persons cannot be convicted on the basis of evidence collected during such faulty investigation.”The 1985 serial blasts, often dubbed as Delhi’s bloodiest brush with terror, were carried out with transistor-like contraptions with an explosive mixture of picric acid and ammonium nitrate, in addition to dry batteries. Bombs fitted in these transistors went off in Delhi and adjoining areas of UP and Haryana and unexploded bombs were recovered from various parts of Delhi.The accused were chargesheeted for offences of waging war against India, murder, attempt to murder, criminal conspiracy and various other charges of IPC and Explosives Substances Act. Of the 59 total chargesheeted people, 12 were declared proclaimed offenders and 12 people died whereas five were discharged in the case. A total of 1,399 witnesses were mentioned in the chargesheets and the prosecution examined 354 witnesses to prove the charges against the accused.It was observed that, unfortunately, the original chargesheet filed by Delhi Police was misplaced and a “reconstructed” one was filed. “Therefore, prosecution cannot establish the existence of original documents on the basis of list of documents mentioned in the chargesheet.The court also observed that a departmental inquiry was initiated against the then court officials responsible for misplacing the court documents. The order pointed towards some of the contradictions in the chargesheet in terms of circumstances that showed complicity of the accused.One such instance was about a bus having one of the accused with a transistor bomb. The court noted that, in an earlier part of the chargesheet, it was mentioned that the bus was going towards Ashram Chowk, but, subsequently, it stated it was onwards Kalyanpuri. “This contradiction in the chargesheet itself has not been explained by the prosecution,” the court said.The chargesheet also stated that on finding the bus crowded, the same accused got off and boarded a bus — on which he placed the bomb — going towards Maharani Bagh. “No details/particulars of the bus, including its number, etc., were collected by the investigating officer. No evidence was collected to clarify as to whether the bomb placed in the bus exploded or remained unexploded and, if the bomb remained unexploded, whether the same was defused or not.“In fact, nobody has come before the court to depose that he defused the bomb,” the court pointed out.While additional public prosecutor L D Singh submitted that it was a case of “heinous nature”, defence counsels R M Tiwari, Seema Gulati, Rakesh Mahajan and Nitin Rai Sharma had argued that their clients had been false implicated in these cases.The court noted that it was the prosecution’s case that accused people had hatched a conspiracy to create disharmony among various communities to take revenge of the Blue Star Operation and riots that happened in November 1984. It, however, observed that the prosecution had “miserably failed” to prove that any relatives, friends, near and dears of the accused died in the 1984 riots or in Blue Star Operation. It said, “It is amply clear from the evidence adduced on record that during investigation of the present case, police officials had picked up various people and made them approvers after pressuring and torturing them.”Holding that vital links were missing in the chain of circumstances, the court added that it could not be proved conclusively that the crime was committed by the accused and none else.The court also highlighted in its order that the accused were warned that if they did not depose as per demands of police, then they would be made an accused in the present case and their family members were “pressured” and “tortured” by police. “A number of witnesses have deposed about the manner in which police pressured people to depose on the dotted lines to create a false edifice of the alleged conspiracy,” it said.

Title: Aurangabad: New legal aid clinic at NLU to spread awareness
Content:
Representative image

AURANGABAD: Justice Sanjay Gangapurwala of the Bombay high court on Sunday said several oppressed, suppressed and depressed classes from the society were unaware of the legal aid and necessary legal remedies available.

Speaking at the inauguration of the legal aid clinic at the National Law University (NLU) here, he appealed to all law students to reach out to such underprivileged people. “The legal aid clinic should create awareness among people. The facility must also make people aware of the different welfare schemes of the state,” he said.

“Through the legal aid clinic, students must go to villages and guide the rural population on their legal rights. Many people still do not know about the different welfare programmes and schemes. The clinic can spread awareness,” he said.

Set up at on the Kanchanwadi campus of the NLU, the legal aid clinic is expected to provide free legal advice and counselling for people from various sections of society, as well as facilitating mediation from time to time. The facility will have a pro-bono panel of resource persons who will volunteer and handle different cases that come to the clinic.

Gangapurwala said an alternative dispute resolution system was necessary. “There is a dire need of making pre-litigation mediation mandatory,” he added.

K V S Sarma, the vice-chancellor of NLU, Aurangabad, said, “The clinic will give much-needed exposure to law students about mainstream and alternative dispute resolution systems.”

Justice Prasanna Varale of the Bombay HC, district and sessions judge S M Bhosale and NLU registrar Ashok Wadje also attended the event.

Title: Valiyakesavan: Ban to be lifted today
Content:
Thrissur: The forest department finally lifted the ban on Guruvayur tusker Valiyakesavan from Monday onwards.

The decision was based on the expert committee report, said Thrissur assistant conservator of forests (ACF) P M Prabhu. As per the direction from chief wildlife warden the forest department expert team led by Kerala Veterinary and Animal Sciences University head of the department Dr Syam K Venugopal, and Dr David Abraham AFVO, Thrissur inspected the tusker Valiyakesavan, on Saturday and submitted a report to Thrissur ACF.

“While considering the report we will lift the ban on Valiyakesvan from Monday onwards for the next one month on a trial basis. The tusker can be used for the parades of Guruvayur Temple and for the parades of nearby temples. After one month we will again inspect the tusker and fully release the tusker,” said Prabhu.

“It was found that the tusker was cured of the fibroid cyst,” said the official.

Guruvayur Devaswom deputy administrator S Sasidharan said, “When the forest department lifts the ban on Monday we will use Valiyakesavan for Guruvayur Temple festival parade from Tuesday onwards. In addition, we will use Valiyakesavan for Pallivetta (Royal hunt) and Arattu (Holy bath) rituals on March 14 and 15.”

“Normally Padmanabhan and Valiyakesavan led the rituals of the Guruvayur Temple festival. Due to the demise of Padmanabhan the temple committee wishes Valiyakesavan to lead the rituals,” said Sasidharan.

The forest department had imposed restrictions on Guruvayur tuskers Padmanabhan and Valiyakesavan on December 7 against parading, due to age and health-related issues .

Later, the forest department formed an expert committee to inspect the health condition of the tuskers. Based on the expert committee report, the forest department lifted the ban on Padmanabhan on February 3. But later, the condition of Padmanabhan worsened and he died on February 26. TNN

Title: Coronavirus scare fails to tamp down Holi spirit in Prayagraj markets
Content:
Residents out to shop and the congested lane of a market in Prayagraj on Sunday

PRAYAGRAJ: As the threat posed by novel coronavirus (Covid-19) looms large, concern over a potential outbreak failed to deter Prayagraj residents from thronging markets on Sunday for some last-minute shopping for Holi.

Popular markets like Chowk, Civil Lines, Katra, Bahadurganj, Mutthiganj and Sulemsarai wore a crowded look on Sunday as shoppers came out in large numbers.

Be it sweet shops selling ghujiyas or those offering gulal and herbal colours, there was hardly a shop without a crowd of customers .

Most shoppers said they were not bothered by the advisories issued by the government urging residents to avoid public gatherings due to the spread of novel coronavirus. The footfall in these markets only swelled by afternoon.

“My family and friends have decided to play Holi using natural colours as there is no threat of coronavirous in the city. Reports from other parts of the world might have dimmed the excitement, but there is nothing stopping us from playing Holi,” said a shopper in Civil Lines Vinayak Mehrotra.

Dhoomanganj resident Alok Srivastava said “People are not avoiding buying Holi supplies and colours that are for sale. I would be celebrating Holi with my friends and neighbours as well.”

Garima, who came to Civil Lines for shopping, said, “Why shouldn’t we celebrate Holi? The festival is celebrated is just once a year. If we take precautions, no harm will be done.”

Meanwhile, health department officials on Sunday claimed that no coronavirus cases have been reported in the city till now and they are trying to make more and more people aware about precautionary measures.

Title: Flouting norms, two-wheelers being rented out to tourists in Mussoorie, allege residents
Content:
Mussoorie residents facing parking woes

MUSSOORIE: Taxi operators as well as residents have raised objections over the trend of two-wheelers being given out on rent to tourists in Mussoorie. It has been alleged that various norms were violated by two-wheeler rental operators while at the same time, vehicles are being arbitrarily parked across the town and are also creating traffic congestion and chaos.

SS Panwar , secretary of Mussoorie Taxi Association , said that operators need to have sufficient parking spaces for vehicles, a proper office space and also amenities such as toilets to obtain licence. He added, “Most of the two-wheeler rental operators do not have any parking, nor any office space or other facilities. They are violating all norms of the transport department.”

He also claimed that a large number of rented vehicles ply with private numbers while many operators run more number of vehicles than the sanctioned number.

Taxi operators added that two-wheeler rentals are taking away their business and jeopardising their livelihoods. “Last year, our revenues dipped 50% due to a spurt in two-wheeler rentals. We have to pay installments for our vehicles, meet maintenance costs and also take care of our families. How are we supposed to do that?” asked Mukesh Kharola , a taxi operator.

A few residents added that two-wheelers are eating up into the limited parking space that the hill town has. “They are parked everywhere across the town, creating a nuisance. They also cause a lot of traffic congestion,” said a Gandhi Chowk resident.

However, two-wheeler rental operators refuted the charges of violation of norms and any other malpractices.

“We have obtained due permission from the transport department and are functioning as per norms,” a two-wheeler rental operator who did not wish to be named, told TOI.

Mussoorie has around 800 to 1,000 two-wheelers, including commercial and private, that are operated on a rental basis. One can hire a scooty or a bike for a day for Rs 800 and Rs 1,500 respectively. For the same period, a Harley Davidson will cost around Rs 5,000.

Mussoorie SHO Vidhya Bhushan Negi , meanwhile, promised action against those flouting the rules. He said, “We will ensure that roadside parking of two-wheelers with commercial numbers is stopped. We will also initiate inquiry into the allegations of renting of private vehicles.”

Title: Counting error by returning officer leads to Serula re-poll
Content:
Panaji:A year after the controversial results of the elections to the managing committee of the Serula comunidade were declared, the high court has directed that the elections to the posts of attorney, substitute attorney, treasurer and substitute treasurer be reheld - this time via open ballot.

During the elections that were held in March 2019, there was arithmetic incongruity on the part of the mamlatdar who was the election officer presiding over the elections—despite the process being videotaped.

More raised hands were counted than the voters actually present, the court found. The court observed that although there were only 375 voters, the show of hands counted were 378 votes for the post of substitute treasurer, 385 votes for the post of attorney and 379 votes for the post of substitute attorney.

“What troubles this court’s judicial conscience is the election officer’s indifferent attitude. In the first round, the disgruntled panel of candidates did their best to stymie the election process. The election officer and the police were mere spectators,” said the high court in its December order. “ In the second round, the panels do not seem to have played any disruptive role. Instead, the election officer played spoilsport. The candidates plead they have no clue how the excess votes were accounted for,” the order said.

“So the election officer alone could have explained how it had happened—how more hands were raised, than there actually were,” the court noted adding that the mamlatdar has allowed the rival candidates to slug it out and settle the matter for themselves.

“As a public servant, the mamlatdar is expected to be more responsible and responsive. He could have cleared the air and assisted the court; rather, he is bound to do so. As a result, his attitude has led to further delay and expenditure, which otherwise could have been avoided,” the court held.

Title: Vocalist Mandar gives rich treat
Content:
Classical vocalist Mandar Gadgil regales the audience in ‘Brahmanaad’ musical programme organized by SCZCC, in... Read More

Nagpur: Different nuances of various ragas were captured effectively by classical vocal singer Mandar Gadgil from Pune at a programme titled ‘Brahmanaad’, organized by South Central Zone Cultural Centre (SCZCC), on Sunday.

As morning chill in the air has subsided, a good number of connoisseurs of music soaked in the warmth of class that was evident in the gayaki of Mandar who triggered emotions by selecting the ragas suitable to the event and performing them with aplomb.

Mandar chose ‘Lalat’, which is essentially sung at dawn, to begin his performance and presented a bandish ‘Ghatan lagi rain’ in vilambit Ek Taal. He caught on to the pulse of the audience with his melodious voice as he sang in madhyalaya, transforming the mood of the performance.

His presentation of ‘Ja ja re ja balamwa’, wooing the one close to heart, was immediately lapped up by the audience. A rather soft rendition, his mellifluous voice matched the sentiments that a yearning person has.

Recitation of raag Bhatiyar was lilting as Mandar made full use of his vocals, presenting taans and aalaps, with ease.

He splashed colours of singing that he has in his armoury when he sang a hori in raag Bhairavi. Music lovers related to the raga as the festival of Holi is round the corner.

The jugalbandi of high-pitched vocals and instrumental music made the performance top notch.

The thumping beats of tabla, coupled with soft instrumental sound of harmonium, went along perfectly with the vocals of Mandar. He made his presentations sound pleasant.

Mandar was accompanied by Ram Khadse on tabla and Narendra Kadwe on harmonium.

In between, Mandar engaged with jugalbandi between his rendition, tabla and harmonium.

As Sunday was celebrated as International Women’s Day, SCZCC director took the opportunity to felicitate women employees of the centre who work tirelessly to make cultural programmes organized by SCZCC successful.

Those who were honoured included Ujjwala Indurkar, Sabia Naz, Shital Sonpipare, Geeta Shanguwar, Nisha Pande, Shweta Tiwari, Chitra Manohare and Jyoti Gurve.

The programme was anchored by Shweta Shelgaonkar.

Earlier, the programme was inaugurated with the lighting a traditional lamp by SCZCC director Deepak Khirwadkar, deputy director Mohan Parkhi, social worker Abhay Gokhale, Deepali Khirwadkar and Swarupa Dande.

Programme officer Shashank Dande, Shrikant Desai and Deepak Patil were present.

Quotes

* I am a regular visitor to ‘Brahmanaad. I am also learning the art of singing. Therefore, watching Mandar Gadgil perform classical vocal was a treat for me

Priyanka Dubey | housewife

* What a great start to the morning than to listen to fine classical music? I thoroughly enjoyed the programme in the pleasant morning hours

Rohit Tiwari | marketing employee

* I always look forward to attending ‘Brahmanaad’ event. SCZCC invites new and renowned artistes which acts as a tonic for learners and people alike

Manjushree Tattiwar | businesswoman

Title: New facility to ease filing of complaints for women, kids
Content:
Kozhikode: The city police, here, have launched a women empowerment initiative ‘Shelter’, to help women and children file their grievances easily . Shelter is a mobile helpdesk of the city police which would enable women to present their grievances without visiting police stations.

The mobile helpdesk will be stationed at different locations in the city police district limit to help women. Women who are hesitant to visit police station to file petitions can make use of the facility.

“The mobile helpdesk will provide an opportunity to the women to interact with women police personnel outside the police station,” said A V George, district police chief (Kozhikode city) during the inaugural function. There will be a woman sub-inspector and two women cops in the vehicle, he added.

The mobile helpdesk will be controlled by the women cell. The service of women police persons from various police stations in the city limit will also be utilized for the scheme.

The mobile helpdesk will be functional from Monday to Saturday, said K M Leela, inspector of police women cell. The location of the vehicle will be communicated in advance and the vehicle will be stationed at areas where women can easily reach it, she said.

Women will be able to file all types of complaints at the women helpdesk. They can also contact the women police persons by dialling the helpdesk number.

“Women can share their issues on the phone first. We will then help them prepare a written petition and inform them about when we will reach the locations,” said the woman inspector.

The ‘Shelter’ will travel to different locations from 10am to 5pm. The vehicle will be stationed near panchayat offices, village offices and other places where women frequent.

The help desk project was launched to mark women’s day. As per the present plan the helpdesk will continue the mobile service till December 31, 2020.

The plan is to sensitize women on the importance of alerting police about crime against women. The helpdesk was opened by writer Khadeeja Mumtaz. District police chief A V George and other officials were present.

To improve women safety in the city limit, the city police are also planning to install complaint boxes in 50 select locations in the city. Women and children will be able to convey their grievances through the complaint boxes.

They can also ring the mobile helpdesk at :9497923380

Title: Rs 34 lakh siphoned off from 6 bank accounts of a Kolhapur company
Content:
Representative image

KOLHAPUR: The cybercrime police have registered a case against an unidentified person for siphoning off Rs 34 lakh from six bank accounts of a company through 20 transactions.
