According to police, the complainant identified as Mahadev Kashinath Kamble works with a city-based industry and looks after its financial transactions. On March 7, when Kamble checked the bank accounts that he was handling, he noticed that Rs 34 lakh cash was siphoned off from six of the company’s accounts between 11.28 am and 12.42 pm. A total of 20 transactions were done during this period and the cash was transferred to different accounts through RTGS and NEFT.

He immediately rushed to the bank and informed the officials about it. Later, he lodged a complaint with the cybercrime police.

“We have registered a case against an unidentified person under several sections of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) including section 406 (Punishment for criminal breach of trust) and 420 (Cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property) and section 43, 54, 66 C and 66 D of IT Act,” said a police officer.

“We suspect that the crime has been done by more than one person and by someone who was aware of the transactions being done by the accountant or someone in the industry. The suspects must be closely related with someone from the industry and had committed the crime after getting some relevant information regarding the bank and the transactions of the industry,” he added.

The officer said that they have initiated an investigation into the case and will soon find reach out to the suspects.

Title: Gadchiroli women cops undergo C-60 commando training
Content:
Representational pic

Nagpur: A group of women cops from Gadchiroli, responding to a call by SP Shailesh Balkawade, have undergone the ‘jungle warfare and guerrilla tactics’ of the district polices’ elite force ‘C-60 commandos’.

The unit of the women cops, groomed on the lines of C-60 commandos, are learnt to be kept reserved for a ‘specific purpose’.

The training and accomplishments of the C-60 commandos in dealing with Maoists violence had catapulted to a nationwide fame after the April 2018 encounters when they had set a benchmark by eliminating 40 cadres of the reds at Kasnasur-Boriya encounters.

Around a month ago, Balkawade had sent a wireless message to all the posts asking for women cops from the district who are keen to undergo ‘one-month training’ at the Gadchiroli polices’ own jungle warfare and guerrilla tactics academy in the district which trained the C-60 commandos. The SP had a handful of interested cops coming forward to join the training from different parts of the district.

Balkawade said the cops were hand-picked from the interested lot on the basis of their physical abilities and other parameters. “There was a specific reason for creating a group of women commandos but it cannot be discussed. We have just kept them ready and fit to serve the secret mission when required,” he said. “It’s a fact that Maoists have almost 50% of their dalam strength in women but our creating the specially trained group was not in respond to such a situation,” said the SP.

Balkawade also stated that women cops for the first time have been introduced in the ‘Long range patrolling’ (LRP) in which they are required to remain, operate and move in the forest in anti-Maoist missions for couple of days at a stretch. “We had already introduced women in the Short range patrolling (SRP) in the past but just now have started sending them on few LRPs too based on the situation but as a part of a team and not as an independent contingent,” he said.

Balkawade also extolled the contribution of the women in the ‘grambhets’ or village visits in collecting intelligence by meeting with the housewives who would not otherwise open up with men cops. “There are certain issues which women would not be able to discuss with men. In such a situation, women cops can more easily cater to such a need,” he said.

Balkawade also said women cops are now being more increasingly used in the outreach programs like ‘Jan jaagaran melawas’ or different camps in the interiors.

Title: T govt to auction land to fund welfare programmes
Content:
Hyderabad: To fund the TRS government’s flagship welfare schemes and capital expenditure, the K Chandrasekhar Rao government will auction government land to mobilise Rs 10,000 crore-Rs 12,000 crore in the next financial year (2020-2021).

“The government will sell non-performing assets and land available with Deccan Infrastructure and Land Holdings Limited , Telangana Housing Board and Rajiv Swagruha to raise money. The United AP government had established them when real estate sector was in a slump. Now, real estate is in a boom phase again. We will exploit land banks and use the money to implement various schemes,” finance minister T Harish Rao said in his budget speech on Sunday.

Official sources said Housing Board and DIHL possess about 4,000 acres land bank, while TSIIC, Hyderabad Metropolitan Development Authority (HMDA) have about 2,000 acres land ready for auction. HMDA has already started developing a layout at Kokapet in an 650 acres. “Various government departments have identified land parcels which can be used for resource mobilisation. The government had planned resource mobilisation last year too, but could not go ahead due to series of elections,” a senior official of revenue department said.

Apart from land auction, the municipal administration department hopes to raise Rs 3,000 crore to Rs 4,000 crore by giving Hyderabad Outer Ring Road toll fee collection contract for longer period, between five and 10 years. Officials said National Highways Authority of India has already been doing this for the past few years.

Later, interacting with the media after the budget presentation, finance minister Harish Rao said apart from auctioning land, strategies were being worked out to improve revenues from sand and other minerals. “With increasing license fee by the excise department, the government has been getting Rs 300 crore additional revenue a month for the past three months. Going by this, excise department alone gets Rs 6,000 crore additional revenue for 12 months in the next financial year,” he said. The minister said the government was also considering giving one-time settlement for commercial establishments for clearing arrears.

The state government has already made its intentions clear to enhance government land value (market value) for registering properties and power tariff from April.

Title: Excercise extra caution: Health minister urges Pongala devotees
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: Health minister K K Shailaja has asked those with Covid-19 symptoms — fever and cough — to stay away from pongala offerings to Attukal Devi on Monday.

The minister who convened a meeting of the rapid response team of the health department here on Sunday said those who have come from infected areas but not showing symptoms should offer the pongala at their respective houses.

Foreigners, who have come for offering pongala, have been asked to offer it at the hotels where they are staying. All the hotels, resorts and homestays have been given necessary direction to provide space at their premises for this. “It is not possible to cancel the Pongala festival as the people have already reached the state capital for it. Hence, what we can do is only self-precaution,” said Shailaja.

In 32 wards of the state capital, 23 health teams have been constituted to conduct house-to-house visits, the minister said. These medical teams will visit houses soon after the pongala festival to screen people. “Those with symptoms of fever and cough will be immediately quarantined and, if needed, will be shifted to the isolation wards of hospitals,” she said.

All the residents’ associations have been asked to report to the district medical office or nearby hospitals if there are people who have travelled from the infected countries or from within the country and have developed fever symptoms. All primary health centres have been directed to immediately shift such people coming with fever symptoms to the isolation wards set up at district hospitals and general hospitals. The samples of all these people should be immediately sent to the virology institute at Alappuzha.

The health minister also visited the Attukal Devi temple on Sunday and reviewed the arrangements made by the district health administration. She said all precautionary measures have been taken and the people too will have to cooperate to prevent any contingency.

Title: Stinking reality: Mounds of garbage greet students of school in Old City
Content:
Students walk through a garbage-strewn lane outside their school in Kabutar Khana area in Old Hyderabad.

CHARMINAR: While textbooks teach students the importance of hygiene and health, this school in Old City is struggling to keep its surroundings clean, thanks to the mounds of uncleared garbage near its entrance. Apart from being an eyesore and causing a stench, the sight of animals feasting on the scattered garbage greets students of the school in Kabutar Khana , Hussaini Alam , regularly.

Local residents and officials of the school said that the garbage is posing serious health risks. They are worried that the locality will soon turn into a haven for mosquitoes.

School authorities said that repeated pleas to the civic authorities to clear the waste have fallen on deaf ears. “We have complained many times to the GHMC authorities, asking them to clear the garbage from outside the school building, but nothing has been done so far. Though the school is clean, as soon as the students step out, the sight of garbage strewn all over greets them,” said Monika Verma, administrator of Sri Maheshwari Vidyalaya , Kabutar Khana.

One of the students said that due to the unpleasant smell wafting from the garbage strewn all over, parents have become apprehensive of sending their wards to the school.

“We want the authorities to do something and clear the garbage. It’s a potential health hazard. Also, due to the stench, we can’t have our lunch properly,” said another student of the same school.

Apart from cleaning the garbage, residents have also requested the government and GHMC officials to ensure regular fogging in Old City areas to keep mosquitoes away.

Title: Mass copying: Two sacked, retired teacher may lose pension
Content:
Representative image

AURANGABAD: Two teachers were terminated from service and a third could lose pension benefits after they were found to have played a role in a mass copying incident during the SSC examination last year.

The termination notices were issued by the Saraswati Bhuvan Education Society (SBES) here, which also recommended the withholding of pension of one retired teacher, Bapu Kothawade.

The mass copying incident took place on March 11, 2019, at a school run by the SBES in the Gondegaon village of Soygaon taluka , in Aurangabad district . The students were writing the mathematics paper.

The incident had sent shockwaves through the academic circles in the region. As many as 321 students were found guilty of malpractice by the Maharashtra State Board of Secondary and Higher Secondary Education, which also barred them from appearing for three exams until March 2020.

Two teachers — Pradeep Mahalpure and Sandip Mahalpure — have been terminated from services, the SBES said in a press release. The Society has also written to the government recommending the withholding of Kothawade’s pension. An inquiry into the incident alleged that Kothawade, who was appointed as supervisor, had abetted the copying.

“The MSBSHSE and the education department had asked for stern action against the guilty teachers for their involvement in the mass copying incident, following which, an internal inquiry was conducted. The probe found the three teachers guilty and necessary action has been taken against them. The incident not only caused academic loss to students but also dented the reputation of the organisation,” the SBES said.

Besides the three teachers, all staffers of the Gondegaon school will not receive their annual increment.

The ban on the 321 students had sparked protests from a section of parents who claimed that varying scores in the mathematics paper I showed that mass copying hadn’t occurred.

All the students were summoned for a probe by the MSBSHSE in batches of 100 on June 14, 15 and 17 last year. During the inquiry, officials informed the students about their marks even as their SSC results were on hold.

A section of parents demanded photocopies of the mathematics answer sheet as proof to substantiate their claims of disparity in the marks secured by students. But the MSBSHE rejected the request.

The parents also did not carry out their threat of legal action against the MSBSHE. The SBES too refused to support those who denied the incident of mass copying.

Title: Delhi-NCR: Greener Holika dahan with cow dung
Content: NEW DELHI: Holika dahan will cause less pollution in certain areas this year. All credit goes to a students’ group from IIT-Delhi. To check the pollution caused by the burning of wooden logs, these IIT students distributed cow dung logs in several housing societies across Delhi-NCR in the past one week.Track the pollution level in your cityMembers of Enactus team claim to have so far distributed 2,500 kg of cow dung logs, which they began developing in 2018 as part of their project— Arth.“Since 2018, we have distributed 10,000 kg of cow dung logs to crematoriums in the city. Wooden logs are highly used at crematoriums where up to 400 kg of wood is used in a single cremation. We were exploring other possible uses of this eco-friendly alternative when the idea to target Holika dahan struck us,” said Ritika Chaplot.According to the IIT-Delhi student, they distributed the logs at a nominal rate at 14 societies across Delhi-NCR. The students visited areas like Vasant Kunj, Mayur Vihar, Faridabad, Ghaziabad and Noida. “Often in large societies, the festival is celebrated collectively. A huge quantity of wooden logs is required for that. We were able to convince the residents about the usefulness of cow dung logs,” said Chaplot.Priyansh Agrawal, a first-year student at IIT-Delhi, added: “The idea is to preserve Indian traditions and look at eco-friendly alternatives to check pollution.”Cow dung is procured from about 20 gaushalas in Delhi-NCR and then dried using a machine. It is then put into another machine which produces logs.Each drying machine can process up to 500 kg of cow dung at once.The students claim that burning of cow dung logs emits less pollutants in the air compared with wooden logs.YK Saxena, a CPCB scientist who is leading a similar initiative in Bhopal, said air pollution can be tackled by developing more eco-friendly alternatives. “The problem of pollution already exists in and around Delhi-NCR, and with our initiative, we aim to solve the dual purpose of checking pollution as well as better cow dung waste management. Burning cow dung logs produces more ash than the traditional wooden logs, thus reducing the amount of emissions released,” Saxena added.

A huge quantity of wooden logs is required for that. We were able to convince the residents about the usefulness of cow dung logs,” said Chaplot.Priyansh Agrawal, a first-year student at IIT-Delhi, added: “The idea is to preserve Indian traditions and look at eco-friendly alternatives to check pollution.”Cow dung is procured from about 20 gaushalas in Delhi-NCR and then dried using a machine. It is then put into another machine which produces logs.Each drying machine can process up to 500 kg of cow dung at once.The students claim that burning of cow dung logs emits less pollutants in the air compared with wooden logs.YK Saxena, a CPCB scientist who is leading a similar initiative in Bhopal, said air pollution can be tackled by developing more eco-friendly alternatives. “The problem of pollution already exists in and around Delhi-NCR, and with our initiative, we aim to solve the dual purpose of checking pollution as well as better cow dung waste management. Burning cow dung logs produces more ash than the traditional wooden logs, thus reducing the amount of emissions released,” Saxena added.

Title: Kerala Coronavirus News: Efforts on to trace passengers of Doha-Kochi flight QR 514
Content: KOCHI: With three passengers from Italy, who arrived in Kochi from Doha on February 29 by Qatar Airways flight QR 514, having tested positive for Covid-19 , the health department and Cochin International Airport Ltd have started tracing the 179 fellow passengers.An urgent meeting, convened by district collector S Suhas, was held at the airport on Sunday to review the situation. Passengers, on the same flight, have been advised to call Disha helpline: 0471 2552056, 1056 (toll free).The meeting decided to trace all the passengers, their secondary contacts and employees who attended to them in Kochi. “Their names and contact details have been received and we are trying to trace them. All airport employees—immigration, security, baggage, ground handling, cleaning etc—who attended to them on February 29 have been directed to approach medical teams in case they feel feverish.A disinfection drive has also been initiated at the airport premises. Officials are also checking CCTV footage to track the movement and activity of the three passengers inside the airport,” said Suhas.Sub-collector Snehil Kumar; district medical officer Dr N K Kuttappan; port health officer Dr P S Ashraf; airport health officers Dr K P Hamzakoya and Dr Raphel Teddy also attended the meeting.Meanwhile, officials said the three passengers, who tested positive, might have missed the health screening at the airport. Cial started implementing health screening for all international passengers on March 3, following the direction of the Union health ministry.“Till then, it was only for passengers coming from selected countries, such as China, Thailand and other South Asian countries. But officials said that there were inflight announcements and intimation at immigration counters for passengers to report their recent travel to areas affected by Covid-19. However, these three passengers failed to report their travel details,” said a Cial official.From now own, apart from procedures like universal screening, all passengers will have to fill forms about their travel/ contact details. Also, flights arriving from Malaysia, Thailand and Singapore will be given dedicated parking bay and aerobridge (parking bay 19 and 20, aerobridge 1 and 2). The passengers arriving from Malaysia, Thailand and Singapore will be given dedicated health screen counters, immigration counters, hand-baggage screening, x-ray, baggage conveyor belts.After the last passenger arrival of these flights, disinfection process will be conducted inside the Aero Bridge and later in the arrival areas like health counters, immigration areas, customs clearance, x-ray machines, baggage trolleys, wash rooms, etc.

Title: Coronavirus in Uttar Pradesh: Allahabad HC seeks report on steps to curb threat
Content: PRAYAGRAJ: Hearing a PIL seeking suitable precautionary steps to prevent spread of coronavirus infection in the Allahabad high court premises at Prayagraj and Lucknow, a division bench comprising Chief Justice Govind Mathur and Justice Ramesh Sinha on Sunday directed the state government to file a complete report, including the steps taken by it, by March 17, 2020, the next date of listing.The bench also directed the Registrar General to take all necessary steps immediately in consonance with the policy of state government, including installation of infrared thermal scan device, and the court administration to ensure zero error cleanliness in Prayagraj and Lucknow premises. This public interest litigation filed by advocate Shashank Shree Tripathi requested the court to direct state government to ensure suitable precautionary steps to prevent infection of COVID-19 (Novel Corona Virus) and a direction for instituting a high-level precautionary committee of experts for prevention of COVID-19 spread in high court.The petitioner said a huge number of people visit court premises every day and may include those infected by COVID-19. Some documents on seriousness and fatal effects of the virus had also been annexed with the petition. The counsel for the high court submitted that the Registrar (Protocol) had by a communication dated March 7, 2020 requested the chief medical 0officer, Prayagraj to take precautionary measures to check spread of COVID-19. In response, the CMO conveyed that a team has already inspected the high court premises and more teams have been set up for rapid response to COVID-19 spread, if any.The court observed, “The state government has issued certain advisories and has also taken certain steps to check COVID-19.”

Title: women celebrate women’s struggle
Content:
Panaji: The issue of chairpersons not being appointed to the Goa state police complaints authority as well as the commission for women were raised during the celebration of ‘Citizens Rights are Women’s Rights’ on Sunday.

Highlighting the “struggle of women”, the women’s collective Bailancho Saad stated that these systems meant to help women have collapsed.

“Instead of addressing complaints women have had counter complaints filed against them. This has been the greatest challenge to women today,” Martins said.

A rape survivor narrated her struggle with a false case filed against her by police and the government’s denying her compensation under the victim compensation scheme for want of funds.

“I was not provided legal aid when I was arrested and I was kept in the lock up for four days due to which I lost my job. My medical records were hidden from me and were not produced in the chargesheet. I have also been told that there are no funds available for women under the women’s compensation scheme,” she said.

To ensure the safety of women, Martins highlighted the importance and necessity of electrification. “Kadamba bus stand, the GMC parking area are not electrified. Electrification is important,” she said.

The women’s collective also took a stand against CAA- NPR-NRC stating that women are already struggling with documentation. “Many women who apply for the senior citizens scheme don’t have birth certificates. When women are put out of the house and want to set up a home they don’t get a gas connection, they don’t have a ration cart, the electricity connection is not in her name. Although women in Goa have equal property rights, men are the administrators and women don’t get their share,” she said.

“There are several issues that have come in this struggle we are very apprehensive of this NPR and NRC which will come. Women now itself have problems with documents so you can imagine if this comes true, women will be further marginalised. There will be more human rights violations if there are detention centres so we demand that the CAA- NPR- NRC should not be implemented,” Martins said.

Title: No commercial activities on school premises, rules HC
Content:
Prayagraj: The Allahabad high court has directed the district magistrates of all the districts in state to ensure that no commercial activities of any kind, like running coaching centres, shops or holding weddings, are organized on the property of recognized and government-aided schools.

Hearing a petition filed by one Deependra Vikram Singh of Jaunpur, Justice Ashok Kumar said, “No marriage function or commercial activities can be organized on the land and building of schools/colleges/institutions.”

While directing to list the petition on March 3, 2020, the court directed that a copy of this order be provided to Uttar Pradesh chief secretary and principal secretary (education) by the state counsel within three days for compliance and appropriate actions.

The court further directed the chief secretary and principal secretary (education) to issue appropriate orders within two weeks and ensure true compliance of the government order dated September 29, 2012, which prohibits any commercial activities on the land and building of recognized and government aided institutions.

In addition, the court also directed all DMs to call for the explanations from institutions and to direct them to furnish details as to how and when they permitted commercial activities in their institutions, particularly the use of playground, which is exclusively meant for the students of the institutions for sports activities.

The petitioner, a member of a society, which looks after the affairs of educational institutions alleged in the petition that the management of Tilakdhari Inter College and Tilakdhari Post Graduate Degree College of Jaunpur district is allowing non-educational activities, like permitting private persons to use the property of institutions to run shops, use the playground of institutions for purpose of marriage functions/ ceremonies and other commercial activities.

He said that since both institutions are government aided, therefore, in permitting other events than educational and sports activities, the management of the aforesaid institutions is not only collecting money but clearly disobeying the September 29, 2012 GO and also prohibiting the students of institutions to use the playground for playing/ sports activities.

Title: 75-year-old killed in Patna over land dispute
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

PATNA: Armed criminals shot dead a retired postal department employee near his residence on Veer Kunwar Singh Path in north S K Puri of Patna on Sunday morning.

The 75-year-old Sakaldeo Rai was about to enter his home after purchasing vegetables when two criminals on a white sports bike pumped three bullets into his chest around 10.40am and escaped through the narrow lane leading to Boring Road, an eyewitness said.

A dispute over 32 katthas of land at Chandmari village under Shahpur police station in western Patna is stated to be the reason behind the murder. “The person riding pillion tapped Rai’s left shoulder. When he turned towards them, he fired at Rai, who fell down. His elder son Manish was also standing in one corner of the house. He rushed towards Rai but he died on the spot,” the eyewitness said. He further said that the one driving the bike was wearing a helmet while the killer had not hidden his face.

Incharge City SP (central) D Amarkesh said Rai’s son Manish identified one of the accused from CCTV footage as Suraj, the son of Devendra. Manish runs a restaurant on the ground floor of the three-storey building owned by the deceased. Rai’s younger son Manoj is a software engineer and lives in New York.

When contacted, Shahpur police station SHO Dheeraj Kumar said a scuffle had taken place over land dispute between Devendra and one Mahendra Rai on January 3, 2018. “FIRs were lodged from both sides. Devendra and Mahendra’s son Rahul Rai had been sent to jail in that case,” he said, adding Mahendra was from Sakaldeo’s side.

“The land dispute between Sakaldeo and Devendra is very old, but no related case is lodged with the police. Several panchayat meetings had taken place on the issue,” he said.

A person close to Sakaldeo’s son told TOI that Manish had once gone to Beur jail to meet Rahul but incidentally Suraj was also there to meet his father. “Suraj had tried to thrash Manish by grabbing his collar,” he added.

Rai lived with his wife, son Manish and other family members in the three-storey building. Sakaldeo had retired as a section officer from GPO, Patna.

Title: Payyambalam beach to go plastic-free soon
Content:
Kannur: If everything goes according to plan, the tourist spots in the district would soon become plastic-free, as the district tourism promotion council (DTPC) has initiated steps in this connection.

As the first step, the main tourist attraction in the district headquarters, Payyambalam Beach, would be declared plastic-free and the project would start from April 1.

The project is being launched with the support of the Suchitwa Mission, district administration and Kannur corporation would utilize the CSR fund of Rs 30 lakh.

The plan is to ban all plastic products including the recyclable ones, according to the officials.

Plastic carry bags, nonwoven carry bags, flex boards, plastic banners, plates, cups, spoons and other utensils made of plastic, as also thermocol would be banned, said DTPC secretary Jitheesh Jose.

“We decided to launch the project in Payyambalam on a pilot basis because this is the place where the most number of people visit, and if we are able to successfully implement it here, we would be able to introduce it in other places as well,” he said.

To begin with, the authorities would strengthen the surveillance and there is a proposal to install surveillance cameras to nab those who dump waste there and impose fine, he said.

Outsiders dumping waste in Payyambalam is a major issue. Those who bring plastic products will not be permitted to take it on to the beach, he said.

Green volunteers under Kudumbashree would also be deployed to manage it.Even the hawkers who sell eatables and other products have to make sure that they do not use any plastic products.

Even for ice cream, plastic containers would not be permitted, and the shopkeepers, hawkers and visitors should cooperate with the green mission, said the authorities.

“We are also planning to have facilities to provide alternative products for the visitors coming to Payyambalam so that we can strictly implement the campaign,” he said.

The aim of the DTPC is to make all the tourist destinations plastic-free in the next few months, he added.

Title: Pocso case chargesheet filed in record 24 hours
Content:
Kanpur: Chakeri police on Saturday filed a chargesheet within 24 hours of registering of the FIR against a man for allegedly molesting her six-year-old neighbour.

This was one of the most expedited chargesheets filed in a Protection of Children from Sexual Offences ( Pocso ) Act cases in the region in recent times, said inspector Ram Kumar Gupta.

He said the FIR was registered against the accused Dilawar on Friday on the basis of the complaint filed by the minor’s parents.

The police arrested the accused on Saturday and quickly prepared the chargesheet.

"We submitted the chargesheet in the case today. We will request the court for fast trial in the case,” Gupta told TOI.

Title: Illegal mining site raided, 11 vehicles seized
Content:
Representative image

KOLHAPUR: A flying squad of the revenue department raided an illegal stone crushing unit operating under the buffer zone of the Sahyadri Tiger Reserve and seized eleven vehicles including nine dumpers and two excavators on Saturday.

The Shahuwadi police station has registered an offence against the nine suspects for illegally mining in the said area. “The repair work of the road connecting Ukhalu and Ambaiwada fall in the buffer zone. We got information that a stone crusher has been set up in the nearby area where road repair work is being done and the work of illegal mining and crushing of a stone is being done. After confirming the information we sent a flying squad that attacked the spot on Saturday. As soon as the people working at the spot found that we have raided, they ran away from the spot. We seized the 11 vehicles from the area,” said Guru Birajdar, Tehsildar, Shahuwadi taluka.

According to the officials, the suspect has started a stone crusher unit with an aim to provide the raw material for the construction of the road on Ukhalu-Ambaiwada road. The revenue officials conducted panchnama of the spot and found that the stones worth Rs 10 lakh were mined and crushed from the spot.

A case has been registered against the nine suspects with Shahuwadi police station under relevant sections of IPC including section 379 and section 4, 21(1,2) of Mining and Mineral Development and Regulation Act, 1957. Police have launched the search operation for the suspect.

Title: Goa: Nearly 7,000 polling staff to cast postal ballots
Content: PANAJI: Around 7,000 individuals who have been selected for election duty and will not be able to vote on the polling day will cast their votes through postal ballots, while undergoing training for zilla panchayat elections , the state election commission (SEC) said.Polling staff, including Goa police personnel, will have to apply to the returning officer for postal ballots at least four days before the polling date through Form 18, the SEC said.“The facilitation of casting the vote through ballot paper will be done during the second training session. A ballot box shall be kept at the training location and employees who have been issued a postal ballot paper will be told that they can deposit the ballot paper in the ballot box after marking them,” SEC commissioner R K Srivastava said.The returning officer should supply Form 18 to all election duty staff during the first training session. Accordingly, the returning officer will provide the postal ballot papers during the second training under an acknowledgement.The SEC has appointed 15 returning officers (RO) to oversee the polling process, which will take place at 1,237 polling booths — 641 in North Goa and 596 in South Goa — for the ZP elections.“The superintendent of police shall depute a nodal officer at RO level to collect the application in Form 18 from the police officers engaged for the election duty and submit to the RO at least four days before the poll date,” Srivastava said.Elections for all the 50 zilla panchayat constituencies in Goa will be held on March 22 and the counting will take place on the next day. Ballot papers will be used in the elections which will be held on party lines.

Title: Pune police to auction 373 unclaimed vehicles after 60 days
Content:
Representative image

KOLHAPUR: The city police department has decided to auction 373 unclaimed vehicles that are piled up across various police stations in the city.

They had set a deadline of 60 days for owners to claim their vehicles stating that the unclaimed vehicles will thereafter be auctioned.

The city police department has issued a notice through local newspapers mentioning the details about the vehicles, registration number, chassis number as well as the engine number so that the owners can come forward and claim their vehicles.

“These vehicles have been lying at police stations since several years now. They were seized by the police department from time to time, including those seized during road accidents. Some vehicles are in good condition and some are in a bad shape. All these vehicles have been kept at the dumping yard in Shiroli MIDC police station,” said a senior police officer.

“The vehicles include the ones that were stolen and abandoned by culprits. In many cases, the owners might have claimed insurance of the vehicles and may not be interested in claiming the vehicles. In some cases, we tried to reach out to the owners but either they have shifted to new places or have simply refused to claim the vehicles,” he said.

Police said that they have appealed to the vehicle owners to come forward and claim their vehicles and take them home after completing procedure as per rules. “We will wait for 60 days from today as we have issued notice through the newspapers and if no one claims these vehicles, we will initiate the process of auctioning them as per section 85 of Maharashtra Police Act. The vehicle owners can visit the Shiroli dumping yard located in Shiroli police station premises during this 60-day period and claim their vehicles,” he said.

Of the 373 vehicles at the yard, 166 are from Karvir police station, followed by Juna Rajwada (73), Shahupuri (70), Laxmipuri (28), Rajarampuri (18), Shiroli MIDC (11) and Local Crime Branch Ichalkaranji (7).

Title: Hyderabad: Patrol car finds pregnant woman on road, shifts her to hospital
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

HYDERABAD: A woman gave birth to a baby girl after a police patrol vehicle spotted her lying on the road in Saidabad and shifted her to a hospital in the wee hours of Sunday.

Urmila, a resident of Gandhinagar in Asmanghad, is a widow and lives with her three-year-old son. Her husband died a few months ago due to ill health. “She was walking towards the hospital where she was being treated along with her son at around 3am when suddenly her labour pains began. Unable to bear it, Urmila sat on the footpath,” said Saidabad inspector K Srinivas.

The patrol car was was passing by when the cops noticed the woman and stopped the vehicle. “The constables Mahesh and Nayeemuddin immediately took her to Red Cross hospital,” Srinivas added.

Title: Delhi Air Pollution: After three ‘satisfactory’ days, air quality dips in Delhi
Content:
While the capital was aided by a spell of incessant rain and strong winds, experts said its withdrawal and a d... Read More

NEW DELHI: After recording three straight days of ‘satisfactory’ air quality — Delhi’s cleanest air spell since September — the overall Air Quality Index (AQI) fell to the ‘moderate’ range on Sunday with a reading of 164 on CPCB’s daily bulletin. In comparison, the AQI was below 80 on Thursday, Friday and Saturday — falling to as low as 64 on Friday.

Track the pollution level in your city

While the capital was aided by a spell of incessant rain and strong winds, experts said its withdrawal and a drop in wind speed had led to a slight deterioration in air quality. The IMD has meanwhile forecast another spell of rain to hit Delhi on the night of March 10, as well as March 11 and 12.

System of Air Quality and Weather Forecasting And Research (SAFAR) forecasts air quality to remain in the ‘moderate’ range in the next 48 hours before another spell of rain hits Delhi on March 11 and 12, which could once again lead to an improvement in air quality.

“AQI is likely to marginally improve and stay in the lower end of moderate category on March 10 and 11,” said SAFAR.

Kuldeep Srivastava, scientist at India Meteorological Department (IMD), said a fresh western disturbance will influence parts of north Rajasthan, Haryana and western Uttar Pradesh on March 10-11, bringing a spell of light rain on the night of Holi (March 10), as well as on March 11. A light drizzle could also be recorded in the morning on March 12. “The major impact of the western disturbance will be on March 11, with strong gusty winds of 35-40 km/hour also blowing. This will once again lead to an improvement in air quality and bring down the mercury,” said Srivastava.

Meanwhile, the maximum temperature on Sunday was recorded at 24.8 degrees Celsius — four notches below normal. The minimum temperature was also recorded three notches below the normal mark, at 11.1 degrees Celsius.

Met officials forecast a rise in mercury in the next 48 hours, with the maximum likely to touch 27 degrees Celsius by Monday and 28 degrees Celsius by Tuesday. “There will be a drop in the maximum temperature from Wednesday after rain. It will remain below the normal mark on Thursday too,” said a Met official.

Title: T Harish Rao: Use purchasing power to beat recession
Content:
Telangana finance minister T Harish Rao

HYDERABAD: Despite an overall economic slowdown in the country, the state government has prioritised welfare schemes and has even enhanced allocations towards such schemes, finance minister T Harish Rao said. “The government believes that the antidote to recession is to enhance people’s purchasing power and spending resources on capital expenditure,” he told media after budget presentation.

The minister said that the Kalyana Laxmi scheme is likely to see another 70,000 beneficiaries following the increase in allocation from Rs 1,540 crore to Rs 2,240 crore. The allocation for Asara pension scheme was also raised from Rs 9,402 crore to Rs 11,750 crore. Harish Rao state that a few innovative schemes were also proposed in the budget.

“Since Godavari is alive for about 150km throughout the year, it was decided to develop a tourism circuit under the Godavari Tourism Circuit Project by allocating Rs 300 crore. The government would finalise the modalities on this,” he said and added that under Mission Bhagiratha, 38 municipalities were not covered as contractors did not come forward or withdrew from the project. To settle this, he said, another Rs 800 crore was allocated towards the scheme.

Title: Equal for Equal
Content:
Men themselves have wondered what they see in me

They try so much but can’t touch my inner mystery

-- Maya Angelou | American poet

Bengaluru: Last week, Kannada writer Vijaya, popularly known as Vijayamma, received the Central Sahitya Akademi Award for her autobiography ‘Kudi Esaru.’ The award for the 78-year-old writer - who also happens to be a journalist, an activist, an academician, a publisher and a film critic - is a long overdue salute to the never-say-die spirit of all those women who live inspiring lives, fighting adversity, challenging stereotypes, questioning gender bias and refusing to be bogged down by hegemonic masculinity that conspires to silence their voice at every step. The prestigious award is also a recognition for women’s autobiographical writing in Kannada, which has emerged as a powerful form of feminist literature in recent years.

“It is not easy to document memories. It is a painful process,” writes Vijaya in the opening pages of her autobiography. The intensity of her pain and suffering shakes readers to the core. Utter poverty in childhood, domestic violence, sexual torture at the hands of the man she was married to and a series of forced abortions leave such an unsettling feeling among readers that one would wonder how anyone could even survive after going through such a trauma. But Vijaya not just survives, she thrives. Through sheer grit and determination she rises like a phoenix from the ashes and soars high into the sky, turning her story of misery into one of success and glory.

Initially reluctant to pen her autobiography, Vijayamma says she finally yielded to plenty of persuasion by her sons, friends and relatives. And as she sat down to write, a plethora of questions pervaded her mind: “After all, why should I write? Whom would it benefit? Aren’t there other women who have bigger achievements to their credit than me and who have undergone worse sufferings? Or am I scared to put my private experiences in public domain? Scared of whom?”

Such questions have indeed been the historical reasons for the delay in the process of women’s autobiographical works taking shape as a full-fledged genre in world literature. Critics observe that even in the western world, while powerful men of the 18th century like Benjamin Franklin wrote their autobiographies glorifying themselves as role models, any significant attempts by women achievers to document their life began only in 1960s, albeit with hesitance, modesty and self- effacement.

In her critical essay published in the book ‘Iruvanthige’ (ed. Savitha Nagabhushan, Tarini Shubhadayini) Geeta Vasanth, assistant professor at Tumkur University, points out that Kannada literary world had to wait till late 1970s for women’s autobiographies to emerge. Initially their numbers were few and far as compared to Marathi but swelled significantly in the 21st century. Guru Dutt’s mother Vasanthi Padukone’s ‘Jeevana Horata,’ written in 1977, is probably the first ever autobiography by a woman in Kannada. Then came the autobiography of Parvatamma Mahalingashetti (daughter of former chief minister Nijalingappa), which made a commendable effort to record the domestic, social and economic condition of women in the 20th century.

In 2008, writer Vaidehi chronicled some memoirs of Saraswatibai Rajwade, a 20th century child actor and writer from Dakshina Kannada. A childhood spent in penury, Saraswati’s marriage at the age of 15 to the deputy collector of Thanjavur did bring her riches but confined her to home. Her insecure husband, a widower 37 years older than her, would lock her up while he left for work, hanging a ‘Not at Home’ board outside. When his suspicious nature crossed all limits of decency, a disgusted Saraswati yanked the mangalasutra from her neck and flung it on his face. In her pain and loneliness, she took to books and also began to write and became an accomplished writer under the pen name ‘Giribaale.’

Work-life balance

As women became more educated and started pursuing their chosen professions, striking a work-life balance threw new challenges. In her life story written in the format of a novel, Shashikala Vastrad exposes man’s fragile ego which gets bruised for the simple fact that his wife is working, talented and has an independent personality. His manhood finds its fulfilment in clipping her wings. And even when the spouse is understanding and supportive, woman finds it difficult to focus on her career because childcare and household chores are considered her ‘department,’ and claim most of her time. In fact, marriage itself is like a speed-breaker in a woman’s life. The joy of motherhood often comes at the cost of career. Missed opportunities remain a source of regret. The autobiographies of physician-writer Anupama Niranjan and theatre personality Bhargavi Narayan effectively bring these issues to fore.

When personal is political

“Behind every successful man there is a woman, and behind every successful woman there is a dissatisfied man,” so reads a line from a poem by Prathibha Nandakumar. With her daring and ultra-modern poems like ‘Naavu Hudigiyare Heege’(This Is How We Girls Are, 1977) Prathibha created a stir four decades ago and when she published her autobiography ‘Anudinada Antaragange’ in 2012 she gave a new twist and turn to women’s writing in Kannada. In what was a reminder of the response to Malayalam writer Kamala Das’s ‘My Story,’ Prathibha’s bold and riveting account evoked severe reactions of admiration and criticism as she upheld her personal self and candidly wrote about her sensuality, passions, trials of marriage, indulgent relationships, eternal search for love and self-awakening.

“In case of men, relationships outside marriage are looked at as an extension of their experience, whereas the same is considered a crime in case of women,” observes Geeta Vasanth. Taking on the patriarchal ideologies that tend to decide how a woman should walk, talk and live, theatre personality, actor and former minister Umashri, a born fighter, lets out her anguish in her memoirs ‘Benki-Bedagu’: “I damn this heartless society which is always on its toes to cast aspersions on a woman’s character instead of valuing her struggle and hard work.”

These empowering stories of women from different walks of life are also excellent social commentaries of their times, documenting a wide range of issues like poverty, women’s education, literary and cultural movements, theatre, cinema, healthcare, political ideologies, growth of media, trade unions, religious practices and traditions and so on. Fighting male dominance that ranges from passive aggressiveness to tyranny, these women of substance derive their strength from within and celebrate life, being a source of inspiration to many. Their stories do not remain their stories alone. The individual becomes collective and the personal becomes political. For instance, when theatre personality and former Rajya Sabha MP B Jayashri recalls in her autobiography the horror of her step-father attempting to sexually abuse her in her adolescent days, or when she regrets the fact that nobody in her family ever bothered to get her admitted to a formal school, she speaks not just about herself. Her powerful voice represents the plight of lakhs of voiceless girls in the country and calls for political attention and legal address.

And for those men who criticize that kitchen, children and household chores still occupy much space in women’s autobiographies, here’s a quote by Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg: “A truly equal world would be one where women ran half our countries and companies and men half our homes.” The campaign theme of International Women’s Day - 2020 is ‘Each for Equal.’ Collectively each one can help create a gender equal world. So, are we game?

EMPOWERING VOICES

Should I call my life’s journey ‘A saga of a deserted woman?’ No. I don’t like the words ‘deserted’ and ‘abandoned.’ I leave it to the readers to decide what it is – Vijaya

No doubt women are now economically independent and have achieved social standing. Yet, a conflict still goes on in their minds between ‘them and society’ – B Jayashri

If something is being denied to you simply because you are a woman, then it needs to be protested – Prathibha Nandakumar

AN INSPIRING JOURNEY

Born in 1942, Vijaya lost her mother early in life and grew up amidst pangs of poverty. She got married at a young age while pursuing her matriculation. Sexual, emotional and physical abuse turned her married life into hell. But she did not succumb. She rose from the mire, took life head on, raised her two sons as a single parent, continued her college education after divorce, completed her postgraduation and PhD in Kannada literature, and rose to fame as a fiction and non-fiction writer and film critic. She set up her own printing press and encouraged budding writers. She introduced several talents to Kannada film industry. As an activist she brought hopes in the lives of women garment workers and pourakarmikas. Many accolades came her way including the State and Central Sahitya Akademi Awards and the Rajyotsava Award. ‘Kudi Esaru,’ (Boiling Curry) is an objective account of her story as a fighter, survivor and achiever.

Title: In 10 yrs, Lamakaan turns into creative hub of Hyd
Content:
Hyderabad: Of all the hurdles that Lamakaan , a first-of-its-kind cultural hub in the city, has overcome in its 10 years of existence, few were as hard as working around the steep rise in onion prices last year.

“Surprised? That’s because Lamakaan runs almost entirely on the back of its kitchen,” says Anant Maringanti, among the 14 curators of the cultural centre on Road No. 1 Banjara Hills which is all set to celebrate its 10th anniversary. It’s a business model anyone who wishes to start such a space can emulate, he suggests.

At the centre’s tiny open kitchen that feeds hundreds a day, the pace is brisk and there’s little time for chit chat. The head chef recalls that in the initial days after the centre opened a decade ago, only a few came to watch the sparse shows and not more than a bowl of samosas was sold. But it wasn’t long before word of the quality of Lamakaan’s shows including dance programmes, music events, debates and talks as also its piping hot chai spread and the centre turned into a bustling creative space.

Over the years, Lamakaan, which in Arabic means a house without boundaries, has hosted 852 plays, 317 art shows, 812 workshops, 507 art performances, 1,050 talks, 30 night school events and 466 movie screenings, most of which were free.

The property originally belonged to M Hassan, a founder-member of the Society to Save Rocks, after whose death his nephew Ashhar Farhan assumed the reins of the space and turned it into a liberal hub for progressive cultural practices along with other co-founders in honour of his uncle. “Lamakaan has, so far, been driven by the people,” Farhan explains, adding that his team is exploring ways to improve it further. With many similar spaces mushrooming across the city, Lamakaan must reinvent itself.

“The change too will be driven by the people,” says Farhan.

Title: Transistor bomb blasts case in Delhi: ‘Our lives are over... can’t make up for years lost’
Content:
A Delhi court has acquitted 30 people in the 1985 transistor bomb blasts, which left 49 people dead and 127 in... Read More

NEW DELHI: After one of the longest trials in the capital’s history ended with the acquittal of 30 of the 59 accused in the 1985 transistor bomb blasts case, three of the freed men said on Sunday that the acquittal could not make up for the years they had lost.

Daljit Singh, now 58, is unable to reconcile to the damage caused to him and his family. It was in May 1985 that he had last felt a free man: it was after he had written his BA final exams in Delhi. “I went to my hometown Chandigarh... I later learnt the police had raided my house in Delhi,” he said.

Daljit said police were under pressure to solve the case. The investigation, he said, was “selective” in leaving out the real culprits. The six months that he was in jail in Delhi and UP would set a long, arduous legal battle in motion. “Neighbours turned hostile...The family sold off the house for pittance to fight my case,” he said.

His parents died in the hope they would see their son being cleared. His relatives boycotted him. Bail came six months after spending jail time. The reprieve gave way to fresh challenges. “During festivals such as Dussehra, my family and I would venture out separately to watch the celebrations,” said Daljit.

After app-based cab aggregators entered the scene, Daljit lost out on his only skill of driving taxi. “As I couldn’t earn, I couldn’t educate my children. Now, I am struggling to marry off my son,” he says.

Gurmeet Singh was 18 years and four days old on the day of his arrest. Now 52, he recalls how his family faced harassment on a regular basis. “Nobody from my family got a passport. It would be either me or my family who would get called at the police station whenever a blast or any similar incident occurred,” he said.

While out on bail in the 90s, Daljit was with his brother on a bike in R K Puram when he was apprehended by police and let off only four days later. “The three decades are nothing short of a nightmare. They called it transistor bomb blasts. It was only 21 years after the incident that the hearing gained some speed. It saw several judges. Although there were 1,100 witnesses, there was not a single eyewitness,” he argues.

Jaspal Singh, now 54, lost out on what he calls the “prime years”. He said: “A lot was lost in the passing years. I lost my job. And when I walked out on bail, there was a serious resentment in my social circle towards me.”

Desperate for help, his family knocked on the doors of some of the privileged. “But they also shut their doors. Life is over despite my acquittal. My parents lost theirs hoping to see their son walk free,” says Jaspal.

Advocate Nitin Rai Sharma, who defended some of the accused, including the main accused Kartar Singh who died during the case’s pendency, and his wife Surjit Kaur, feels justice was delayed and denied to the accused and the society at large. He points out that it was a “shoddy investigation” under a “political witch hunt” for one section. “Many accused were teenagers at the time of their arrests. That Kaur faced trial for 35 years and lost two of her sons and husband speaks volumes of the state’s apathy,” he says.

Title: UP: Scolded by father over ‘gutkha’, girl immolates self
Content:
Representative image

KANPUR: A 24-year-old girl immolated herself on late Saturday night after she was allegedly scolded by her father over her habit of consuming ‘gutkha’.

The incident took place around 10 pm at a house in Shastri Nagar in Kakadeo police station area.

According to police, Arvind, cousin of deceased Manisha , said that his uncle had scolded her for eating ‘gutkha’ while she was preparing food on Saturday night.

According to him, earlier also on several occasions, Manisha’s father had reprimanded her for her excessive gutkha’ consumption habit, the police said.

“On late Saturday night too, her father rebuked her when he caught her red-handed chewing ‘gutkha’ while she was cooking food in the kitchen. Manisha, who was extremely upset, went inside her room with a container of kerosene and after bolting herself set herself on fire,” the police added.

Minutes later, Manisha rushed out engulfed in flames.

“On seeing her aflame, her kin tried to save her and admitted her to the burn unit of Lala Lajpat Rai hospital in a critical condition where she succumbed on Saturday,” said police officials.

Kakadeo police station in-charge, Kaushal Kishore Dikshit , said, “Manisha’s death was a clear case of suicide. Her body has been sent to the mortuary for the post-mortem examination. As per the family members, she took the drastic step on being scolded by her father over her excessive gutkha consumption habit.”

Title: Equal for Equal: Stories women have to tell
Content:
Vijayamma, who was awarded the Kendriya Sahitya Akademi award for her autobiography ‘Kudi Esaru’

Men themselves have wondered what they see in me

They try so much but can’t touch my inner mystery

-- Maya Angelou | American poet

Bengaluru: Last week, Kannada writer Vijaya, popularly known as Vijayamma , received the Central Sahitya Akademi Award for her autobiography ‘Kudi Esaru.’ The award for the 78-year-old writer - who also happens to be a journalist, an activist, an academician, a publisher and a film critic - is a long overdue salute to the never-say-die spirit of all those women who live inspiring lives, fighting adversity, challenging stereotypes, questioning gender bias and refusing to be bogged down by hegemonic masculinity that conspires to silence their voice at every step. The prestigious award is also a recognition for women’s autobiographical writing in Kannada, which has emerged as a powerful form of feminist literature in recent years.

“It is not easy to document memories. It is a painful process,” writes Vijaya in the opening pages of her autobiography. The intensity of her pain and suffering shakes readers to the core. Utter poverty in childhood, domestic violence, sexual torture at the hands of the man she was married to and a series of forced abortions leave such an unsettling feeling among readers that one would wonder how anyone could even survive after going through such a trauma. But Vijaya not just survives, she thrives. Through sheer grit and determination she rises like a phoenix from the ashes and soars high into the sky, turning her story of misery into one of success and glory.

Initially reluctant to pen her autobiography, Vijayamma says she finally yielded to plenty of persuasion by her sons, friends and relatives. And as she sat down to write, a plethora of questions pervaded her mind: “After all, why should I write? Whom would it benefit? Aren’t there other women who have bigger achievements to their credit than me and who have undergone worse sufferings? Or am I scared to put my private experiences in public domain? Scared of whom?”

Such questions have indeed been the historical reasons for the delay in the process of women’s autobiographical works taking shape as a full-fledged genre in world literature. Critics observe that even in the western world, while powerful men of the 18th century like Benjamin Franklin wrote their autobiographies glorifying themselves as role models, any significant attempts by women achievers to document their life began only in 1960s, albeit with hesitance, modesty and self- effacement.

In her critical essay published in the book ‘Iruvanthige’ (ed. Savitha Nagabhushan, Tarini Shubhadayini) Geeta Vasanth, assistant professor at Tumkur University, points out that Kannada literary world had to wait till late 1970s for women’s autobiographies to emerge. Initially their numbers were few and far as compared to Marathi but swelled significantly in the 21st century. Guru Dutt’s mother Vasanthi Padukone’s ‘Jeevana Horata,’ written in 1977, is probably the first ever autobiography by a woman in Kannada. Then came the autobiography of Parvatamma Mahalingashetti (daughter of former chief minister Nijalingappa), which made a commendable effort to record the domestic, social and economic condition of women in the 20th century.

In 2008, writer Vaidehi chronicled some memoirs of Saraswatibai Rajwade, a 20th century child actor and writer from Dakshina Kannada. A childhood spent in penury, Saraswati’s marriage at the age of 15 to the deputy collector of Thanjavur did bring her riches but confined her to home. Her insecure husband, a widower 37 years older than her, would lock her up while he left for work, hanging a ‘Not at Home’ board outside. When his suspicious nature crossed all limits of decency, a disgusted Saraswati yanked the mangalasutra from her neck and flung it on his face. In her pain and loneliness, she took to books and also began to write and became an accomplished writer under the pen name ‘Giribaale.’

Work-life balance

As women became more educated and started pursuing their chosen professions, striking a work-life balance threw new challenges. In her life story written in the format of a novel, Shashikala Vastrad exposes man’s fragile ego which gets bruised for the simple fact that his wife is working, talented and has an independent personality. His manhood finds its fulfilment in clipping her wings. And even when the spouse is understanding and supportive, woman finds it difficult to focus on her career because childcare and household chores are considered her ‘department,’ and claim most of her time. In fact, marriage itself is like a speed-breaker in a woman’s life. The joy of motherhood often comes at the cost of career. Missed opportunities remain a source of regret. The autobiographies of physician-writer Anupama Niranjan and theatre personality Bhargavi Narayan effectively bring these issues to fore.

When personal is political

“Behind every successful man there is a woman, and behind every successful woman there is a dissatisfied man,” so reads a line from a poem by Prathibha Nandakumar . With her daring and ultra-modern poems like ‘Naavu Hudigiyare Heege’(This Is How We Girls Are, 1977) Prathibha created a stir four decades ago and when she published her autobiography ‘Anudinada Antaragange’ in 2012 she gave a new twist and turn to women’s writing in Kannada. In what was a reminder of the response to Malayalam writer Kamala Das’s ‘My Story,’ Prathibha’s bold and riveting account evoked severe reactions of admiration and criticism as she upheld her personal self and candidly wrote about her sensuality, passions, trials of marriage, indulgent relationships, eternal search for love and self-awakening.

“In case of men, relationships outside marriage are looked at as an extension of their experience, whereas the same is considered a crime in case of women,” observes Geeta Vasanth. Taking on the patriarchal ideologies that tend to decide how a woman should walk, talk and live, theatre personality, actor and former minister Umashri, a born fighter, lets out her anguish in her memoirs ‘Benki-Bedagu’: “I damn this heartless society which is always on its toes to cast aspersions on a woman’s character instead of valuing her struggle and hard work.”

These empowering stories of women from different walks of life are also excellent social commentaries of their times, documenting a wide range of issues like poverty, women’s education, literary and cultural movements, theatre, cinema, healthcare, political ideologies, growth of media, trade unions, religious practices and traditions and so on. Fighting male dominance that ranges from passive aggressiveness to tyranny, these women of substance derive their strength from within and celebrate life, being a source of inspiration to many. Their stories do not remain their stories alone. The individual becomes collective and the personal becomes political. For instance, when theatre personality and former Rajya Sabha MP B Jayashri recalls in her autobiography the horror of her step-father attempting to sexually abuse her in her adolescent days, or when she regrets the fact that nobody in her family ever bothered to get her admitted to a formal school, she speaks not just about herself. Her powerful voice represents the plight of lakhs of voiceless girls in the country and calls for political attention and legal address.

And for those men who criticize that kitchen, children and household chores still occupy much space in women’s autobiographies, here’s a quote by Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg: “A truly equal world would be one where women ran half our countries and companies and men half our homes.” The campaign theme of International Women’s Day - 2020 is ‘Each for Equal.’ Collectively each one can help create a gender equal world. So, are we game?

EMPOWERING VOICES

Should I call my life’s journey ‘A saga of a deserted woman?’ No. I don’t like the words ‘deserted’ and ‘abandoned.’ I leave it to the readers to decide what it is – Vijaya

No doubt women are now economically independent and have achieved social standing. Yet, a conflict still goes on in their minds between ‘them and society’ – B Jayashri

If something is being denied to you simply because you are a woman, then it needs to be protested – Prathibha Nandakumar

AN INSPIRING JOURNEY

Born in 1942, Vijaya lost her mother early in life and grew up amidst pangs of poverty. She got married at a young age while pursuing her matriculation. Sexual, emotional and physical abuse turned her married life into hell. But she did not succumb. She rose from the mire, took life head on, raised her two sons as a single parent, continued her college education after divorce, completed her postgraduation and PhD in Kannada literature, and rose to fame as a fiction and non-fiction writer and film critic. She set up her own printing press and encouraged budding writers. She introduced several talents to Kannada film industry. As an activist she brought hopes in the lives of women garment workers and pourakarmikas. Many accolades came her way including the State and Central Sahitya Akademi Awards and the Rajyotsava Award. ‘Kudi Esaru,’ (Boiling Curry) is an objective account of her story as a fighter, survivor and achiever.

Title: Coronavirus in Hyderabad: 35k international passengers screened at RGIA since Feb 18
Content: HYDERABAD: The Airport Health Organisation (AHO) has screened 35,654 international passengers for coronavirus (Covid-19) since February 18 at the Rajiv Gandhi International Airport and referred seven suspected cases to Gandhi Hospital.“We began screening passengers from 12 affected countries on February 18 and on March 3 we started universal screening of all international passengers,” AHO regional director Dr Anuradha Medoju told TOI.“At Visakhapatnam Airport , the state health department is currently screening passengers as we do not have a team there. However, we are sharing all information regarding the standard operating procedures with the AP health department,” Dr Anuradha added.She pointed out that no screening has been taken up at Vijayawada and Tirupati airports as there are no flights operating to the affected countries.“Around 5,000-6,000 passengers are screened daily. Contacts of all suspected passengers have been kept under observation by the state health department,” Dr Anuradha said.“We are on alert as new cases have been reported in Kerala. However, there are no new positive cases in Telangana,” director of state public health G Srinivasa Rao told TOI.

Title: TDP comes up with 10-point campaign for local body polls
Content:
TDP chief N Chandrababu Naidu

AMARAVATI: TDP is gearing up its cadres for local body elections.

TDP senior leader and politburo member Yanamala Ramakrishnudu appealed to people to defeat YSRC for ditching backward classes by downsizing reservations. He said the BCs lost nearly 16,000 posts in local bodies due to the reduction in the BC quota to 24% from the previous 34 percent.

TDP has launched a campaign highlighting 10 issues and urging people to think for one minute before they vote.

TDP alleged that YSRC let down people with its decision on Amaravati and charged the government was imposing J-tax on liquor sales.

TDP also highlighted the removal of Ramzan tofa , Sankranti Kanuka and Christmas kanuka offered during its government.

The opposition alleged that closure of Anna Canteens was an anti-poor decision.

Title: NMC declares all 22 rooftop restaurants fire-unsafe
Content:
Nagpur: Over 26 months after the infamous Kamala Mills fire incident which claimed 14 lives and injured several in Mumbai on December 29, 2017, the Nagpur Municipal Corporation’s (NMC) fire and emergency services department has declared 22 rooftop restaurants in the city as fire-unsafe.

It is for the first time in the civic body’s history that rooftop restaurants have been declared unsafe.

Following action from fire department under Maharashtra Fire Prevention and Life Safety Measures Act, 2006, the state’s urban development department (UDD) has stressed the need for the NMC to also inspect these rooftop restaurants for violation of building bylaws under Maharashtra Regional and Town Planning (MRTP) Act and submit report.

Municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe, on March 6, reportedly directed officials of town planning, enforcement departments and zone offices to conduct inspection and initiate action under MRTP Act immediately. Mundhe also slammed officials of these departments for neglecting action for so long.

The fire department has also written a letter to town planning department suggesting action under MRTP Act.

During the ongoing budget session, MLC Jogendra Kawade has submitted a starred question following which the UDD sought information from the NMC. After getting the civic body’s reply that fire department has taken action against 22 rooftop restaurants in the city, the UDD has on March 6 questioned the NMC’s inaction and directed it to submit action taken report for building bylaws violations.

NMC’s fire department officials told TOI that rooftop restaurants were declared unsafe in a phased manner in the last one month. “We have not declared entire buildings unsafe, except rooftop restaurants. Action on remaining part of the buildings will be decided after inspection to assess whether building bylaws have been flouted. We will ask for disconnection of power and water supply if these rooftop restaurants continue to operate. We will send the cases to police department for registering an offence and may also seal the establishments later,” said the officials.

Unofficial sources put the number of unauthorized restaurants on terrace of commercial buildings at around 50, but as per fire department there are only 22 restaurants and action has been initiated against all of them.

Following ongoing PIL in the Nagpur bench of Bombay high court, the fire department is completing all formalities of action.

The officials said, “We have demolished structures of four rooftop restaurants after serving notices in the past. We will continue inspections at rooftop restaurants which have not been covered under the drive as of now.”

Despite blatant violations, the town planning, enforcement departments and zone offices have ignored the misuse of terrace of the buildings. As per rules, any such use of terrace is not allowed and the violation attracts stringent action under MRTP Act.

Officials added that the number of buildings declared unsafe has gone up to over 1,510. “Police department has not registered offence in over 120 cases sent to it in the last one year. We are inspecting all buildings again and again and taking action in case of non-compliance of our notices,” they said.

The NMC fire, town planning, enforcement departments and zone offices are also ignoring residential bungalows being converted into restaurants and lounges in various parts of the city. These restaurants and lounges pose serious threat to life and also cause traffic congestion in residential areas.

IAN

*NMC fire department started inspection of commercial buildings and action in a few cases

* Many restaurants are being operated on terraces of hotels and commercial buildings across the city

* Rules prohibit such use of rooftops

* NMC fire, town planning, enforcement departments and zone offices turned blind eye

*After inspections, fire department found 22 rooftop restaurants in city

*Department declared all 22 restaurants unsafe for fire

* These are situated on Wardha Road, Amravati Road, Sitabuldi, Manish Nagar, Koradi Road, Sadar, Ramdaspeth, Dharampeth, Dhantoli, Takli Sim, Abhyankar Nagar,

*UDD directed NMC to also conduct inspection for building violations

* Civic chief ordered immediate inspection and action

*All rooftop restaurants continue to operate

* NMC also turning blind eye towards residential bungalows being used as restaurants and lounges

Title: Visakhapatnam homes now turn ‘smart’ with Internet-linked devices
Content:
Architects and civil engineers are of the opinion that the trend of using IoT is here to stay.

VISAKHAPATNAM: It was ‘ Aditya 369 ’— a 1991 Telugu science fiction film directed by Singeetham Srinivasa which had attempted to paint the picture of a remote-controlled futuristic universe. In 2020, with rapid strides in technology, we are gradually inching towards that future.

Home-based applications with the support of IoT ( Internet of Things ) are gaining popularity all over the world, including Visakhapatnam. Apartments, commercial buildings including hospitals and hotels are gradually adopting this technology with the primary purposes of enhancing security and conserving energy.

As per NASSCOM, the number of IoT devices in India is expected to increase significantly from 200 million units in 2016 to 2.7 billion units by 2020. NASSCOM claims that adoption of these devices will make India a leader within this space. The IoT market in the country is poised to reach US$ 15 billion by 2020, accounting for 5 per cent of the global industry.

Architects and civil engineers are of the opinion that the trend of using IoT is here to stay and it will gradually transform lived experience with greater reliance on technology.

Karuna Kumari, a senior architect with Anuhya Architects and Interiors said that innovation and invention are necessary to save time and energy and these materials are cost-effective, strong and eco-friendly; therefore leading to their adoption across multiple sectors.

“We suggest cost-effective and environment-friendly methods in our plans. Some accept them, while some don’t. But IoT will be the future of the construction sector,” Karuna told TOI.

Peela Koteswara Rao, executive member of Credai, Visakhapatnam chapter said that the construction sector is taking up IoT in the city. “At present, it is mostly hospitals, villas, hotels and companies that are using IoT, primarily for security purposes. We hope that IoT in home appliances also make entry into domestic constructions like apartments and homes soon,” Rao added.

O Naresh Kumar, CEO of Symbiosis Technologies said, “I have ordered IoT-based home appliances, including a security system for my home and company. These will help save electricity and improve security.”

Meanwhile, Samir Kakkar, director, Legrand India— an IoT electrical and digital building appliances’ retail unit in the city, said that these products are becoming affordable and with low internet costs, IoT devices will get more popular with time.

Title: Arvind Kejriwal: Ban travel to nations hit by coronavirus
Content: NEW DELHI: As the threat of novel coronavirus grows, Delhi government has decided to get DTC and cluster buses, metro trains and hospitals disinfected every day as a precautionary measure.The decision was taken in a state-level taskforce meeting chaired by chief minister Arvind Kejriwal on Sunday.The CM said that he would meet Union health minister Harsh Vardhan on Monday to request a ban on travel to countries badly affected by the virus. Addressing a press conference, Kejriwal said that the government had earmarked 168 beds in 25 hospitals — 19 government and six private — for Covid-19 patients.“Three cases of novel coronavirus have been reported in the capital so far. One case is still under investigation. Delhi government is worried about it but we are fully prepared to tackle it. There is no need to panic and we need everyone’s cooperation,” the chief minister said after the taskforce meeting.The taskforce was set up by the chief minister on March 4 to tackle the spread of novel coronavirus in the capital. It includes top officials of different departments concerned, the municipal corporations and Delhi Police.Since most of the patients so far have a history of international travel, the chief minister has urged people to inform the state government if anybody in their neighbourhood has returned from abroad in the past fortnight.The chief minister said that after examining the three cases, it was found that the first infected person came in contact with 105 people and the second with 168. The third person came in contact with 64 people in the last 14 days. “They are being isolated and checked for symptoms,” he added.Delhi government has deployed 40 doctors at the airport to screen passengers. “So far, 1,40,603 air passengers have been screened and put on surveillance,” Kejriwal said.He also appealed to employers to give paid leaves to all those quarantined so that their livelihood is not affected.Kejriwal said that 25 hospitals have facilities where people can submit their samples if they develop the symptoms of coronavirus. “We are ensuring separate facilities for collection of samples and treatment in these hospitals so that if any patient arrives there, he/she doesn’t come in contact with others,” he said.Delhi health minister Satyendar Jain said those who have no symptoms of the disease need not panic. “Only people who have returned from abroad and have symptoms are required to give samples in the hospitals,” he added.Following media reports that there is a huge rush of people to buy masks and hand sanitisers due to the scare, Kejriwal said that healthy people are not required to wear masks. He urged people to wash their hands frequently with soap and water.The state government has also announced a 24x7 state-level control room helpline. The numbers are 011-22307145, 011-22300012 and 22300036.

Title: ‘Teach children values to make them good citizens’
Content:
Vidarbha Sahitya Sangh held a seminar to mark Women’s Day

Nagpur: Parents today are quite confused about raising their children. Should they conform to traditional values or adopt a modern approach? This confusion is making young generation confused too and in this chaos, the right values are not being taught to children. This is why the atrocities against women are increasing, said famous ghazal singer Vishnu Solanke on Saturday.

Speaking as the chief guest at a seminar organized by Vidarbha Sahitya Sangh Library on the stance of literature on rising atrocities against women to mark International Women’s Day, he said children are needed to be taught importance of values to become good citizens.

Solanke talked about sexism and patriarchy which has been going on since ancient times and is still prevalent. “Unfortunately, the emotional trials and tribulations faced by women are quite disregarded. There was so much injustice done to Urmila, wife of Laxman in epic Ramayana. But no one knows about it. Today, the condition is no different,” he said.

Lawyer Gaurav Khond was of the opinion that literature today is also manifested in the form of short films and web series. “Lack of censorship on these platforms is exposing young minds to immoral activities. It is a big cause for crime against women.

Amruta Indurkar, a lecturer, said atrocities against women can be physical and mental in nature. “Causing mental and physical abuse, rape and harming the dignity of a woman are all forms of atrocities.” She cited the examples of writers such as Pratima Joshi and Monica Gajendragadkar who have highlighted the plight of women in their literary works.

Suruchi Dabir and Madan Kulkarni also spoke at the event.

Shubhada Shankhye, PI (Bharosa Cell) was felicitated for contribution to the uplift of women.
