Title: Coronavirus scare clips 'Wings India 2020' to solely business event
Content: HYDERABAD: Wings India 2020 , the biennial flagship event of the civil aviation ministry to be held at the Begumpet airport this week, is on track, but the event will leverage digital communication modes for many of its meetings and avoid public gatherings amid the Coronavirus scare, said Union ministry of civil aviation joint secretary Usha Padhee here on Sunday.Telangana IT and industries principal secretary Jayesh Ranjan said the event that was earlier supposed to be a four-day event starting March 12, will now be crunched into a to three-day event to be held during March 12-14. He pointed out that the general public will not be allowed this time but the aero show will take place as planned.When asked about the number of delegates expected to attend the event, he admitted that the number will be less this year but refused to give a figure saying more clarity will emerge in 2-3 days. In the 2018 edition of Wings India around 700 delegates, including representatives of 14 airlines and major aircraft manufacturers, participated.“We have several elements in the event to ensure that those who are not able to travel can join via videoconferencing. For instance, we had a ministerial session, where some ministers were from coming from abroad but now they will participate through video conferencing or send us a video message. We will be focusing on the state ministers who will be attending the session,” said Padhee, who was in the city to meet state government officials and inspect the arrangements being made for Wings India 2020.She said many international delegates have already been advised to avoid travel and instead participate via video conferencing and Wings India 2020 will be more of a business event than a public one. “The focus will be on ensuring that the business quality or outcomes of the meetings is not impacted in any way,” she said. Padhee said that the state government has been very proactive in tackling the Coronavirus scare so far and is well equipped to cope with any crisis.

Title: Telangana budget: KCR govt bets big on its winning flagship schemes
Content: HYDERABAD: Though the economic slowdown has hit the state’s revenues, the K Chandrasekhar Rao-led government has not cowed down by it and instead enhanced budgetary allocations for many of its flagship welfare schemes, which the pink party feels paved for its victories in election after election in the last six years.Though budgetary allocations were reduced for some welfare sectors such as Most Backward Classes Corporation (MBC) from Rs 1,000 crore in 2019-20 to Rs 500 crore in the 2020-21 budget, the allocation for Rythu Bandhu, Kalyana Lakshmi for backward classes, crop loan waiver and Aasara pensions schemes which TRS feels gave it huge mandate in elections have got enhanced allocations.Allocation for Rythu Bandhu scheme, under which farmers get Rs 10,000 per acre per annum towards agriculture input cost, has been enhanced from Rs 12,000 crore in the 2019-20 budget to Rs 14,000 crore in 2020-21. The Rs 2,000 crore enhancement was due to anticipated increase in number of beneficiaries under Rythu Bandhu.Even the budget for Kalyana Lakshmi scheme to the backward classes has been enhanced by Rs 650 crore. The allocations for Aasara, a pension scheme for the aged, was increased by Rs 2,356 crore to extend sop to new beneficiaries under the age-group of 57 years to 65 years.As against an allocation of Rs 9,402 crore for Aasara pensions in 2019-20, Rs 11,758 crore was allocated in the 2020-21 budget. In fact, finance minister T Harish Rao announced that Aasara pension for new beneficiaries would be given from the 2020-21 fiscal. The budget for animal husbandry and fisheries department was increased from Rs 602 crore in 2019-20 to Rs 1,586 crore in the 2020-21 fiscal.The TRS government had spent Rs 16,124 crore towards crop loan waiver scheme in its first term (2014-2018). In its second term, the TRS government would require Rs 25,936 crore to implement the loan waiver promise. The state finance minister announced that they would release Rs 1,198 crore in March itself to waive the crop loans below Rs 25,000 each taken by 5.83 lakh farmers. As against Rs 6,000 crore allocated for crop loan waiver in 2019-20, the government has allocated Rs 6,225 crore in the 2020-21 budget with a promise to implement it in four instalments.Though Harish Rao announced that the budget allocation for minority welfare was Rs 1,518 crore for the 2020-21 fiscal as against Rs 1,369 crore in 2019-20, sources said the minority welfare budget has actually been reduced by over Rs 480 crore. The government had allocated Rs 2,004 crore in the 2019-20 budget for minority welfare and later revised it to Rs 1,369 crore, the sources added.

Title: Coronavirus fails to dampen Holi spirit in Bareilly
Content:
Locals throng market in Bareilly’s Civil Lines on Sunday

BAREILLY: At a time when coronavirus (covid-19) scare has gripped the country and with confirmed and suspected cases being reported every day, Bareilly residents hardly seem to be deterred and have set the market abuzz with their shopping spree ahead of Holi. Preparation for Holika Dahan is going on in full swing and people in several localities were seen playing Holi, even as the festival a couple of days away.

As people, including schoolchildren and college students, have started pouring colours on each other, doctors have advised them to avoid being a part of big gatherings and coming in close contact with people as a precautionary measure.

Shopkeepers, in the meanwhile, said the footfall in markets is usual — like any other festival — and people are turning up to buy sweets, colours, etc. Besides, clubs, restaurants and hotels are being decked up and special arrangements are being made for food, parties, dance and various other activities in anticipation of high footfall.

Talking about the preparations, director of Bareilly Palace hotel Shrawan Agarwal told TOI, “Fortunately, no coronavirus case has been reported in the region, so there is no major impact. Like every year, this year too we have received bookings for Holi, though there won’t be huge gatherings.”

Owner of East Lite hotel in Civil Lines Nikhil Thapar, however, said they were avoiding bookings for Holi because of coronavirus scare. “People come in close contact while playing Holi, which should be avoided as a precautionary measure.”

Markets in several city areas such as Bara Bazaar, Civil Lines, Qutubkhana and others witnessed heavy footfall. “People are coming for shopping as Holi is just a day away. The number of visitors is likely to surge tomorrow. There is no significant change in the number of people visiting markets. Everyone seems to be in celebratory mode,’ said Amit Agarwal, a shopkeeper in Civil Lines.

Meanwhile, taking a precautionary measure, the health department has set up a 300-bed hospital in Bareilly to quarantine suspected cases of coronavirus. Following the government instructions that such containment zone for hosting mass patients should be built away from the populous area, the 300-bed hospital has been set up in an under-construction building.

Advising people to take utmost precaution while celebrating Holi, Bareilly chief medical officer (CMO) Dr Vineet Shukla said, “There are high chances of contamination in social gatherings. While playing Holi people come in close contact with each other, which they should avoid as virus remain active on the wet surface. Even if people are attending parties and joining gatherings, they should keep themselves dry and avoid close contacts.”

Title: Food department team attacked by bakery owner
Content:
Representative image

JHANSI: A team of officials of the food department which had gone to collect samples of eatables from a bakery in the city on Sunday afternoon were allegedly attacked by the bakery owner and his employees. The bakery was later sealed and the officials are in process of lodging a case in this connection.

According to reports, a team of officials of the food safety department had gone to collect samples from a bakery but the the owner resisted.

Following heated arguments between the officials and the bakery owner, the latter along with his workers, allegedly attacked one of the officials. The team immediately informed the police following which city magistrate Salil Kumar Patel and CO (city), Sangram Singh arrived with the force. After hearing both the sides, the police took the CCTV footage for the purpose of investigation.

The city magistrate said, “The officials of the food department have sealed the bakery and are in the process of lodging an FIR”.

Title: Coronavirus in Telangana: Isolation ward should have no link to other blocks, says health minister Eatala Rajender
Content: HYDERABAD: With Kerala reporting five more positive cases of coronavirus (Covid-19), health minister Eatala Rajender visited the Government General and Chest Hospital at Erragadda on Sunday and inspected the arrangements in place for a separate isolation ward in the hospital.“Dedicate a building that is at a distance from all other blocks to conduct tests and treat people who come with symptoms. No passageway to the isolated building should be linked to the other blocks,” the minister said, adding that more beds should be made available in the isolation wards.The hospital authorities informed the minister that a two-floored building with four wards has been identified as an isolation centre at the chest hospital. Currently there are eight ventilators and 56 beds available at the centre. However, Rajender asked them to arrange for four individual rooms.The decision to designate a hospital exclusively for Covid-19 patients was taken on Tuesday after the health minister held a review meeting with municipal administration and urban development as well as panchayat raj and rural development departments.Meanwhile, a 12-member team that went to Kerala on Thursday to understand the measures taken by the government to prevent outbreak, returned to the city on Sunday. The team, headed by Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC) additional commissioner B Santosh, includes superintendent of Gandhi Hospital P Shravan Kumar , Hyderabad district medical and health officer J Venkat , and Chest Hospital superintendent Dr Mahaboob Khan.

Title: Congress: TRS govt’s inflated allocations an eyewash
Content:
Congress floor leader in Telangana assembly Mallu Bhatti Vikramarka (centre)

HYDERABAD: The Congress has charged the TRS government of making inflated budgetary allocations on paper to project itself as a welfare-oriented government. They said that the government did not have the money to implement the schemes as it was already debt-ridden.

“Budgetary allocations are mere projections and we have serious doubts whether the TRS-government will actually release the money allocated in the budget ,” Congress floor leader in the assembly Mallu Bhatti Vikramarka said and termed the enhance allocations an eyewash.

“When the average growth rate of the of the budget outlay was 15% between 2014-15 and 2018-19, when the economy was vibrant, how can it grow to 29% in 2020-21 when the economic slowdown has dented the state’s revenue and share of central funds have been cut by over Rs 3,000 crore?” Bhatti sought to know.

Former minister Mohammed Ali Shabbir also termed the budget unrealistic and said the TRS government makes allocations but spends nothing. He also slammed that government for slashing outlay for welfare of minorities. “When the government can increase its spending by over Rs 40,000 crore under other heads, then why was minorities’ welfare budget slashed,” the former minister said.

Title: Upgraded GEMINI to boost India’s maritime security
Content:
Rajkot: With Mariner's Instrument for Navigation and Information (GEMINI) — the indigenously developed technology that aims to disseminate information to fishermen in mid-sea — set to be taken to the next level, India’s maritime security will get a major boost.

Till now, it was used only to provide information to fishermen about the weather perils and catch information while in mid-sea. However, the improved communication device will now be two-ways, with fishermen being able to provide crucial information to security agencies on the coasts.

GEMINI is the mariner navigation and information device enabled through GAGAN and developed by Hyderabad-based Indian National Centre for Ocean Information Services (INCOIS).

Talking to TOI, scientist at INCOIS, Nimit Kumar said: “The ocean is not used only for fishing, but for activities that may hurt our national security. Currently we have bandwidth limitation because we are using AAI satellite for the purpose. ISRO, meanwhile, is developing a satellite for us. So, when we get our own dedicated satellite we plan to provide two-way communication through this device in which the Indian boat can give distress signals to coast guard or navy. The security agency will also be able to verify about any boat that it’s Indian or not.”

According to INCOIS sources, this technology will provide digital identity to the Indian boats in the next few years. At present, the only identification mark for Indian boats is the national Tricolour, a system that has been prevalent for the last 200 years.

This digital identification will also put an end to false claims of Indian boats being captured in foreign waters, they said.

Title: Women should speak up fearlessly, says Bhujbal
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: The district guardian minister Chhagan Bhujbal on Saturday said that the women should speak up against any crime and the Bharosa cell set up by the Nashik rural police will help them give justice.

Speaking during the inauguration of the dedicated cell for women and children by the Nashik rural police, Bhujbal said that there need to be more security measures for the women. “Not only Bharosa Cell, there should be a women special police station in the district,” Bhujbal said.

The Bharosa cell is set up at the rural police headquarters in Adgaon. It is a one-stop solution in resolving issues of women and children, which has a dedicated staff of nearly 15 male as well as female members including an assistant police inspectors, doctors, etc. “A country becomes backward if its women are not educated. We should teach women karate at an early age. In fact, men should also be educated about how to respect women,” Bhujbal added.

Moreover, on the backdrop of International Women’s day , the rural police honoured ten women from across the district for being in unconventional job roles and giving remarkable contributions to their fields.

Superintendent of Police, Nashik rural, Arti Singh, said “All of us have success stories and all of us have struggled in our own way. Recognising and honouring such women will encourage others to make more success stories.”

The identified women were honoured by guardian minister Chhagan Bhujbal at Bhujbal Knowledge City on Saturday.

Actress Mansi Pathak, who is also the daughter of police head constable Uday Pathak posted at Sinnar Police Station, was one of the awardees. “The recognition reminded me of my first award in class X. I am really happy and excited,” she said.

The long-distance runner known as Savarpada Express, Kavita Raut Tungar, was also one of the ten identified women.

The other selected women were from various fields like education, law, modelling, journalism, social work, etc. Asha Khairnar was recognised as an ideal mother, as her husband and son, both are serving the police department.

Title: Three murders in 24 hours rock Shahjahanpur
Content:
Representative image

BAREILLY: Three murders, all in different locations of the city, left Shahjahanpur residents shocked on Sunday. Reportedly, the accused were in an inebriated condition in all three crimes. Among these, two murders were reported from district’s Nigohi block.

In the first crime reported from Unkhurd village, a 35-year-old man, identified as Naresh Kumar, was shot dead by his childhood friend Ballister Singh after they had an argument over a booze party. Police have arrested Ballister and have booked him under relevant sections of the IPC and the Arms Act.

In the second crime which took place in Ghusgava village of Nigohi on Saturday, a 55-year-old man, identified as Suresh Pujari, was hacked to death by his sloshed nephew Sonu Yadav over a petty issue. The accused has been arrested.

The third murder was reported from a village in Tilhar block where a 52-year-old man, identified as Jugal Kishore, was beaten to death by his relatives in the clash between two groups. The two sons of Jugal and his wife Kalawati sustained injuries in the clash. Heavy police force was deployed in the village after the clash. Police have launched a manhunt for the accused in the case.

Meanwhile, additional SP (city) Dinesh Tripathi told TOI, "Personal enmity led to these murders. We have taken action against accused and are trying to maintain law and order in the district."

Title: Hyderabad: Customs seize gold worth Rs 41 lakh at RGIA
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

HYDERABAD: Customs officials arrested a passenger trying to smuggle 932 gram of gold , valued at Rs 41 lakh, concealed inside the coil of a PVC cable at RGI Airport on Sunday. The passenger arrived from Dubai . Officials noticed something suspicious in his checked-in baggage and opened it.

Title: Funds for Hyderabad a poll tactic, says K Laxman
Content:
BJP Telangana state chief K Laxman

HYDERABAD: BJP state chief K Laxman on Sunday sought to know how the state government has proposed an increased outlay of Rs 1.82 lakh crore in the state budget for the year 2020-21, despite claiming that there was an economic slowdown in the country.

In a statement to the media, he asked how the government would generate the extra amount of Rs 40,000 crore that was needed. “Budget allocation for projects in Hyderabad have been made keeping in mind GHMC elections. The government was never bothered about the city ,” he said

He said government did not allocate any money towards unemployment allowance in the Budget.

Title: 34 cheated for Rs 6.44 lakh on pretext of online payments in Nashik
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: As many as 34 people from Nashik city were cheated of Rs 6.44 lakh by an unknown person, who, under the garb of sending online payments , siphoned off the money from the victims’ accounts.

According to the cyber police, Nashik, the accused had managed to gain the trust of the victims by making small payments for buying a product put up for sale through online e-commerce websites by the complainants. This was followed by the request for payment to complete the deal. But the complainants failed to understand that the request was actually for making payments to the accused and thus they lost their money.

The cases were reported between September 1, 2019, and March 3, 2020. A total of 34 complainants had put up their goods for sale on e-commerce websites.

The police said that all these complainants either have some business or they put up their personal goods for sale online.

The accused would call them up and fix the deal. Once the deal was settled, the accused would send the money across immediately to strike a deal. The accused would then ask them to make the payments with more concrete payment mode, which he would claim was a reliable one. He would ask them to accept the request only.

He then would send a QR code to the accused, which, actually was a request to make payment.

“This was the trick the accused used to cheat the victims. The complainants failed to understand what the request was for and they accepted it. The acceptance resulted in the making of payments – from the complainants to the accused,” the police said.

Title: International women’s day celebrated
Content:
Kanpur: Institute of Hotel Management (IHM) at CSJM University on Saturday celebrated the International Women's Day with fanfare.

A cultural programme, organised on the occasion, was inaugurated by Prof RC Katiyar of CSJM University and Prof Sanjay Swarankar, dean, academics and research, Pravin Katiyar, former president of IMA, Kanpur Chapter, and Vivek Singh Sachan of CSJM University. Prof RC Katiyar, who was chief guest on the occasion, said women are no way inferior to men and they were matching footsteps with males in almost all fields.

Guest of honour, Pravin Katiyar, said that women should be respected and should also be given respect at homes.

Students Suhani Gupta, Vaishnavi, Sheetal Yadav, Riya Singh, Sakshi, Surabhi and Priyanka presented dance performance which was appreciated by one and all. Vartika Sharma and Smita Yadav recited poems on women empowerment .

Title: Pilibhit: Police seize 100 litres of spurious liquor; five booked
Content:
Representative image

PILIBHIT: Nearly 100 litres of spurious liquor made from urea, and another 100 litres of raw material and five kilos of urea were seized from an illegal liquor distillation unit running on an agricultural field at Ujhainia village under Jahanabad police station in Pilibhit district.

The raid was part of an anti-spurious liquor drive by Pilibhit police ahead of the festival of Holi. An FIR has been lodged against five people who were nabbed from the spot.

According to Mani Ram, SHO, the unit was raided after police received a tip-off. The use of urea in making liquor is hazardous for human health.

Sub inspector Sundar Singh led a police team to the spot and caught five villagers -- Prem Shankar, Prem Kumar, Jabar Singh, Vedpal and Jagan Lal – working in the plant.

The police team seized the distillation plant as well as the liquor and raw material.

The accused were booked under IPC section 272 (adulteration of food or drink intended for sale) and the Excise Act. The accused were produced before the remand magistrate and were sent to jail, he said.

Title: Bareilly: Power department to recover dues from 25 defaulters daily
Content:
Representative image

BAREILLY: In an attempt to make power consumers pay their electricity bills on time, the power department has set a target of cracking down on at least 25 defaulters every day to recover the dues. Besides, power corporation officials have also been directed to disconnect supply of consumers having arrears of Rs 3,000 or more with immediate effect.

According to the information from the power department, there are 1.82 lakh consumers in urban areas and 1.12 lakh in rural areas in Bareilly district. Thousands of these consumers have outstanding bills, said officials.

Speaking with TOI, Madhyanchal Vidyut Vitran Nigam Limited (MVVNL), superintending engineer (rural) Tariq Jalil said, “Uttar Pradesh Power Corporation Limited (UPPCL) director (distribution), Vijay Kumar, had visited the city earlier this week and discussed various issues pertaining to line loss, electricity supply, power theft and bill arrears. As pending power dues is a major issue, directions were issued to chalk out a plan to recover the money in the city and sensitize people about the need for paying their bills in time.”

Now, Jalil said, for recovering power dues, linesmen deputed on feeders will be entrusted with the task of recovering electricity dues from at least 25 power consumers every day in urban and rural areas.

Disconnection of supply to consumers who have run up bills up to Rs 10,000 or more was initiated earlier, Jalil said. The limit has now been reduced to Rs 3,000.

Title: Ram Madhav & Vijayvargiya among BJP probables for RS in Madhya Pradesh
Content:
The names of BJP national general secretaries Ram Madhav and Kailash Vijayvargiya are in the list of contender... Read More

BHOPAL: Amid the ongoing political upheaval, BJP has decided to field two candidates for the three Rajya Sabha seats in Madhya Pradesh that will go to polls on March 26. A meeting of BJP state election committee chaired by newly appointed state president V D Sharma, convened here on Sunday at the party’s state head office, forwarded fifteen names in the panel for the two seats. BJP’s central election committee will finalise the names, he said.

According to sources, among the prominent names under consideration for Rajya Sabha by the saffron party are national general secretaries Ram Madhav and Prabhat Jha, national vice presidents Uma Bharti and Kailash Vijayvargiya , state leaders Vinod Gotia, Omprakash Dhurve and Deepak Vijayvargiya.

“We have decided to contest two Rajya Sabha seats in the upcoming elections to the Upper House. We are hopeful to win one and keeping our options open for the other seat. We are quite confident to win the other seats too,” Sharma told TOI.

Sharma added that the election committee members had spoken to some claimants over phone and in person after which a tentative list of candidates was prepared to be forwarded to the central election committee. The meeting was attended by leader of Opposition (LoP) Gopal Bhargava, Rajya Sabha member Prabhat Jha, former state chief Satyanarayan Jatia and former minister and MLA Rajendra Shukla .

Going by the numbers, BJP has 107 members in the state assembly and require at least 58 votes to win one seat. For two seats, the party needs support of 116 MLAs which will require support of nine additional MLAs to win the second Rajya Sabha seat. BJP’s decision to contest two seats came amid high political drama in the state where the party is being accused of horse-trading to lure Congress MLAs.

BJP is also under threat of losing two of its MLAs, including Narayan Tripathi from Maihar and Sharad Kol from Beohari, who had voted earlier with the Congress and are keeping a constant touch with chief minister Kamal Nath. This is a serious cause of concern for the saffron party, said sources.

Both BJP and the ruling Congress have chalked out a strategy to keep their flock of MLAs together to prevent any cross-voting in the Rajya Sabha polls. BJP leadership has also asked the legislators to stay alert and promptly inform them in case they are approached by the rival camp in connection with the elections. Both the parties will win one seat each and the real tussle is for the third seat.

The Congress with 114 members in the assembly has support of four independents, including two BSP and one SP members that takes its tally in the House to 121. Two seats are currently vacant in the 230-member house. The Congress will require support of only two additional members to win a second seat. However, amid discontentment in the party, as some MLAs are still missing even after five days after the political drama unfolded, the Congress is yet to finalise names for the Rajya Sabha elections.

“We are winning two Rajya Sabha seats as all the Congress MLAs and our alliance partners have assured support to us. The BJP will be wiped out in the elections,” claimed state public relations minister PC Sharma, on Sunday.

Title: Class 10 student kills self in Saidabad
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

HYDERABAD: A 17-year-old class 10 student committed suicide at her house in Saidabad on Sunday. The victim, a resident of Subramanya Nagar , hanged herself. It was found that the family of the victim was looking for a groom for her marriage while she, allegedly, did not want to get married. A case was registered.

Title: Telangana budget pours cold water on HMWS&SB demands
Content:
MLA's congratulate Telangana finance minister T Harish Rao.

HYDERABAD: The budget has come as disappointment for the Hyderabad Metropolitan Water Supply and Sewerage Boards (HMWS&SB). As against the water board’s demand for Rs 2,150 crore, the allocation in the current budget stood at just above Rs 900 crore. However, the water board can hope to see a share of the Rs 10,000 crore corpus allocated for the development of Hyderabad.

Except for the repayment of Hudco loans, allocations for key projects such as the laying of a 158km pipeline along ORR, construction of Keshavapuram reservoir, implementation of the water safety plan , construction of STPs in GHMC’s peripheral areas and others were absent in the budget.

The water board had taken loans of around Rs 3,500 crore from Hudco for the completion of three phases under the Krishna Drinking Water Supply scheme and one phase of the Godavari Drinking Water Supply Scheme. “In the 2020-21 budget, the state government has allocated just above Rs 900 crore for the repayment of these loans,” a senior water board official told TOI. “Daily water supply to Hyderabad, areas in GHMC periphery and along ORR may become difficult given meagre allocation of funds,” a retired HMW&SB official said.

Title: Illegal brick kilns fined Rs 3.15 crore by MPCB
Content:
Representative image

BAREILLY: Coming down heavily on some illegal brick kilns in Rampur and Sambhal districts, Moradabad Pollution Control Board (MPCB) has levied a hefty penalty of Rs 3.15 crore, around Rs 15 lakh each.

According to information from the regional pollution control board, inspections were conducted on March 6, 2020, which revealed that 20 brick kilns were operating against the guidelines of Uttar Pradesh Pollution Control Board (UPPCB) and were polluting the air as they lacked adequate pollution control mechanism.

Speaking to TOI on Sunday, UPPCB regional officer, Moradabad, Ajay Sharma said, “Inspections were carried out on March 6 after receiving information about rampant operations of unauthorized brick kilns in Sambhal and Rampur districts. As many as 20 such brick furnaces were identified to be violating UPPCB norms. The erring kilns lacked proper mechanism to curb air pollution being emitted from these furnaces while all of them were being operated without pollution board’s consent.”

The regional officer added, “The identified kilns did not follow several high court orders pertaining to operations nor did they adhere to the guidelines set by pollution control board. Since none of them had acquired a legit no-objection certificate from UPPCB and no legal procedure was being followed, a penalty of Rs 3.15 crore has been imposed. Twenty erring brick kilns have been pulled up for violating regulations. A detailed report has been forwarded to the headquarters to initiate further legal action against the unauthorized kilns and shut its operations. Further orders are now awaited.”

In February, UPPCB had levied a hefty penalty of Rs 9.58 crore (Rs 1.36 crore each) on seven godown operators for illegally storing animal skins, triggering air pollution and flouting pollution board norms in residential areas of Moradabad.

Title: Women take up maintenance of trains in Nashik
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: Not limiting themselves to soft skills like clerical and management jobs or driving locomotives, the women employed with the railways are now seen working with men in fields that demands laborious works.

“In Bhusawal division, we have women working in almost all spheres, including under-carriage maintenance of coaches, shunting of the trains besides working as points man, guards and loco pilots. With women working in field jobs, there is no section where women are absent,” senior officers from the divisional railway manager’s office, Bhusaval, said.

The Bhusaval division of railways has formed a 11-member woman team that maintains coaches at Bhusawal coaching complex. This sector was once dominated by men given the nature of work that requires strength and involves working at heights and even under the carriage of trains, lifting of heavy duty material, etc.

“We have 11-member women team which works in group of seven when others are either on weekly offs or leaves. This team carries out the maintenance of coaches at the Bhusawal coaching complex. They are responsible for the all the primary inspection and safety of coaches as per the manual and brake testing of the rakes,” a senior railway officer said.

Some of these women are graduates while some are either SSC passed or have got the certificate of Industrial Training Institute (ITI) in various trades.

“These women have been trained for the job and their work is confined to the complex,” the officer said.

Title: On Women’s Day, Srikakulam woman awarded Nari Shakti Puraskar
Content:
Padala Bhudevi receives the award from President Ram Nath Kovind on Sunday.

VISAKHAPATNAM: Padala Bhudevi from Srikakulam district received the Nari Shakti Puraskar from President Ram Nath Kovind on International Women’s Day on Sunday for her contributions towards the welfare of tribal women.

Bhudevi is the only woman from the two Telugu-speaking states to receive the honour, which was conferred to 15 women across the country.

Bhudevi has worked for the development of tribal women, widows, and ‘podu’ lands through Chinnai Adhivasi Vikas Society , a community-based organisation. Bhudevi, who was forced into marriage at the age of 11 and subjected to physical and mental abuse, has also trained 30 women in making mehendi cones and hair care products.

Title: Nashik zone gets 1840 solar power pumps, relief for farmers
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: The Nashik division of the Maharashtra State Electricity Distribution Company Limited (MSEDCL) has installed 1,840 solar power pumps to enable the farmers to pump out groundwater during the daytime.

The solar pumps have been allotted to the farmers, who paid for the new connections but did not receive it.

The solar pumps were sanctioned through central government’s Atal Solar Krishi Pump Yojana and state government’s Mukhyamantri Saur Krushi Pump Yojana in which the farmers had to pay less than 10 percent of the total costs of the pump. The same was also warranted for a period of five years.

Out of the total 1,840 solar pumps allotted, 1049 pumps were installed in Nashik, 195 pumps in Malegaon while 596 pumps in Ahmednagar circle.

The MSEDCL officers further pointed out that the Nashik circle had large numbers of farmers and the land was also well irrigated, while the Malegaon circle was largely dry. The Ahmednagar district is vast in terms of geographical dimensions, but even this region falls in the rain shadow region and hence the demand for the pumps was limited.

The solar pumps ensure the farmers do not have to rely on the power supply, especially in the backdrop of the power-sharing issue. “There is a regular complaint of the farmers about the lack of voltage, or the power supply disruption due to failed transformer, have to wait for a couple of days before the transformer is reinstated. The worst part is that the farmers are forced to water their plants in the night – which happens turn-by-turn,” the MSEDCL officer said.

With solar power the farmers get the power in the day time and get assured supply as well. The farmers do not have to worry about the failed transformers and also about the maintenance of the solar power pumps for the first five years.

Title: Bhuj fraudsters dupe Jaipur jeweller of Rs 17 lakh
Content:
Accused in police custody

RAJKOT: Three Bhuj-based frauds who conned a Jaipur-based jeweller of Rs 17 lakh on February 21, were arrested on Saturday night. Police said accused Nawab Traya, Iqbal Chauhan and Hasan Naude had cheated Pawan Soni.

Soni had come into contact with Traya on social media after the latter had created a fake ID in the name of Rajendra Soni on Facebook and offered to sell gold at two to three percent less from the original price to Soni.

According to the police, Traya told Soni that he would sell the gold at 15% less price, if he took delivery of the metal in Bhuj. Lured by the offer, Soni and his uncle Radheshyam came to Bhuj on February 21 and met Traya.

“Soni was supposed to pay Traya Rs 34 lakh for 1kg gold, but had brought only Rs17 lakh. When he said he didn’t have enough money, Traya asked him to pay Rs17 lakh to him now and that he would give Soni 2kg gold. But, he said the gold will be delivered to Soni only in Ahmedabad. He told Soni to pay the remaining amount after reaching Jaipur,” said R N Khant, inspector, Bhuj police.

After Soni paid Rs 17 lakh in cash, Traya told Soni that his driver would take him and his uncle to Ahmedabad in his car where the gold will be delivered to the duo. After reaching Ahmedabad, the driver told Soni to go to Geeta Mandir bus stand and wait for him, while he would go and fetch the gold for him. However, the driver never returned and Soni realized that he had been duped.

Soni lodged a complaint against Traya with Bhuj police on March 4. Soni had clicked photographs of Traya on his cellphone which he showed to the cops who ascertained his identity as a notorius fraudster of Bhuj. “We arrested Traya and Chauhan and Naude while they were travelling in their SUV on Bhuj Airport Road,” said Khant.

Title: UP: Rape accused of minor held after two months
Content:
Representative image

BAREILLY: In a major breakthrough, Moradabad police on Sunday arrested a youth and solved a case relating to the rape of an eight-year-old mentally handicapped girl who was found abandoned near the government airstrip at Mudhapandey on December 22. The girl was shifted to hospital in Moradabad and later, she was referred to a higher facility in Meerut. After battling for life for nearly one month, she succumbed to injuries.

The accused, identified as Satyabhan alias Kinnu, 24, was booked for rape and provisions of the POCSO Act.

The girl was identified on the basis of a missing complaint lodged by her family.

Amit Pathak, senior superintendent of police, said that after two months, police managed to nab Kinnu.

Amit Kumar Anand, additional superintendent of police (city), said, “On December 22, an eight-year-old mentally handicapped girl was raped. It was indeed a very challenging case since the survivor was unable to give any clue about the accused.”

The ASP said the SSP had instituted a team, which included a counsellor having expertise in crime against children, to crack the case.

While investigating the case, police learnt about Kinnu, who had a history of molesting women. “We took him into custody. During interrogation, he confessed to the crime,” Anand said. The accused was a labourer and a resident of the same village, where deceased girl used to live.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Nashik district gets 1,584 crore for development of roads
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: The state government has proposed a layout of Rs 1,583.87 crore for roads in the district of which the Public Works Department (PWD) will spend Rs 354 crore on regular roads while Rs 1,205 crore will be spent on Hybrid Annuity Model (HAM) in which widening and developing of five new roads.

The PWD department maintains and improvises the roads that fall under the Major District Roads and State Highways category that criss-cross the district, connecting the towns, major villages with the district and the taluka headquarters or even the major national highways passing through the district.

The major sum of the budget allocated is for the Hybrid Annuity Model (HAM). “The plan is that the five roads will be constructed in the next three years for which the contractors will receive the 60 percent of the cost of the road stage-wise. The rest of the 40 percent will be paid stage-wise in the next 10 years wherein the maintenance will be carried out by the contractor. The failure of the contractor to maintain the road will result in forfeiting the amount,” a senior PWD officer said.

At the same time the major allocation of Rs 23.84 crore has been made for the bridges and culverts across the five districts falling in Nashik region – Nashik, Ahmednagar, Dhule, Jalgaon and Nandurbar districts. “The amount will be spent on the consultant and the system to ensure we have detailed computerized information of the bridges and the culverts across the region,” the officer added.

The works include construction of bridges, widening of roads, black topping of the roads where it has been damaged, widening and strengthening or the bridges as well as the roads, improvement of the damaged roads, etc.

The officer said that the work would be carried out during this financial year and the administrative approvals for all these would be sought in due course of time. Good numbers of works – where only black topping is required will be carried out immediately before the rainy season.

Title: Man burnt alive at in-laws house in Bareilly, murder suspected
Content:
Representative image

BAREILLY: A 24-year-old man, Raju Kashyap, who was married about four months ago, was allegedly burnt alive at his in-laws house in Deorania area of Bareilly district on Saturday night. Police claimed there may have been a quarrel and the man had set himself on fire.

The man was a resident of Bahedi town and had come to meet his wife to “gift her clothes”. News of his death shocked his parents and they alleged that their son was set ablaze by his wife and her family members.

Police said they later found that the couple had a quarrel and the man poured kerosene on him and killed himself. An FIR has been registered against four persons, including wife, at Deorania police station under IPC section 306 (abetment of suicide) on the complaint of father Ramgopal Kashyap.

On Sunday, Ramgopal told TOI, “As per the rituals, woman usually spends her first Holi at her maternal house after marriage. So, my daughter-in-law went back home. Raju left to meet her and had purchased new clothes for her on Saturday. In the evening, Raju told us that he would stay there. But, later in the night, we received a call saying that Raju has committed suicide.”

“We have come to know that there was an argument between my son, his wife and in-laws over a youth. We have asked police to take action against all the people responsible for my son’s death,” Ramgopal added.

SHO Deorania Rajkumar Singh said, “We have registered an FIR against the wife, mother-in-law, brother-in-law and a youth for abetment of suicide. We have detained a few suspects for questioning and waiting for the autopsy report to ascertain whether it was a suicide or he was murdered.”

Title: Coronavirus treatment in India: AIIMS to be nodal centre
Content:
AIIMS in Delhi

NEW DELHI: The health ministry has asked AIIMS to designate part of the new emergency wing at its trauma facility, Jai Prakash Narayan Apex Trauma Centre, for setting up of isolation beds for acute management of Covid-19 patients.

This isolation facility will have a capacity to admit about 20 patients at a given point of time. Officials said the patients will be triaged here, following which they will be transferred to National Cancer Institute (NCI) in Jhajjar.

“We plan to create 125 beds for Covid-19 patients in NCI. Of this, 25 will be ICU beds and the rest will have advanced facilities for monitoring and acute management of Covid-19 cases,” sources said.

Six other AIIMS in Bhopal, Bhubaneswar, Jodhpur, Patna, Raipur and Rishikesh have also been directed to keep ready 12-15 isolation beds for coronavirus patients. The number can be increased up to 30 if need arises, officials said.

Jawaharlal Institute of Postgraduate Medical Education and Research, Puducherry has also been asked to keep aside beds for isolating patients.

Union health minister Harsh Vardhan, who had a meeting with Poonam Khetrapal Singh, the regional director of WHO, on Sunday said he apprised her of the extensive capacity building efforts as part of the government’s mission-mode preparedness. “… I assured her that India is using speed, scale and determination coupled with best practices to push back #corona,” he tweeted.

On Saturday, PM Narendra Modi had reviewed the coronavirus situation in the country at a meeting with officials and directed them to identify locations for sufficient quarantine facilities and make provisions for critical care in case the disease spread further.

Sources said all top private hospitals have also been asked to be ready to handle Covid-19 cases. Dr V K Paul, member, Niti Aayog, told TOI the private hospitals have agreed to create facilities. “We need to be prepared for the worse while doing our best to contain the disease,” he said.

In Delhi, six private hospitals, including Max super speciality, Apollo and BLK hospital, have already created isolation wards. In Gurugram, Medanta Medicity has created an isolation ward where 14 out of 16 Italian nationals who tested positive for coronavirus are being treated.

While 80% Covid-19 cases are mild to moderate, a WHO-China Joint Mission Report released recently shows 14% develop severe symptoms like shortness of breath and 6% turn critical with symptoms like respiratory failure, septic shock and/or multi-organ dysfunction or failure.

“Individuals at highest risk for severe disease and death include people aged above 60 years and those with underlying conditions such as hypertension, diabetes, cardiovascular disease, chronic respiratory disease and cancer,” the report says.

Title: International Women’s Day celebrated across state
Content:
Dehradun: On the occasion of International Women’s Day on Sunday, several awareness programmes and celebratory events honouring the city’s girls and women unfolded across Dehradun.

Chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat inaugurated the “Poshan Pakhwada 2020”, organized by the state ministry of women and child development. This is the second edition of the nutrition campaign in the state. Speaking at the event, the CM addressed the issue of malnutrition among girls. “There is a need to create awareness among women and girls regarding anaemia. Programmes like Poshan Pakhwada should regularly be conducted to create awareness,” Rawat said, as he unveiled the ministry’s mascot “Saruli Bua” and released some short films in Garhwali and Hindi language on the prevention of anaemia.

“Dieticians should be present in the fairs taking place across the state and create awareness among women, so they can eventually prevent malnutrition. The state government schemes for women empowerment should also be promoted properly, so that nobody is deprived of the benefits,” Rawat added.

Meanwhile, the Federation of Obstetric and Gynaecological Societies of India (FOGSI) organised free clinics for policewomen who aren’t able to take proper care of their health due to long duty hours. The cops were offered free gynaecological consultation and breast-cancer check ups. Apart from Dehradun, the clinics were set up in Rampur, Haridwar, Rudrapur, Kashipur and Haldwani as well. Nearly 2,000 policewomen took part.

At a women’s day event inside the Survey of India premises in Hathibarkala, governor Baby Rani Maurya said in her address that given the right opportunities, women can flourish as well as men. “Women can truly be made strong only by the means of education. If girls get the support of their parents and the right opportunities, they can scale numerous heights in life. I appeal to all parents to give freedom to their girls to hone their talent, so that they can achieve big in life,” Maurya said in her speech.

Villages in the outskirts of Dehradun had a unique way of celebrating women’s day. Families with only daughters were felicitated, as were widows. Almost 80 women were felicitated amid the message of “Beti Bachao, Beti Padhao” in one such event in Galjwadi village.

In Tapkeshwar temple, too, several programmes were held to create awareness among women regarding hormonal imbalance and stress-related issues.

Title: Congress government in MP in full majority, claims BJP MLA Tripathi
Content:
Representative image

BHOPAL: Amid the political turmoil in the state with Congress and BJP trying to get even with each other, BJP MLA from Maihar Narayan Tripathi is leaving no stone unturned to embarass his party. Tripathi on Sunday met chief minister Kamal Nath, the third time in last three days, and claimed that Congress government in Madhya Pradesh is in ‘full majority’ and there is no crisis.

After meeting Nath at his official resident, Tripathi told waiting reporters that he had urged the chief minister him to approve Maihar as new district. He said, “Kamal Nath-led Congress government is in full majority. I met CM to ask for naming Maihar as a new district and discuss about a resolution in the assembly on the formation of a separate Vindhya State.”

The BJP leader who had supported the Congress sponsored bill in the state assembly during a voice-vote on an amendment and also praised Kamal Nath for his decisions, said that the chief minister gave a patient hearing to his demands. “I had demanded that the new district be notified before the budget session of MP Assembly. CM has assured for naming Maihar a new district. There are few more proposals for new districts and all these proposals will be taken up together," said Tripathi.

The BJP MLA has openly supported the Congress government against the party’s wish.

“When I met chief minister Kamal Nath ji at his residence, Bisahulal ji (referring to senior Congress MLA Bisahulal Singh , who was said to be missing for the past few days during the political drama) was also there,” Tripathi told reporters.

The BJP leader however, did not respond to queries on his loyalty to his party and whom would he support in the forthcoming Rajya Sabha elections. "This will be decided during the course of the budget session. For Rajya Sabha, will take a decision when the time comes," he said.

Tripathi had also called on chief minister Kamal Nath on Friday and Saturday. He was spotted by the reporters with minister Honey Singh Baghel at the Nath’s official residence at Shyamla Hills. However, he had claimed that he is a BJP MLA and would continue to support his party.

The BJP has meanwhile claimed that Tripathi is very much in the party fold. "Nobody is going anywhere. All BJP MLAs are with the party and supporting the party too," said BJP state spokesperson Rajneesh Agrawal.

Title: Bhind cops summon ‘missing’ MLA’s brother
Content:
Representative image

BHOPAL: Bhind police on Saturday summoned the brother of BJP MLA from Ater, Arvind Bhadoria .

Arvind’s name had also cropped up in alleged horse-trading attempts levelled by Congress against BJP, for toppling the government.

Sources said a police team went to the residence of Bhadoria and summoned his brother Devendra Singh Bhadoria to the CSP office on Saturday. Later, Devendra Singh stayed at the Kotwali police station for nearly 45 minutes before heading back home.

SP Bhind, Nagendra Singh said, “It was only a routine process as some information regarding a case had to be sought from him. We discussed about it and then he left for home.”

Sources from the police, however said that the questioning of Devendra Singh Bhadoria was in relation to the missing person FIR registered at Bhopal against a Congress MLA. It was suspected that Arvind Bhadoria could be aware of it and since Bhadoria was also not present in Ater, his brother was summoned for inquiry about the whereabouts of Arvind Bhadoria, following a query from Bhopal, said sources.

On March 3, Congress has alleged that a group of BJP leaders have allegedly offered money to Congress MLAs to switch sides. Congress alleged some BJP leaders, along with former CM Shivraj Singh Chouhan and former minister Narottam Mishra, were present at the hotel in Manesar in Haryana where eight to 10 Congress MLAs were staying in the night of March 3.

Title: 40-year-old man killed over love affair
Content:
Rajkot: Dhoraji police arrested a man on Sunday for committing a murder in Jhanjhmer village of Dhoraji taluka in Rajkot district two days ago. The accused, identified as Shakaria Samaliya (46), was arrested after the body of Kamlesh Chauhan (40) was found in a well near a check dam on the outskirts of Jhanjhmer village on Saturday.

Cops arrested Samaliya as he was the last person to have been seen with the deceased. Chauhan’s wife Kamali told the police that Samaliya had taken Chauhan for a fishing and liquor party on Thursday evening.

However, after Chauhan failed to return home the next day, Kamali started searching for him and asked Samaliya about her husband’s whereabouts. The accused feigned ignorance, she alleged. Then the villagers informed her about the recovery of a body in the well near the check dam.

When the body was fished out, Kamali identified it to be her husband. On Saturday night, Kamali lodged a police complaint in which she named Samaliya as the accused.

“We arrested Samaliya from Dhoraji from where he was planning to flee. During interrogation, Samaliya told the police that he killed Chauhan as he was allegedly having had an illicit relationship with his daughter. Samaliya said that he had first got Chauhan drunk and then bludgeoned him to death. After this, he threw Chauhan’s body in the well,” said V H Joshi, inspector, Dhoraji police station.

Title: Pregnant woman ends life over dowry harassment
Content:
Mysuru: A 23-year-old pregnant woman committed suicide over alleged dowry harssment in Kalkunike village in Hunsur on Saturday evening.

The police have registered a case under Section 304 (culpable homicide not amounting to murder) of IPC on the basis of a complaint lodged by the woman’s father B Basavanna, a resident of Banchalli Hundi in Nanjanagud taluk. He alleged that his daughter committed suicide due to dowry harassment.

According to police, the woman, B Lakshmi, had married K Yogesh, a resident of Kalkunike village nearly 10 months ago.

Lakshmi's parents alleged that her in-laws and husband were pressuring her to get more dowry even though they had paid money at the time of wedding. They alleged that within two months of the wedding, her husband and in-laws started harassing her, forcing her to take an extreme step. She was found hanging from the ceiling fan.

According to sources, on Friday, Lakshmi had called her parents and requested them to take her back to her native village as she can't tolerate the harassment. Her parents consoled her by saying they will come on Saturday and take her back. But on Saturday, her in-laws called her parents informing them about the death.

The family members of Lakshmi held a flash protest in front of Hunsur town police station demanding action against all the accused. The body was handed over to the family on Sunday after a postmortem in KR hospital in Mysuru.

Title: Bat droppings, liquor bottles soil Mahabs, once again
Content: CHENNAI: The Modi-Xi meeting last October infused new life into Mamallapuram. The UNESCO-tagged monuments got a facelift and tourists flocked to the ancient town in droves — several taking photographs at the very spots the two leaders had posed. But 150 days later, Mamallapuram has gone back in time, again — the Pallava-era monuments are in a state of neglect, battling bat droppings and vandals.Drastic cut in the number of casual workers hired for maintenance and security by the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) has left these monuments unattended. For instance, bas-relief art works in Mahishamardhini rock cut Mandapam on the hillock in the backyard of Arjuna Penance is infested by bats. Their droppings on shoulders of the sculpture is rolling down to rest of the structure inside the cave, changing the colour of stone. It is one of the 35 monuments declared as a world heritage site by Unesco .A site at Saluvankuppam — that had thrived during Sangam, Pallava and Chola rule for about 1,300 years till 14th century AD — unfenced rocks with ancient Tamil inscriptions near Tiger Cave has become an open-air bar for tipplers. Empty liquor bottles are strewn around the ASI site comprising an excavated ancient Murugan temple on East Coast Road.M Manimaran, a resident of Pudhu Nemmeli Kuppam, said people passing by the spot often stop to unwind and drink.“A security guard takes care of the Tiger Cave and the temple. Another man used to clean trash every day but I did not see for one week,” said another villager.But last year, before the summit, all the monuments had come under a heightened security. ASI cleaned up the monuments and had deployed 43 workers — one per monument — for maintenance. However, only 13 individuals are on duty since January, ASI sources said. The security apparatus has been confined to ticketed monuments but none of these monuments has CCTV cameras for protection.Former ASI epigraphist S Rajavelu, whose discovery of Tamil inscriptions led to the excavation of ancient Murugan Temple at Saluvankuppam post the 2004 Tsunami, said monuments that were kept unattended would be destroyed.“The monolithic temples and stone art works at Mamallapuram are one of the oldest and rarest monuments in the world. If they are not subjected to periodic chemical conservation, our privileged heritage would be lost forever,” Rajavelu, an adjunct faculty at the department of history in Alagappa University , Karaikudi, said.When contacted, ASI superintending archaeologist of Chennai Circle A M V Subramanyam said ASI was “serious” about maintenance and conservation. “There is no neglect of monuments and the chemical branch of ASI would carry out conservation work in a couple of months at Mamallapuram. A private company has proposed to adopt the group of monuments at Mamallapuram under the Monument Mitras Scheme. This would facilitate in better maintenance soon,” he said.

Title: Pranay murder case: Maruti may have killed self due to stress, says family
Content:
Forensic and police officials outside Arya Vaishya Bhavan where Maruti Rao was found dead in Hyderabad on Sund... Read More

HYDERABAD: A chargesheet that had been served to T Maruti Rao on February 29, in connection with the alleged honour killing of his son-in law Pranay Kumar , is said to have caused Maruti severe stress. His family suspects that this could have led to him taking his life in an Arya Vysya Bhavan room on Sunday.

Maruti is known to have broken down several times regarding the issue, even in the presence of a local advocate.

The case was scheduled to heard by a local court on Tuesday and a decision on framing of charges was to be taken. Maruti was on the lookout for a suitable lawyer to fight his case and was travelling to Hyderabad to meet an advocate on Sunday. On his way to Hyderabad he purchased a bottle of pesticide which he consumed in the Arya Vysya Bhavan room.

Maruti’s daughter Amrutha had filed a petition in High Court several days ago requesting the court to direct the trial court to conclude the case at the earliest. The Nalgonda police had filed a chargesheet against Maruti and other accused in June 2019. Maruti who was out on bail for the last several months was initially arrested a few days after Pranay’s murder on the charge of engaging hired assailants.

Maruti’s brother Shravan said that the former was worried about not being given enough time to plan a response to the 1,600 page chargesheet. Shravan also denied all rumours of property disputes between the brothers.

“ We do not know the exact reason for his suicide but we suspect he committed suicide due to stress about the case,’’ Shravan said. Maruti’s wife Girija who broke down on seeing her husband’s body was consoled by a large number of people who visited Maruti’s residence in Miryalguda .

Responding to Amrutha’s reaction that her father might had committed suicide due to regret, Shravan asked, “What wrong did my brother do to feel regret?’’



In Video: Hyderabad: Telangana businessman in honour killing case commits suicide

Title: Hotel manager, owner booked for celebratory firing in Pilibhit
Content:
Representative image

PILIBHIT: A case was registered against the manager and the owner of a hotel and organisers for alleged celebratory firing during a wedding ceremony in Pilibhit city on the intervening night of February 26 and 27.

An FIR was registered at Sungarhi police station following a complaint lodged by inspector (crime) Naresh Pal Singh after a video of the firing went viral on social media platforms.

In the video clip, also available with TOI, a woman and a few men could be seen firing gunshots in the air from a revolver.

In his complaint, Singh said, “During the inquiry, it was found that a few inebriated women and men were firing in the air amid a congested gathering during the celebration. A misfiring could have resulted in a casualty. When inquired, hotel staff refused to disclose any information about the wedding organisers, which is a punishable offence.”

SHO Rajesh Kumar said an FIR was registered against the manager and the owner of the hotel and the organisers under sections 308 (attempt to commit culpable homicide) and 336 (act endangering life or personal safety of others) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) and relevant section of the Arms Act.

“The video has been included as evidence in the process of investigation,” added the SHO.

Title: Six migratory birds died in a week in Vidyaranyapuram
Content:
Mysuru: Six painted storks have died due to suspected Ranikhet disease in Vidyaranyapuram in the past 10 days. The veterinaries have sent the samples from the dead birds to Institute of Animal Health and Veterinary Biologicals in Bengaluru for confirmation of the disease.

Ranikhet is a viral disease found only in painted storks, a migratory bird.

Mahaveer Ramaprasad, corporator, Ward No 55 said: “In the past ten days, nearly eight to ten migratory birds have died. I immediately brought it to the notice of veterinarians who in turn visited the spot and sent the samples to Bengaluru.”

Dr Nagaraj, assistant director, veterinary hospital, Chamundipuram, told TOI “When we got information from the local corporator about the death of migratory birds, we rushed to the spot. These birds died on February 28 and 29. On Saturday too, two birds died. The migratory birds come to nearby sewage water bodies and later in the evening they stay on two trees. They leave in the morning. They might have died while resting in the trees. We are keeping a watch on other birds but we have not got any report about more deaths other than the six painted storks. If it is Ranikhet disease, it is not communicable to human beings. We have trimmed the tree and have told the concerned authorities to make it more hygienic. We are expecting results from the laboratory by Monday or Tuesday.”

He also said that it is the first time that deaths of painted storks have been reported in such numbers in Mysuru.

Tourists come with masks

Meanwhile, most tourists visiting Mysuru are found wearing masks, possibly as a preventive measure against coronavirus.

Narayanagowda, president of Hotel Owners Association, said: “Compared to last year, there is 20 to 30% less tourists this year. In February and March the inflow of tourists is generally less due to exams. However, this year, there is a further dip in tourist arrivals, possibly due to the scare over coronavirus.”

Title: Two back from Switzerland, quarantined in Naidu hospital amid coronavirus fear
Content: PUNE: Two women who recently returned from a novel coronavirus-hit country were quarantined at the PMC’s Naidu Infectious Diseases Hospital on Sunday after they complained of minor illness.The other travellers who were quarantined on Saturday tested negative for the contagion.“Both the women developed flu-like symptoms after returning from Switzerland. Their throat swab samples have been sent to the National Institute of Virology for testing. None of the travellers quarantined earlier have tested positive for the contagion so far,” public health expert Sanjeev Wavare of the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) said.At present, the Naidu hospital in Pune is the only designated isolation facility for residents/travellers returning from China and other affected countries. “The novel strain of the coronavirus has governments and health experts across the world on their toes. However, one of the oldest and most effective methods of containing a contagious virus has always been contact tracing. It is the most simple and efficacious way to contain the virus. But, in addition to health officials, it calls for participation from the society,” infectious diseases expert Sudhir Patsute said.In contact tracing method, health officials find out who the suspected persons (in this case, travellers returning from affected countries) have been in contact with. Thereafter, they are isolated and tested for the infection.Experts also stressed that the government should focus on spreading awareness about the novel coronavirus (COVID-19) infection at the moment, while quite a few neighbouring countries are scrambling to contain the contagion spread.Medical practitioner and health activist Abhijit More said, “At present, the main thrust is on screening travellers returning from affected countries, isolating those complaining of minor illness and testing them for the coronavirus infection. But, the focus on disseminating information to the masses, creating awareness and educating them via media needs to be strengthened. Mobile service provider companies, too, have started spreading awareness about preventive measures among the masses.”

Title: Gift Rampur Nawab’s antique arms to army museums, descendants told
Content:
The rare firearms are more than a century old

RAMPUR: A top Army officer has requested the grandson of the erstwhile Nawab of Rampur to consider gifting the recently-found large cache of rare antique guns, swords, knives and other items for display at Army museums.

The request from the Army brass comes against the backdrop of ongoing division of properties among the family members of the erstwhile Rampur Nawab. One after another strong rooms are being thrown open under the watchful eyes of district officials. After a prolonged legal battle, the Supreme Court had in July 2019 directed division of assets among the family members of the erstwhile Nawab.

In the first week of February, the locks of Armoury in the family’s Khasbagh Palace were opened. Hundreds of carved vintage guns, gem-studded swords, knives with handles made of precious stones were found in the room. According to collectors, it is a minefield of antiquity. The rare firearms are more than a century old and have been manufactured by renowned names, like Charles Lancaster, Henry Marton, Colt, Manchester , Rifle & Co., Buckgnot Enfield , Holland & Holland, W&C Scott London, HW Marton, CC Smith, RT Martimer, Greener, S & Smith, John Manton London, Thomas Smith, Wellington & Sons.

The letter, requesting the Nawab’s descendant to donate the antique arms, came from Lt Gen N S Raja Subramani, AVSM, SM, VSM General Officer Commanding (Uttar Bharat).

Quoting a TOI report into his letter written to Nawab Kazim Ali Khan-- the grandson of the erstwhile Nawab of Rampur-- the Army officer said, “May I, therefore request you to kindly consider gifting these items of military interest after consultation with all royal family members. I can assure you that these items will find a pride place in our museums and army institutions with a plaque of Rampur state.”

“I look forward to hearing from you,” Lt Gen Subramani said.

Nawab Kazim expressed willingness to donate the antique arms. But he is not the only stakeholder.

“I have received the letter from Lt Gen Subramani and it is a great honour for our family that the weaponry of our ancestors will be kept and displayed in the museums of the Indian Army. I have informed other family members about the letter. Soon, we will unanimously take decision on this matter.”

“If all goes well, the weaponry is expected to be displayed in the Army museums at Bareilly, Lucknow and New Delhi,” Kazim said.

“A few days ago, when the Armoury was opened, brigadier MS Jodha had come here. We had a discussion about the preservation of our rich cultural heritage. He told us that three large barrel guns of the erstwhile Rampur state are kept inside the Garwhal Regiment Museum at Lansdowne, Uttarakhand,” he said.

Rashid Khan, a local arms dealer, who has also been appointed by the administrative authorities to inspect and count the weapons of the erstwhile princely state, said, “The Armoury is invaluable in terms of antiquity. Muzzle-loading guns, pistols with gold carvings, revolvers, rifles with bayonets and swords forged out of rare metals together make up a collector’s dream.”

Title: As IMFL becomes costly, illicit liquor flows in Agency areas
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

VISAKHAPATNAM: The demand for illicit liquor is on the rise in Agency areas in Visakhapatnam and neighbouring districts following the implementation of the new excise policy and the rise in price of Indian-made foreign liquor ( IMFL ).

An excise official said, “Earlier there had been not much demand for such illicit liquor, such as arrack. But, since October 1, 2019, once the new liquor policy was implemented there has been a steady rise in the price of IMFL. So people, especially residents of the Agency areas, are switching to low quality and cheap illicit liquor.”

Officials also attributed the rise in demand for illicit liquor to the timings and number of ‘off shops’ — a retail store that sells only liquor. At present, government-run liquor shops remain open between 11 am to 8 pm.

In Agency areas, people have to travel long distances to buy IMFL as the number of liquor shops is few and far between.

This has spurred the growth of gangs that illegally manufacture liquor in areas such as Narsipatnam, Chintapalle, Koyyuru, Pederu and Araku.

Although officials of the excise and prohibition department organise raids at regular intervals, the sale of illicit liquor continues due to staff shortage in the department and the large Agency tracts that officials have to cover.

“Around 50 per cent of posts in the department are still vacant. The Agency areas in the districts are quite huge and often it becomes difficult to keep a strict vigil. If we raid one place, the next day they shift their hideouts to another place,” said a senior official.

Since mid-February the department has booked around 30 cases and arrested 20 persons. About 170 litres of arrack and 7,000 litres of jaggery were seized. One litre of arrack is made from 10 litres of fermented jaggery.

“Until and unless the government increases the time limit for ‘off shops’ and reduces the price of IMFL, this problem would persist and will increase. We have to keep a strict vigil to crackdown on this menace,” an official added.

Title: Failure to inform authorities about coronavirus ‘illegal & punishable’: MP government
Content: BHOPAL: The Madhya Pradesh government will make mandatory disclosure of travel history by visitors to or from Coronavirus-hit countries. Nondisclosure of travel history will be punishable. The move comes after the Kerala fiasco where a family that traveled to Italy returned without declaring their travel history to the country-hit and later they tested positive for the disease.Sources said failure to inform authorities about travel history to Covid 19 impacted countries and symptoms would be considered a crime. The rule would apply to Indian and foreign nationals.So far there has been no confirmed case of COVID-19 in MP. However, over 500 people have been placed under quarantine.Another measure for self-discourse, comes in backdrop of health department finding it tough to trace such people with travel history. In view of rising cases from France, USA, Spain, it was decided to have dedicated aerobridges of these countries also in addition to the 12 countries already on list of mandatory screening, according to union ministry of health.Health department screens people via a list provided by Indian bureau of immigration. However, the address and numbers can be outdated. In some cases contact numbers were found to be changed. Also permanent address of foreign nationals can be hard to trace.Union health ministry has asked AIIMS Bhopal administration to designate a part of the new emergency wing for setting up of isolation beds for suspected COVID-19 patients.This isolation facility will have a capacity to hold patients at a given point of time and once confirmed to be positive and later transferred to a designated facility. One such facility has been designated outside Bhopal in a private medical college.After the Rashtrapati Bhavan decided not to organise the traditional Holi gatherings as a precautionary measure, PM Narendra Modi tweeted that people must be careful about rumours being regarding COVID-19. The state government too has initiated a ‘Namaste, Aadaab’ campaign, asking people to avoid handshake.

Title: Bareilly: After electrocution, family buries girl in sand; survives
Content:
After regaining consciousness, the girl was shivering in cold as she was kept in the sand for hours

BAREILLY: A 17-year-old girl, who became unconscious after an electric shock, was buried neck-deep in sand for hours by her parents who believed that the “traditional therapy” practiced in the region would make her better. Nazma Khan was making cow-dung cakes in a field when she accidently touched a live wire. She became unconscious and was rescued by women who were also in the field in Zia Nagla village of Bareilly.

But, instead of taking the girl to a nearby hospital, the family members buried her into a heap of sand for hours. The girl had a narrow escape, a health official said, adding that the family had risked her life by believing in the “flawed practice”.

“The idea was to bring down her blood circulation and it works in most of the cases where there is a scope of recovery,” a local said. However, when contacted, chief medical officer of Bareilly, Dr Vineet Shukla, said, “This practice is wrong and may put the life of the victim at risk. The heart of such patient is affected first. We usually give CPR for revival.”

The girl, when she gained the consciousness, was shivering in cold after being kept in the sand for hours. “My daughter is fine now. The traditional treatment worked. We will take her to hospital if needed,” said Shahid Khan, the father.

When contacted, station house officer (SHO) of Shergarh police station, Ashwini Kumar said, “A team will be sent to the village to check the condition of the girl. They didn’t go to hospital and the electricity department was also not informed. We will look into the matter.”

Title: Exam fear drives boy to suicide
Content:
Rajkot: A Class XII science stream student ended life by hanging herself to death in her hostel room at Sarangpur in Barwala taluka of Botad district on Saturday. Primary investigation revealed that 17-year-old Akshar Patel was tense because of the board exams.

According to police Akshar was student of BAPS run Gurukul of Sarangpur village in Barwala.

He was studying with other students on Friday night and all of a sudden he went to his room and hanged himself.

The hostel authority found his body on Saturday morning.

Patel is resident of Jalalpur village in Dholka taluka of Ahmedabad district. Sources said that he did not want to pursue science stream after Class X, but took the admission at the insistence of his parents.

The police found nothing suspicious from the room of the deceased. His body has been sent for postmortem, police said.

Title: Mountaineering twins get Nari Shakti Puraskar by President
Content:
Dehradun: Mountaineering twins Tashi and Nungshi Malik were felicitated with the Nari Shakti Puraskar by President Ram Nath Kovind at the Rashtrapati Bhavan in New Delhi on Sunday.

The Dehradun-based twins were among the 15 women who were conferred with the award for their achievements. They were the first women twins to scale Mt Everest in 2013 which gave them the nickname of “Everest Twins”.

The twin sisters have earlier won India’s highest adventure honour — ‘Tenzing Norgay National Adventure Award’ in 2016 and ‘Global Young Explorers Award’ — from the President of Iceland in the same year.

Last year, they were among the nine women sportspersons recommended for the Padma Awards by the sports ministry.

On Sunday, the twins dedicated their award to the resilience and optimism of the girl child. “We climb on behalf of all girls, many of whom are denied their basic human right to survive,” Nungshi said.

Later in the day, they along with other awardees attended an interactive session with Prime Minister Narendra Modi at his official residence in New Delhi.

The Nari Shakti Puraskar is given every year to individuals, groups and institutions recognising their exceptional work towards the cause of women empowerment, especially of vulnerable and marginalised women.

Title: Coronavirus in Bhopal: Medical fraternity divided over efficacy of masks
Content:
Representative image

BHOPAL: Amid fears of Covid-19 spread, people are stocking up medicines and other emergency essentials anticipating a shortage, although medical experts are of the opinion that items like masks should only be used when a person has symptoms to avoid the spread.

After the Rashtrapati Bhavan decided not to organise the traditional Holi gatherings as a precautionary measure, PM Narendra Modi tweeted that people must be careful about rumours being regarding Covid-19. The state government too has initiated a ‘Namaste, Aadaab’ campaign, asking people to avoid handshake.

But Covid-19 hasn’t deterred people from Holi festivities, which are still being planned with a gusto. “We are organising a massive Holi event and Covid-19 would not dampen the event. We would be cautious for sure and appoint a doctor to detect people with symptoms of Covid-19 at the entrance,” said a Ratibad resort event manager Arun Malviya. Going for a dry and delightful Holi with no water balloons, paints and pichkaris is not on the agenda of many people in Bhopal.

Masks are available in stores, but do they really help is a question on the minds of many. “Doctors are not recommending the measure. Since no vaccines are currently available for Covid-19, the most effective weapon in such a situation seems to be a face mask,” said a pharmacist.

Medical community, however, is divided over the effectiveness of masks, indicating that hand-wash and sanitising surfaces is the best way to keep oneself safe. Going by estimates, there are around 22,000 face masks with the state help department. However, N95 masks are selling for upwards of Rs 300 in some stores.

“There is a spurt in demand of masks. However, it is not like Delhi where things like hand sanitizers have vanished from the market,” said Adtiya, a pharmacist. “Medical supplies for now is being maintained. There are rumours about short supply of essential salts and reagents, but we are witnessing any shortage.”

A representative of MP medical suppliers association Lalit Jain said, “We have urged all sellers and retailers not to hoard and keep the supply lines open, so that prices don’t shoot up.”

Title: Two die, six injured by electrocution in US Nagar
Content:
Rudrapur: Two men were killed and six others seriously singed while trying to fix a flag on a bamboo pole for “Holika Dahan” ceremony. The bamboo was wet and came in contact with a high-tension wire above, said police.

The incident took place around 10 pm in Amba Vihar colony, located at Chaiti turn on Bazpur road in Kashipur, Udham Singh Nagar district.

The deceased have been identified as Abhishek Sinha, 26, a practising lawyer, and Lokesh Chandra Pargain, 21. According to police, the men were preparing for Holi prayers the next day and were setting up a flag near the point for “holika dahan”.
