While Abhishek died on the spot, Lokesh and six others were taken to a hospital. Lokesh died on the way after he was referred to a higher center in Moradabad, Uttar Pradesh. The others received treatment at private hospitals in Kashipur.

Title: Coronavirus in Pune: Pune residents told to exercise caution while playing Holi
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: In the wake of the coronavirus outbreak, federations of housing societies have issued notices telling residents to exercise caution while playing Holi this year.

Federations across Pune and Pimpri Chinchwad have advised members to be careful while playing Holi.

Suhas Patwardhan, chairperson of the Pune district cooperative housing federation, said, “In Pune, thankfully there aren’t any cases of novel coronavirus (COVID-19). So, we are telling everyone to be cautious while playing,” he said. The federation has over 18,000 registered cooperative societies.

About the precautions they had issued, Patwardhan said, “We have told people to avoid physical contact. Essentially, we are not discouraging them from playing. But, we are telling them to exercise caution.”

Patwardhan said the public should be careful and avoid crowds. “Most people are aware of the precautions,” he added.

Meanwhile, the Pimpri Chinchwad Housing Societies Federation has also issued similar instructions.

Sudhir Deshmukh, a member, said there were over 100 housing societies registered.

“Rather than discouraging them, we are asking people to be careful while playing. Apart from the usual instructions of playing Holi with eco-friendly colours and not wasting water, we are also telling them that if a person is not feeling well, then s/he should not be playing at all. They should take due care,” Deshmukh said.

Some societies such as the Kondhwa-based Sai Dwarkamai Cooperative Housing Society have organized games for children on Tuesday to avoid the Holi celebrations.

Kanta Kulkarni, chairperson of the housing society, said they had taken a conscious decision to not play Holi this year.

“We have a total of 94 flats and the idea was to spread awareness about coronavirus. We explained to the children why we were not playing Holi and playing games instead to make them understand,” Kulkarni said.

She said residents needed to be alert. “We need to make the children alert too. We will burn a bonfire, but we will not play with the colours. Children love to play. So, instead of Holi celebrations, we have organized housie for them to play,” Kulkarni added.

Title: Hawkers, trash return to pavements of ancient town
Content:
CHENNAI: Months after the state and central governments spent crores to renovate Mamallapuram, hawkers have returned to the stake claim of the footpaths. They have encroached the platforms and portions of the carriageway, selling stone sculptures, chappals, snacks and knickknacks.

Ahead of the Modi-Xi meeting, the state government had evicted more than 100 hawkers from the pavements around the Shore Temple.

With the coastal town bustling with tourists throughout the year, especially on weekends, tourists often jostle for space with two-wheelers on the roads and hawkers on the pavements.

Mamallapuram-based tour guide R Boobalan said tourists have begun to complain about poor maintenance and encroachments. “It is no more the renovated Mamallapuram,” he said. Illegal and haphazard parking too is back. Vehicles are parked in no-parking zones opposite Arjuna’s Penance and Krishna Butter Ball, he said.

The civic infrastructure of the town panchayat is proving insufficient to handle the pressure. According official sources with Mamallapuram Town Panchayat, the volume of garbage has increased by one tonne following the jump in the number of tourists.

“We have increased the number of shifts for conservancy workers to ensure trash is removed throughout the day,” a town panchayat official said.

But the beach behind the Shore Temple and the pathway leading to it tell a different story. Littered with trash, the sands have become a no-go zone for tourists who want to go on a bare-feet walk like the Prime Minister, and maybe shoot an Instagram video.

Title: When Dancing Girl from Mohenjo-daro was in town
Content:
The Dancing Girl recreated by Majiah Murmu

CHENNAI: A couple of months ago, when Majhia Murmu was asked to make the replica of the Indus Dancing Girl to be presented to the guests as part of a book launch in the city, he was clueless. Even though this Bhubaneswar-based Dokra artist is known for his stunning lost-wax sculptures, he felt a bit embarrassed mainly because of the subject being a prehistoric bronze sculpture (2300-1750 BC) found in the Indus Valley Civilisation city of Mohenjo-daro (in today’s Sindh province of Pakistan).

It was British archaeologist Ernest Mackay who discovered the Dancing Girl in Mohenjo Daro in 1926. The ancient artefact is displayed at the National Museum, New Delhi . The Dancing Girl was one of the two rare ancient bronze sculptures (the other being the figure of a girl currently displayed at Karachi Museum) that was found with some notable and flexible features.

Murmu and his friend Anam Tudu started collecting details about the Dancing Girl. Once started, Murmu didn’t look back. Result: 75 pieces of the Dancing Girl. “I made many sculptures using the lost wax process. But this was a bit challenging mainly because of the significance of the subject. The initial ones didn’t come out well, but I didn’t give up,” said Murmu. Both Murmu and Tudu belong to the Santal tribal community of Mayurbhanj district of Odisha.

The lost wax process to make sculptures has been in existence since the time of Indus Valley Civilization. It is a method of metal casting in which a molten metal is poured into a mould that has been created by means of a wax model. “We had the book launch in Chennai in December 2019 and we wanted to give mementos to people who contributed to this project. We decided to give the replica of Dancing Girl figurine as the memento. When we distributed the statuettes, many praised the way they were recreated by Murmu,” said G Sundar, director of the Roja Muthiah Research Library in the city.

Fascinated by the talent of Murmu, Sundar decided to meet the artist when he visited Bhubaneswar. “I was introduced to a man wearing a T-shirt with dark glasses. He seemed to be cleaning the rough surfaces on a sculpture. When I asked him, he showed me how it was made and to my surprise I found that he was not making a single die for making many pieces,” said Sundar. “The lost wax process involves making as many numbers of wax models to create so many numbers of actual figurines out of them. It’s a laborious process and each sample was made with perfection.”

The production starts with collection of raw materials, which include ant hill clay, fire clay, firewood, paddy straw, cow dung, charcoal, sand, bee wax, raw brass among others. “There are four stages. The unfinished replica needs to be kept out for drying in the sunlight. We use bamboo knife for polishing the half-dried products. We had to do it with extra care as this is a prehistoric model,” said Murmu.

Title: Drunk UP constable suspended for firing in air over tiff with colleague
Content:
Representative image

BAREILLY: Constable Ompal Singh has been suspended for allegedly firing at least seven rounds in the air with his service pistol following a heated argument with his colleague near Ganeshpur Devipura on Saturday night.

The constable was deployed at police response vehicle 292 (PRV) in Moradabad district. His medical report suggested that he was drunk. The report was forwarded to senior superintendent of police (SSP) Amit Pathak following which the SSP suspended the constable and ordered a probe. The incident took place under Bhojpur police station limits. SHO Satraj Singh said the constable’s service weapon was taken away immediately after the incident.

The PRV 292 was stationed around 2km from a police station on the Moradabad-Ramnagar highway. After the incident, the PRV’s driver Vipendra drove the vehicle to the nearest police station and informed the SHO.

“The constable had a heated argument with sub-commander Vipin Premi which escalated into a verbal fight and then in a fit of rage constable Ompal pulled out his pistol and fired seven rounds in the air, leaving the other cop stunned,” the SHO said.

The SSP said that consuming alcohol on duty and firing indiscriminately was an act of gross indiscipline. “Area circle officer of Thakurdwara is tasked to probe into the matter. As of now, the constable has been suspended and further action will be taken once the probe is completed,” the SSP added.

Title: Coronavirus in Tirupati: Two persons test negative for Coronavirus in Tirupati
Content: TIRUPATI: Two persons who returned from abroad and admitted to the isolation ward at SVRR Government General Hospital in Tirupati tested negative for coronavirus on Sunday.The swab samples of the two persons who returned from Singapore and Germany tested negative at the Sri Venkateswara Institute of Medical Sciences in Tirupati, said the medical superintendent of SVRR Hospital Dr N V Ramanaiah.So far no positive case of coronavirus has been reported in the state and the state health department has taken several measures to prevent the spread of the disease.

Title: Cloud cover in sight throughout the week in Pune
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The India Meteorological Department (IMD) has forecast cloudy sky conditions in the city for most days during this week.

On Sunday, Shivajinagar and Lohegaon observatories recorded 33.1ºC and 33.8ºC temperatures, which were below normal by 1.4 and 1.2 notches, respectively.

IMD officials said the minimum temperatures would see a marginal rise and hover around 17ºC during the next few days. The maximum temperatures are expected to be around 32ºC-33ºC.

“There will be thunder and lightning , accompanied by light to moderate rain, at isolated places in Marathwada and Vidarbha on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday. Vidarbha may witness hailstorms on Wednesday,” an IMD official said.

The recent cold and wet spell in the norther part of the India has influenced the weather in Maharashtra, IMD authorities said.

At present, the only weather system that is affecting Maharashtra is a cyclonic circulation over north Karnataka, the IMD officials said. On Sunday, Akola was the hottest city (maximum temperature 36ºC) in Maharashtra.

Title: Jaipur: Ranthambore tiger that strayed into MHTR grievously hurt
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: Male tiger, MT-3 that travelled around 150km from Ranthambore Tiger Reserve (RTR) is suffering a grievous injury on its head.

The wound is now infested with maggots and a forest team is trying to trace the big cat to treat the injury. According to sources, “On Saturday, the tracking team saw the wound on the forehead of MT-3. It was bleeding and the animal cannot lick the wound as it is out of reach.”

Following this, the team from Ranthambore was pressed into operation to rescue the animal. However, the search and rescue operation is yet to be successful as the tiger is yet to be found. “Blood samples were collected from the area where the tiger was last seen. It appears the wound is maggot-infested,” a source said.

As the injury appeared on the peculiar spot, the forest officials are not ruling out the possibility of a snare. “There are many villages, including Ghati and Mashalpura, which have a history of snaring. The demand for bushmeat has always been there and local poachers often use this technique. It is possible the tiger got entangled in the snares meant to kill herbivores for bushmeat by local poachers,” the source added.

T-98, which is now known as MT-3, is the offspring of T-60 of RTR and is around four years old.

The injury has also exposed the glaring chink in tiger monitoring at MHTR as the collar of the tiger is not functioning. “Had the collar been working, the tiger could have been traced and timely treatment could have been provided,” said a forest staff on condition of anonymity

Male tiger T-98 that had strayed from and reached Ghati village of Mukundra Hills Tiger Reserve (MHTR) in February last year was collared and released in the Darrah range, but the collar is not functioning at present which is making it difficult to locate the tiger.

Title: Gujarat: Four persons booked for spying near Naliya IAF base
Content:
Representative Image

RAJKOT: Four persons, including a minor, were booked under the Official Secrets Act for spying after they allegedly clicked photographs near the Naliya Indian Air Force (IAF) base in Kutch district.

It was in January that the IAF personnel had caught the four persons on the outskirts of Mothala village of Abdasa taluka and handed them to the police over suspicion that they were spying the sensitive defence area.

Police said the four identified as Rafiq Azam (23), Abbas Padhiyar (19), Arbaz Sumra (20) and a 17-year-old were booked on Sunday. Padhiyar and the minor are students, while Sumra runs a cellphone shop in Naliya.

The four are, however, yet to be arrested.

“The accused were allegedly taking photographs and videos of the radar and air strip of the IAF base by climbing up the terrace of a house near the IAF base. We are probing whether they have sent the photographs to someone in Pakistan or elsewhere,” said A R Zala, sub-inspector with Bhuj special operation group (SOG).

At the time of detention, cops seized two digital cameras and four smart phones from their possession.

“We have sent the cameras and cellphones for forensic examination. We are also probing the social media accounts of the four to find out with whom they were in touch,” added Zala.

An IAF jawan, manning the watch tower of the IAF base, spotted the four men with the cameras on the terrace of the house and saw them clicking photos of the prohibited area on January 29.

The jawan then alerted his seniors who sent IAF personnel to the spot and detained the four. The IAF then handed them over to the Naliya police station, which took the application of complaint in this regard and gave the investigation to Bhuj SOG.

However, as espionage charges could not be established against four at that time, the cops had let them off. But, after Bhuj SOG investigated the case and found that that they had indeed taken photographs and videos for espionage. A case was registered under section 3 of the Official Secrets Act that deals with penalties for spying at a prohibited place.

Title: UP: Car carrying three cow carcasses overturns
Content:
Representative image

PILIBHIT: Carcasses of three cows were recovered from a car that had overturned in a roadside ditch near Kanjanath Patti village under Jahanabad police station on Sunday. The car was heading towards Richha town in Bareilly district from Pilibhit. After the accident, the car driver fled the spot. Police have impounded the car and lodged an FIR in the matter.

Mani Ram, SHO, the carcasses were buried after their autopsy.

An FIR was lodged against unidentified person under various provisions of the Uttar Pradesh Prevention of Cow Slaughtering Act, the SHO added.

Title: A swim with pals after exam turns fatal for engg student
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The Haveli police found an engineering student’s body from the Mutha Right Bank canal along the Nanded-Dhayari Road early on Sunday, nearly 12 hours after he was washed away during a swim with his college friends.

Inspector Ashok Shelke of the Haveli police said Jayesh Ramrao Bhandare (23) was from Nashik and staying at Vadgaon Budruk. He said Bhandare was a third-year engineering student at a college in Narhe.

The officer said Bhandare and four of his friends wrote the final paper of their third-year exam on Saturday and reached the canal site on bikes. Though three of them knew swimming, Bhandare and another didn’t know. They waded into the water on seeing the low level in the canal.

The level in the canal suddenly increased, as the irrigation department released more water into it. Bhandare was washed away by its current. His friends tried to save him, but in vain. They alerted the Pune Metropolitan Region Development Authority ’s fire brigade and the Haveli police. Fire brigade and police officers continued a search operation till late in the night.

Shelke said “We urged the irrigation department to not release water for a while. As the water level reduced, Bhandare’s friends reached the site and his body was found nearly 800m from the accident spot.”

Title: MP Government moots law to make construction on private land legal
Content:
Representative image

BHOPAL: Dealing with haphazard diversion of land and growth of illegal colonies over the past 15-years, Madhya Pradesh government is mooting a legislation that would provide relief and legalise constructions on private land that was not in planned area.

Sources said that this order would be applicable only for individual constructions and not illegal colonisers.

“Master plan is a guideline document. As for illegal colonies, government is looking at a legislation that would cater to legalise constructions on private land,” said MP urban administration, principal secretary, Sanjay Dubey.

While the measure would not impact large colonies, in the short term, it would provide relief to independent constructions, to bring them into some sort of planned town development, indicate urban development experts.

“Choice of location near to work place or away from workplace is required to have its place in BDP 2031, these flexibilities will reduce the growth of illegal colonies and unplanned urban sprawl. In either case, public transport is the prime concern to be integrated with residential areas. The already vacant houses also need to be reviewed in terms of accessibility to public transport and infrastructure provisions,” states the draft Bhopal master plan 2031.

The new proposal would be a tight walk as similar measures have been struck down by court. Under the new proposal to be tabled in Vidhan Sabha , illegal encroachments or development on government land would not be covered.

After the introduction of Bhopal master plan 2031 this week, a detailed zonal plan is expected. It would provide legal impetus to the measure. Municipal Corporation Act , 1956, or M P Municipality Act, 1961, has no provision for regularization of illegal colonies.

Earlier too, urban development department has mooted plans to legalise colonies by charging 20% development charges for repairing sewage line and road and water supply.

Last year, Madhya Pradesh, the Gwalior bench of MP High Court struck down the decision of previous BJP government led by Shivraj Singh Chouhan to legalise about 4,000 colonies. MPHC bench declared rule 15A framed by the state government for regularization of illegal colonies as ‘ultra vires’ (done beyond its legal power).

Title: 100 extra buses on Bareilly-Delhi route for Holi
Content:
A UPSRTC bus

BAREILLY: Uttar Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation (UPSRTC) has added 100 extra buses on Bareilly-Delhi route to facilitate passengers travelling during the festival period. The extra buses will ply on the route till March 15.

Speaking with TOI, the roadways Bareilly division regional manager, SK Banderjee, said, “Considering the heavy rush of passengers, specially who travel on the Bareilly-Delhi route during the festival period, the transport corporation has added around 100 buses to this route. Besides, frequency of buses has been increased on other long routes, including Bareilly-Lucknow, Bareilly-Agra, Bareilly-Kanpur and Bareilly-Dehradun, to facilitate passengers till March 15.”

To ensure attendance of roadways’ employees during the festive period, UPSRTC has also introduced an incentive scheme for its drivers, conductors and workshop staff. The regional manager said, “Drivers and conductors who will remain present on duty till March 15 and cover 300 km per day will be given Rs 4,000 as an incentive. Besides, contractual drivers and conductors will be given Rs 3,150 as incentive for remaining on duty during the period.”

Officials said additional incentive of 55 paise per km will be given, especially to contractual drivers and conductors, for covering more than 300 km per day during the festival period. Workshop and depot staff will be given Rs 1,200 as incentive for working constantly during the festival period.

Title: Amroha police seize car carrying beef; accused at large
Content:
BIJNOR: Amroha police seized a car loaded with beef near Bamboogarh-Kaisla Bypass Road in Bijnor on Sunday.

The incident took place after the police suspected the car and tried to halt it for routine checking. The driver and another person, who were in the car, fled, and the police have ordered a probe.

According to Amroha Dehat station house officer, Arihant Siddharth , the police were checking vehicles on the wee hours at Kailsa bypass area.

“Police spotted a car close to a swimming pool. Police tried to stop the vehicle, but they did not stop. After a brief chase, police intercepted the car. Meanwhile, the driver and another person escaped,” he said.

Police have seized the car laden with around two quintals of flesh. They are yet to determine whether the meat was of cow or bull. A case has been registered against unidentified persons.

In another case, Bijnor police seized around 59kg of flesh during a random vehicle checking in Chandpur area. The accused are still at large.

Title: Pune Municipal Corporation builds 310 ‘best toilets’ to regain lost position in national competition
Content:
Representative image

Pune: The civic body claims to have completed the target of converting 25% public toilets into ‘best toilets’, in order to regain its lost position in the nation-wide annual sanitation competition, Swachh Sarvekshan .

The move, the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) officials said, would help the civic body in improving the city’s ranking in Swachh Sarvekshan. The city had dropped to a worrisome 37th position last year.

A total of 63 parameters was defined by the Union government to declare a public toilet ‘best’. The set parameters stated that for better ranking, any city would need to have at least 25% ‘best toilets’. Based on the number of public toilets in the city, the civic body had to convert 310 out of 1,124 public toilets into such facilities.

“The 310 toilets were revamped to meet the parameters set by the Centre. Facilities such as sanitary napkin dispenser and incinerators have been provided in these toilets. Other mandatory facilities including basins, urinals and disabled friendly sanitation facilities, have also been provided,” a PMC official said.

“These units are located across the city. Besides the key locations, such toilets can also be seen in some of the remote areas. The head office of PMC’s solid waste management and ward offices have jointly built these facilities. The civic body has spent nearly Rs10.5 crore on the initiative. Each new toilet has cost us nearly Rs3.5 lakh.” the official added.

“The city could not get ODF+ revalidation around six months ago. So, the PMC decided to improve the public sanitation facility and applied for higher certification, that is ODF++,” head of PMC’s solid waste management department Dnyaneshwar Molak said.

He said a third party inspection committee visited the toilets. “They inspected 49 facilities across the city, following which ODF++ certification was awarded. It has paved the way to fight for the position of the cleanest city in the country,” Molak added.

Title: Disposal bags must with sanitary napkins from next Jan: Javadekar
Content:
PUNE: All the sanitary napkin manufactures will have to provide disposal bags. The Union government has planned such a policy, Union minister of environment Prakash Javadekar said on Sunday.

He was speaking at a programme organised by SWaCH, a waste management collective, in Pune. “From January 2021, sanitary pad manufacturers will have to provide packets for disposal of each pad,” he said. Mayor Murlidhar Mohol was also present for the programme.

Production and usage of sanitary napkins and diapers have increased but they are still being discarded in a way which is harmful to waste pickers, the minister said.

“We will implement the rule that from January 2021 all sanitary pad manufacturers will have to give degradable bags for disposal of each sanitary napkin. This rule is already in existence, but is not being followed by the manufacturers,” he said.

Javadekar said a decentralized model was needed wherein garbage by educational institutes and housing societies should be disposed of on the premises itself.

“The rule for compulsory picking of garbage and disposal for municipal towns will be made compulsory for all the habitations with more than 3,000 population,” he added.

He said he will fund the construction of 50 big and 50 small garbage sheds designed by SWaCH. It will be given from his MP local area development funds.

SWaCH founder Laxmi Narayan said money spent on transport of garbage should be utilized in encouraging people to make garbage into compost at the source. “Pune needs a facility that buys plastic waste which will be an incentive for waste pickers and segregation,” she said.

Rani Shivsaran, a SWaCH member, said a permanent shed for sorting of garbage at each ward was necessary. Initiatives like V-Collect help pick up items lying unused from homes and prove additional source of income.

The civic body has been taking a slew of measures for efficient waste management in the city. Citizens willing to process wet garbage generated at home can seek funds from the Pune Municipal Corporation .

The civic body will partly fund the two-bucket vermi compost units for citizens. The units can be set up in independent houses and residential flats. Based on the size, a unit can cost between Rs 4,000 and Rs 10,000. The initiative has been taken to promote segregation and disposal of garbage at source.

Title: Delhi: In times of coronavirus, commuters and drivers wary of each other
Content:
While commuters see cabs as a safer option, they are not sure whether they are also totally safe (Photo: ANI)

NEW DELHI: Ritesh Sharma regularly takes the cab to work. But in the midst of the novel coronavirus scare, the Vasant Kunj resident has started wearing a mask for his trips to central Delhi and back. “New cases are being detected every day. While I find app-based cabs a safer travel option than public transport, I’m still apprehensive. These cabs ferry a large number of passengers through the day and I’m worried whether the drivers keep the vehicles sanitised,” Sharma said. “I hope wearing a mask helps, but there is still the problem of touching surfaces like door handles and locks,” he said.

Suchismita Das, a Malviya Nagar resident, says she has had to forgo the cheaper alternative of shared rides. “For now, I have stopped taking shared rides. As you can’t completely avoid touching common surfaces, I vigorously clean my hands with a sanitiser as soon as I get down,” she said.

Drivers, too, are a wary lot, especially of passengers who might have travelled abroad recently. “Drivers working on both Ola and Uber platforms pick up and drop a large number of passengers at Delhi airport,” said Deepak Saraswat, general secretary of Sarvodaya Driver Association of Delhi. “How will a driver know if the passenger is coming back from a trip to a country like Italy, Thailand or Malaysia?” Sanjay Samrat, president of Delhi Taxi, Tourist Transporters and Tour Operators Association, met Union health minister Harsh Vardhan on Saturday to request stringent health checks at Delhi airport to ensure that no traveller infected by novel coronavirus uses tourist cabs or buses.

Cab aggregators Ola and Uber said they were taking necessary measures and also sensitising their driver-partners about precautions. “Our walk-in centres across cities have been equipped with a steady supply of health advisory material, sanitisers and masks, which can be picked up and used by the driver-partners to ensure the highest levels of cleanliness for themselves and their vehicles. This will help create a safer and cleaner ride experience for our customers as well,” Ola said in a statement. The company said that it was reiterating the importance of personal hygiene through a dedicated preparedness module for driver-partners to create awareness.

“We urge customers to join us in this initiative by adhering to health guidelines including personal hygiene and seeking immediate medical attention if they have flu-like symptoms. This will go a long way in ensuring their well-being as well as that of fellow passengers and driver-partners,” it added.

An Uber spokesperson said: “We are always working to help ensure the safety of our employees and everyone on the Uber platform, and we continue to be concerned by the ongoing spread of coronavirus. We have formed a dedicated team of Uber operations, security and safety executives, guided by the advice of a consulting public health expert, to respond as needed in each market where we operate in South Asia. We remain in constant contact with local public health authorities and will continue to follow their advice. We have also communicated their recommendations to our drivers.”

Saraswat, however, claimed that even if the drivers were apprehensive of picking up a passenger, they couldn’t expect any help from the companies. “Not only would the driver have to pay a cancellation charge, but he would also be ‘offloaded’ from the aggregator platform. It takes three to four days for drivers to get themselves back into the system in such cases,” he said.

But Uber insisted that if driver-partners felt uncomfortable about picking up a passenger for safety reasons, they could choose not to accept or cancel the trip. However, they can’t discriminate against anyone based on their race or nationality. Ola said that its Partner Care teams and Safety Response teams were available 24x7 for any concerns that might arise for driver-partners and customers respectively. “We encourage everyone to proactively report any instance that may be symptomatic for us to help action and guide appropriately,” the company said.

Kamaljeet Gill, president of Sarvodaya Driver Association of Delhi, said: “When it comes to the coronavirus scare, drivers are at the forefront as we have to pick up passengers from hospitals and airports and you don’t know who could be infected. Our association has distributed hand sanitisers and masks to drivers and also asked them to keep their cabs clean.”

Title: Three held, 21 red sanders logs seized
Content:
Red sanders anti-smuggling task force arrested three smugglers and seized 21 red sanders logs in two separate incidents near Tirupati on Sunday.

According to rask force DSP Venkataiah, information was received that red sanders smugglers were loading logs into their vehicles to smuggle them away near Srivari mettu forest area near Tirupati on Sunday.

The team led by DSP Venkataiah and inspector Subramanyam who reached the spot noticed about 20 smugglers loading logs into two vehicles.

The smugglers who realised there was movement of task force personnel, tried to abscond. But the task force team chased their vehicle and upon inspecting the vehicle, seized 17 red sanders logs and the vehicle used for the smuggling activity.

Two smugglers identified as Yezhumalai (35) and Shankar (51) were arrested by the task force sleuths.

Earlier in the day, task force teams combing the forest area near Srivari mettu arrested one smuggler identified as Chinna Swamy and seized four red sanders logs.

Title: Ladies, finding it hard to commute? Rosto Ride Share will steer the way
Content:
Panaji: For women commuters, this will certainly be a game changer.

While the concept of carpooling is popular in other countries, the idea is catching up in India only in recent times, albeit in the metros. For Goan women, especially those without a car, daily commute and navigation through traffic can now come at a low cost, or even free of cost, through the Rosto Ride Share.

Through this initiative, women in Goa can text on the number 9922411239 on WhatsApp to avail of a ride to their desired destination within the state.

The initiative was launched on Women’s Day at Porvorim-based Sensible Earth, a centre that promotes sustainable living. “Mobility is one of the biggest challenges that disempowers women in Goa. It is either not safe, unreliable or too expensive, and we feel that women need the freedom to move around freely,” said Sanjiv Khandelwal, co-founder of Sensible Earth.

The technology, however, doesn’t support tracking the vehicle’s movement much like app-based aggregators Ola and Uber in other states do. “From a safety point of view, however, we are getting everyone’s proof of identity and contact information before they’re added to the group. Therefore, there is a fair amount of security from that point built in,” Khandelwal said.

The idea of Rosto Ride Share germinated as an offshoot of activist Cecille Rodrigues’ #RostoGoa campaign wherein she first highlighted potholes in a dance-video that went viral, and then painted stripes on speed breakers to make them conspicuous, and the roads, safer. “It’s very important to have less traffic on the road. We must therefore take up the initiative of carpooling or bike-pooling for sustainable living,” Rodrigues said, adding that women can avail of this service not only to go to work but also if they require to attend events or parties that may end late.

“Through this initiative, we’re also trying to help out senior citizens and women who finish their work late and wait for buses. The public transportation system in Goa is in a very bad situation, so we as women drivers can stop by and ask other women if they require a ride through this platform,” she added.

As the initiative gathers momentum and gains popularity, Rodrigues intends to expand this service by starting an app for pick-up and drop services for women.

Title: Pune: Auto driver helps return jewellery worth Rs 7.57 lakh
Content:
Bharat Kisan Bhosale (fouth from left) found Deepak Pandurang Chitrala’s (in a blue jumper) bag with the help ... Read More

PUNE: An autorickshaw driver picked up an abandoned bag, containing gold jewellery worth Rs7.57 lakh, from a prepaid booth near the railway station on Sunday morning, took it to the GRP station and tracked down the owner with the help of the police.

Railway passenger Deepak Pandurang Chitrala, a resident of Hadapsar, arrived at the Pune railway station early on Sunday morning and went to the prepaid booth to book an autorickshaw, said an officer of the Government Railway Police (GRP).

He kept the bag on the floor while booking the autorickshaw but forgot and absent-mindedly left it in the booth, a police officer said.

Autorickshaw driver Bharat Kisan Bhosale saw the bag and took it to the police station. The police found gold ornaments in the bag.

The police then checked the bag for some clues to track down its owner, said inspector Sureshsingh Gaud of GRP.

On realizing that the bag belonged to a man from Hadapsar, a police team headed towards Hadapsar. In meantime, another team found Chitrala roaming the area in search of his bag.

The police team verified his identity, had Chitrala check all the ornaments and then handed the bag to him, a police officer said.

Title: Clarify stand on NPR: MKSS to Rajasthan government
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: The Mazdoor Kisan Shakti Sangathan (MKSS) has asked the state government to clarify its position on National Population Register (NPR) which is starting from April. MKSS was celebrating International Women’s Day at Shaheed Smarak which has become the epicentre of anti-CAA protests in Rajasthan. Activist Aruna Roy, while addressing the women here, said that NPR is linked with NRC and states should vehemently oppose it.

“The government should clarify as to what efforts it is making to stop the NPR exercise in the state,” said Roy. Echoing her concern, Nikhil Dey asked the state to take strong action against NPR just like it has taken against CAA . Roy called the movement that has been running from the past one month as historic and unprecedented.

“The movement is being collectively led by brave women. It has restored people’s faith in democracy and till the aim is achieved it should continue,” said Roy, who has been frequenting the protest site which is mainly run by Muslim women. She said that this movement filled women with confidence.

Anam Hussain, a second-year student who has been visiting the protest site regularly said that this International Women’s Day is the most memorable one. “My parents were very protective and had never allowed me to participate in any voluntary activity until the start of anti-CAA protest. Even I was not aware that my oratory skills are highly convincing,” said Hussain.

Several other women groups celebrated programmes at the protest site. Most of the protesters here got to know for the first time that March 8 is observed as Women’s Day.Meanwhile, members of at least 20 ‘Save the Constitution’ bodies which are holding anti-CAA protest called for a meeting at Muslim Musafirkhana to discuss the future course of action. The meeting was held to bring all the movements on a common platform.

Title: Bhopal: Missing Congress MLA back, says ‘no grouse with Nath government’
Content:
Representative image

BHOPAL: Another of the ‘missing’ MLAs, Congress veteran Bisahulal Singh, returned to Bhopal on Sunday, suggesting that the weeklong political storm over alleged horse-trading’ may be on the wane. On Saturday, Independent MLA Surendra Singh Shera had come back to the fold.

Bisahulal Singh, four-time MLA from Annuppur, flew from Bengaluru to Indore, escorted by tourism minister Surendra Singh Baghel on Sunday afternoon. At Indore, he was greeted by home minister Bala Bachchan and brought to Bhopal in a state aircraft.

After a lengthy meeting with chief minister Kamal Nath at his residence in the evening, Singh told mediapersons that he was with the Nath government.

Coming out of CM House with finance minister Tarun Bhanot , Singh said “I was on a pilgrimage. I was moving around, visiting places of worship. I have no grouse against the Kamal Nath government. I am with the government.”

Asked if he was promised a ministerial berth by the CM or he had asked for it, Singh said: “It is for the chief minister to decide.” The 70-year-old Congress veteran denied that he was taken forcibly to Bengaluru by BJP leaders, or that he was kept captive by BJP.

Singh’s nephew, who lives in Bhopal, had filed an FIR at TT Nagar police station, fearing the elderly MLA had been abducted.

With Singh back, there are two more Congress MLAs ‘missing’ -- Hardeep Singh Dang, who had sent his resignation on March 6, and Raghuraj Singh Kansana.

There was a buzz in Congress circles since Shera’s return on Saturday that at least one Congress MLA would be back within 24 hours. On Sunday morning, Congress tweeted pictures of the tourism minister sitting with Singh at Bengaluru airport.

Congress media coordinator Narendra Saluja, tweeted pictures of Singh with Baghel and wrote: “Woh teen din se BJP ke changul mein phanse the (he was in BJP’s grip for three days).”

On March 5, when higher education minister Jitu Patwari had returned to Bhopal with three MLAs – BSP’s Ram Bai and Sanjeev Kushwah and SP’s Rajesh Kumar Shukla -- senior Congress leader Digvijaya Singh had said that four other MLAs, who were in Manesar, had been “taken to Bengaluru by BJP leaders” and that Bisahulal Singh was “bodily lifted and taken against his will”.

However, just like the other MLAs who have returned, Bisahulal Singh also denied that he was taken by BJP or held against his wishes. Dang and Kansana are apparently lodged at a hotel in Bengaluru. Congress sources say the party has established contact with them.

Title: Pune man uses duplicate key, steals Rs 9.7 lakh from ATM
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: An unidentified man stole Rs9.71 lakh by opening the cash-dispensing unit of an ATM in using a duplicate key. The incident occurred in Talegaon Dabhade on February 22, while the bank’s branch manager lodged an FIR with the police on Saturday.

“The bank officials approached the police almost after gap of 14 days with their complaint because the theft did not come to light immediately. A study of the bank server log revealed that there was some misappropriation of cash from the ATM unit,” police inspector Shahji Pawar of Talegaon Dabhade police said, explaining the delay in filing the complaint.

“Further, the machine was not damaged and there were no signs of any online tampering with the machine. So, the theft remained under the bank’s radar,” he said.

“However, there were fewer withdrawals and more deposits in the ATM unit, and the bank’s server highlighted the issue,” he explained.

Following this, the bank officials studied the CCTV footage of the ATM kiosk and saw the man stealing the cash without damaging the machine. “The footage further revealed that the man used a key to open the cash tray and also keyed in the correct password of the machine to open its screen and disengage it from the server for a few minutes,” Pawar said.

The unsuspecting bank officials continued to deposit cash in the ATM unit for the past 14 days, he said.

“The ATM unit has two safe keys — both are in the possession of the bank officials. These two keys were not removed by anyone from the bank premises,” he said.

“Prima facie, it is suspected that unidentified man, who is seen in the CCTV footage, prepared a duplicate of the ATM unit’s keys and also knows the password of the machine. We will also investigate the possibility of an insider hand in the theft, as the ATM unit’s password is known to only some officers and cash depositing officials,” he said.

Title: Ex-serviceman, wife and son found dead
Content:
Kollam: Three members of a family at Ittiva, Vayyanam near Kadakkal in the district were found dead on Sunday.

According to Kadakkal police, the initial assumption is that Sudarshanan, 60, of PK House, Ittiva, Vayyanam, an ex-service man may have hacked his wife Vasantha Kumari, 55, and son Visakh alias Sudesh, 25, to death before hanging himself. While the bodies of Vasantha Kumari and Sudesh were found in the kitchen and living room of the house, respectively, Sudarshanan’s body was found in an adjoining extended room.

The neighbours informed of sound of quarrelling and cries from Sudarshanan’s house around 9am. When nobody came out of the house till 3pm they alerted the police. Surdarshanan and his family members used to quarrel over domestic issues, and there was a pending case in this regard, police said.

As per an agreement after police intervened, Sudarshanan was allowed to stay in the extended portion of the house. When he fought with his wife, the son would oppose him, and it would come to blows. The persisting quarrels may have led to the deaths, police said.

Title: Crackers at wedding in Pune set 2 cars, three bikes on fire
Content:
The blaze spread fast

PUNE: Two four-wheelers and three motorcycles outside a marriage hall were reduced to ashes on Sunday afternoon after firecrackers were burst to celebrate a wedding at Chale village, about 37km from Pune, near Paud in Mulshi taluka. No one was injured.

Paud police inspector Ashok Dhumal told TOI, “A car, an SUV and three bikes were damaged. The fuel tank of one of the vehicles in the parking area may have been leaking when the crackers were burst. A stray cracker may have landed on the fuel streak on the floor, resulting in the fire around Sunday noon.”

The parking area was almost full to capacity with guests for the wedding. The sudden fire set people rushing to retrieve their vehicles from and take them to a safer place, Dhumal said.

Eyewitnesses told the police that the firecrackers started soon after the marriage was solemnized. “We are also investigating another theory by some other witnesses who said the fire may have been caused by a short circuit in a vehicle,” he added.

Title: UP child rights body reaches Muzaffarnagar to probe role of children in anti-CAA violence
Content:
MUZAFFARNAGAR: A team of the state child rights body has visited Muzaffarnagar to inquire about the alleged involvement of children in violence during the protests against the amended citizenship law last December.

A massive violence had erupted in Muzaffarnagar on December 20 last year during protest against the CAA, in which minor were spotted among the protesters.

The team, led by Uttar Pradesh State Commission for Protection of Child Rights chairman Vishesh Gupta and member Jaya Singh, on Saturday visited the affected areas—Minakshi Chowk, Sadat Hostel, Kachchi Sadak— where large scale violence erupted and recorded the statements of some people.

Speaking to reporters, Gupta said, “We are here to conduct a probe about the role of minors in the December 20 violence and to find out whether the kids were forced to participate in the protest or not. This is only the first stage; we will inquire from every possible angle. After finishing with our investigation we will submit our report to State Commission for Protection of Child Rights.”

It should be noted that after a month of the violence, a Special Investigation Team (SIT), probing the cases of violence during the anti-CAA protests, had booked 33 jailed protesters for allegedly provoking children to throw stones at policemen during the clashes.

The probe agency had also invoked sections of Juvenile Justice (Care snd Protection of Children) Act, 2015, against the accused. All the 33 accused were earlier charged under various sections of the Indian Penal Code and sent to jail.

Among the charges faced by the 33 protesters under the Juvenile Justice Act include— use of children by militant groups, sale and procurement of children for any purpose, including illegal adoption, and offences against disabled children.

The SIT had got the permission to slap the additional charge on the 33 accused from court.

According to police, nearly 50 cases were registered at Nagar Kotwali and Civil Lines police stations, in which more than 250 people named and thousands of unnamed were booked. Police have arrested more than 90 people so far in the matter.

Title: Criminal arrested in Muzzafarnagar; Rs 73,000 cash, firearms seized
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

MUZAFFARNAGARr: An accused, who has 10 pending cases of loot, was arrested by Muzaffarnagar police on early Sunday.

The incident took place when the police had halted a suspected motorbike during a checking. However, upon being confronted by the police the driver and pillion rider started to run.

The police nabbed one of the accused he was hit by a bullet and suffered injury in his leg, whereas the other one escaped. Police have also seized Rs 73,000 cash and country-made weapons from them.

The arrested accused has been identified as Mohsin, who was involved in loot conducted at a petrol pump in New-Mandi area several days ago.

Deputy superintendent of police Dhannjay Singh said, “We are now trying to arrest his associate who fled. The injured has been admitted at a hospital.”

Title: Aunt strangulates minor girl to death, hides body in sack
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

MEERUT: In a shocking incident, a four-year-old girl was murdered by her paternal aunt who strangulated her to death for allegedly being “jealous over her husband ’s love towards her”.

The woman strangulated her, put her body in a sack and hid it in a room on the terrace in Incholi area. It was only after relatives’ suspicion that she confessed to the police. The girl’s hands were tied and her mouth was stuffed with cloth.

Meerut SP (rural) Avinash Pandey said, “The incident came to light on Saturday evening when the four-year-old girl went missing from her house. The relatives started looking for her and eventually found her body at paternal aunt’s house. During interrogation, some relatives raised their suspicion towards the aunt. They narrated that in the past too, she had thrashed her. When we started interrogating her, she confessed to the crime.”

“Her body has been sent for postmortem and a case has been filed against the woman in question under relevant sections of the IPC. She has been arrested and a probe is on. Forensic evidence has been taken for further probe,” Pandey said, adding, “The accused has claimed that she was envious of the love that her husband showed towards the baby girl and hence took such a step.

Title: Three vehicle thieves held
Content:
Accused in police custody

Rajkot: Three vehicle thieves were arrested and as many as 11 stolen two-wheelers recovered near Dhoraji bus stand in Dhoraji of Rajkot district on Sunday.

Police said accused Jitendra Dave (23), Sunil Solanki (22) and Akram Pathan (19) had stolen the vehicles from Dhoraji, Jetpur, Upleta and Rajkot. “We arrested the trio on basis of a tip-off that they were riding a stolen bike. During interrogation, the trio confessed of having committed 11 thefts. We recovered 11 two-wheelers from their possession,” said V H Joshi, inspector with Dhoraji police station.

Title: Coronavirus in Delhi: SDMC to separate cold, cough patients
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: South Delhi Municipal Corporation has decided to make separate arrangements at its dispensaries, maternity homes and hospitals for people affected with cold, cough and other respiratory issues so that they don’t come in contact with other patients.

“There are 112 dispensaries, maternity homes and hospitals under our jurisdiction. It was decided at a meeting chaired by the commissioner that people afflicted with even common cold and cough will be directed to OPDs from the entrance only. This will help avoid their movement in the main complex,” a senior SDMC official said.

The civic agencies, which have created isolation wards in the medical centres for suspected Covid-19 patients, have started distributing masks to doctors and other staff.

Through an official circular, the health department of EDMC has advised setting up of separate OPD counters at Swami Dayanand and Veer Savarkar hospitals for flu-affected patients. North corporation, too, has also marked a 14-bed ward in Hindu Rao Hospital for suspected novel coronavirus patients besides distributing 3,000 N-95 masks and deputing a nodal officer.

The agencies are taking precautions to avoid crowds at citizen bureau centres and property tax offices. “We may arrange for more counters to avoid queues at citizen bureau centres, considering that March 31 is the last date for submitting house tax,” the official added.

Senior EDMC officials have also been asked to conduct meetings with resident welfare associations and traders’ association, requesting them to avoid social gatherings for Holi.

Title: Coronavirus in Jaipur: Fever subsides, Italian tourist’s chances to leave hospital
Content: JAIPUR: The 69-year-old Italian patient, who had right lower lobe pneumonia and tested positive for coronavirus ( Covid-19 ) at Sawai Man Singh ( SMS ) Hospital, now has no fever . He is constantly improving.According to the hospital authorities, his recovery is satisfactory and he will be discharged from the hospital in next 7 to 10 days. “His blood count has become normal and pneumonia is subsiding,” said a health department official.SMS Hospital officials are in touch with the Italian embassy and are giving them updates about the patient’s recovery. SMS Hospital officials said the patient’s wife’s condition, who also tested positive for Covid-19 on March 4, is also much better.However, she had written series of mails to the Italian embassy complaining about the facilities at SMS Hospital, where she and her husband are undergoing treatment.At the time when the 69-year-old Italian tourist was brought to the hospital on March 29, he was suffering from breathlessness and fever. He was admitted to hospital’s isolation ward as a suspected case of Covid-19. When the hospital authorities conducted test, he tested negative for Covid-19 in the first test. Since he tested negative in the first test, he was shifted to medical ICU from isolation ward.When his condition deteriorated, the hospital authorities conducted a second test where he tested positive for Covid-19. For confirmation, the health authorities sent his swab sample to National Institute of Virology, Pune. The test on March 3 showed that he was affected by coronavirus. Since then he is undergoing treatment.

Title: Senior Rane may join Cong campaign in Sattari
Content:
Valpoi: The campaign for the zilla panchayat election in Sattari may take an interesting turn if former chief minister Pratapsing Rane actively joins the Congress campaign, political observers say.

Health minister Vishwajit Rane has already started working to drum up support for the three candidates fielded by BJP.

As many as 10 candidates are in the fray for three constituencies in Sattari. In Nagargao constituency (OBC women) Rajashri Kale of BJP is pitted against Usha Mest of Congress. In Honda constituency (general) there are as many as five candidates - Ganpat Gaonkar (independent), Gurudas Gaonkar (independent), Pundalik Madkar (AAP), Ramesh Gawade (Congress) and Sagun Wadkar (BJP).

In Keri constituency (women) there are only three candidates - Devayani Gawas( BJP), Kavita Kasar (independent) and Parinita Rane (Congress).

President of Valpoi block congress committee Dasharath Mandrekar said that Pratapsingh Rane would join the Congress’ campaign in Sattari . "We met senior Rane and got a good response from him. He has told us that he would fully support Congress candidates and if necessary will also participate in the campaign," Mandrekar said.

Title: One Stop Centre panels rejiged
Content:
Panaji: The state government has reconstituted committees to monitor the functioning of ‘one stop centres’ in both the districts on quarterly basis.

Under the One Stop Centre scheme of the central government, the centres are to provide support and assistance to women affected by violence both in private and public spaces. As per the scheme, the centres are to be integrated with a women helpline to provide a range of services which include medical assistance, legal assistance and shelter besides counselling.

Besides reconstituting the committee, the government has renamed “the Management Committee” as “District Level Task Force” for South Goa and North Goa.

The committee is headed by the respective district collector and consists of 12 other members for each district, according to a notification issued by director of women and child development, Deepali Naik.

Title: 4 UP cops booked & suspended for abductions, extortions
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

MEERUT: Police in UP’s Bulandshahr on Sunday booked its four men for allegedly abducting people with criminal background and extorting money from their families by threatening encounter. Three head constables and a constable posted with Bulandshahr police were booked on the basis of a complaint filed by a lawyer.

The four policemen were identified as head constables Sanjeev Malik, Yograj Singh, Zaikr Hussain and constable Dheeraj Kumar, all posted at Sikandarabad police station in Bulandshahr. All four have been suspended pending investigation, for which a SIT has been constituted.

According to SSP Bulandshahr, Santosh Kumar , “There is evidence of the four policemen’s involvement in abduction of people, especially from tribal and nomadic groups. After the abduction, they used to extort money from their families by threating to slap criminal charges. They also used to threaten encounter.”

“After inputs, a departmental probe was launched. During the initial probe, most of the claims were corroborated. It hinted at organised gang behind abduction and extortion from people of tribal groups with criminal background,” SSP Santosh Kumar said.

Investigating officers claimed that it may be the tip of the iceberg and several other policemen from neighbouring districts could be part of the larger nexus.

“Using police input on criminals, they would abduct the victim and use his phone to intimidate family by threatening them of police encounter or slapping of criminal charges against the abducted victim,” the SSP said.

An FIR under IPC section 323 (voluntarily causing hurt), 343 (wrongful confinement for three or more days) and 386 (extortion) and relevant sections of prevention of corruption act was lodged at Sikandrabad police station. An SIT under IPS officer Gopal Chaudhary and ASP Bulandshahr was constituted to probe the case.

“It is highly unlikely that we get witness in the case. So we will have to back our claim with technical evidences by digging up call records, tower locations, electronic money trail if any to establish the link between the victims and accused policemen,” the SSP said.

Title: Wild boar plays spoil sport at Bhopal wedding reception
Content:
Injured Mayur Bhade

BHOPAL: An uninvited guest created ruckus at a dream marriage reception at a prominent hotel along Van Vihar road on Bhopal outskirts on March 6 leaving the groom’s brother injured, much to the dismay of guests that included some from Europe. The wild boar unleashed terror among the guests and the family has now lodged a complaint with the local police and sought action against the hotel management for negligence.

More than 29 guests including some international guests were present as the girl was getting married to an Austrian groom.

Police said marriage of Monika Bhade, a resident of Betul in Madhya Pradesh took place at the hotel with a groom from Austria, Europe on March 4.

Father of Monika, Devendra Bhade, 54, who works with Western Coalfields Limited (WCL) in Pathakheda, Betul said, “There were 29 guests including some from Europe and other countries who stayed at the hotel. On March 6, we had to drop our guests to airport as they had to catch a flight. At around 5.48 am, a wild boar entered the premises and approached us while we were at the porch to see off the guests. My son Mayur, 30, did all he could to ensure guests are safe. He locked some of them in the washroom and some at other places, but unfortunately the animal injured him in his thighs. We tried for primary aid, but it was not available at the hotel and the staff were also not supportive.”

“We then dropped the guests and rushed him to a hospital. Doctors claim that the injury is grievous, and it would take time before he could be discharged,” he said.

“We stayed at the hotel and it was the responsibility of the hotel to ensure our safety. I want police to act against the hotel, but the response of police too has been cold, so far. I do not want that anyone who stays at the hotel in future to face the same problems that we did,” he said.

When contacted, assistant manager, front desk of the hotel, Pranay Soni told TOI, “We have proper security at our premises. The said incident took place between 5.45 am and 6 am and the animal sneaked in as the main gate was opened to facilitate entry of some staff. Our guard tried to stop it, but he was injured. The second guard tried his best to stop the animal.”

“We immediately informed the Van Vihar (local zoo) and forest staff rescued the animal after a seven hour mission,” he said.

Title: Uttarkashi administration observes women’s day, launches calendar dedicated to notable women of the district
Content:
UTTARKASHI: Uttarkashi district administration organized an event at the district auditorium on Sunday, on the occasion of International Women’s Day. Local artistes and school students presented cultural programs. Artistes of the Samvedna Samuh organization performed street plays themed on women empowerment.

Gangotri MLA Gopal Rawat , municipality chairman Ramesh Semwal , DM Ashish Chauhan and his wife Anukriti Chauhan inaugurated the event and launched a year 2020 calendar, which was dedicated to famous women of the district.

They also felicitated the winners of a science exhibition, a fashion show, painting, cooking and several other competitions, which were organized for local women and schoolgirls.

Addressing the gathering, MLA Gopal Rawat said, “After a long struggle, the mentality of society is finally changing towards the female gender. Due to this, women today are proving their worth in armed forces, politics, social work, administrative services and other social sectors. However, we still need to fight against many ill practices like dowry, female foeticide and sexual harassment, to bring about real change.”

Title: Tough task for Congress in South Goa after BJP placates rebels
Content: MARGAO: With the BJP succeeding in quelling the dissidence among its party workers following rebellion by those denied the ticket, Congress faces an uphill task in South Goa for the ZP polls, political observers say.With Quepem MLA Chandrakant Kavalekar and Canacona MLA Isidore Fernandes, who were elected as Congress candidates in the 2017 assembly elections, now holding key positions in the saffron camp, Congress found itself in a pitiable position in fielding its candidate in the ZP constituencies dominated by these legislators.Though BJP faced rebellion in a couple of constituencies, it soon went into damage control mode and ensured that the rebels withdrew from the fray. Last weekend saw BJP’s organiSing secretary, Satish Dhond rush to Rivona and Sanguem persuading the dissidents to return to the BJP camp.In Salcete, a close contest is on the cards in all the nine constituencies of Salcete where altogether 35 candidates are in the fray.Congress has fielded candidates in all the nine constituencies, followed by AAP which is contesting seven candidates. Ironically, BJP managed to field its candidates in just two constituencies, Davorlim and Guirdolim, despite having its MLAs wielding sway over several of Catholic-dominated Salcete constituencies.Nevertheless, Congress faces a formidable challenge in Velim, Navelim, Nuvem and Raia constituencies where independent candidates, Anthony Rodrigues, Cipru Cardozo, Breezy Barreto and Domnic Gaonkar, respectively, enjoying the support of the local MLAs and apparently backed by the BJP, are likely to put up a good performance.Congress also faces a challenge in Colva and Benaulim constituencies which will witness a three-cornered contest. In Colva, Congress candidate Suzie Fernandes, NCP’s Vania Baptista and AAP nominee Aishwarya Fernandes are engaged in the battle, while in Navelim, a close contest will be witnessed between Royla Fernandes of the Congress, Menino de Bandar of the NCP, and Hanzel Fernandes of AAP.Significantly, AAP claimed that 33 percent of its candidates were women.In the 2015 ZP elections, while Congress had refrained from fielding candidates on party lines, BJP had held sway over the South Goa ZP.

Title: Two more suspected Covid-19 quarantined in Rajasthan
Content: JAIPUR: Two more suspected cases of coronavirus (Covid-19) have been found in the state. An Australian national in Udaipur, while a 23-year-old girl of Sriganganagar, who had returned from Italy on February 29, were quarantined as suspected Covid-19 cases after they were found suffering from fever and cold on Sunday. However, two South Africans, who were quarantined at Sawai Man Singh (SMS) Hospital on Saturday, have tested negative for the disease.Health authorities heaved a sigh of relief as 294 of the total of 301 samples received by the health department till Sunday morning, have tested negative for Covid-19. “Out of these, only two (Italian tourists) tested positive, while 294 have tested negative, report of five is under process,” said Rohit Kumar Singh, additional chief secretary, health department.The Australian national has been admitted to a private hospital, where he will be quarantined. “We are keeping a close eye on his health. If his condition deteriorates, we will take samples for Covid-19 test,” said Dr Dinesh Kharadi, chief medical health officer (CMHO) Udaipur.In Sriganganagar, a 23-year-old girl was suffering from cold and cough. “She belongs to Sriganganagar but returned from Italy recently. She came to district hospital with complaints of breathlessness. Her samples have been taken and sent to Jaipur for test,” said Dr Girdhari Lal, CMHO, Sriganganagar. A team of doctors attended to her and quarantined her. She is a student of a college in Italy.In Jaipur, four Italians, one person each from Hong Kong, Germany, Japan and two from South Africa have already been quarantined in the past few days. “They all have tested negative for Covid-19,” said Dr DS Meena, medical superintendent, SMS hospital.With the health department taking all possible measures to contain Covid-19 in the state, the Indian Council of Medical Research has expanded its national laboratories testing for Covid-19. It has released a list of 51 testing laboratories for the entire country. Till now, only SMS Hospital’s microbiology laboratory was conducting Covid-19 test but now among the 51 testing laboratories, three more laboratories have been allocated to the state. The laboratories in government-run medical colleges of Jhalawar, Jodhpur and Bikaner will be equipped for conducting Covid-19 test. Besides, Udaipur and AIIMS Jodhpur, will be equipped with the facility for sample collection centres.In Jaipur, the screening for residents who come under the periphery of three kilometres of the hotel, where Italian tourists (Covid-19 positive cases) stayed, is in progress. In the past three days, health department screened 18,000 people in door-to-door survey of the area to find out influenza-like illness cases.

Title: Wronging a right: Age-old trees that were de-choked choked again
Content:
Nagpur: In a move that defies logic, the age-old trees that were de-choked some years back have been choked again with cement at Katol Road. Afraid that the trees might die, infuriated greens have demanded immediate action.

The issue was brought to notice by C Vijay Nayudu, president of Nagpur Municipal Corporation’s (NMC) contractors welfare association. The trees were de-choked under Nayudu’s supervision some years back.

While passing through Katol Road a few days back, Nayudu was shocked to find the same trees choked completely. According to him, the trees were choked by the National Highway Authority of India (NHAI) while laying interlocking tiles on the pavements. TOI could not contact the NHAI official concerned for confirmation.

At first, Nayudu spotted labourers filling the gap between tiles and base of two trees with cement. “When I stopped to check, I was shocked to find that many trees on the pavement were brutally choked. First of all, there was no mandatory space left between the tiles and tree base. On top of that, the little space left was filled with cement,” he told TOI.

Environment activists demanded immediate de-choking of the trees. Founder of NGO Green Vigil Kaustav Chatterjee, who inspected the spot on Sunday, found more trees choked in a similar manner. “It is completely senseless to choke the already de-choked trees. NMC must take strict action,” he said.

NMC garden superintendent Amol Chorpagar assured to take action on Monday. “Our officials will carry out a spot inspection and take immediate measures to save the trees,” he said.

In February last year, NMC chief engineer Ulhas Debadwar had issued orders to remove interlocking tiles for de-choking trees. In May last year, the civic body had launched a massive drive to de-choke around 9,419 fully-grown trees spread over 382 kilometres road length. Taking serious note of the fact that many age-old trees in the city were on the verge of keeling, the initiative was taken by the then municipal commissioner Abhijit Bangar.

Highlighting that the city needs more such drives, Chatterjee suggested that zone-wise de-choking should be carried out. “While NMC has de-choked many trees on major roads, it should now focus on saving trees on internal roads. Zone-wise survey should be done to identify choked trees,” he said.

The activist added that de-choking should be done before rainy season. “Only then, the water would be able to percolate in the roots,” he said.

Title: GTDC residencies see Rs 1.8 crore drop in revenue for 2018-19
Content: PANAJI: Goa Tourism Development Corporation ( GTDC ), which operates 11 residencies, experienced a drop in revenue of Rs 1.8 crore in 2018-2019.The GTDC hotels’ room occupancy rates dropped by 2% in 2018-19, when compared to 2017-18, for which the corporation blames last year’s low tourist footfalls, heavy monsoon and floods.GTDC has residencies at Colva, Panaji, Old Goa, Farmagudi, Calangute, Mapusa, Miramar, Margao, Mayem, Vasco and a second annex residency at Calangute.The percentage occupancy for the period between April and August 2019 recorded a fall at every hotel, except for the Panaji residency. The Panaji residency, which overlooks the Mandovi, was renovated more than three years ago.The average occupancy at its residencies between April and August 2018, was not even 50 %.Though most of GTDC’s properties are situated at prime locations, and some are sea-facing, they are mostly old, poorly-maintained and badly-operated, barring a few.An official said while properties are old, the service is also not on par with similarly placed properties operated by private players.“The residencies are in beautiful locations and close to the beach, and yet, they are not as profitable as other hotels. Firstly, because the service offered is not good. Also, they are not making a profit as the operating costs remain high, due to the salary component,” the official said.Standard room tariff, he said, at GTDC residencies , is above Rs 1,000 and the tariff for an air-conditioned room is over Rs 2,000.“When the staff is sluggish and guests do not get services they expect, there is no way occupancy will be impressive,” he said.He said the Mapusa residency, despite being centrally-located, close to the bus stand and the famous Mapusa market, and only a few kilometres away from the bustling coastal belt of Calangute and Candolim, it does not enjoy 100% occupancy. “It is an old property, and gives out vibes that it is a shady hotel. I don’t think the property will earn even average business,” he said.“Blaming it on fewer tourist footfalls or heavy rainfall will not help increase occupancy— GTDC will have to look at innovative ways to improve the quality of their residencies,” he added.

Title: Couple with ‘IS link’ held in Delhi's Okhla
Content: NEW DELHI: Delhi Police’s Special Cell arrested a couple with alleged links to the Khorasan module of Islamic State terror group from Okhla early on Sunday.The couple — Jahanjeb Sami (36) and Hina Bashir Beg (39) — is accused of instigating anti-Citizenship Ammendment Act (CAA) protests and motivating youths to carry out terror strike in retaliation.Sami was given the name of Abu Muhammed Al Hind by IS leadership and was using aliases and identities like Dawood Ibrahim , Xaib and Abu Abdullah, police claimed. He belonged to Shivpora locality in Srinagar and was living with his wife in C block, Jamia Nagar , in Okhla Vihar area, they added.Hina was allegedly masquerading as “Katijah al Kashmiri and Hannabee” on pro-IS chat and media platforms while scouting for vulnerable youths. “They are members of banned terrorist outfit ISIS and propagating its ideology of hatred against non-Muslims and, thereby, also inciting Muslims to kill non-Muslims. They are also inciting Muslims to take up violent struggle against the state. They are inciting Muslims against CAA too,” Pramod Kushwaha, DCP (Special Cell), claimed.Four mobile phones, a laptop, an external hard disk and other incriminating material were allegedly seized from the couple’s house.During investigation, the cops claimed to have found that the couple created several anonymous IDs on social media platforms, such as Telegram, Facebook, Threema, Sure Spot, Instagram and Twitter, to propagate IS ideology.They have been booked under IPC sections of sedition, promoting hatred between two groups and criminal conspiracy apart from sections 13 and 20 of Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act. They were influenced by slain ISJK commander Amir Sultan alias Abu Huzaifa al-Bakistani, who was killed in a drone strike in Afghanistan ’s Nangarhar province last year, police said. The couple was earlier handled by Abdullah Basith, a Hyderabad-based operative arrested by NIA for running an IS module, they added. They knew him as Khattab.Tipped off by an intelligence agency, the cell had been tracking the couple for two months and kept a close watch on their online activities, which allegedly gathered pace in February. The cops began to close in after they allegedly started circulating the IS digital magazine, Sawt al Hind (Voice of Hind).“The couple was trying to recruit youths into IS-India province (Wilayah-al-Hind) using social media platforms and was in touch with several senior members of Islamic State in Khorasan province ( ISKP ) in Afghanistan and Syria through chat platforms,” said an official.“The couple was allegedly trying to brainwash youths into carrying out suicide attacks in the country. Sami was also trying to arrange arms and ammunitions to unleash violence during the anti-CAA protests and in the aftermath of it,” the official added.The two were running a Twitter handle named @kashmirosint. Sami has pursued a B Tech and an MBA. He is a computer expert with experience in web and multimedia designing. Hina pursued an MBA after completing her Bachelor’s in Computer Application. She has claimed to have worked at banks like Kotak Mahindra, Motilal Oswal securities and ABN Amro, claims that cops are verifying.

Title: Bane for China, corona turns out to be a boon for desi pichkari makers
Content:
People selecting pichkari at shop in Patna on Friday ahead of Holi festival.Pic by-Pramod Sharma

Nagpur: Corona virus impact has brought an opportunity for Indian manufacturers this Holi season. As the virus outbreak has hampered trade from China, even imports of pichkaris (water gun) and other items sold during Holi have been hit. This has given a chance to Indian manufacturers to take over the market that was traditionally dominated by Chinese players.

However, traders down the chain are apprehensive that the scare and calls to tone down celebrations by the government agencies may hit their business for the coming two days.

The market that was dominated by Chinese products since nearly last ten years has been largely replaced by Indian items this festive season, say local traders. “This did not happen overnight, but certainly coronavirus was a major reason,” said bulk dealers here.

“The process began three years ago and finally as the imports have taken a hit due to the outbreak, nearly 90% of the market has made in India goods,” said Ashok Sanghvi of M/s Modern Rakhi Bhandar, a bulk trading firm in seasonal festive items at Itwari. “The Indian players have managed to meet the rate and the quality of the Chinese manufacturers,” he said.

Sanghvi said, “Even before the corona outbreak, the traders here were facing hassles in procuring Chinese items due to procedural issues from the Customs’ side. Three years ago, the traders approached toy manufacturers in Delhi to take up the production of Holi items too. The units began procuring dyes to make the goods. Till last Holi, as much as 70% of the supply was Indian and now it is 90%.” Colours continue to come from Hathras town in Uttar Pradesh, which is the major hub, he said.

Retail traders, on the other hand, said the stockists having Chinese items are trying to take advantage of the situation and have jacked the prices. The corona scare is barely two months old the but the stocks are piled up even before that. “Given the sentiment, the local stockists have hiked the rates by 20% to 40%,” said retailers.

“Sales are not down despite the strictures related to safety measures. However, the Chinese items are not available as much as they were last year. In general, the rates have gone up by 40%,” said Kishore Jaikalyani of M/s Kishore General Stores in Gokulpeth.

A little away at M/s Pankaj Stores, the shopkeeper said the sales are nearly half of the last year. “We used to get creative designs of water guns from China apart from masks and wigs. Such items are in short supply. We have simple pichkaris from Indian suppliers. The rates of both the items are up but sales are down,” he said.

The balloons used for filling water come from China. “As against 50 a packet, it is being sold at Rs80 by the wholesalers this season,” added a shopkeeper nearby.

Title: VNSGU a distant 16th in state universities ranking
Content:
cap

Surat: Veer Narmad South Gujarat University (VNSGU), one of the oldest universities that covers largest area dominated by tribal communities in the state, stands at a poor 16th rank among the universities by Gujarat State Institutional Rating Framework (GSIRF). Knowledge Consortium of Gujarat (KCG) views it as a pioneering attempt towards creating world class institutions in the state.

Over 2.5 lakh students study in various departments and colleges of the university, with their number increasing with each passing year. But the ranking has proved that the university has poor infrastructure compared to some newly developed universities.

Former top academicians of the university said that situation was getting worse as far as higher education was concerned in VNSGU. "Senior professors and students often share their pain with me. Academic level is going down and due to political interference even senior teachers can’t do anything," former vice-chancellor of VNSGU, B A Parikh told TOI. Parikh was VNSGU VC from 1991 to 1997.

"I am told that the situation has become worse of late. In this condition the rank will drop obviously," Parikh added.

Retired professor and former leader of university teachers, Suryakant Shah, explained, "The VC's appointment and his credentials are under doubt. How can a university perform better? There are several vacant posts of teachers and top officials are busy politicking. Despite being ranked poorly, this university will now be judging a few of its affiliated colleges that have been ranked better." Universities were judged on various criteria like teaching, learning and resources, research and professional practice, graduation outcome, outreach and inclusivity. A university is supposed to file various details on the basis of which the ratings are given.

"Heart of any educational institute is its teachers. In VNSGU, the current top officials targeted teachers for one or the other reason. Research has also suffered heavily and the ranking shows the actual condition of the university," said Sanjay Desai, a syndicate member, VNSGU.

Ketan Desai, a syndicate member, said, "I can't comment on the current situation since I am not aware under which all criteria the university has performed poorly. I need to check how the applications were filed and many good colleges have got poor ranks too.”

VNSGU VC Shivendra Gupta and registrar Rajendra Patel were not available for comments.

Title: Expanding Trichy means growth in every sector, say experts
Content:
Trichy: Trichy City Corporation was last expanded in 2011 by adding Thiruverumbur to the civic body’s jurisdiction, but after that nothing has happened on the corporation’s expansion front.
