As the civic body holds only a limited land parcel, urban developers have opined that adding new area will pave way for infrastructure development and revenue generation as it will attract private investors on the city’s land availability, human resource and augmented consumer population.

Despite having the geographical advantage of being located at the centre of the state and better connectivity to all cities, the growth of the city in the past decade has been underwhelming. To overcome this, city development enthusiasts suggested bringing the urbanised municipalities, town panchayats and village panchayats to the corporation’s fold. Since the development schemes from the central government are based on a city’s population, expanding the city by adding the urbanised suburbs will help the local body avail more funds. People had suggested to include Thuvakudi in the east, Manachanallur, Number One tollgate in the north, Nachikurichi in the west and Olaiyur, Gundoor in the south to the corporation. "Expansion will really help Trichy develop as it will open many investment opportunities. More players in the service sector will grab opportunities, which is needed for industrial growth," A Shankar, COO, Strategic Consulting, JLL India, said.

Apart from increasing revenue, the expansion will result in the corporation getting more land parcels for infrastructure development. Except for Panchapur, at present the civic body has very minimal land parcels. With a rise in population across the suburbs, residents of Vasan Nagar and Anna Nagar near OFT expressed their desire to be a part of the corporation.

"Madurai and Coimbatore Corporations have 100 wards each, but Trichy with 65 wards is in disadvantage as bigger cities get priority in welfare schemes. Present urban agglomeration should be included in Trichy city as expanding the city is vital," N Manivannan, member, Trichy Intra-City Development Endeavours (TIDES), said.

However, there is a hesitation from the residents as Thiruverumbur, which was added to the city in 2011, still awaits basic amenities. Though there was a proposal in 2016-17 to expand the corporation’s jurisdiction, nothing has happened on it. "The decision to expand the civic body has to be taken by the state government in consultation with the elected council. Adding industrial area such as Thuvakudi may benefit the civic body," a corporation official said.

Title: Delhi Violence: Agencies probe role of ‘external force’ in Delhi riots
Content:
A day after of North-East Delhi riot situation of Shiv Vihar.As residents remain in houses.

NEW DELHI: The home ministry ’s official version that the Delhi violence was “spontaneous” and MoS (Home) G Kishan Reddy’s statement that riots were orchestrated to defame India during US President Donald Trump’s visit may not be as contradictory as they might seem, according to law enforcement agencies probing the sequence of events.

While there were ongoing sit-in protests in northeast Delhi prior to February 22, a communal clash did not seem imminent until a trigger was provided during the intervening night of February 22-23 by an “external force” that, police sources allege, prevailed on the anti-CAA women agitators to escalate the protest to a full-fledged roadblock by relocating to the arterial Jafrabad Metro station road.

Police sources said this “external force” could be women’s rights group Pinjra Tod, formed in 2015 largely by Delhi University women students to protest restrictions enforced on female students in Jamia University. An officer claimed Pinjra Tod activists were present in the Seelampur-Jafrabad area on February 22 evening and urged the anti-CAA protesters at the dharna site and other nearby areas to make their anti-CAA protest more impactful by creating a roadblock at the Jafrabad Metro station road.

The blockade, which soon led to blocking of the feeder roads as well, is seen to have provoked a counter show of strength, triggering Hindu-Muslim clashes. The skirmishes, which until the evening of February 23 were limited to stone-pelting from both sides and a few incidents of arson, turned into a full-blown communal riot by February 24 afternoon when Trump was in Ahmedabad.

“Looking at the sequence of events, the assessment is that had the sit-ins continued as before in northeast Delhi and the Jafrabad Metro station roadblock not created, clashes that spiralled into communal riots may not have followed. In that respect, the violence was ‘spontaneous’,” said an officer.

A Pinjra Tod member, however, denied that the organisation had prevailed upon women anti-CAA protestors to shift to Jafrabad Metro station site to block the road. “They did so out of their own volition. We are shocked how this narrative blaming us is being spread by some people, and how this has got so much traction,” the member said.

A police officer said investigations so far do not point to “outsiders” or “stones and bricks” being brought in from neighbouring states, with a view to engineer riots. Given the information about the alleged role of Pinjra Tod activists, officials are probing why a group that had so far confined itself to fighting for rights of women students, got involved in the anti-CAA stir and to what extent.

“The assessment is that there may have been two reasons behind getting the anti-CAA women protesters to shift from the small Jafrabad dharna to an arterial road. One, an attempt to create an alternative protest site in apprehension of the Supreme Court moving to end the dharna at Shaheen Bagh, and second, to create a negative image of India coinciding with the US President’s visit,” said a source.

Investigators said Pinjra Tod activists were at the dharna site not merely in solidarity with women protestors but were also actively involved in scaling up the protest. “Even if Pinjra Tod is given the benefit of doubt in that it could not have anticipated the likely consequences, they jumped into an already tense situation when Bhim Army had given an anti-CAA bandh call the following day. This action might amount to instigation and will be probed,” said an officer.

The Pinjra Tod member said, “It’s unbelievable how we, with the little resources we have, can engineer something like this (riots). Yes, we support the anti-CAA protests and our members, who are politically active, were visiting the protests sites to express solidarity with the Muslim women.” She, however, followed this up by saying a few Pinjra Tod activists who joined women protestors as they moved to Jafrabad road, were acting in “their personal capacity”.

When asked if and when Pinjra Tod had expanded its mandate from “fighting the patriarchal discrimination against women university students” to get involved in anti-CAA stir, the Pinjra Tod member, who did not want to be named, insisted that they were only doing it out of solidarity. “That we were the trigger behind the communal violence that broke out thereafter, is a flawed and irresponsible narrative. It were people like Kapil Mishra who provided the trigger,” she argued.

Title: Two approach hospital for medical tests
Content:
Surat: Two men approached SMIMER hospital on Sunday for medical examination fearing infection of nCovid-19 (coronavirus). However, they did not have symptoms of the disease.

A 58-year-old man approached the doctors claiming that he has severe cough, cold and fever. He informed that he returned from Kerala three days ago and suspected that he was infected with the disease. He was asked to go home after medical examination.

A 40-year-old man approached the hospital claiming that he returned from Turkey six days ago. Since Turkey is not among the affected country, he too was sent home after examination.

Title: Lung transplant centre in city may be a reality soon
Content:
Nagpur: The state government will clear all hurdles and bring a state-of-the-art lung institute in Nagpur soon, said secretary of department of medical education and research (DMER) Dr Sanjay Mukherjee on Sunday.

“This will not only bring advanced treatment for lung disorders to the city but also create ground for ambitious lung transplant facility here,” he added.

“MD pulmonology programme at the department of pulmonary medicine in Nagpur GMCH has completed 25 years which is a milestone. State government has been considering the proposal of lung institute by this department since long. We have decided to expedite this project with all possible cooperation,” said Mukherjee.

Lung institute is considered need of the hour for Nagpur because the city is surrounded by 14 big thermal power stations and residents are at risk of respiratory ailments due to pollution. Union minister Nitin Gadkari had assured in 2016 that he would bat for this institute at the central government level. After this, the department had submitted a proposal worth Rs600 crore which was pending with the DMER.

“Nagpur deserves this institute the most and we are very hopeful now as the state secretary himself has set the ball in motion,” said Dr Sushant Meshram, professor and HoD of pulmonary medicine, GMCH. The department had organized Pulmo and Sleep Meet 2020, a unique academic event on Sunday, to mark the 25th anniversary of the MD course and World Sleep Day that falls on March 13.

“We discussed a series of issues on sleep apnoea syndrome, progressive and end-stage lung disorders, and various aspects of lung transplants during this one-day event. A public forum on lung disorders was also held in the evening,” said Dr Meshram.

Dr Apar Jindal from Chennai gave presentation on the lung transplant scenario in India and challenges. “Average waiting period for lung transplant in the country is 6 to 36 months. This is because transplant surgeons have only about 4-6 hours to complete entire transplant operation after the donor lungs are retrieved. Still, lung rejection rate is going down in India. Survival period of transplanted lungs has increased from 3 years to 7.4 years since 2012,” he said.

Dr Jindal said that government support was necessary to bring the lung transplant facility in centrally-located city like Nagpur.

GMCH dean Dr Sajal Mitra, world renowned sleep medicine specialist professor Nancy Collap from USA, veteran pulmonologist Dr BR Maldhure and office-bearers of newly instituted Sleep Apnea Association of India attended the conference and shared their inputs.

Hope revives

Currently, there are only four active lung transplantation programmes in country

Three of them are in Chennai and one in Coimbatore

Lung institute in Nagpur may address challenges like demand-supply mismatch, lack of standardized donor management and geographical remoteness

Geographical limitations are foremost reasons due to which many donated lungs cannot be used

A helipad is also proposed at lung institute of Nagpur to get away with this limitation

Title: Coronavirus in Jaipur: Hotel rooms where Italian tourists stayed sealed
Content:
JAIPUR: The rooms of the luxury hotels where the Italian tourists stayed in Bikaner, Jodhpur, Udaipur and Jaipur, have been sealed. The action has been taken after two people, from a 23-member Italian group, tested positive for Covid-19.

The group had travelled through major tourist places in Rajasthan and reached Jaipur on February 28. They were tested positive for Covid-19 on March 3 and 4.

Apprehensive of possible transmission of the disease, health authorities have denied entry of any hotel staff or guests in these rooms since they could become source of Covid-19 infection.

To disinfect these rooms, health authorities are using 1% sodium hypochlorite for mopping all hard surfaces such as handles, chairs, tables, etc.

“We disinfected 13 rooms in the hotel, where the Italian group stayed. After that we sealed the rooms for at least 14 days to ward off risk of transmission of the disease to other people staying in the same room,” said Dr Dinesh Kharadi, CMHO, Udaipur.

The tourists spent one day (February 22) in Bikaner, two days (February 23-24) in Jaisalmer, one day (February 25) in Jodhpur, and three days (February 26-28) in Udaipur before leaving for Jaipur.

In Jaipur, the health department sealed 16 rooms, in Jodhpur the entire floor, while 13 rooms were sealed in Bikaner after they were disinfected. “We are taking all possible measures to check the spread of Covid-19,” said Dr BL Meena, CMHO, Bikaner, while adding that they have kept 143 people in home isolation for 28 days, who came in contact with the Italian tourists.

Moreover, the health authorities have started door-to-door survey in the periphery of three kilometres of the hotels. They are constantly monitoring the health of those who came in contact with the Italian couple. So far, no person among contacts has been tested positive for Covid-19, the health authorities claimed.

Title: Pongala today amid Covid-19 vigil
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: Around 350 volunteers of disaster management authority task force of the district administration, 250 volunteers of green army of city corporation, health department staff and residents associations will observe strict vigil during the Attukal pongala festival on Monday, which is being held a day after five new positive cases of coronavirus disease (Covid-19) were reported in Pathanamthitta district. Attukal pongala, the largest congregation of women in the state, will begin at 10.20am on Monday.Railways and police have given instructions to its personnel on duty for pongala. Senior police officers have directed police officers on duty to carry extra handkerchiefs and masks while on duty. Rajesh Chandran, senior divisional commercial manager, Thiruvananthapuram division, Southern Railway, has directed the railway staff on duty at Thiruvananthapuram Central station to wear full sleeve clothes and surgical gloves. He said railway employees should take caution as large group of devotees will be arriving at Thiruvananthapuram for pongala.District collector K Gopalakrishnan has asked devotees to be alert in the wake of fresh Covid-19 cases. The district administration has arranged 23 health teams in city areas. On Sunday, health minister K K Shailaja flagged off five bike first responders along with fourteen 108 ambulances. In order to coordinate activities, a 108 ambulance emergency response centre has been started. This will be coordinated with the support of ham radio operators under Radio Amateur society of Ananthapuri.Bike first responders will have an emergency medical technician of Kanivu 108 ambulance and a ham radio operator. They will visit the spot and provide care for needy patients. If further medical care is needed, they would call for ambulance. The service of 108 basic life ambulance will be available in Attukal, Thampanoor, Killipalam, Karamana, Manacaud junction, East Fort, Kamaleswaram junction, Kalady, Power House Road, Konchiravila, Kallooramoodu, Bypass, Manacaud Valiyapally junction, etc.The district administration has asked residents associations to identify persons who returned from Covid-19-affected countries and also about persons who show symptoms.In order to track cases in the future, the district administration will record videos of pongala offering in the city. It will also conduct awareness sessions at railway stations, bus stands, temples, etc.Deputy collector Anu S Nair said that there was nothing to panic as community spread was not reported.The rituals will begin at 10.20am when temple tantri Thekkedathu Kuzhikattillathu Parameswaran Namboothiri hands over the lamp from sanctum sanctorum to chief priest P Eswaran Namboothiri. The chief priest will light the hearth inside the temple and hand it over to the co-priests to light the pandara aduppu, which will mark the beginning for pongala offering. The pongala will be sanctified by 2.10pm.

Title: Northeast Delhi riots: Shahrukh Pathan taken to crime scene in Maujpur
Content:
Shahrukh Pathan had pointed a gun at a lone policeman

NEW DELHI: A Crime Branch team, along with Shahrukh Pathan , who was arrested for pointing a pistol at a policeman and opening fire during the riots two weeks ago, reached Maujpur on Sunday to recreate the sequence of events and to identify the route he took to flee.

The police custody of the accused, Shahrukh, ends on Monday. So far, police have seized the car, pistol and clothes he had worn and also arrested a drug dealer for harbouring him. Investigations revealed that he had fired three rounds but none hit anyone. Later, he was face-to-face with a police officer, at whom he pointed the pistol.

Meanwhile, police officers questioning suspended AAP councillor Tahir Hussain and stated that he is being defensive in the interrogation. Two of his neighbours, Liaqat and Risayat, were arrested on Saturday. A court sent Liaqat to 14 days in judicial custody while Risayat was sent to three days in police custody. As per officials, it was the father-son duo (Liaqat and Risayat) who initiated the violence in the area. Police will question Risayat to ascertain how there was material such as petrol bombs and stones stocked up on Hussain’s roof. The cops are questioning Hussain’s neighbours and the help to ascertain where he was during the violence. They have identified 10 more people who were on the roof.

Hussain had a licensed weapon that was deposited in the wake of the elections, post which, on February 22, he got it back. Police suspect the timing of him getting the gun back and the violence have a connection. The gun has been sent for forensic examination.

Meanwhile, another body was pulled out from a drain in Karawal Nagar, which is yet to be identified.

Title: Bravo! Cops ensure pet bird’s flight back home after missing complaint
Content:
Nagpur: It was an unusual ‘missing’ complaint which even the complainant was hesitant to file, but Mankapur police not only accepted it but also reunited a family with their pet bird ‘Bravo’, an African Grey Parrot which is an exotic bird species, within hours.

Bravo belongs to Vinod Mahure, a senior manager at Western Coalfields Limited (WCL). The bird was brought from a breeder in Hyderabad around two years ago.

“My daughter, who is an MBBS, is a bird lover. She had bought Bravo for Rs50,000 with the money she had received as her first stipend. Bravo is a very intelligent bird and learns quickly. He is like a son to me and an integral member of our family,” Mahure told TOI.

According to Mahure, Bravo and their pet dog come to him as soon as he returns home from office in the evening. “And while having tea, I offer toast to Bravo who loves it,” he said.

On March 3, as usual Bravo approached Mahure after he returned home. “When I stepped outside for while to talk on the phone, Bravo too followed me. Before I could realize it, he had taken off and vanished. Though it was almost dark, we searched for Bravo everywhere but could find no trace.” So upset were they after losing the bird, none of them had dinner that night, said Mahure.

The next day, Mahure approached Mankapur police station and informed senior PI Vazeer Sheikh about the incident. “Initially, I was a bit embarrassed to approach the cops but the PI was very helpful. He took cognisance of my complaint,” said Mahure.

PI Sheikh immediately alerted other police personnel on wireless and gave them details about Bravo and his description.

During his meeting with the locals on the evening of March 4, PI Sheikh told them Bravo and also shared the bird’s pictures on social media.

When one of the residents informed Mankapur police that he had spotted a grey bird, cops along with Mahure rushed to the spot. “I had lost all hope of finding Bravo. But when I saw him sitting on a mango tree and called him, Bravo immediately flew towards me and landed on my hand. He was very frightened, thirsty and hungry after being away from home for almost 24 hours. It is a dying breed and they are a bit heavy, so it is hard for them to find food,” said Mahure.

Title: Man, bank manager booked for fraud
Content:
Nagpur: Following directives of a court, Sitabuldi police have registered a case of fraud against a man and a manager in State Bank of India ’s Ramdaspeth branch for allegedly transferring fixed deposit amount of Rs30 lakh of a deceased customer without the consent of all legal heirs between July 2019 and January 2020.

The accused have been identified as Padmakar Kukde and Dilip Meghani, branch manager.

According to police, Kukde’s father Kumar had a fixed deposit with the Ramdaspeth branch of SBI. After Kumar’s death, Padmakar with the help of Meghani got the money transferred in his name by submitting fake documents.

Padmakar’s sister Madhuri learnt about it and confronted her brother. She later filed a case in court. Following the directions of the court, Sitabuldi police have registered a case under sections of 420, 409, 468, 471, 34 of Indian Penal Code (IPC).

Police said that though role of the branch manager was not clear, thorough investigation will be carried out. An offence has been registered against the branch manager as the complainant alleged he was complicit in the fraud. No arrests have been made in the case.

Title: 3k-strong police team to ensure security
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: City police will be fielding a strong posse of 3,000 personnel on the streets on Monday to ensure the safety and smooth conduct of pongala .

Police have divided the force into four zones. Each zone is controlled by an officer in the rank of SP. The temple and the surrounding places are identified as Inner Zone. Woman battalion commandant D Shilpa Devaiah is in charge of this zone.

The Outer Zone, which comprises the city roads where devotees take position to offer pongala, is under the supervision of SP K S Vimal, who is the commandant of special armed police camp in the city.

The vehicular movement and parking is under the control of Traffic Zone. Special cell SP V Ajith, attached to police headquarters, has the charge of Traffic Zone.

The fourth zone is Emergency Zone, which has the responsibility to attend to exigencies such as fire accidents and health emergencies.

Deputy commissioner P A Muhammed Arif is in charge of the Emergency Zone.

Besides the personnel of Inner Zone, Woman Commandos and quick response team (QRT) will also be deployed on the temple premises.

Bike patrolling squads will patrol the roads and bylanes. Officers in mufti and shadow cops will be looking out for eve teasers and chain snatchers.

The entire police force is consists of 21 deputy superintendents, 62 inspectors, including 12 women, 450 sub-inspectors, 700 women police officers and 1,760 men officers. In addition to this, a team of officers from Tamil Nadu too will be on duty to assist the police here.

Police will be monitoring the entire pongala action from two control rooms, the city police control room and the special control room set up on the temple premise.

As many as 65 cameras have been installed in the temple zone. Drone cameras will also be used to monitor the activities.

Title: First loco pilot and train guard of NWR inspiring many
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: Once considered male bastions like any other field, these women conquered them with their grit, hard work and family support.

Being a loco pilot or a train guard is a demanding job, but Durgesh Sankhla and Renu Verma have inspired many others to pursue this path.

Durgesh, 38, joined the railways as assistant locomotive pilot in 2011 and after working in Jodhpur division, she is now seen in various local and express trains in the Ajmer division.

“It feels great when people give me respect for being the first woman locomotive pilot in the North Western Railway (NWR). Though I am presently working as assistant locomotive pilot, I am sure with my promotion I would be able to handle the train fully,” said Durgesh, who is a known name in the fraternity of locomotive pilots in Ajmer division. She spoke to TOI soon after bringing train number 59608 from Pushkar to Ajmer on halt.

After Durgesh joined the service, she inspired many to become a loco pilot in NWR. “We now have 15 women loco pilots. They are disciplined and punctual in their duties,” said a senior officer of the commercial wing of the NWR.

Like Durgesh, Renu Verma, too, broke the ceiling by clearing the departmental exam to become a rail guard in September 2019. She is the only train guard in NWR. “I was working as gateman and thereafter was promoted as pointman. Sadly, it has been a male bastion and the designations are not gender-neutral. There was a departmental vacancy and I asked my husband if I can prepare for the test and apply for the post of guard and he supported me. Thus, I became a guard in September 2019,” she added.

Renu’s husband, who has a private job, is a proud man in Bandikui. “I feel very proud when people remind me that I am husband of the first train guard of NWR. My job was to support her. It is her sheer hard work and commitment that has helped her.”

Title: Blaze of piety: Cautious city ready for Holika dahan
Content:
Ahmedabad: In the shadow of COVID-19, the city and state prepared to celebrate the Holi festival with caution with Holika Dahan falling on Monday and Dhuleti on Tuesday.

City-based experts said that the best time to light the bonfire would be after 7pm. Mahendra Jha, trustee of Jagannathji Temple, said that the event marks the victory of good over evil and also teaches us to have faith.

“Special prayers have been organized on Monday and Tuesday along with shringar for the deities,” he said.

Traditionally, several bonfires are created using cow dung cakes, wood and inflammable material at designated spots where the devotees perform a parikrama and offer popped sorghum and millet along with dates and other offerings to the holy fire. In several parts of Gujarat, the wind direction on the day is also considered to be indication of the summer and monsoon.

Several schools and colleges celebrated Dhuleti on Saturday.

At Iskcon temple and at Harekrishna temple at Bhadaj, the ‘Gaur Purnima’ would be celebrated on Monday with Chappan Bhog and Abhishek. Vishnunamdas of Iskcon temple said that flower holi will be celebrated with 2,000kg of flowers.

At Kalyanpushti Haveli in Vastrapur, the bonfire will take place at 7pm and rajbhog at 10.45am whereas dolotsav (dhuleti) will take place at 10.30-11am. At Swaminarayan Temple, Maninagar, the phooldolotsav will take place from 8am to 10am on Tuesday.

Title: SMC deputy town planner caught taking Rs 1.50L bribe
Content:
Ashwin Tailor

Surat: Sleuths of anti-corruption bureau (ACB) nabbed a 47-year-old deputy town planner of Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC) for allegedly accepting a bribe of Rs1.50 lakh here on Sunday. The accused was nabbed near Udhna crossroads when he accepted the money while sitting in his car to dodge ACB. The accused had demanded money from an official of a commercial complex to not demolish unauthorized construction in the building.

Ashwin Tailor, deputy town planner in Limbayat zone, began to perspire heavily when he was caught, ACB sources said. The trap was laid by K J Chaudhary, police inspector, under supervision of N P Gohil, assistant director, ACB.

The accused had found unauthorized construction in a commercial building and served notice to its management. The building officials approached him to spare them for which Tailor demanded Rs1.50 lakh.

The accused told the complainant to come near DCB Bank on Udhna crossroads. When the complainant reached there, he saw the accused sitting in his car. Tailor asked the complainant to get in and accepted the money and immediately ACB officials entered the vehicle and nabbed him.

ACB officials informed that Tailor was already facing an inquiry of having disproportionate assets. "ACB is inquiring into the wealth of a few SMC officers and Tailor is one of them," said an ACB officer.

Tailor has a tainted service record. He was suspended by municipal commissioner in 2017 for allegedly removing a page that had noting of top officials. The file was related to land demanded by a petrol pump owner near a heritage site. "A departmental inquiry was ordered against J M Patel, deputy commissioner, Debashish Basak, town planner, and Tailor. Based on the findings of the inquiry, Tailor was suspended," the ACB officer added.

Tailor was reinstated in his job in November 2018.

"The disproportionate assets inquiry is continuing against Tailor. ACB is carrying out a search in his house,” the officer added.

Title: Sans feeder service, Metro gets mostly weekend joyrides
Content:
Nagpur: The ridership of Nagpur Metro continues to remain abysmally low as MahaMetro has failed to provide feeder services at the existing stations and open new ones.

Services had started on Reach I (Sitabuldi to Khapri stretch) in March 2019. Five out of 11 stations had been started at that time and MahaMetro had promised to start remaining six by December 2019. However, so far only one new station — Jaiprakash Nagar — has been started. Feeder services, that too partial, are available only at Khapri station.

According to figures provided by MahaMetro, the daily average ridership of Reach I in December 2019 was 3,613. This reduced to 3,531 in January, 3,555 in February and 3,457 in March. Clearly, the figure is hovering around 3,500 mark. The ridership of Nagpur Metro as per the detailed project report (DPR) should be 3 lakh per day.

The situation in Reach III — Sitabuldi to Lokmanya Nagar stretch — is even worse. The ridership in February was 3,152 and in March it was 3,055.

Even these figures are misleading. The ridership is far higher on weekends and lower on weekdays. This shows that many Nagpurians still use the Metro for joyrides instead of commuting to their place of work or study. The ridership of Reach I on February 9, a Sunday, was 7,922 and 2,502 on February 11, a Tuesday. The ridership of Reach III on February 9 was 10,046, but came down to 3,071 two days later.

According to MahaMetro spokesperson, feeder city bus service is available only on four routes — Airport South and Airport to Beltarodi, Khapri to Mihan, Jaiprakash Nagar to Mhalgi Nagar and Jaiprakash Nagar to Jaitala.

The spokesperson said that proposals had been submitted to Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) for integrating Metro and city bus service. “About 4,500 persons travel daily from Sitabuldi to Butibori. We have asked NMC to run feeder service from Khapri station to Butibori so that these people use the Metro,” he added.

He further said that about 5,500 persons travelled from Sitabuldi to Hingna every day. “NMC should run feeder buses from Lokmanya Nagar station to Hingna,” he added.

On feeder services, the spokesperson said that 575 people were using Metro’s e-bicycles every day. “We are trying to start e-rickshaw services from March 25. These vehicles need charging point and we are setting up one at Khapri station,” he added.

Title: Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation bets on ‘Jan e-rickshaw’ for last-mile connectivity
Content:
The AMC has already provided a parking dock for this new set of e-rickshaws opposite Keshavbaug

AHMEDABAD: The ‘ Jan e-rickshaw ’, the new electric rickshaw to be launched on Ahmedabad streets shortly is being positioned by the civic body to be its best bet for improving last-mile connectivity to homes and offices from bus or metro stations.

The Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) feels the rickshaws will help increase city transportation use, which has been declining since the last eight years.

The Ahmedabad Municipal, Corporation (AMC) has already provided a parking dock for this new set of e-rickshaws opposite Keshavbaug.

When TOI visited the dock a few days back close to 20 odd e-rickshaws were parked.

“These rickshaws will help improve connectivity to interior residential and office areas of the city,” said a senior AMC official closely associated with the project. The figures give it away. The 89km BRTS coverage has, in fact, cut citizens’ total usage of the AMTS by nearly 18% since 2009 — defeating the very purpose of the mass transit system. Interestingly, the city's vehicle population has increased to 43 lakh from 24 lakh in 2009.

Transportation critics have pointed out in the past that the failure in tackling crucial issues like last-mile connectivity for public transport, subsidised road taxes and parking fees, integrating BRTS with other public transport systems as reasons behind lesser public transport use and traffic problems.

Title: Currency coins worth Rs 14 lakh seized in Valsad
Content:
Two persons were detained with the packet of coins

Surat: Two persons were caught by a team of Surat range IGP office in Valsad on Sunday after they were found in possession of Rs5 and Rs10 coins worth Rs13.80 lakh. They initially told police they were taking the money for use at toll plaza but later confessed to be heading to traders dealing in them.

Police detained Pintu Vasant Kachela and Dattatrey Bhamre, a resident of Dastan village in Surat, when they were going in a car with the money near Dharampur crossroads. The duo was later allowed to go by the cops who seized the coins from them.

Title: Vijayawada swings into poll mode with notification announcement on Monday
Content:
VIJAYAWADA: The post of mayor in Vijayawada city has been reserved for a woman (general category). Previous women mayors in the city include Panchamarthi Anuradha , Tadi Sakunthala, Muthamsetty Ratna Bindu and Mallika Begum.

The election notification will be released on Monday and the nomination process will commence from March 11 and last till March 13. Candidates can withdraw their nominations by 3 pm on March 16.

After the state election commission (SEC) released the schedule for municipal elections on Saturday, Vijay Kumar G Srkr, commissioner of municipal administration released ward-wise reservations for 16 municipal corporations and 103 municipalities across the state.

Reservations were declared for 672 divisions in municipal corporations and 2,123 wards in municipalities, Vijay Kumar said, adding that elections will be held only in 12 municipal corporations though reservations have been confirmed for all 16 municipal corporations in the state, following court orders.

As population in the city increased, the number of wards in the city was increased from 59 to 64 after the 2014 elections. Thirty-two of the 64 wards are reserved for women (19 for general women, 10 for BC women and 3 for SC women ), in keeping with 50 per cent reservations for women in local bodies.

Of the 19 wards reserved for general women, one will be allocated to the post of city mayor, based on reservations declared by officials.

Authorities of the Vijayawada Municipal Corporation (VMC) and the Krishna district administration have started preparations for the local body polls. District collector and VMC special officer A Mohammed Imtiaz directed officials to follow guidelines while officials asked political parties to avoid putting up flex banners and other promotinal posters.

Special election officers have started to implement the model code of conduct. Officials added that they will cover the statues of political leaders starting Monday and impose penalties on candidates found erecting banners without obtaining permission.

Police have started conducting checks at multiple locations across the city.

Title: Metro likely to face funds crunch next year
Content:
Nagpur: As Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) and Nagpur Improvement Trust (NIT) have refused to pay any more money and the state government is not giving its full share, work of Nagpur Metro is likely to be hit severely in next financial year. The cost of the project is Rs8,680 crore and MahaMetro needs about Rs1,200 crore from the three agencies.

A source in MahaMetro said that the total share of the NMC and the NIT was Rs868 crore of which the two agencies had given only land worth Rs228 crore. “Both have refused to pay the remaining Rs640 crore. We have been repeatedly urging the state government for the last two years to force them to pay their share of money but are yet to receive a single communication in this regard,” the source said.

The state government itself is not paying its full contribution. MahaMetro had sought Rs518 crore in 2019-20 through supplementary grants but did not get a single penny. Now it needs Rs788 crore of which it was allocated only Rs245 crore in the state budget. Now, the state needs to pay Rs543 crore through supplementary grants. If it bears civic bodies’ share then it will have to sanction another Rs1,183 crore.

Of the state government share, Rs210 crore is equity, Rs181 crore is subordinate debt towards the state taxes and remaining is subordinate debt towards the central taxes.

Former chief minister Devendra Fadnavis has been urged by Metro officials to make the NMC and the NIT pay their share but to no effect. The NMC is ruled by Fadnavis’ party, the BJP. The former CM handled the urban development portfolio, which could issue directives to the NMC and the NIT. Moreover, even during Fadnavis’ regime MahaMetro did not get the entire amount it sought, which is the reason for the huge backlog.

On the other hand the central government and the foreign lending agencies have been prompt in paying their share. “So far, the centre has provided us Rs1,067 crore equity and only Rs47 crore remains. It has paid Rs418 crore as subordinate debt towards the central taxes and only Rs23 crore remains. The lending agencies have given us Rs4,219 crore and assured to pay the remaining Rs302 crore next year,” said the source.

TABLE

Total project cost | Rs8,680 crore

Remaining central contribution | Rs70 crore

Remaining foreign loan | Rs302 crore

State’s balance share | Rs543 crore

Unpaid share of NMC, NIT | Rs640 crore

Total funds more needed | Rs1,555 crore

Title: Delhi Violence News: AAP government starts giving out full compensation to victims of northeast Delhi riots
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: AAP government on Sunday started disbursing full compensation to the victims of the northeast Delhi riots . Till March 8, the government had disbursed a total compensation amount of Rs 4.5 crore.

According to a government statement, families of 35 people who were killed in the riots were given full amount of Rs 10 lakh on Sunday. Many of these families were earlier given an ex gratia of Rs 1 lakh by the government and the remaining amount was given after the verification of the compensation forms.

The government has so far received compensation forms from 39 families who lost a member in the riots. While the remaining four families have also been given the ex gratia of Rs 1 lakh each, the remaining, said officials, would also be disbursed soon.

Similarly, the government on Sunday handed over Rs 2 lakh each to the families of 10 people who were seriously injured in the clashes. The families of 70 severely injured had deposited their forms for compensation at the helpdesks set up by the government at different places in the last few days.

“The remaining 60 have already been given the ex gratia of Rs 25,000 each. All severely injured will get the full compensation soon,” said an official. Of 562 claims of damaged shops, the government gave full compensation to 50 on Sunday.

Of 1,102 completed compensation forms received by the government till March 8, 95 were disposed of by handing over the full amount while 282 were given the ex gratia.

Deputy chief minister Manish Sisodia had set up a special team on Friday to verify compensation documents.

Title: Ahmedabad: After bomb scare, drunk man gets bail
Content:
Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel International airport

AHMEDABAD: A flyer in inebriated condition — Madanlal Prajapat, 31, of Bengaluru — created a bomb scare at Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel International Airport on Saturday by claiming that his bag contained an explosive device. This put the airport staff on high alert and police were called in. However, nothing suspicious was found in his bag.

“We found that the passenger was drunk and was trying to create panic at Terminal-1, Counter 13 of the domestic airport,” said inspector K C Rathwa of the airport police station. “He seemed to be in a hurry to get out of the airport and that is why he created a bomb scare. He was arrested on Saturday and is currently out on bail.”

The FIR was lodged by assistant head constable Dhansukh Gulabbhai. “We have arrested him under the Prohibition Act and sections 110 and 117 for creating a ruckus at the airport and giving false information about a bomb in the bag,” said a police official.

Police officials said Prajapat had gone to Rajasthan about a week ago. “He had to travel to Bengaluru from Ahmedabad. He was drunk and that is why he was in a hurry to exit the airport,” said a police source.

Title: KSRTC arranges 100 special buses
Content:
T’puram: Over hundred buses have been arranged by KSRTC to clear the rush of devotees visiting the city to offer Pongala for Attukal temple festival on Monday. The services from various locations in the city to Attukal temple will begin from 2am onwards.

The buses towards Balaramapuram, Neyyattinkara, Kaliyikkavila and Nagercoil will be operated from Karamana and Killipalam area. The buses towards Thiruvallam-Kovalam, Vizhinjam, Poovar, Venganoor, Poonkulam-Kakkamoola, Peringamala region will be operated from area near Kamaleswaram school. The buses to Peroorkada, Nedumangad, Vattiyoorkavu and Palode area will be operated from Vellayambalam and East Fort. Buses to Venjaramoodu, Kilimanoor, Kottarakara, Attingal, Kollam (via NH and MC road) will start from Thampanoor. Bus services from Bakery Junction will cover the route Bakery-Vazhuthacaud-Peyad.

The buses towards Pallichal-Venganoor, Vellayani-Kakkamoola, Papanamcode-Malayam-Malayinkeezhu, Ooruttambalam-Kattakada will be available for devotees at Karamana, Killipalam and Maruthoorkadavu. “The bus services will be operated at these stops till rush of devotees clears,” said KSRTC zonal traffic officer. KSRTC control room can be contacted for details related to bus service at 0471-2463799, 9447071021 or WhatsApp number: 8129562972. TNN

Title: Don’t discharge woman in a coma, court tells hospital
Content:
Bengaluru: A 39-year-old woman, who is in a coma for 11 months after alleged medical negligence during a minor surgery to remove non-cancerous lumps in her breast, will remain in hospital following an interim order from the Karnataka high court.

Kavitha H’s husband Anand K had approached the high court alleging Sagar Hospitals at Tilak Nagar was demanding he pay a Rs 23 lakh bill towards his wife’s medical expenses and was threatening to discharge her.

“In the facts and circumstances of this case, the court deems it necessary to direct 4th respondent (Sagar Hospitals) not to discharge the petitioner’s wife from its care till the next date of hearing. The 4th respondent should also understand that if faulty treatment is given to the petitioner’s wife, it may be guilty of medical negligence,” the high court said in its interim order on March 3.

The matter is listed for hearing on March 16.

Sagar Hospitals did not respond to emails, messages and calls from TOI seeking to know its version of the events.

The patient’s husband also lodged a complaint of medical negligence against Sagar Hospitals with the Karnataka Medical Council, which issued a showcause notice to the hospital on February 26. KMC has asked both the parties to appear before it for a hearing on March 21.

Was meant to be a

day-care procedure

Speaking to TOI, Anand recalled the day (April 22, 2019) when his wife was taken to the hospital for a day-care procedure. “She was fit and fine and walking. We chose to get the surgery done during my daughter’s school holidays. It was a surgery that would cost just Rs 12,000. I was asked to pay the amount prior to the procedure which would be reimbursed through the Central Government Health Scheme. She was taken to the OT at 3pm. There was no intimation from doctors for the next three hours. Around 6.30pm, the doctors came out, only to say she wasn’t recovering,” said Anand.

Anand claimed till today the hospital hasn’t explained why his wife slipped into a coma. “According to some other specialists I consulted, my wife’s is a case of complication arising out of anaesthesia. The doctors who operated on her haven’t explained what went wrong,” he said.

Title: Bengaluru: Cop-couple’s daughter, 15, steps into Shivajinagar traffic inspector’s shoes
Content:
Sania at Shivajinagar on Sunday

BENGALURU: When Sania S Moula issued directions to remove vehicles from a no-parking zone and asked riders to wear helmet at several places in Shivajinagar on Sunday morning, many were left befuddled. For, the 15-year-old looked every inch a schoolgirl and wore no khaki. But those pulled up had no choice but to fall in line, as she sat inside a police jeep and shot off her orders.

Sania, after all, was playing the role of Shivajinagar traffic inspector, a job she had been assigned to mark International Women’s Day. Her mother Shabhana works at the traffic police headquarters as a head constable, while father S Moula, also a head constable, works at Anekal police station.

Sania, who had never visited a police station till Sunday, received a ceremonial welcome at Shivajinagar station. She immediately left in a police jeep, sitting on the passenger seat reserved for the officer to whom the vehicle is assigned. Inspector Anil Purohit, whose place she had taken, was at the wheel.

As they reached Balekundri Circle, Sania asked autorickshaw drivers why they had parked their vehicles at bus stops. While the drivers were initially confused, Anil introduced Sania to them. She also alerted riders speaking over the phone, warned them against not wearing helmets and directed her colleagues to clear vehicles from a no-parking area.

“It was an exciting day. It also instilled confidence in me. I thoroughly enjoyed my stint as a cop inside and outside the police station,” Sania later told TOI.

Shabana said it was not just an honour for her daughter but for women in general. “Purohit, who worked with me at the traffic headquarters, asked me to bring my child and explained about their Women’s Day celebrations. I am happy she gained a lot of confidence,” she said.

Sania is a class 10 student of Ujwala Vidyalaya at Whitefield.

Title: Woman dies of KFD in Wayanad
Content:
Kozhikode: Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD) or monkey fever has claimed one life in Wayanad , with a 48-year-old woman succumbing to the disease at the Kozhikode government medical college on Sunday. This is the first KFD death in the state this year.

Meenakshi, the deceased tribal woman, hailing from Narangakunnu Colony at Kattikulam near the Kerala-Karnataka border was admitted to the Mananthavady district hospital on March 4 with symptoms of the disease and were shifted to the medical college on March 6.

Three other people who tested positive for KFD are under treatment, with two persons admitted to Kozhikode medical college and one at the Mananthavady district hospital.

Wayanad DMO Dr R Renuka said that the condition of the three patients was stable. There have been 13 positive cases so far this year and nine patients were discharged after recovery.

The department has stepped up surveillance and preventive measures in view of the KFD season, normally coinciding with the summer months, but those in high-risk categories are reluctant to get vaccinated, the DMO said. All the reported cases this year was from the Thirunelly panchayat which is surrounded by forests, she added.

Health department authorities said people living on forest fringes and those venturing into forests for livelihood like collection of minor forest produce, wood, etc, have been directed to get themselves vaccinated.

Applying insect repellent ointments, using anti-tick lotions on domestic animals grazing in forest areas are some precautionary measures. Forest department staff too have been directed to take KFD vaccination.

KFD is transmitted primarily through bites of infected ticks (Heamaphysalis spinigera). The KFD outbreaks coincide with high nymphal activity of Haemaphysalis spinigera ticks — the main vector of the disease — during January to May. Monkeys acquire infection through infected tick bites and act as amplifying hosts with the virus getting transmitted to other ticks on monkeys.

Title: Rajpath staffer threatened over rebuke
Content:
Ahmedabad: A floor-in-charge of Rajpath club on SG Road on Saturday filed a complaint with Vastrapur police alleging that the brother of a gym trainer of the club had allegedly threatened him for scolding the trainer. In his FIR, Pavan Bhavsar, 29, a resident of Maninagar and the floor in-charge, states that he has been working the Rajpath club for two months and four gym trainers work under him.

On Friday, when Bhavsar was on duty, he found the four gym trainers including two men and two women holding a discussion in the club. At that time, Bhavsar’s superior told him that the four should not conduct a discussion in the gym of the club, states the FIR.

After that, Bhavsar summoned the four persons to his office and scolded them for flouting the club’s rule by holding discussion in an improper way and told them they were guilty of indiscipline. Bhavsar told them that they should not repeat such a mistake again and let them go.

Bhavsar further states in his FIR that he received a call from an unknown number on Friday night. The caller identified himself as a gym trainer’s brother and threatened Bhavsar for scolding the trainer, and said he would face dire consequences if the trainer lost his job.

“The man told me that he will kill me with his licensed revolver if his brother was sacked by Rajpath club. The man threatened to assault me and defame me,” said Bhavsar in his FIR.

Later, Bhavsar continued to receive threat calls so he contacted his superiors in the club and then approached Vastrapur police.

Inspector M M Jadeja of Vastrapur police station said that the accused had not yet been identified and the cops have summoned the gym trainer at whose behest the man had threatened Bhavsar.

Police have registered a complaint of criminal intimidation and began an investigation.

Title: Ahmedabad: Karnavati restaurant contractor gets notice
Content:
A grab of the video of the club kitchen posted on social media

AHMEDABAD: The management of Karnavati Club on Sunday issued a notice to the restaurant contractor at the club’s fine-dine restaurant, seeking explanation of poor hygiene in the kitchen. The decision came after a video shot by a club member went viral, where the club restaurant kitchen is shown in a filthy condition, with filthy floors and dirty vessels.

Narrating the sequence of events, a senior club management official said, “The member placed an order for food at 2.17am on Sunday at the restaurant which usually closes by 3pm. After finding hygiene compromised, the member immediately stormed into the kitchen around 2.45pm and shot a video and later circulated it among club members. When the in-charge at night intervened in the matter, asking the member to file a complaint, the said member refused to register an official complaint and instead, left the premises without even paying the bill.”

“If the concern was genuine, the complaint should have been brought on record. Despite this, we have issued a notice to the contractor, demanding an explanation for the situation in the kitchen,” said the senior club management official.

Sources said that when the restaurant contractor was verbally asked for an explanation of the kitchen condition, he said that cleaning of the restaurant was going on as it was near closing time.

Title: Wife accuses IPS of criminal breach of trust, lodges FIR
Content:
Lucknow: An FIR was lodged against a serving IPS officer by his wife at Hazratganj police station on Sunday.

The woman has accused her husband of criminal breach of trust, criminal conspiracy, and disappearing of evidence. The FIR was lodged on the direction of special secretary (home department) Anil Kumar Singh.

The complainant woman was married to the IPS officer in 2016, while the latter was posted as SP (city) in Ghaziabad.

She has also alleged in the FIR that her husband had multiple affairs and in order to conceal it the latter framed her in false case and got her arrested on August 10, 2019. Since then, she has been lodged in Ghaziabad jail. She has also alleged that a senior sub-inspector at the behest of her husband also stole her five mobile handsets, which had evidences of her husband’s multiple affairs outside marriage, while she had gone to lodge a complaint at Sahibabad police station.

“I had then gone to lodge a complaint against a friend of my husband who had then forcefully entered the residence to collect evidences, which I had of his multiple affairs,” she told in her FIR to the police.

She has added in the FIR that she had also learnt on the same day that her husband had got a non-bailable warrant issued against her in Rs 2 lakh fraud case. Her name was added by the police at the insistence of her husband in May 20, 2019. She has also alleged that her husband is trying to eliminate her and has got lodged four FIRs against her.

The FIR has also been lodged against a friend of the IPS, a sub-inspector, and police team which arrested the woman at Kavinagar police station under the same charges.

The woman is also a practising lawyer in the Delhi high court but has been languishing in jail since August, 2019.

Title: Gujarat: At Nahri restaurants, tribal women cook recipes of success
Content:
Each outlet makes a turnover of Rs 50,000 or more every month

SURAT: Flavour’s quintessentially tribal in every spirit of the word here — from taste to the décor — in the Nahri restaurants.

Structured as a tribal hut, flavours of freshly cooked vegetables wafting in the air, menu written in a blackboard and served by women staff dressed in red or blue sarees — the distinctive feature in each of the 13 Nahri restaurants — which has managed to create a niche for itself in south Gujarat with its epicurean spread.

Nahri, the name taken from the tribal dialect meaning food for the guests, started with one restaurant in 2007 at Gangpur near Vansadahas to spread the taste of authentic tribal food in the region. Today, the chain of restaurants conceptualised and developed by BAIF Development Research Foundation opened 13 more doors across three districts.

Thousands flock to these restaurants located in remote tribal areas to savour nagli (Ragi) rotla with bamboo pickle, but very few would know that behind the curtain, the ropes are managed only by women of a self help group (SHG).

Nahri is a successful business model today with each outlet making a turnover of Rs 50,000 or more every month on an average. Even some of the more popular restaurants earn around Rs 70,000 per month.

"We are now working towards branding of the concept. We want this network of restaurants to spread gradually. We are now planning to give Nahri the look of a chain restaurant and also bring uniformity in its menu," said Sandip Yadav, senior programme manage, BAIF Development Research Foundation.

Nahri has eight branches in Dang and five in Navsari and Valsad. The latest addition is a meal-on-wheel concept in which a Nahri restaurant has been started on a mini truck by SHG of Savarkhadi village.

"The truck goes to different locations on each days of the week where weekly markets take place. While people get good quality food on the spot, we get good business," said Mani Dawda, programme operator, BAIF.

The restaurants serve only one dish — Dangi Thali comprising Nagli or Rice Rotla, green vegetable, black gram dal, rice, bamboo pickle and a chutney of green and red chillies.

“The dish was finalised after testing nutrition value of various tribal food items with support of Tata Trust," said Yadav. In developing the chain of restaurants to this level BAIF received support of NABARD, ONGC and department of science and technology of central government.

"The women members of SHG come from needy financial backgrounds and work at their own farms besides serving at the restaurants on rotational duties. The earnings have helped them ensure education for their children and medication for their family members," Dawda added.

Title: Aurangabad resident cheated of Rs 52 lakh
Content:
Representative image

Nashik: A 70-year Aurangabad resident was cheated by three-four persons of Nashik to the tune of Rs 52 lakh. A complaint has been registered with the Indiranagar police station.

The complainant said that he had met a person, who has a religious trust in Nashik, through his friend in May 2019. The person had told the complainant that he had to set up a hospital and hostel for girls. However, before constructing these buildings, he wanted to hold a ‘yagya’ , which would cost him Rs 2 crore.

The person told the complainant that he was in need money and though he had sufficient quantity of gold with him, he did not want to sell it until the yagya was complete. Subsequently, the man from Nashik and one another person took Rs 52 lakh from the complainant.

However, later, the complainant came to know that the religious man had neither conducted the yagya nor was he returning his money. He then lodged a complaint with the Indiranagar police.

Title: 43-yr-old in GMCH Covid-19 -ve, Chanda youth new suspect
Content:
Nagpur: The 43-year-old suspected novel coronavirus patient, who was admitted to the quarantine ward of the Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH) on Saturday, has tested negative for the infection.

The suspect’s reports came from the lab facility at Indira Gandhi Government Medical College (IGGMCH) late on Sunday evening. As his condition was improving, he will be discharged most probably on Monday morning.

Meanwhile, a 28-year-old youth from Chandrapur having travel history to Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan was admitted on Sunday with complaints of cough, cold and fever. “The youth had visited Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan between February 12 and 28 for business purpose. He returned via New Delhi on February 28,” said GMCH medical superintendent Dr Avinash Gawande.

According to doctors, this patient was suffering from cough and cold for the last five to six days. As fever also developed in the last two days, he was advised to report to Nagpur GMCH and test for Covid-19. The youth has been admitted to the Covid-19 isolation ward no. 25. His swab samples have been collected and sent for testing.

On Sunday evening, guardian minister of Nagpur district Nitin Raut visited the GMCH and inspected preparations to tackle coronavirus cases. Sources said Raut appreciated the arrangements at the GMCH.

Title: Covid-19 outbreak may affect international admissions this year in Karnataka
Content: MANGALURU: Following the Covid-19 outbreak international tourism has taken a hit and travel plans have been put on hold. Dakshina Kannada and Udupi districts which are an education hub, attract many international students. Academicians are optimistic and are hoping that by the time the National Eligibility-Cum-Entrance Test (NEET- UG) is conducted, the situation will be under control.Dr P Giridhar Kini, director, admissions , Manipal Academy of Higher Education (MAHE), Manipal, told TOI: “We do not foresee any impact of Covid-19 on international admissions. They are on schedule. The government of India is taking steps to contain the spread of the disease. We are sure that the situation will be fully under control by the time NRI students come to India to write the NEET examinations on May 3,” he said.At MAHE, the current strength of foreign and NRI students is more than 3,000.Dr Gangadhara Somayaji K S, registrar, Yenepoya (deemed to be university) said that it is too early to ascertain the impact of Covid-19 on international student admissions. The admission process has started and there is a possibility that people may be scared to travel.Similarly, the officials at the Nitte (deemed to be university) have not noticed major changes. Registrar Dr Alka Kulkarni said, “We have not noticed any difference in the number of enquiries that the institute has been receiving. For postgraduate admissions (medical and dental) there are no issues as the counselling process is online. For undergraduate students who will take NEET, there is still time, and we are hoping that the situation will be under control by then,” she said.Meanwhile, faculty from across colleges who had scheduled travel for seminars and conferences in places affected by Covid-19 have put their travel plans on hold. Many felt that a slowdown cannot be ruled out.

Title: Manoj Tiwari: BJP to initiate dialogue with Muslims on CAA
Content:
Manoj Tiwari

NEW DELHI: To dispel “misinformation” over the amended citizenship Act, Bharatiya Janata Party has decided to initiate dialogue with Muslims living in riot-affected areas of northeast Delhi.

Delhi BJP chief Manoj Tiwari said the party will soon engage professionals and eminent members of the community with “rational thinking” to reach out to prominent Muslims and religious heads. He added that a panel comprising non-political individuals from the community would be set up, who along with local party functionaries would call small meetings of residents and discuss the merits of the Act.

“We will build a team of neutral and non-political people with diverse professional backgrounds to interact with the members of the Muslim community. Initially, they will go to Muslim-dominated areas in northeast Delhi and may later visit other parts of the city too,” Tiwari, who represents northeast Delhi in the Lok Sabha, said.

At least 53 people were killed and over 500 injured in violent communal clashes in several parts of northeast Delhi in the last week of February. A large number of people were forced to abandon their houses and either leave Delhi or live with friends or relatives in other parts of the city for the fear of being targeted by the other community.

According to a trade body, property worth at least Rs 25,000 crore was burnt or vandalised in one of the worst communal riots in the capital since the 1984 anti-Sikh carnage.

Tiwari said that BJP had been trying to tell people across the country that CAA had nothing to do with Indian Muslims and added that the members of the community must come forward now to bust the myth around the Act. “They should tell the community not to fall prey to illusion being created by some. Those leading the anti-CAA protests are doing it for political benefits but it is causing heavy losses. Progressive thinkers should initiate discussion in the community. If a group of intellectuals from the community explain this to people, they will definitely understand,” the Delhi BJP chief added.

Title: ...While parties’ search for viable candidates begins
Content:
Vijayawada: Following the notification by the Krishna district administration confirming ward-wise reservations for municipal elections, political parties have turned their focus on selecting candidates. The reservations were made based on the population in the city.

The ruling YSR Congress (YSRC) is leading the race in selecting candidates. Competition for tickets is high, with as many as five candidates competing in some wards. Vijayawada Central legislator Malladi Vishnuvardhan, party in-charge of Vijayawada East Devineni Avinash and endowments minister Vellampalli Srinivas will finalise the list of candidates by Monday evening. The YSRC is also focusing on selecting candidates for the post of mayor, reserved for a woman from the general category.

Meanwhile, some YSRC candidates have started a door-to-door campaign in the city.

The Telugu Desam Party (TDP) is looking to give tickets to sitting corporators. The party is focusing on publicising development activities undertaken by it in its five-year-long tenure in the municipal council. The TDP is also preparing a manifesto for the development of the city and is likely to submit a report to party chief N Chandrababu Naidu and finalise the list of candidates on Tuesday morning.

The Jana Sena, which is contesting local body elections for the first time, is focusing on giving tickets to party workers who have supported it since its inception. Demand for Jana Sena tickets in Krishna Lanka, Balaji Nagar, Ramalingeswara Nagar and Kothapeta is high as the party fared well in these areas in the 2019 general elections.

Left parties, the Communist Party of India (CPI) and the Communist Party of India (Marxist), have decided to contest the local body elections together. Both parties have a significant cadre in the city and are looking to win a majority of the seats. Key functionaries of the Left parties organised a meeting on Sunday to discuss seat-sharing between them.

Title: Ahmedabad vulnerable to viral outbreaks
Content: AHMEDABAD: In May last year scientists from five leading central government-run disease and virology institutes of the country had detailed the list of viruses that were potent enough to cause an outbreak in different regions of the country. Ahmedabad district in Gujarat was among the 17 districts in the country mentioned as vulnerable to viral outbreaks in the study published recently in The Indian Journal of Medical Research Ahmedabad district in recent years have reported two major viral outbreaks for the first time in the country, the most recent being Zika viral infection in 2016-17 when three patients were detected with the virus, while a fourth case was reported from Tamil Nadu later that year. However, no Zika-associated microcephaly cases have been identified in the country, till date reports the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR)- National Institute of Virology (NIV). The other viral outbreak being the Crimean Congo haemorrhagic fever (CCHF) virus. Since its first detection in the country in 2011 in Ahmedabad, many sporadic outbreaks of CCHF have been investigated in Gujarat and adjoining Rajasthan. “A nation-wide survey by the ICMR-NIV Pune, revealed wide seropositivity amongst sheep, goat and cattle population across the country. Since 2011 till December 2018, almost 81 cases have been diagnosed positive for CCHF” (NIV, unpublished data) claims the research paper.The research paper also mentions that children in states like Gujarat Andhra Pradesh and Nagpur in Maharashtra were vulnerable to Chandipura virus outbreak. The paper has warned that Chandipura virus is also known to infect mosquitoes, mainly Aedes aegypti as it survives in the salivary gland of the mosquito for 4 to 5 days and is then transmitted. Another set of warning mentions Gujarat’s history of the outbreak of the Kyasanur forest disease (KFD) of 1960 in Saurashtra and Kutch.“The pathogenic and public health significance of KFD remains unexplored for a long time. Several of these infections take a heavy toll on the animal husbandry and agricultural industry,” says the paper authored by Devendra Mourya, of NIV, Pragya Yadav, PT Ullas, Sumit D, Rima Sahay, Anita Shete of Maximum Containment Laboratory, Pune; and others.

Title: Motorists may soon pay the price for defaulting penalty
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: City police may soon start recommending temporary suspension of driving licence of motorists who fail to remit penalty. A decision in this regard has been taken owing to the poor response of the motorists in following the instructions in the challans served to them and remitting penalty.

City police commissioner Balramkumar Upadhyay said that only a very small percentage of total persons booked had remitted the penalty.

“We are currently mulling over issuing three warnings to motorists and if they still ignored the notice, we would be forwarding their case to motor vehicles department with a recommendation to suspend their driving licence temporarily,” said Upadhyay, adding that the warnings would be issued in regular intervals within a period of two months.

The number of traffic offences detected by the city police had spiked more than ever in the past few months after the police started relying on mobile phone cameras instead of normal inspections.

Cases are also being booked based on the images and videos sent by public to the TC Vigil WhatsApp number of the city police. But it has been noticed that majority of motorists booked through police camera and TC Vigil WhatsApp number are ignoring the challans served.

In January alone, over 6,000 two-wheeler riders, including pillion riders, were booked for riding without helmet . But only over 1,000 persons remitted the penalty.

Similarly, the total number of riders booked for the same offence in February was just over 7,000. But, the number of people who remitted penalty was just 1,913.

“Our aim is not just to detect more cases but to make the erring motorists accountable for their offence and discourage them from repeating the offence,” the commissioner said.

According to M K Zulfiquer, assistant commissioner (city traffic, south) the normal procedure followed in the past was to forward the case to the court when the motorist failed to remit the penalty.

“It takes a lot of time to process the case files and forward them to court. Hence, often very few cases are randomly chosen and sent to courts. The court also refuses to entertain very old cases. As a result, a vast majority of offenders go scot free,” he said. The new system, if implemented, will ensure that all motorists booked are held accountable no matter how late it is, he added.

Currently, police are carrying out a special drive ‘Operation Head Gear’ to book two-wheeler riders and pillion riders who do not wear helmets. The aim of the drive is to encourage maximum riders to adhere to helmet rule and thereby reduce fatality owing to head injuries.

The drive kick-started on March 1 will conclude on March 31.

Title: Phone down the drain in jail check
Content:
Ahmedabad: An undertrial prisoner lodged at the Sabarmati central prison threw his phone into the toilet when a special jail squad carried out a surprise check on Saturday night.

The prisoner, identified as Shaktisinh Chudasma — who is accused of assault — threw his phone into the latrine of Barrack 1. According to the complaint registered with Ranip police, the cops could only determine that the phone was golden coloured before it disappeared down the drain.

The special squad found a cellphone from another undertrial prisoner, Pratapsinh Solanki. Solanki tried to hide his phone beneath a bedsheet but cops found it. Police have registered a case of disobeying a notification of a government official and have invoked charges under the Prisoners’ Act.

Title: Nashikites turn up in huge numbers for Nirbhaya Marathon
Content: NASHIK: Putting aside the fear of coronavirus , over 20,000 Nashikites turned up for the Nirbhaya Marthon event organised on the occasion of International Women’s Day on Sunday. Amid the beats of drums, Nashikites ran for fitness and to support the cause of women’s safety.Vinayak Dhobale won the 21 km half marathon in the mens caterogy with the timing of 1 hour, 12 minutes and 3 seconds while Asha TP bagged the first prize in the women’s category by completing the half marathon in 1 hour, 22 minutes and 32 seconds.Commissioner of Police Vishwas Nangare-Patil said, “The response by Nashikites for the Nirbhaya Marathon was simply overwhelming. This also went on to show the concern of Nashikites for women’s safety. The event was incident free. We also distributed 20,000 booklets on women’s safety.We also launched a video on women’s safety which was appreciated by one and all. The celebrities called for the event too spent a good time with the participants.”The marathon was flagged off from the Thakkar Dome. The police had kept sufficient time in between the different runs starting from 21 km half marathon to the 3 km fun run.The talk show organised by the police with cricketer Ajinkya Rahane and other celebrities had to be cancelled in the view of coronavirus scare. However, Rahane, Sairat fame Rinku Rajguru and Janhavi Kapoor encouraged the participants.

Title: Covid-19: One under radar in Mangaluru
Content: MANGALURU: One person, who arrived at Mangalore International airport from Dubai was sent to a quarantine facility set up at District Wenlock Hospital on Sunday over suspected coronavirus infection.District health and family welfare officer Sikandar Pasha said the passenger who arrived from Dubai showed signs of fever when screened. “As a precautionary measure, the passenger will be kept in quarantine facility overnight and discharged after a thorough check up if the person is found tests negative,” he said.VV Rao, airport director, MIA said all passengers arriving at the international terminal are being screened as per DGCA and ministry of civil aviation guidelines.

Title: Ward 33 residents start crusade to stop weekly veg market in their area
Content:
Nagpur: Buoyed by the success of anti-encroachment drive undertaken by municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe , citizens of ward no. 33 in South-West Constituency are now up in arms to put an end to the weekly vegetable market set up on the main road and narrow internal lanes of their residential areas on every Monday.

Residents from Samrat Ashoka Colony, Kashi Nagar, Rameshwari Road, Dwarkapuri and Hawrapeth have requested the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) and police department to ensure continuous drive against encroachments in their area.

The NMC, following mayor Sandip Joshi ’s policy to take stringent action against encroachments on roads and footpaths, kicked-started its drive on January 1. Mundhe, who assumed charge in the NMC on January 28, started action against weekly vegetable markets on main and internal roads in residential areas from February 1.

The action committee formed by the citizens of ward no. 33, while appreciating the drive against vegetable markets across the city, pointed out problems faced in their area due to a weekly vegetable market for the last 12-13 years. They met Mundhe and all four corporators of the ward to request them to shut the market.

According to the committee, they staged a silent demonstration on February 10 and 17 extending support to the NMC’s drive while demanding a similar action in their area. “A few vendors manhandled some of the residents. On February 24, we did not allow vendors to set up stalls. NMC and police deployed their teams to shut the market on March 2. But few vendors created hurdles. NMC lodged a complaint with Ajni police station and offence was registered against 20 persons,” the committee stated.

NMC and police teams were in the area from 2pm to 9.30pm, after which few vendors set up the market again,” the citizens said.

The citizens added that continuous and stringent action is needed to keep a check on vendors who are backed by anti-social elements. A group supporting the vendors is threatening us. There is a racket behind setting up of this market, they said.

On February 21, ward’s corporators Manojkumar Gawande, Vandana Bhagat, Vishaka Bante and Bharti Bunde lodged complaints with Joshi demanding stringent action against the market.

According to Gawande, residents are suffering a lot due to the market. “Earlier, the market used to be set up only on Rameshwari main road but now stalls are coming up even on internal lanes which are just six-five metre wide. Entrance to residential units are blocked. Also, vendors dump garbage and urinate in the area. NMC should set up a daily market on an open area nearby,” he told TOI.

Title: Jamuna Prasad Saroj appointed first Dalit chief of Apna Dal(S) UP unit
Content:
Jamuna Prasad Saroj

LUCKNOW: BJP ally Apna Dal (Sonelal) on Sunday played the Dalit card by appointing Jamuna Prasad Saroj as the party’s first Dalit state president. Saroj, MLA from Soraon reserved seat in Prayagraj, hails from Pasi community, the second largest group after Jatavs among the Dalits.

Bahujan Samaj Party chief Mayawati is a Jatav.

Saroj’s appointment comes days after BJP’s estranged ally, Om Prakash Rajbhar, founder of Suheldev Bharatiya Samaj Party (SBSP), entered into a political alliance with Bhim Army chief Chandrashekhar Azad. Azad is expected to float his political outfit on March 15, the birth anniversary of BSP founder Kanshi Ram.

The elevation of 52-year-old Saroj, a postgraduate from Kanpur University , is seen as Apna Dal’s bid to consolidate its position among Pasis, who account for 16% of the Dalit population in the state. Jatavs account for around 57% of the total Dalit population.

Saroj has replaced Rajendra Prasad Pal , an OBC, who has been elevated and made party’s national general secretary. Apna Dal (S) spokesperson Rajesh Patel said party chief Anupriya Patel decided to elevate the two leaders to key higher positions after taking their qualities into consideration and consulting senior party leaders.

Saroj is MLA from Soraon, an assembly segment in Phulpur seat, which was represented by UP deputy chief minister Keshav Prasad Maurya until Samajwadi Party’s Nagendra Pratap Singh wrested it from BJP in 2018 byelections. But BJP regained the seat in 2019 Lok Sabha elections.

Apna Dal (S), which is a Kurmi (backward) dominated party, is tying to make inroads into Dalit vote base in the run up to 2022 UP assembly elections.

Title: Water supply to be disrupted in city areas tomorrow
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: The water shortage faced by various areas in the city is likely to continue even after Attukal pongala. Several areas are facing water shortage after KWA began stocking water for pongala from March 6.

A day after pongala, KWA will shut down the 74mld treatment plant on Tuesday to do maintenance of a valve in the line bringing water from PTP Nagar tank to Vellayambalam area.

KWA has announced shutdown from 10am to 4pm on Tuesday for valve maintenance works. Areas to be affected include Thirumala, PTP Nagar, Maruthamkuzhy, Pangode, Kanjirampara, Vattiyoorkavu, Kachani, Nettayam, Malamukal, Kulasekharam, Valiyavila, Kodunganoor, Kundamankadavu, Kallumala, Mannarakonam, Punnakkamugal, Mudavanmugal, Poojapura,Karamana, Nemom, Pappanamcode, Thrikkanapuram, Kaimanam, Karumam, Kalady, Attukal, Manacaud, Kamaleswaram, Ambalathara, Beemapally, Poonthura, Valiyathura and Vallakadavu.

Sources in KWA said that it was difficult to operate a valve in the line which brings water to Vellayambalam area. “We have done temporary works to make it operational. We waited till pongala as the maintenance works demanded a shutdown. Now, the work will begin on Tuesday. Around 6 hours will be needed,” said KWA officials.

Areas such as Vellayambalam, Kowdiar, Kanaka Nagar etc. are affected by water crisis for the past few weeks. The shutdown will only worsen the water crisis in the city. Sources said that it would take around 24 hours to normalize water supply in elevated areas after the shutdown.

Interestingly, KWA has been supplying additional 15mld water per day to the city after the recent renovation of the plants at Aruvikkara. Though additional water has been pumped to the city for over a month, it has not reflected on the water availability in the city. Sources said that elevated areas continue to suffer while people in the low lying areas are using more water in the summer. “KWA lacks automated valve control systems. The manual operation of valve is not effective in ensuring water availability in all areas. The additional 15mld water should have to be efficiently diverted to elevated areas,” sources said.
