KWA officials said that water available at Peppara reservoir was enough to meet city’s requirements till June. The water level at Peppara was 103.45 metres on Sunday.

Title: Dhoni on a mission to stay master of his own destiny
Content:
Chennai: When Martin Guptill’s throw from the deep broke the stumps at the striker’s end to finish M S Dhoni and India’s dream of winning the 2019 ODI World Cup in England, it seemed to be the end of the road for the former Indian captain, at least on the international front.

Dhoni kept adding fuel to the fire by deciding to stay away from international cricket for the next eight months, but there were enough indications from all quarters that he wouldn’t stop playing for Chennai Super Kings ( CSK ) anytime soon. But the issue whether Dhoni should be considered for India again stayed alive. In fact, there’s a rumour going around that when during finalisation of the new national selection committee last week, the common question to the aspirants was whether they would consider Dhoni for the World T20s in Australia later this year.

While there are quite a few among the bosses at Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI) who believe Dhoni shouldn’t be considered for India anymore because of his audacity to take an eight-month sabbatical from India services, the detractors can’t really say that with conviction. They know it doesn’t take too long for the narrative to change in Indian cricket and a few match-winning cameos from the maverick’s bat during the IPL can swing things in his favour all over again.

And given Dhoni’s track record with CSK, it’s not an impossible dream. Dhoni has stayed the epitome of consistency for CSK in the 11 seasons that he has played for the team and there have been different shades to his relationship with the franchisee. It started in 2008 as an unknown quantity and Dhoni showed his calmness and maturity to build a team in the first three years. Once the groundwork was done, from 2011-13, it was only about the rise and rise of CSK — it was a success similar to Pep Guardiola’s Barcelona — a team that was running away with everything in football during those years. And then the match-fixing scandal happened and it was in those turbulent four years that the Dhoni-CSK relationship actually grew stronger. Dhoni played for the Pune franchisee for two years, but was open about his love for Chennai, which endeared him to the fans even more. And on CSK’s return, it was Dhoni who went against all popular notion of T20 being a young man’s sport and built a ‘Dad’s Army’, which won one title and lost the second in the last ball of the tournament.

But 2020 is a different story altogether. It is for the first time that Dhoni is going into an IPL where he has to prove to the world that he is still good enough. Most believe that even if he decides not to play for India anymore, he wants to do it on his own terms. And for that, a brilliant show in CSK colours is necessary.

Dhoni, on his part, is leaving no stone unturned. Yes, he hasn’t played international cricket for a while, but since January, he has been training very hard in Ranchi. And since the beginning of March he is in Chennai to prepare for the two-month grind. "Till last year, Dhoni always landed with a few days to go and a week’s practice was enough for him. But this time, it’s a proper pre-season and he is going flat out in practice. And make no mistake, he is super fit," bowling coach L Balaji, who is supervising the sessions, told TOI.

While Ambati Rayudu and Suresh Raina had landed in February, quite a few others like Piyush Chawla, M Vijay, Monu Singh and Sai Kishore have joined since Dhoni has arrived. Harbhajan Singh and the others who are not playing at present are also expected over the next one week. "With Dhoni here, the atmosphere is fantastic. The younger players, who may find it difficult to pick Dhoni’s brain during the IPL, are finding it easier now to interact with him and learn more," Balaji said.

The live streaming of the practice sessions are available too on social media and the fan frenzy has already started around Dhoni. On every practice day, there are a few thousands at the Chepauk to watch the master at work. It’s going to go up and Dhoni knows how much this midsummer madness means to his Chennai followers. Come IPL, he will look to make all of them happy, just as he will try to make a quiet point to the world that he is still master of his own destiny.

Title: Covid-19: AMU postpones exams for over 6,000 distant education students
Content:
Agra: Owing to the Covid-19 scare, Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) has decided to postpone all examinations of distant learning courses for students in Aligarh, Kerala, Murshidabad in West Bengal, Kishangarh in Bihar and Delhi. The examinations were to start from March 15.

Confirming this, director of distant learning centre, AMU, Nafees Ansari said 6,000 students who are enrolled in four degree courses, including BCom, MCom, Bachelor of Library Science, and BSc Computer application, will now appear for the exams from April 1. He said the decision was taken in view of fear of spread of Coronavirus, and that the UGC had also issued a circular directing the varsities to avoid mass gatherings.

Ansari told TOI that other examinations related to PG Diploma courses will be held as per schedule from April 1 as the number of students in these courses are less.

UGC secretary Rajnish Jain had recently said in a communication to vice chancellors of all universities, “Avoid large gatherings on campus. Any student or staff with travel history to any COVID-19 affected country or in contact with such persons in the last 28 days should be monitored and home quarantined for 14 days.”

Meanwhile, the university has also postponed all annual hall functions and cultural programs. No permissions will be granted for organizing functions at Kennedy auditorium, said administrative officials.

VC Tariq Mansoor also stated that if possible, the national and international conferences may also be postponed and people should restrain from unnecessary travel. He also directed that JN Medical College to be ready with an isolation ward for COVID-19 patients.

Title: Ahmedabad private hospitals brace for COVID-19 cases
Content: AHMEDABAD: The majority of the cases of the new strain of coronavirus disease (COVID-19) that came to the Civil Hospital in the past fortnight came from private hospitals. The doctors identified primary symptoms and recorded travel histories, after which the suspected cases were referred for further screening.City-based hospitals have started training staff to identify COVID-19 symptoms and making preparations for isolation wards. Dr Bharat Gadhavi, president of Ahmedabad Hospitals and Nursing Homes Association (AHNHA), said that currently the primary role for the hospitals is to ensure that the symptoms are recorded properly and the persons are directed for screening.“At a short notice, about 100-plus isolation beds can be prepared in Ahmedabad. The city and state has experience of handling major viral infections in the past. It’s equally important to train nursing staff and majority of the hospitals are imparting training. Several rules have also been put in place — the first and foremost is to reduce direct touch including handshakes,” he said.Till Sunday, Gujarat had sent 47 samples of suspected viral infections to the laboratories at National Institute of Virology (NIV), Pune, and BJ Medical College, Ahmedabad. “All 47 samples have tested negative including five samples which were received in the past two days - three of which had come from Ahmedabad where the persons had history of travel in COVID-19 affected countries,” said a senior state health department official, adding that about 3,700 doctors in private set-ups have been trained in the past fortnight.The first suspected case in the city was referred to Civil Hospital from a private hospital on SG Road. The private hospital officials said that they have adequate resources in terms of masks and ventilators. “The current priority is to ensure that the suspected cases get stabilized and are sent to government-run isolation facilities,” said the director of a city-based hospital.The health department has provided standees and posters to all major hospitals outlining symptoms related to COVID-19 infection and numbers of the state and national helplines. India so far has recorded 34 confirmed cases of the viral infection including those from Ladakh and Tamil Nadu. No deaths have been reported in India so far.

Title: Gujarat: Only 2% of Rs 2.17 lakh crore budget set aside for women
Content:
Representative Image

GANDHINAGAR: Though the Gujarat government claims its budgets are designed to empower women, the actual financial allocation for women has been limited. After analyzing the Gujarat government’s gender budgets, Mahender Jethmalani of Pathey Budget Center said: “The state government must be appreciated for presenting gender budget statements since 2014-15 to earmark more resources for gender equality and to address women’s concerns, needs, and vulnerabilities.” Jethmalani went on to say: “But the gender budget statements need many improvements.”

The gender budget under Category A is Rs 4,505.89 crore, Jethmalani said, which is just 2.07% of the state’s total budget of Rs 2,17,287 crore. Currently, 24 departments report GB (Gender Budget) allocations under Category A (100% women-specific schemes) and Category B (33% to 99% mixed schemes). Of the 24 departments, only 15 have formulated 100% women-specific schemes.

“Nine departments are yet to formulate 100% exclusive schemes and programmes to address women/female needs,” Jethmalani said. He further said,“Currently, GB statements provide information on women-specific schemes under Categories A and B without budget codes.” He said women-specific schemes under GB statements should represent budget codes so that allocations can be verified from the detailed budget estimates of departments.”

Jethmalani added, “The Gujarat GB statement provides budgetary information under the proposed provisions for the next financial year and probable expenditure for the previous year but not the actual expenditure.” The GB statement should also present the actual expenditure to verify the claims, he said.

Jethmalani said that officials formulating schemes for GB should have practical knowledge of the discrimination through the life cycle of girls and women to respond to practical and strategic needs. Therefore, they should engage with women’s groups, he said. The departments should adopt the strategy for gender responsive budgeting, Jethmalani said, to help integrate a gender-inclusive perspective across the planning, budgeting, implementation, monitoring, and auditing continuum.

Title: Police chief felicitates 14 women police officers on International Women’s Day
Content:
Girls dance during the Women’s Day celebrations at Tummalapalli Kalakshetram in Vijayawada on Sunday.

Vijayawada: International Women’s Day was celebrated at various places in Vijayawada and other parts of the Krishna district on Sunday. While a few organisations took out rallies to spread awareness related to women’s issues, others conducted various programmes and meetings relating to the same. Several organisations also felicitated women for their contribution sin various fields.

The Vijayawada city police organised an event at the police commissionerate and police chief Ch Dwaraka Tirumala Rao felicitated 14 woman police officers for their dedication and determination in discharging their duties.

Speaking on the occasion, Tirumala Rao, additional police commissioner, B Srinivasulu , chairperson of Vasavya Mahila Mandali Keethi, psychiatrist Dr Radhika Reddy and few others said that women are doing well in almost all fields. Men and women are equal and are multi-tasking together to balance their family and professional lives, they added.

Marking the day, Machilipatnam police organised “Run for Women” from district court centre to Police Parade Ground on Sunday morning. Women police personnel, students, women employees of various departments and few others took part in the run, which was flagged off by the SP Krisha district Ravindranath Babu and trainee DSP Sravani. The police presented cash prizes and congratulated the winners of the run.

In another programme, Ravindranath Babu, along with his wife Hymavathi, felicitated women from various fields for their great contribution towards the safety and empowerment of women in Machlipatnam region.

In other parts of Krishna and Guntur districts, rallies and competitions marked Women’s Day celebrations.

Title: BJP’s outreach plan: Rs 50cr for rural roads
Content:
Lucknow: In a rural outreach ahead of the 2022 assembly elections, the ruling BJP has released funds for construction of roads connecting hamlets with a population of 250 people.

In the first phase, public works department has sanctioned Rs 20 crore for construction of connecting roads in villages of 11 districts, including chief minister Yogi Adityanath’s bastion Gorakhpur, SP chief Akhilesh Yadav’s parliamentary constituency Azamgarh, Ballia, Deoria, Kushinagar, Maharajganj, Farrukhabad, Kanpur Rural, Etah, Chitrakoot and Banda.

According to a communiqué dated March 7 sent to PWD engineer-in-chief Rajiv Ratan Singh, the department said Rs 50 crore would be required for construction of connecting roads in the 11 districts, of which around Rs 20 crore has been released in first phase.

The department has demarcated roads assembly seat-wise to zero in on areas needing a road connectivity. Significantly, Azamgarh has bagged the lion’s share as 43 rural areas spread over nine assembly seats of the district are proposed to be taken up by PWD. Likewise, 15 hamlets in Gorakhpur are proposed to be developed under the project.

The move is seen as the Yogi government’s bid to project its developmental agenda and consolidate its position among the rural masses, even as BJP gears up to take on the two regional satraps — SP and BSP —which have a significant vote bank essentially in rural areas.

According to the letter issued by the department, the work should be started only after technical assurance from the competent authority. The department has also fixed the responsibility of PWD engineer-in-chief to ensure the quality of construction and timely completion of the project. Also, the funds would be utilized as per the requirement and should not be kept in the bank or post office.

The department has also directed that the spending of the funds would be verified by the state government from time to time.

The department has also asked the engineer in chief to ensure that the work of connecting roads is done by any other government source. The labour cess would, however, be borne by the labour department.

Title: Chavara MLA Vijayan Pillai dies at 69
Content:
Kollam: Chavara MLA N Vijayan Pillai passed away on Sunday. The 69-year-old MLA, who was undergoing treatment for cancer at a private hospital in Kochi for the past few months, died on Sunday morning.

The cremation will be held on the premises of his residence - Vijayamandiram, in Charava at 10am on Monday.

Vijayan Pillai, son of Narayana Pillai, a locally popular politician, stepped into politics through RSP. In his over four-decade-long political career he had served both in the LDF and the UDF. He was a member of the Chavara grama panchayat committee for 21 years since 1971. He was also elected to the district panchayat from the Thevalakkara division. Following a rift in RSP, he joined Congress in 2000. But, when K Karunakaran formed the Democratic Indira Congress, he joined the party. Later, when DIC merged with the Congress, Pillai returned to the Congress. But during the UDF rule in 2011, he quit Congress in protest of the ‘abkari’ policy of the UDF. Following this, he joined the K R Aravindakshan faction of the CMP and contested as a CMP independent of the LDF.

Neendakara taluk hospital, Panmana ayurveda hospital, Neendakara cancer centre etc were built during his tenure.

He is survived by wife Suma, and children Sujith, Sreejith and Sreelakshmi.

State leaders, including chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan, ministers K Raju, J Mercy Kuttymma, MP N K Premachandran, MLAs O Rajagopal, M Mukesh, M Noushad CPM district secretary S Sudevan, DCC president Bindhu Krishna, condoled his death.

Title: Another drunken driver takes a life on city road
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: In an incident similar to the accident in which journalist K M Basheer was killed, a labourer engaged in road work was killed after he was hit by a car driven by a drunk driver in the city on Saturday night.

The accident occurred near Ambalamukku under Peroorkada police station limits.

According to the police, Johnfred (38), who was a resident of Irayankode near Cheriyakonni is the deceased. He was a contract labourer of BSNL.

He was knocked down by a speeding car around 11.30pm on Saturday while he was engaged in digging the road for maintenance works around 200 meters away from Ambalamukku Junction. There were a few other labourers with Johnfred.

They were saved after they ran to safety after seeing the vehicle approaching in their direction at a dangerous speed.

Though he was rushed to hospital his life could not be saved. It is alleged that the car that rammed Johnfred was moving along the wrong lane, from Peroorkada to Ambalamukku direction.

The police said that the car was driven by Ajayaghosh (54), a businessman residing at Ambalamukku. The police have recorded his arrest, charging him with the offence of culpable homicide not amounting to murder (IPC 304).

Besides this, sections 279 of IPC (rash driving) and 185 of Motor Vehicles Act (drunk driving) were invoked against the accused. He was produced before the court and remanded in judicial custody on Sunday.

Johnfred leaves behind wife Sandhya and three children, Jyothish (6), Jyothi (4) and Jyothika (1). He had been working as a labourer under contract with BSNL for the past nine years.

Title: BCA to begin search for a new Ranji team coach
Content:
Vadodara: Baroda team is set to get a new coach for the next cricketing season. The Baroda Cricket Association (BCA) management has already decided to embark on its search mission for a new Ranji team coach later this month.

The decision was taken as the current coach, Sanath Kumar, is recovering from a brain-stroke he had suffered earlier this month. “We will have an important annual general meeting (AGM) on March 19 after which we will begin search for the new coach. We are looking for an experienced hand who can manage the players and coach them well,” said Ajit Lele, BCA secretary.

When asked if they have already listed any possible names, Lele said, “Former India cricketer Chandrakant Pandit’s name is being considered. His current term with other cricket association is ending. Also under considerations are names of Level III coach, Mukund Parmar and ex-India player Rishikesh Kanitkar.” He, however, was quick to add that they are still weighing options and nothing has been decided yet.

A section of BCA, however, feels that the association should go for a local coach. “Baroda has once won Ranji Trophy and later ended in the finals under local coach. BCA can rope in a local former cricketer instead of giving hefty fees to some outsider,” a BCA official said.

But the BCA management has no plans to hire a local Ranji coach as it feels that the locals get influenced by persons having vested interests.

After Kumar’s sudden exit, former India player Munaf Patel is playing the dual role of mentor as well as coach for Baroda. Kumar was appointed as Baroda coach in June last year by the managing committee. This Kumar’s second stint with the Baroda Ranji team as he had earlier worked here in 2011-12.

In his earlier stint as coach here, Baroda was champions in Syed Mushtaq Ali Trophy and performed well in Ranji tournaments. Fifty-six-year-old Kumar has played 11 first class matches between 1986-87 to 1988-89. “He suffered paralysis on the right side of his body but is recovering,” Lele added.

Title: KIIFB deals transparent, allegations baseless: CM
Content:
Alappuzha: Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan has denied all the allegations against the Kerala Infrastructure Investment Fund Board ( KIIFB ) here on Sunday.

The chief minister was speaking after inaugurating ‘Kerala Nirmithi’, an infrastructure expo showcasing projects being executed under the aegis of the KIIFB at Alappuzha EMS Stadium

He said that it was not right to destroy KIIFB by levelling baseless allegations. On the allegations related to YES Bank against KIIFB, Vijayan said that KIIFB had withdrawn its deposits from the bank. “It clearly shows the alertness and correctness of KIIFB. The public is not showing any interest in the allegations being levelled against KIIFB. The goal of the government is to complete projects in a time-bound manner,” he said.

“KIIFB has an inspection system that is foolproof. All its dealings — receiving and distribution of funds — are completely transparent. It ensures maximum quality for the projects and their execution in tune with the deadline. The listing of masala bonds on the London Stock Exchange shows that even agencies from abroad are taking notice of KIIFB’s activities,” said the chief minister.

Pravasi Chitty has been able to mobilize Rs 150 crore, and Rs 50 crore was collected through Pravasi dividend scheme in two months, he added.

“The state government has promised the people that it would undertake development projects to the tune of Rs 50,000 crore in five years. However, we have already taken up projects worth Rs 54,000 crore even before completing four years,” Vijayan said.

“Over 250 projects funded by KIIFB in the state are in the last stages of fruition. In Alappuzha, 86 projects worth Rs 3,187 crore have been given approval,” he said.

Finance minister T M Thomas Isaac presided over the function. Food and civil supplies minister P Thilothaman and PWD minister G Sudhakaran were also present on the occasion.

The expo will conclude on Tuesday.

Title: Karnataka: Scheme for rehabilitation of riot-hit Muslims languishes
Content: BENGALURU: It was floated with the idea of giving Muslim youth arrested for taking part in communal riots, but released without conviction or on good behavior, a second chance, but three years on the Mane Malige scheme is limited to the paper it was typed on.The scheme, government records show, provides financial assistance to Muslim youth to compensate for "social stigma" and loss of education during their time in jail. Launched in 2017-18 under the Siddaramaiah government, the scheme never took off. Thanks to political uncertainties in the subsequent two fiscals, it was buried.Congress’ UT Khader , a former minister from Mangaluru, a hotbed of communal clashes, said he was unware of the scheme, while former BJP minority welfare minister Prabhu Chauhan indicated his department was broke.Chauhan said he was unable to concentrate on the department due to lack of funds on account of the floods in North Karnataka .As per the state’s Economic Survey report for 2019-20, since 2017, as much as Rs 7.5 crore was allocated for the scheme, but not a single beneficiary was identified. Yet, National Crime Records Bureau (NCRB) data suggests that in 2018 alone, as many as 29 incidents of communal violence occurred and there were 32 victims.However, incumbent minority welfare minister Shrimant Patil said he has already taken cognizance of the scheme and it will be implemented soon."Till date there was no information on the scheme shared by previous ministers. At a recent department meeting last week, I instructed district officials to identify victims of communal rioting from the minority community and submit a list. Funds will be disbursed," said Patil.The minister said there is special emphasis on the coastal districts and Mangaluru, which witnessed rioting during the anti-CAA stir. "We will disburse Mane Malige scheme funds to those families who lost bread winners in the riots," Patil said.

Title: City celebrates Women’s Day
Content:
T’puram: The women and child development department organized a night walk on Saturday, wherein over 500 women participated, in the capital city as part of International Women’s Day celebrations. Minister for health and social justice K K Shailaja too joined the programme. The night walk, from Nishagandhi to Gandhi Park, East Fort, was accompanied with the music of percussion instrument chenda.

“Gender inclusive occupation of public spaces is the aim of the programme. Women have freedom to travel and the society should accept it,” said Shailaja.

The night walk was held in association with traders’ collective, residents’ associations and Kudumbashree. The participants engaged in night shopping as part of the programme.

Women and child development director T V Anupama, planning board member Mridul Eapen, gender adviser T K Anandi, Kerala State Women’s Development Corporation MD V C Bindu, district women and child development officer Sabeena Beegam, additional director Sundari and NSS volunteers too participated in the night walk. The programme concluded with art and cultural events at Gandhi Park.

A series of events, including dance and music programmes and poetry events, was organized at Manaveeyam road, the cultural corridor of the city from Saturday evening.

A night cycle ride from Manaveeyam road to Shangumugham was conducted.

The booking counter at Thiruvananthapuram Central station was managed by all-woman staff. The Milma Dairy plant which processes and sells around 2.5 lakh litres of milk daily was controlled by women officers on Sunday. tnn

Title: Don’s murder: CBI to plug holes in case
Content:
LUCKNOW: A day after CBI registered a case in connection with the murder of dreaded don Munna Bajrangi alias Prem Prakash inside Baghpat jail by gangster Sunil Rathi on July 9, 2018, Bajrangi’s wife Seema Singh is hopeful that the mystery surrounding the killing will soon be unravelled.

CBI will try to find answers to questions like how the pistol found its way inside the jail, why was Bajrangi shot barely 12 hours after being shifted from Jhansi jail, and the motive for murder.

The case was transferred to CBI on the direction of the Allahabad High Court on February 25 which said the matter required an in-depth and impartial probe. Following the order, CBI lodged an FIR against Rathi on March 7. Although Baghpat police indicted Rathi in its chargesheet filed in court on October 15, 2018, but failed to establish the motive behind the crime and failed to trace the pistol used to execute the murder.

Talking to TOI, Seema Singh on Sunday said the police failed to probe whether Rathi was just a face and there was a deeper conspiracy behind her husband’s murder.

“The police did not carry out investigation against people from whom my husband faced threat to life. We had informed jail officials that my husband could be attacked inside jail but preventive measures were not taken. He was needless shifted to Baghpat jail,” she said.

Title: Whitefly eats into coconut trees, agri crops in Telangana & AP
Content:
HYDERABAD: An alien invasive crop pest, the Rugose Spiralling Whitefly (RSW), is wreaking havoc on a large number of coconut groves, banana plantations and other horticulture and agricutural crops across Andhra Pradesh and Sattupally and Khammam districts in Telangana .

Native to Belize in Central America , the pest was first reported in Tamil Nadu and Kerala in July 2016. Experts have classified RSW as a destructive pest that mainly threatens coconut plantations. “The species has damaged coconut trees across large areas and is attacking other host plants as well,” Dr S J Rahman, principal scientist, All India Coordinated Research Project on Biological Control of Crop Pests, told TOI.

According to Indian Council of Agricultural Research-Central Plantation Crop Research Institute (ICAR-CPCRI), the pest has destroyed 200 host plants in the coconut-producing states of south India, raising serious concerns.

The insect, which derives its name from its egg-laying pattern, is a tiny insect measuring up to 2 mm in length that sucks out sap from under the leaves, inducing stress on the host plant from the loss of water and nutrients. The honeydew excreted by the fly attracts ants and encourages the growth of fungus, thus affecting the plant.

Scientists said that in many cases, economic losses resulting from whitefly infestations are limited and that deficit monsoon due to climate change is one of the key reasons behind the growing pest attacks.

Biological control by parasitic insects, such as Encarsia, lady beetles and spiders, has been found to be effective against RSW. The agricultural department has suggested application of starch solution, installation of sticky traps and spraying of neem oil to kill the pests.

Title: Chhana to make Barodians’ Holi puja fire greener
Content:
Vadodara: Eco-friendly being the buzzword in Sanskarinagari this Holi, Barodians have decided to celebrate the festival by not using wood for the traditional Holi fire. Over the last few years, the trend of using cow dung cakes (or chhana) have picked up and this time dozens of groups and residential colonies have decided to use only cow dung cakes in Holi.

“We know the effects the climate change is having on the globe. Ahead of Holi, many trees get cut which directly impacts our environment. So we have decided to use cow dung cakes instead in our Holi puja. Burning cow dung cakes also purifies air,” said Nikhil Purohit of Manav Prakruti Kendra. Some organizations have also begun supplying such cakes for low rates in the city.

The old city markets were abuzz with customers on the eve of Holi with grown-ups buying dates and puja ceremony articles, the youngsters gunning for the water cannons and Holi arsenal.

Those celebrating Dhuleti too have taken to organic colours to prevent harming the skin. Meanwhile, farsan shops in the city are also busy preparing to serve customers who flock eateries after playing with the colours.

Title: Karnataka deputy CM Govind Karjol exhorts media to focus on rural problems
Content:
Deputy CM Govind Karjol advised media to focus on rural issues at the valedictory of the 35th state conference... Read More

MANGALURU: Deputy chief minister Govind Karjol on Sunday exhorted the media in the state to focus on rural areas of the state and the country as well. Reminding the fourth pillar of democracy that 70% of India resides in rural areas, Karjol said it is this strata of society that needs greater focus compared to issues of urban areas, especially the farmers who play a pivotal role in ensuring food security for the society at large.

Conferring the annual awards of Karnataka Union of Working Journalists at the valedictory of the two-day 35th journalists conference on Sunday, Karjol said the media should focus on the nation’s development.

“This development should not be limited to industries, but also farmers, who have success stories on judicious use of water. Karnataka stands number one in this aspect, and farmers who have adopted this practice should be the focus of attention,” he said.

Exhorting agricultural and horticultural universities to focus on their achievements as well, Karjol said when these positive examples are highlighted, the society will reap benefits of their collective wisdom. There are several such success stories in areas of horticulture, agriculture, irrigation, coconut and coffee growing, he said, adding if these examples get highlighted, the state can certainly go up the national ranking in conservation of water resources.

Referring to various demands that the KUWJ flagged with chief minister B S Yediyurappa during the pre-budget meeting, Karjol said he will personally strive to get the Rs 5 crore welfare fund that the chief minister announced in the budget get increased to Rs 50 crore. “I will strive to ensure Rs 5 crore is granted for construction of a patrika bhavan in Bengaluru, and increase the amount set aside for their construction at the district level from the present Rs 25 lakh,” he said.

Highlighting the contribution that Mahatma Gandhi played in fostering journalism in the pre-independence era with the ‘Young Indian’ and ‘Harijan’ and the impact that these papers had on the freedom movement, Karjol exhorted KUWJ to institute an award in the name of the Father of the nation. This will spur young upcoming journalists to know about the role that Gandhiji played, he said, adding this is as important as remembering veteran journalists as well.

Earlier, Dakshina Kannada MP Nalin Kumar Kateel likened journalists to guru (teacher) who have power of trinity – Brahma, Vishnu and Mahesh– to create, sustain or destroy.

“Journalists play this role in the lives of politicians by pointing out their mistakes and help them get better,” he said. KUWJ announced that the 36th journalist’s state conference will be held in Kalaburagi. Karjol, who is district minister of Kalaburagi, assured his full cooperation for the event.

Title: Telangana: Taxi driver held on charges of raping woman in car
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: A 23-year-old woman, a worker, was allegedly raped by a taxi driver in a car at Chandanavelli village in Rangareddy district on Friday evening. The accused and the woman belong to the same village. He allegedly lured her by offering to drop her near her home.

On Friday evening, the 32-year-old accused, a driver from a village in Rangareddy district, was sitting at a cell phone shop in Hayathabad village charging his phone, Shabad inspector B Shankaraiah said.

“The woman came there to buy a SIM. The accused spoke to her and offered to drop her in the village saying that he was also going home. The woman got into his car,” the inspector said.

After driving for about three kilometres, the accused stopped the vehicle at an isolated place and allegedly raped her inside the vehicle.

“When the woman resisted, the accused slapped her multiple times. After the assault, the woman escaped from the spot. We have received a complaint from the woman, who is married, on Saturday,” the inspector said.

Police sent the woman for medical examination and picked up the accused from his house on Saturday night. A rape case was booked against him under Section 376 of the IPC.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: 75% voting in Gujarat University senate election, held after three years
Content:
For the first time, the counting of votes will take place at Bhasha Bhavan instead of Senate Hall

AHMEDABAD: After a hiatus of three years, Gujarat University (GU) on Sunday held election for 10 seats of student senate and 14 seats of student welfare committee. Out of 25 centres for polling, five were in the city. Except slogans raised at a few places, the election passed off peacefully, said GU officials.

Counting of the votes will take place on Monday from 8am. For the first time, the counting will take place at Bhasha Bhavan instead of Senate Hall. GU has declared a holiday on Monday to prevent any untoward incident.

“Both major factions tried their best to bring the voters to the polling booths. At Rashtrabhasha Hindi College, a skirmish had taken place over the absence of identity cards. Police intervened and prevented a scuffle. Both the factions claimed victory after voting was over. At a few places, the factions called truce fearing cancellation of the polling process,” said an official associated with the elections.

PG Science with 97% voting recorded the highest turnout followed by PG Arts (96%), UG Science (86%), PG Commerce (85%), Law (72%), UG Arts (62%), Education (57%) and UG Commerce (56%).

At law faculty, several of political leaders were also seen as sons of a BJP and a Congress leader were in the fray. On medical and dental seats, the elections were uncontested with only one candidate each standing for the process.\

Title: Telangana: CRPF constable from Maharashtra kills self with service rifle
Content:
HYDERABAD: A Central Reserve Police Force (CRPF) constable hailing from Maharashtra allegedly committed suicide by shooting himself with his service rifle at the CRPF group centre at Malkaram village in Rangareddy district on Sunday. Police said that no suicide note was found.

It is suspected that the constable, Baban Vithal Rao Manwar (40), a native of Pawan Nagar village in Nagpur district of Maharashtra, who recently returned from a month-long leave, took the extreme step due to personal problems.

According to police, Manwar allegedly shot himself under the chin with an SLR (self-loading rifle) while he was on sentry duy.

Following a complaint by CRPF officers, police rushed to the spot and began a preliminary probe.

“We found that Manwar was recently transferred to Hyderabad from Tripura. After reporting for work, he went on leave for a month and reported back to work on March 2. After his return, Manwar told his colleagues that he was finding it difficult to stay away from his family,” said Jawaharnagar inspector P Bhikshapathi Rao.

Clues team collected forensic evidence from the spot and a case was registered under Section 174 of CrPC.

Title: Rapid response teams begin culling of poultry and pet birds in flu-hit areas
Content: KOZHIKODE: The department of animal husbandry on Sunday formed rapid response teams and commenced culling of all poultry and pet birds within 1km-radius of the bird-flu affected areas under the limits of Kodiyathur grama panchayat and Kozhikode city corporation. More than 10,000 poultry and pet birds will be culled in the district during the special drive.The culling operations on Sunday was carried out by 24 rapid response teams under the limits of ward 1, 13,14 and 16 of Kodiyathur grama panchayat and 9-12 wards of Kozhikode corporation. A total of 1,700 poultry and pet birds were culled till Sunday evening.Bird flu cases were confirmed in West Kodiyathur and Vengeri on Friday on the basis of a test conducted at Bhopal based National Institute of High Security Animal Disease (NISHAD).Collector Sambasiva Rao visited the spots to assess the culling operations. Each squad consists of a veterinary surgeon, four livestock inspectors and an attender. The carcasses of the culled birds were disposed by the respective local self government bodies.Meanwhile, forest, dairy development and animal husbandry minister K Raju said all farmers in the state who will have to cull poultry birds as part of preventive measures against bird flu will be duly compensated. The government will take a decision on the amount to be disbursed as compensation later, he said adding that the government has also issued a statewide alert after confirming the case through lab tests.C Santhosh, Kodiyathur grama panchayat secretary said the culling operations will be continued till March 10. “Around 2,000 poultry birds at a private farm died at the farm itself and that confirmed the bird-flu case. Around 500 poultry birds in the farm and other affected areas were culled on the day,” he said.Dr Nina Kumar, district chief veterinary officer said, “We have come across an instance under the city corporation limits where a pet bird owner shifted his pet birds to another location to avoid culling. Those birds will be culled in the coming days,” he said.

Title: ‘Emulate Goa, Kerala’s success in tourism’
Content:
CRUISE CONTROL: Mattar Rathnakar Hegde, chairman, Coastal Development Authority, stressed on need for tapping ... Read More

Mangaluru: A session on coastal development and tourism organised as part of the final day of the two-day 35th State Conference of Journalists under the aegis of KUWJ underscored the need for Karnataka to exploit its 320 km coastline for tourism. Speakers cited the success that Kerala and Goa – coastal states that flank Karnataka—in achieving their tourism potential as the prime reason for the state, that is bountifully blessed, in achieving the same.

Underscoring the potential of coastal tourism, KUWJ in association with DKWJU, the host association of the conference, organised a session on Rani Abbakka , a river cruiser , and not at the conference venue. More than 100 journalists and guests were part of the session that saw the cruiser go up the Phalguni River, all the way up to the river bridge across the Nethravathi River from the Old Port, before returning to the Old Port.

M Rathnakar Hegde , chairman, Coastal Development Authority (CDA), who inaugurated the session, said the sea and the rivers in the coastal districts are their major assets. Despite this, tourism has not grown to the expected level, he said, adding the tourism development department, CDA and other agencies are working in tandem to tap this potential as part of the coastal tourism circuit that has been mooted, and will get the priority the sector needs.

Ganesh Karnik, former MLC, who was the chief guest, said Karnataka offers far more diversity in coastal tourism options compared to Goa and Kerala. “It is imperative for this diversity to be showcased to tourists, especially foreigners, so that tourism can be further developed locally. Apart from the tourism department, the district administration should join hands with stakeholders in giving the necessary fillip for tourism, not just in coastal areas, but in the interiors as well,” he said.

B A Viveka Rai, former vice-chancellor, Kannada University and KSOU, who chaired the session, wished that the assurances made, and projects conceptualised for the development of the tourism potential of the coast do no end up as mere promises. “Local culture and practices should be highlighted in tapping this potential while creating employment for locals,” he said. A website that captures this diversity should be launched to attract tourists in droves to this place, he added.

Title: At Rs 47,000 crore, Maharashtra govt’s guarantees rise 542% in 4 years
Content:
MUMBAI: The Maha Vikas Aghadi government not only has debt burden set to hit a staggering Rs 5.2 lakh crore, but it also faces massive liabilities in the form of guarantees worth Rs 46,891 crore granted to loans taken by state-run entities. That’s a rise of 542% in four years. The figures were revealed in deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar ’s budget speech on March 6.

State guarantees are contingent liabilities and pose a burden to the state if they are invoked. “Guarantees have to be considered seriously when you look at the state’s liabilities. If the entity that has taken the loan cannot repay it, then the state has to step forward,” said former finance secretary Subodh Kumar (retd).

By 2016-17, the state had guaranteed loans worth Rs 7,305 crore. The guarantee bill has risen by Rs 39,586 crore since then. The largest share of guarantees or 36% of the total has gone towards the Mumbai-Nagpur Expressway.

The bulk of the guarantees granted in the last four years by the former BJP-led government were mainly for infrastructure projects. These include Mumbai Metro-4, Mumbai Transharbour Link project and Maharashtra Samriddhi Mahamarg, also known as the Mumbai-Nagpur Expressway. The former government guaranteed loans worth Rs 17,000 crore for the Mumbai-Nagpur Expressway in 2019, despite strong objections from the state finance department which said it would burden the cash-strapped state.

Budget documents show that in 2018-19, the urban development department had guaranteed loans worth Rs 19,131 crore, mainly for Metro-4 and Mumbai Transharbour Link projects; the cooperatives department had guaranteed loans worth Rs 3,941 crore; and the social justice department had guaranteed loans worth Rs 546 crore. The public works department had guaranteed loans amounting to Rs 804 crore.

In 2019-20, the state government granted guarantees to the Mumbai-Nagpur Expressway, which is extimated to cost Rs 55,335 crore. The 701km eight-lane expressway, which will cut travel time between the two cities from 14-15 hours to nearly eight hours, is expected to be completed in 2020-21. It also guaranteed loans worth Rs 1,800 crore to the Cotton Corporation of India .

Budget documents also show that the Maharashtra State Cooperative Bank had invoked guarantees on loans worth Rs 2,322 crore given to cooperative sugar and spinning mills. Of this, Rs 1,049 crore was found to be payable by a claims committee. From the sum, the government paid Rs 74 crore in 2018 and Rs 100 crore in 2019.

Title: In a first, govt allocates Rs 18 cr for infra spending to check migration
Content:
The fund was announced in the budget presented by chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat

DEHRADUN: To check migration from 545 identified villages, the state finance department has allocated a fund of Rs 18 crore to better infrastructure and public facilities in these areas. Each of these villages has a population of less than 50 people.

The fund was announced in the Budget presented by chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat during the assembly session in Gairsain on Thursday. The provision of corpus funds for migration has been made for the first time in the state budget.

According to studies, several villages have been severely hit by migration in the last ten years. Locals migrated from these villages due to several causes, including lack of facilities like hospitals, schools and employment opportunities.

Head of the state migration commission SS Negi told TOI, “The corpus fund will play a very important role in boosting the facilities and infrastructure in the affected villages and the commission will act as a nodal agency to monitor the projects and study the desired effects on migration.” Different departments have been directed to realign their developmental works to include the neglected areas where the population is thinning rapidly, he added.

In Uttarakhand , the migration trends reveal two broad categories — people shifting within the state and people moving out of the state. Migration studies point out that lack of employment opportunities is the major factor behind outward movement of people and lack of other basic facilities is also a big contributor to the trend.

“The villages, where population is less than 50 individuals, lack health facilities which forces people to move to urban areas,” said Negi.

However, there are some who feel that the issue of migration has been underestimated by policymakers and successive governments in Uttarakhand. “The corpus fund of Rs 18 crore alone cannot stop migration or herald a wave of reverse migration in Uttarakhand. People leave their native villages in search of job opportunities, better education and health facilities. Work should be done in all these areas to check migration,” said Doon-based social activist Subhash Sharma .

Title: 3,902 people killed in road accidents in 4 years across Nashik
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: In the four-year period of 2016 to 2019, as many as 3,902 people lost their lives in 9,260 road accidents across the district. Moreover, 7,648 people escaped with injuries — both grievous and minor.

Given a large number of accidents and deaths, the Nashik Regional Transport Office (RTO) on Saturday organised a brainstorming workshop at the Children’s Traffic Education Park to analyse the accidents and come out with measures to bring down the numbers.

“The highest number of road accidents take place on relatively open roads — like the state or national highways — where there is scope for motorists to speed their vehicles. Overspeeding, wrong-side driving and overtaking from the wrong side lead to maximum road accidents,” said Vinay Ahire, the deputy RTO of Nashik.

“An analysis has revealed that older vehicles were involved in the least number of accidents, whereas vehicles that are less than five years old were involved in the maximum number of accidents,” Ahire added talking on concerns about the road-fitness of older vehicles.

It was also found that the highest number of accidents take place between 3 pm and 6 pm and two-wheeler riders account for most fatalities.

The insights provided by Jitendra Patil, the joint transport commissioner (Road Safety Cell, Maharashtra), RTO Nashik Bharat Kalaskar, chairman of Nashik First Abhay Kulkarni, project director of NHAI Bhausaheb Salunkhe proved useful to all RTO officials and inspectors of Nashik, Malegaon, Srirampur, Ahmednagar, Dhule, Nandurbar, Jalgaon and Dhule and officials of the NHAI and other departments.

Title: HR Bhardwaj Death: Former governor of Karnataka Hans Raj Bhardwaj passes away
Content:
Hans Raj Bhardwaj

BENGALURU: Congress functionary and former governor of Karnataka, Hans Raj Bhardwaj , who had been ailing for some time, passed away in New Delhi on Sunday. He was 83.

Although Bhardwaj served as Union law minister for years, he hit headlines when he sent chief minister BS Yediyurappa to jail during his stint as governor from 2009 to 2014.

Appointed by the UPA government as the President’s hand in the state after he was asked to vacate his post as law minister, Bhardwaj had kept Yediyurappa — in his second stint as CM between 2008 and 2010 — on tenterhooks.

When two lawyers — Sirajin Basha and KN Balaraj — approached him in 2011 seeking sanction to prosecute Yediyurappa for his alleged involvement in land denotification cases, Bhardwaj obliged. It resulted in the BJP strongman becoming the first sitting CM to be sent to jail and triggered political upheaval in the state.

Yediyurappa eventually split from the BJP and formed his own party, before returning to the saffron party fold later.

"Bhardwaj’s death is sad news," Yediyurappa said in a tweet. "In his death we have lost a good legal expert and administrator."

HD Deve Gowda, former PM, said, “Bhardwaj will always be remembered for his exceptional service to the nation.”

Title: ICU of Cantonment General Hospital to be renamed as HDU
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: The Cantonment General Hospital at Deolali has recently approved a proposal from Cantonment General Hospital to rename its Intensive Critical Care Unit (ICCU) to High Dependency Unit (HDU) in order to not mislead the civilians about the facilities available in the hospital.

The Cantonment Board Deolali (CBD) officials said that since their ICCU does not have the required facilities that an intensive care unit should have, they have decided to call it HDU.

Bhagwan Katariya, vice-president, CBD, said “The board had put the proposal for the same in the previous board meeting and it has been resolved to change the name of the ward.” An HDU, according to the board officials, is in between of ICCU and emergency wards. It is a midway facility.

Title: Kerala: Crusader for woman-friendly workplaces
Content:
Kusumam R Punnapra

KANNUR: When the state government finally declared that provisions of the Maternity Benefit Act, 1961, would be applicable to employees of private educational institutions, including those in the unaided sector, and that they would be eligible for maternity benefits, including six months paid leave, Thiruvananthapuram-based social activist and writer Kusumam R Punnapra couldn’t have been happier.

It was her fight that finally bore fruit, as is the case of earlier laws that enabled IT employees to get maternity leave and also the right to breastfeed their babies during working hours.

“I had been fighting for this right for quite some time and I am happy that it became a reality on Women’s Day,” she said.

It all began when her daughter landed a job in a reputed IT company right after completing her engineering degree, said Kusumam. “Though I thought my daughter was very lucky to get campus placement, it did not take long to realise that working conditions were every tough and long working hours without any rest were quite common in IT firms,” she said. Finally, her daughter migrated to the UK, where working conditions are much better, but that was just the beginning of Kusumam’s struggles to bring relief to young professional women, after studying labour rules.

The first fight was to ensure the rights of young mothers to breastfeed their babies. It bore fruit, too, though she had to run from pillar to post till the 2015 gazette notification, which said establishments with fifty or more female employees should have day-care centres and facilities to breastfeed their babies within 500 metres of the workplace. “I have seen many young mothers undergo great agony, both physical and mental, unable to breastfeed their babies,” she said.

The amendment to the Kerala Shops and Establishments Act was revolutionary as it made it mandatory for the employer to provide the facility for newborn babies to have their mothers’ milk, even at their workplace.

The fight to get six months maternity leave for techies was also an arduous one and the law was finally passed by the central government in March 2017.

Now, her fight is to have day-care centres near the Secretariat for female staff.

“There are causes aplenty to fight for but we should have the will, which should not be limited to Women’s Day or Breastfeeding Week,” said the crusader, who has devoted her retired life for the cause of working women.

Title: Ahmedabad: Trader duped of Rs 15 lakh with government job lure
Content:
Representative Image

AHMEDABAD: Ghanshyam Sharma, 32, of Naroda has lodged a complaint with the Krishnanagar police station stating that a couple — Mitesh Raval and his wife Payal of Kapadvanj — has cheated him of Rs 13 lakh on the pretext of getting him a job in the central government. Police officials said that they have registered an offence under Sections 406, 420, and 114 of the IPC and are hunting for the accused couple.

According to the complaint lodged by Sharma, one his relatives had introduced the Ravals to him at a religious function in Kapadvanj about two years ago. They had exchanged phone numbers at the time. Sharma, who is in the plastic bags business, stated that in January 2018, Mitesh called him and asked him to pick him and his wife Payal from Dehgam Circle.

“Police source said when they came to Sharma’s house, Payal saw Sharma’s qualifications — BA and BEd. She told Sharma that she can get him a central government job but he would have to pay Rs 15 lakh,” a police official said. Later Mitesh and Payal again came to Sharma’s house and showed him some letters. Sharma fell into their trap and paid them Rs 5 lakh. The Ravals then told Sharma that he would have to come to Delhi with them to give an interview.

According to Sharma, he gave the Ravals Rs 3 lakh more in July 2018 and another Rs 5 lakh in September 2018. However, whenever Sharma asked for the appointment letter, the Ravals told him to wait. After one-and-a-half years, Sharma went to Kapadvanj to meet the Ravals but found them missing. Their phones had been switched off. Sharma then realized that he had been cheated.

Title: Ahmedabad: Boy beaten up, threatened with knife for refusing to share his answer sheet
Content:
Representative Image

AHMEDABAD: A Class X student, 17, giving his board exams was beaten up and threatened with a knife by another student, as he did not allow the accused to copy from his answer sheet.

The incident took place on Saturday at the board exam centre in Krishnanagar. Police have registered a case under sections 323, 506(1) and 506 (2) of the IPC.

According to the complaint lodged by the victim’s father, who is a farmer and stays at Nikol — his son had gone for his board exams at about 10 am in the morning.

According to the FIR, after entering the centre, the complainant’s son sat on his allotted seat. “Another boy, 17, came and sat beside him. The boy who sat beside the farmer’s son told him that he would have to allow him to copy from his answer sheet.

However, the farmer’s son declined. The other then threatened him that after the paper is over, he will see him” said a police official.

According to the boy, he also told the class supervisor and got the other boy reprimanded for demanding to copy.

The FIR mentions that after the exam session was over, the complainant’s son came out of the school and was standing near Khodiyaar Mata Temple, when the accused came there.

The accused then slapped the complainant’s son and pulled a knife from his pocket.

Seeing the knife, the complainant’s son ran away and called his father. After hearing what had happened, the complainant called up the police control room and lodged an FIR against the other boy. Inspector V R Chaudhary of Krishnanagar police station said that as the accused boy is a minor they will take action accordingly.

Title: EPFO freezes bank account of 269 defaulter companies
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: The Employees’ Provident Fund Organisation (EPFO) has frozen the bank accounts of 269 industries and seized immovable properties of eight companies for defaulting payment collectively amounting to Rs 23.33 crore. Moreover, the EPFO has also recovered Rs 37 crore from over 1,000 defaulting companies during the current financial year (2019-20) in the Nashik region.

The Nashik region of EPFO includes five districts — Nashik, Dhule, Jalgaon, Nandurbar and Ahmednagar.

There were 1,636 private establishments, civic and cooperative bodies, which had altogether defaulted on payment of Rs 60.95 crore. “We had started recovery from these defaulters. We could recover Rs 37.62 crore from the defaulters,” said an EPFO official.

“Moreover, we have also taken frozen bank accounts of 269 establishments for defaulting on Rs 23.33 crore. The immovable properties of eight establishments have also been attached,” the official added.

All private establishments, which have 20 or more employees come under the PF Act. These establishments must provide PF facilities to their employees. Apart from private establishments, cooperative institutes and civic bodies also come under the ambit of this Act.

Currently, there are total 12,917 establishments and 17 lakh accounts in the Nashik region along. Apart from that, the EPFO has 1.35 lakh pensioners in the region.

The monthly PF collection of the Nashik regional EPFO office is estimated to be Rs 84 crore, while payment distribution is at around Rs 62.90 crore per month. This includes Rs 30 crore pensions to 1.35 lakh pensioners.

EPFO has classified defaulters in three categories A, B and C as per the duration of a payment default. The EPFO has decided to act tough against employers who default PF payment of their employees. The organisation has also decided to monitor such defaulters every month. As part of this, a real-time default management system has been introduced at the Nashik regional office of the EPFO,” said an official.

The category A includes defaulters who defaulted payment over four months, B category includes defaulters from two to four months and C category includes defaulters who have defaulted payment over one month.

The squad immediately approaches defaulters by phone calls, SMSes and emails, asking them to pay the defaulted amounts. If there is no response, the squad serves notices to the defaulters, giving them an ultimatum, said the official.

Title: Making Nashik the cleanest city in the country is my priority
Content:
Representative image

New mayor Satish Kulkarni has taken several initiatives on sanitation and health services in the city. In a free-wheeling interview with TOI’s Tushar Pawar, Kulkarni shares about the various measures taken for the overall growth of the city and his vision to make the city an IT hub.

How is the financial condition of the civic body?

Various development projects are being carried out across six divisions of the Nashik Municipal Corporation . The financial condition of the civic body is neither too good nor too bad. It is balanced. But the focus is being given on basic amenities like roads, street-lights, water, and other facilities.

What is your vision for the city?

Nashik is a part of the Mumbai-Pune-Nashik golden triangle, but only Mumbai and Pune have developed a lot and Nashik has been neglected in terms of development. How will employment be generated if the new industries do not come here? Hence, we are already in talks with two IT companies to make some investment here. We are also organising a one-day event in the city, inviting big IT companies where we will urge them to make an investment in Nashik.

What are the issues in the city and how is the response to your visit to the respective wards?

Providing basic facilities like water, road, street-light, health services, garbage collection, etc are the duties of the civic body. Hence, I am holding dialogues with city residents in various wards every Saturday to understand the problems they are facing. I have also launched a mobile app – ‘Maza Mahapaur’ to address the grievances of the city residents. I am getting a very good response from the city residents and I am also trying to settle their issues.

There are any financial issues after the new MVA government coming to power?

The development of the city is not only the responsibility of the civic body but also of the state government. We hope we will get funds from the Maha Vikas Aghadi government for various development works.

What are your plans for making the Godavari river pollution-free?

We are seriously working on river conservation. There are 29 nullahs in the city that connects to the Godavari river. The nullahs are causing pollution to the river. We are planning to construct a parallel pipeline along these nullahs for the effluents to flow into Sewage Treatment Plant. In fact, nullahs should only flow for four months of the rainy season. We have Godavari conservation plans, which require funds worth over Rs 400 crore. We are soon meeting the Prime Minister Narendra Modi and union minister to seek funds for the project.

Some city hotels were under NMC’s scanner for releasing stale food and waste. What are your views?

This is really wrong if the city hotels, wedding halls, and lawns are throwing stale foods into the sewer and stormwater lines. In fact, they should give their waste with segregation into dry and wet garbage to garbage collection vans. If they are still not following this, then action should be taken against such erring city hotels. I have already directed the civic administration to take action against such city hotels.

As city mayor, what are your top priorities?

Cleanliness, health services are on the top of my priorities. I want to make Nashik the cleanest city in the country. Measures are taken in that direction by the civic body. Moreover, I am also working on sorting out the parking issues in the city.

Title: 63,000 tonne grapes exported from Nashik district so far
Content:
Representative image

NASHIK: Grape exports from the Nashik district seem to have gathered momentum, with officials announcing that nearly 63,000 tonne of the fruit has been sent out in 4,705 containers so far.

There is still a 17% dip in export numbers. Last year, during the corresponding period, exporters had sent out 75,000 tonne. Farmers said the dip was the result of unseasonal rains that had devastated the region’s vineyards in 2019.

Out of the 63,000 tonne exported so far, 55,000 tonne were sent out to European countries — 36,000 tonne to the Netherland; 6,700 tonne to the United Kingdom; 6,500 tonne to Germany; 1,200 tonne to Denmark. The rest of the grape export was to countries such as Finland, Slovenia, Spain, Ireland, Norway, etc.

Nearly 8,000 tonne of grapes has been exported to non-European countries such as Russia, the UAE etc.

The grape export season will continue through the end of April. Officials said the district’s grape export is expected to touch nearly 1.1 lakh tonne this season. Last year, the number settled at 1.44 lakh tonne.

The district also recorded a 26% drop in the registration of vineyards meant for export during the grape season 2019-20 (December to April). According to government rules, grape farmers have to register their vineyards if they wish to export their produce. As per the state agricultural department, so far, around 28,500 farmers in the district have registered their vineyards for export — that’s across a total of 18,000 hectare. Last year, 38,400 grape farmers had registered their vineyards, across 24,575 hectares.

“The drop is because of last year’s unseasonal rainfall that impacted vineyards through September and October. Most of the good quality vineyards, meant for export of grapes, have been badly damaged. It is difficult to estimate the damage, but we believe there has been a 25 to 30% drop in production,” Manik Patil, the senior office-bearer of the Maharashtra Rajya Draksha Bagayatdar Sangh, said.

Khandu Shewale, a grape farmer and exporter, said: “Many ready-to-harvest vineyards were badly affected by rains in October. I incurred 100% losses. Last year, I had exported 150 tonne of grape. But I could not export anything this year.”

Title: Mohan Bhagwat: RSS chief Mohan Bhagwat kicks off annual national body meet from today
Content:
Mohan Bhagwat

BENGALURU: Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS) sarasanghchalak, Mohan Bhagwat will kick off the annual meet of the Sangh Parivar in Bengaluru on Monday. Bhagwat is scheduled to have meetings with RSS national-level functionaries until Saturday (March 14). These meetings will set the agenda for RSS’ debate at the Akhila Bharatiya Parthinidhi Sabha (ABPS) scheduled for March 15 to 17.

Policy matters related to the construction of Ram Mandir in Ayodhya, CAA-NRC and uniform civil code are likely to be discussed at the summit.

RSS functionaries say the ABPS — apex body of the Sangh Parivar — will pass a national resolution on policy matters each day of the meeting. Beside Bhagwat, sarkaryawah (general secretary) of RSS Suresh ‘Bhayyaji’ Joshi will preside over the entire summit.

About 1,400 senior most members from 40 different Sangh Parivar affiliates — including the VHP and BJP — are expected to attend the summit. BJP national president JP Nadda and Ram Madhav are also expected to attend.

“State units of RSS from across the country will participate along with national leaders of affiliate bodies,” said an RSS functionary. Bhagwat is expected to stay in Bengaluru till March 21 and is likely to take stock of the expanding footprint of RSS in south India.

Title: Observe non-cooperation movement against government: Swami Agnivesh
Content:
United we stand: A section of the participants at the citizenship protection conference held at Jeppinamogaru ... Read More

Mangaluru: Activist Swami Agnivesh asked people to observe a non-cooperation movement against the Union government by not showing documents during the enumeration drive. He was speaking at an anti-CAA rally held under the aegis of Paurathva Samrakshana Vedike at Jappinamogaru on Sunday.

He called on people to intensify their protests against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), National Register of Citizenship (NRC) and National Population Register (NPR). The protest was organised to oppose the CAA and to condemn the violence that took place in Delhi.

He said, “Write this on the walls (that you will not show documents). Make students raise slogans when they go to the school and return home. We have to do this in order to save the Constitution. Your voice should be so loud that it should break their eardrums.”

He said that Prime Minister Narendra Modi continues to lie about the CAA and its link with NRC.

The BJP manifesto mentions the CAA and NRC and home minister Amit Shah, on the floor of the Parliament, has given the sequence about the CAA, NPR and NRC. “The Prime Minister continues to give false statements,” he said.

Karnataka assembly former speaker Ramesh Kumar said no force can curb the agitation against CAA.

Title: Ahmedabad: ‘Accidental informer’ on bootlegger’s hit list, 16 years on
Content:
Representative Image

AHMEDABAD: A Vastrapur resident and real estate agent, Dharmesh Dave, 39, filed a complaint on Saturday evening alleging that one Pavan Tiwari had threatened the complainant over a dispute in which Tiwari had been caught bootlegging 16 years ago.

The complainant, who lives in Takshila Flats near Nalanda Complex, claimed in his FIR with Vastrapur police that in 2004 he used to drive a rickshaw in Amraiwadi. One day that year, Dave’s autorickshaw hit Tiwari’s autorickshaw and the got into a scuffle. Dave then called up cops. When cops arrived they found Tiwari’s autorickshaw loaded with liquor bottles. Tiwari was booked for bootlegging but he later escaped from police custody.

“Since then, Tiwari carried a grudge against me and blamed me for being caught while bootlegging. He alleged I was a police informer, and after escaping from police custody he came and beat me,” Dave said.

He added that Tiwari had fled to Kanpur after the incident and did not contact Dave for around 16 years.

Dave said in his FIR that Tiwari had fled to Kanpur after the incident and did not contact me for around 16 years.

“On March 1, Tiwari called me up and said that he had returned to Ahmedabad city. He threatened to kill me if I ever came to Jashodanagar or Amraiwadi area,” Dave stated in the complaint.

Tiwari had once again called Dave on the same day and allegedly threatened to kidnap his wife and daughter, while abusing him.

Dave said that he had not filed a complaint earlier as he was scared and was busy with his daughter’s board exam. He approached Vastrapur police late on Saturday night and filed a complaint of criminal intimidation and uttering abusive words.

Inspector M M Jadeja of Vastrapur police said that the accused was yet to be nabbed and police are trying to trace him.

Title: Women lok rakshak dal aspirants say government reneged on promise
Content: AHMEDABAD: Women lok rakshak dal (LRD) aspirants, who called off their two-month-long protest after the government announced a formula last month to end the impasse, have threatened to relaunch their agitation.The women claim that although the state government had said that all candidates who scored more than 62.5% marks in the examination will be handed appointment letters by Women’s Day on March 8, the government has not handed any appointment letters yet.The state government announced the formula last month, even as women from both reserved and unreserved categories were protesting in Gandhinagar. With US President Donald Trump scheduled to visit on February 24 and the opposition Congress announcing a protest outside the Motera stadium, the government was keen to end the stalemate.On February 16, deputy CM Nitin Patel announced that all candidates who scored more than 62.5% marks in the examination will get appointment letters.He said that a total of 5,227 candidates will be given appointment letters from the reserved category alone.“More than three weeks have passed since the government announced that all those who scored more than 62.5% marks will get letters. It has not happened. In fact, none of the aspirants have received letters,” said Vaishali Bamania, one of the protesting LRD candidates.The LRD aspirants have decided to wait until March 11, as the high court will hear their petition on that day. “The next date in the high court is March 11. If the government does not make the appointments by March 11, we will meet and decide on what action to take next,” said Suresh Chaudhary , one of the organizers of the protest by LRD aspirants of reserved categories.Protests by aspirants, both from reserved and unreserved categories took place after the government announced results of the women’s LRD examination. Candidates demanded scrapping of a government notification dated August 2018, which did not allow meritorious candidates from reserved categories to get selected in vacancies of the general category.

Title: Job notification for water board issued
Content: Hyderabad: Telangana State Public Service Commission on Saturday issued a recruitment notification for 93 vacancies in Hyderabad Metropolitan Water Supply and Sewerage Board (HMWS&SB). The applications can be submitted from March 16 to 31. For more details, the candidates can visit the website www.tspsc.gov.in. TNN

Title: 2 robbers nabbed after encounter in Sarojininagar
Content:
Lucknow: Two robbers were injured in an encounter with the police in Sarojninagar in the small hours of Sunday. Their two aides, however, managed to flee. Two policemen were also injured.

On Saturday evening, police received a tip-off that four miscreants riding on two motorcycles had snatched a mobile phone and money from a man in Banthara. The police put the stolen mobile on surveillance as it was on and tracked the robbers’ location on Kanpur Road-Bijnor village route in Sarojininagar.

Police intercepted the miscreants at Gulabi Kheda area. While fleeing, one bike of the robbers skidded on the road and two riders, Shubham and Ajay, fell, while their aides, Abhishek and Neeraj, fled on another bike.

“Even after being surrounded by police teams of Sarojninagar and Banthara, Shubham and Ajay fired two rounds at cops. In the retaliatory firing by police, they suffered bullet injuries in the legs and were later taken to Lok Bandhu Hospital. Two cops also suffered minor injuries when they fell while avoiding bullets fired by the two robbers,” said assistant commissioner of police, Krishnanagar, Deepak Kumar Singh.

Title: Coronavirus hits tourism sector, over 5k tourists cancel bookings
Content: NASHIK: The coronavirus outbreak has affected domestic as well as international tourism in the last one-and-a-half month. Moreover, hotel occupancy and sale of non-vegetarian food items in city restaurants have also dropped by 50%.According to Travel Agents Association of Nashik (TAAN), over 5,000 tourists from Nashik district have cancelled their bookings for international and domestic destinations.Some tour operators have given mandatory unpaid leave to their employees for 15-20 days as their businesses have taken a hit.TAAN itself has 107 tour and travel operators as its members. On an average, 50-60 bookings per tour operator have been cancelled in the last one-and-a half month. The impact has been more in the last 25 days, said Datta Bhalerao, senior office-bearer of TAAN.“Over 5,000 bookings, including both international and national, have been cancelled by tourists. The bookings ranged from Rs 5,000 to Rs 6 lakh each. Over 50% of the bookings were for international destinations,” he said.Bookings for destinations such as Singapore, Thailand, Malaysia, Europe, Iran, Italy, China, Indonesia, and Cambodia have been cancelled.When asked, Bhalerao said that the cancellation charges depend on the type of booking — group or individual. It may be from Rs 3,500 per person onwards to 100% in some cases, depending on the cost of the package and the type of tour.Hotel occupancy dips by 25%, non-veg food biz hitApart from tourism sector, hotel occupancy has also reduced by around 25% due to the drop in footfall of tourists.Moreover, the sale of non-vegetarian food in city restaurants have also dropped by around 50%. “The sale of non-vegetarian foods in the city restaurants and hotels are worst affected due to the outbreak of coronavirus. People are not eating non-vegetarian food due to panic about the disease,” said Sanjay Chavan, president, Association of Bar, Hotels and Restaurants (ABHAR) .

Title: Remove land from prohibited list, orders HC
Content:
Hyderabad: Justice MS Ramachandra Rao of the Telangana high court on Saturday directed Ranga Reddy district in-charge collector S Harish to be ready to go to jail for four weeks if he fails to remove 37 acres of land, belonging to D Shriya Reddy and others of Pratap Jungle resorts in Ranga Reddy district, from the prohibited list within two weeks.

The judge pronounced this order after hearing a contempt case filed by Shriya and others. Though the state has lost its case over this land several times, it is not willing to lose its grip over the land. Citing a latest title dispute it raised before a civil court, the state is now refusing to remove the land from the prohibited list.

The judge did not approve this and sought immediate removal of land from the prohibited list under Section 22A of the Registrations Act.

Title: Two nabbed by ACB for taking bribe
Content: Hyderabad: Superintendent and auditor of pay and accounts office, Hyderabad, was nabbed by ACB sleuths for demanding and accepting Rs 5,000 bribe. The accused were identified as Thota Rama Rao, superintendent, and P Gopinath, auditor. They demanded bribe from a deputy inspector of survey and land records to process his pending salary bills of Rs 1.78 lakh. TNN

Title: 100 principals, teachers, clerks debarred from UP Board exam evaluation in Agra
Content:
Representative image

AGRA: Ahead of starting the evaluation process of UP Board examination answer sheets on March 16, the state secondary education council has debarred 103 principals, teachers and clerks in Agra division from it.

In this regard, regional secretary of the secondary education council has sent a letter with a list of debarred examiners to all the district inspectors of schools (DIOS) in the region.

According to the department officials, the list includes those examiners who were found guilty of carelessness and irregularities while conducting exams or in the evaluation process last year.

The list of debarred examiners includes 12 in Agra district, 53 in Mainpuri, 11 in Etah and 26 in Aligarh and one in Mathura district.

Agra’s DIOS Ravindra Singh said, “Ten teachers, one principal and one clerk of the district have been debarred from the evaluation process. Their details will be forwarded to the evaluation centres in the district. Principals of the schools have been asked to collect appointment letters of teachers for evaluation of answersheets.”

Meanwhile, the secondary education council has determined five evaluation centres in the district -- Government inter-college, RBS inter-college, Fatehchand inter-college, Agra Municipal Corporation inter-college and Baptist Higher Secondary School. Five centres each have been selected in Etah and Mathura and four each in Firozabad and Mainpuri.

The state government has ordered the evaluation process be conducted under the surveillance of CCTV cameras and voice recorders. They will be monitored online from Lucknow. The DIOS offices have been asked to make the required arrangements in this regard.

Title: Improving the She team brand
Content:
Ahmedabad: A team of students from MICA worked closely with Ahmedabad city police to understand the issue of women’s safety and improving brand identity of the ‘She’ teams initiated by city police. The project, launched last year, aims at addressing women’s safety issues, especially in public places.

Prof Shubhra Gaur of MICA, guide for the project, said that the students visited colleges, schools and public places such as roads, malls, BRTS and Sabarmati Riverfront, to understand current scenario of crimes against women and its prevention mechanism.

“Based on the insights they generated, some of the suggestions made to the police department include creative visual manual and interactive games for efficient and effective information dissemination,” she said.

Aditi Garg, a student participant in the urban immersion project, said that they even recreated a scenario of eve-teasing. “We recreated the scenario of a girl going alone near Shivranjani crossroads. At 1pm, it was busy but still we experienced verbal teasing and catcalls by a few passersby.
