Ahmedabad is comparatively safer than a few other Indian cities, still it was an exercise to identify improvement areas,” she said.

“We studied other similar initiatives in cities such as Udaipur and Bengaluru to identify the identity issues and branding. Working closely with police also exposed us to various issues faced by the force, especially female cops,” said Karamveer Singh, another student on the project.

Title: From Sabarmati to Cedars-Sinai in US
Content:
Dr Rajendra Makkar

AHMEDABAD: He is currently the associate director of Heart Institute, executive director of Cardiac Interventional Services and director of Interventional Cardiology Division at Cedars-Sinai Medical Centre in Los Angeles — right in the neighbourhood of glitzy Hollywood. But talk about Ahmedabad and Dr Rajendra Makkar’s eyes light up.

“It’s where I was born and brought up. We lived in Sabarmati as my father was an engineer in ONGC,” said Dr Makkar on Sunday. “I attended St Xavier’s School and later NHL Municipal Medical College. I still remember that we used to go to the Sabarmati Ashram to study, drawn by its serene environment.”

He is visiting India, and Ahmedabad is one of the cities where he is collaborating with cardiologists and surgeons to talk about and teach the transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) procedure. In 2019, his unit performed about 700 such procedures, making it one of the busiest centres in the US.

“I was interested in the procedure since its early days and got trained,” said Dr Makkar. “It was fascinating for me to replace a heart valve without stopping it. Earlier, it was seen as a safer procedure for older patients suffering from stenosis (narrowing) of aortic valve due to factors such as degenerative calcification. But now it’s used in several scenarios, some cases involving patients as young as 15.”

But primarily, such procedures are meant to improve quality of life, he said. “About eight years ago, I performed this procedure on a 100-year-old patient. He lived six more years and was active till his last breath,” he said. “With longevity in India improving over the years, I believe it would be popular in the time to come.”

The cardiologist left Ahmedabad in 1990s and first got trained in Michigan before moving to San Francisco. “In three decades, technology has been a great leveller globally,” he said. “Today Gujarati surgeons, and Indian surgeons in general, are performing similar procedures. The difference comes in factors such as infrastructure and health insurance. But as far as skills are concerned, I don’t see much of a difference.”

Title: NEERI team collects water samples from Yamuna in Mathura
Content:
AGRA: National Environmental Engineering Research Institute (NEERI) officials on Friday collected water samples from drains falling into river Yamuna in Mathura and Agra on the directions of the Supreme Court. The move came in connection with the ongoing hearings to protect the Taj Mahal from pollution.

The samples were taken by NEERI scientists from Kosi drain, Masani drain, Bengali Ghat pumping station, Ambakhar drain and Gokul barrage areas of river Yamuna in Mathura.

Talking to TOI, social worker Gopeshwar Nath Chaturvedi, who has been associated with the cleaning of Yamuna, said that samples were taken from five major points that have been polluting the river. “Led by Dr Praveen Kumar, the NEERI team had visited Agra to collect samples,” he said.

According to environmentalist MC Mehta, the team had taken water samples based on his plea for protecting the Taj Mahal which is indirectly affected by the pollution in Yamuna river. He pointed out that there are two drains situated close to the monument and without making the river pollution-free, ‘clean Taj’ would remain just a dream.

Chaturvedi said that the Ganga Action Plan was started in 1985 after Mehta approached the apex court. In 1998, Chaturvedi had filed a PIL in Allahabad High Court to make Yamuna pollution-free.

In the last hearing in the apex court when Mehta pleaded about the rising pollution levels of the river from Delhi to Firozabad in UP, the court ordered for submission of the report by NEERI.

Chaturvedi also criticised the way the Centre’s flagship Namami Gange Programme was being implemented. He said that the unplanned work will act as a hindrance in making river Yamuna pollution-free in Vrindavan and in Mathura.

“Without including Kosi drain in the plan, the stretch of the river in Vrindavan can’t be cleaned,” Chaturvedi said. He added that under the Namami Gange plan, Mathura has been divided into four zones, however, the work is in progress in only two zones (trans Yamuna and Masani zone).

Even a detailed project report (DPR) for the other two zones - Masoom Nagar zone and Koyala Alipur zone - has not been prepared so far, he claimed.

Title: Spat between allies RJD, Congress over Rajya Sabha seat
Content:
Tejashwi Prasad Yadav and Shaktisinh Gohil (R)

PATNA: There is tussle between allies Congress and Rashtriya Janata Dal for a Rajya Sabha seat from Bihar with the former claiming the same while the latter denying that there was ever any “commitment” to give away the seat. In a letter written to leader of the opposition in the assembly Tejashwi Prasad Yadav , which was released to the media on Sunday, Bihar Congress in charge Shaktisinh Gohil reminded RJD of its “commitment” to give one of the two Rajya Sabha seats from the state which the allies can win on their own. Gohil said in the letter that Yadav had “categorically” said at a joint press conference of Mahagathbandhan during Lok Sabha elections that one seat from the “RJD quota in Rajya Sabha” will be left for Congress. “Hope RJD fulfils its promise,” he said in the letter. However, RJD vice-president Shivanand Tiwari denied that his party had made such a commitment to Congress. “RJD’s state president Jagdanand Singh had also made this clear. However, (RJD chief) Laluji has been authorised to take a decision on this matter,” Tiwari said. Of the five Rajya Sabha seats from Bihar for which elections will be held, based on their resepective strength in the assembly, JD(U) and RJD can win two each while BJP can win one seat. On speculations about his candidature, Gohil said, “If Congress gets the promised Rajya Sabha seat, its candidate will be a leader from Bihar only. Anyone like me, who is not a voter in Bihar, will not be a candidate of Congress.”

Title: Four new Disha model police stations inaugurated across Rayalaseema districts
Content:
District collector Dr Narayana Bharat Gupta, along with SP Ramesh Reddy and TTD CVSO Gopinath Jatti, inaugurat... Read More

TIRUPATI: To mark international women’s day, Andhra Pradesh police department inaugurated Disha police stations across Rayalaseema districts on Sunday.

Disha police stations are model police stations being established by the Andhra Pradesh state government to ensure speedy justice to victims in cases of sexual assault, harassment and POCSO offences.

Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy inaugurated the first Disha police station at Rajamahendravaram on February 8, while deputy chief minister SB Amzath Basha inaugurated the second Disha police station in Kadapa on the same day. The state had announced that 18 Disha police stations would be established across the state.

On Sunday, Chittoor district collector Dr Narayana Bharat Gupta inaugurated two Disha police stations in Chittoor district. The collector, along with Tirupati urban SP Avula Ramesh Reddy and TTD’s chief vigilance and security officer Gopinath Jatti , inaugurated the first Disha police station in the district in Tirupati.

The collector later inaugurated a similar model police station at the district headquarters in Chittoor.

Meanwhile, Kurnool district collector G Veerapandian, accompanied by DIG P Venkatarami Reddy and SP Kaginelli Fakeerappa, inaugurated a Disha police station in Kurnool. The district collector and DIG hailed the vision of the state chief minister in bringing down the ever increasing crime rate against women and children by establishing Disha police stations across the state. “AP will now set an example to the rest of the nation on establishment of best policing practices to effectively tackle crime against women and children,” the officials said.

Anantapur district collector Gandham Chandrudu and SP B Satya Yesubabu also inaugurated a Disha police station at Anantapur district.

Title: Thackeray announces Rs 1 crore donation for temple in Ayodhya
Content:
Ayodhya: Maharashtra chief minister Uddhav Thackeray on Saturday evening offered prayers at the Ram Lalla makeshift temple in Ayodhya’s Ramjanmabhoomi site, marking 100 days in power with a reiteration that Hindutva remains the core tenet of Shiv Sena’s ideology, despite splitting with BJP.

Before the 4:30pm darshan of Ram Lalla, Thackeray accompanied by wife Rashmi and son Aaditya, announced a donation of Rs 1 crore to the newly formed Ram Mandir Trust for construction of the temple, emphasizing the money would be from his personal account and not from state coffers.

“This is my third visit to Ayodhya in 18 months and by the blessings of Lord Ram, I have become chief minister. It’s a sad day for those who claimed the Maharashtra government won’t complete 100 hours. I have parted ways with BJP, not with Hindutva. BJP is not the custodian of Hindutva,” he told reporters in Ayodhya during his curtailed itinerary in which he skipped the Saryu aarti and a public event due to the coronavirus threat.

The Sena leader’s visit to Ayodhya triggered an undercurrent of resentment from seers and the saffron fringe, who view Thackeray’s coalition with NCP and Congress as a betrayal of the Hindu cause as parties of these leaders had termed Lord Ram as an “imaginary character”.

Before Thackeray arrived by road from Lucknow, the district administration swiftly doused fires by putting two senior seers and the Hindu Mahasabha president under house arrest to quell black flag demonstrations. Those interned include Mahant Raju Das of Hanumangarhi temple, Mahant Paramhans Das of Tapaswi Chawni Temple and Rakesh Dutt Mishra, president of Hindu Mahasabha, said SSP, Ayodhya, Ashish Tiwari.

Talking to reporters, Thackeray said, “I came to Ayodhya in November 2018 with soil from land of Shivaji. Then, Ram temple was in a state of flux. Again in November 2019, Supreme Court gave a historic decision and I also became chief minister. I have come here for a third time and whenever I come here, I bring good news.”

Disclosing his telephonic conversation with the UP chief minister Yogi Adityanath on Friday, he said, “I requested Yogiji to provide land for constructing Maharashtra Bhawan in Ayodhya to accommodate Ram Bhakts from the state.”

After Thackeray’s departure, Hindu Mahasabha leader Rakesh Dutt Mishra demanded that Ramjanmabhoomi should be “sprayed with water from Saryu and Ganga as the Sena chief minister had desecrated the holy site”.

Title: DGP Sawang keen on making police stations ‘woman-friendly’
Content:
D Gautam Sawang

VIJAYAWADA: In a bid to break the myth of police stations being no-go areas for women, the director general of police (DGP) D Gautam Sawang conducted a video conference with the in-charges of all police stations on International Women’s Day on Sunday. The DGP declared that henceforth all police stations in the state would be woman-friendly and also set out a 19 parameters to be met to achieve the goal.

In a first-of-its-kind initiative, the DGP interacted with not just the station house officers (SHOs), but also with the family members of all police staff, Mahila Mitra volunteers and Mahila Samrakshana Police , who were recently recruited in the village and ward secretariats. The DGP said that it is an attempt to break the mental barrier that prevents women from going to police stations and the taboo that is sometimes associated with women going to police stations.

It was for the first time that many of the women came to the police station despite their husband, father, brother or son working as a cop for years. Interacting with the family members of police personnel, Sawang urged them to encourage other women to approach police stations freely in case of any problem and to spread the word that police stations are woman-friendly.

Sawang set out actionable goals with 19 parameters divided into institutional, structural, environmental, behavioural and action-based goals to make police stations more woman-friendly. “Starting from today, all police stations will work towards fulfilling these parameters especially gender sensitive behaviour of police,” he said.

While interacting with the DGP, family members of police personnel thanked him for implementing the weekly off. Family members of DSP and above rank officials also demanded the DGP to give them a weekly off, to which Sawang replied with laughter, saying his wife also demanding the same. Kanti Rana Tata , mother of Anantapur DIG, thanked the DGP for the Disha mobile app

The DGP also inaugurated a Disha police station in Guntur on Sunday morning.

Title: Covid-19 dampens Holi spirit in Agra
Content: AGRA: The coronavirus scare has hit Holi festival in the city. With seven residents testing positive for Covid-19 in the city and scores of samples being sent for tests every day, a majority of the city organizations have called off Holi get-togethers to avoid assembly of crowds. The celebratory spirit is missing this year, say wholesalers and retailers as the sale of Holi wares has fallen by 50% as compared to last year.According to shopkeepers, they have not been able to sell even 10% of the stock of colors, sprays, water guns, masks, etc. The sale of sweets has marginally increased as against last year.Vinod Agarwal, a Bijlighar locality based wholesaler of Holi ware, said, “As compared to last year, sales have dipped by 50%. We have no Chinese items this time. All the products available were manufactured in Delhi-NCR. The cost of these products is at least 20% more than those made in China.”But more than the cost fact, the fear of contracting coronavirus is such residents donot want to go to public places and indulging in the usual Holi celebrations.The health authorities have issued an advisory to people to shun large gatherings to avoid catching the infection. “At Holi get-togethers, hugging and applying of colors cannot be avoided. People should prefer to stay at home,” said a doctor.Mayor Naveen Jain has also cancelled the annual Holi party organized every year by the civic body at city’s Paliwal Park. “Following the coronavirus scare, I will not be attending any programme on Holi and also advice citizens to stay at home and celebrate the festival with their family members,” he said.“Every year, I look forward to Holi. But this time, after hearing stories about coronavirus, I do not want other people to touch my face to apply gulal,” said Swati Mahajan, a college student.Anil Goyal, a senior citizen of Pratapura, said, “This year, not many people are keen on Holi celebrations due to the coronavirus. Even children are being told to avoid public places and large crowds. There is no point in taking any risk.”Housewife Vineeta Malik said, “As several positive cases of coronavirus have surfaced in Agra. I am very worried about the well being of my kids. I have been organizing Holi parties every year but have cancelled it this year.”

Title: Ahmedabad: Charming snakes is her passion!
Content:
Lakshmi Pandey

AHMEDABAD: A petite girl with a stick in one hand and a drip pipe in another took a look at an injured rat-snake on Sardar Patel Ring Road near Vasteal and rescued the reptile in couple of seconds. The incident happened at 1.30am this Friday. She put the snake in a box, nonchalantly handed it over to forest officials and returned to a hospital where she being treated for pneumonia for around a week.

This woman is Lakshmi Pandey, a 27-year-old PhD student from Ramol who is the only woman snake rescuer of eastern Ahmedabad.

Pandey has been into reptile rescue for 12 years, from the time she had started curing injured birds at the age of 15.

On her passion, she says, “My father runs an NGO which rescues injured birds and animals. I too volunteered to heal injured birds during the kite flying festival and then I gott interested in wildlife.”

After that, Lakshmi worked for three years to rescue pythons. But as pythons are not found in cities, she started rescuing snakes and monitor lizards.

Speaking more about her love for snakes, Lakshmi says, “We, human beings, have taken their space. We have cut forests, built houses on their space and when they (snakes) come into our so called territory, we kill them. This is injustice and that is why I decided to rescue snakes to help save their declining population.”

But Lakshmi also has to bear the disapproval of many people in the society. “People in our society usually fault me for still catching snakes when I have reached a marriageable age, or tell me that no one will marry me if I keep rescuing snakes. Sometimes, my mother is also annoyed, but I keep focusing on saving snakes,” she says.

On the most difficult movements during catching reptiles, she says snakes had bitten her in four instances during rescue. “But none of them were poisonous. Only four types of snakes are poisonous in Gujarat. Rest of them are harmless,” she says, adding that people should not kill snakes and inform forest officials to rescue them.

Title: ‘Arabic becoming popular second language option’
Content:
Madurai: A few days ago, more than 150 students of Class XI and Class XII in the district kicked off their state board exams by sitting language paper in Arabic. If the misconstrued concept that Arabic is only Muslim’s language is broken, it could become a much more popular second language option for students, said a teacher at Al-Ameen Higher Secondary School, K Pudur, from where majority of the students appeared for the Arabic exam.

“Arabic is easy to learn such as Hindi, French or Sanskrit. However, many people stigmatize it with Muslims. I’ve seen many Hindu students show interest in Arabic as well. If not for the stigma, it can garner more interest,” said Hamza Mubarak, Arabic master at Al-Ameen School. He said that on average, it takes only three months to learn reading and writing Arabic and just one or two years to become fluent.

“The uniqueness in the script is that Arabic is written from right to left. But, the consonants and vowels sound similar to those in other Indian languages, apart from a few exclusive special alphabets. The variation of alphabets is also not so hard to get the hang of it,” explained Hamza. Students who recently appeared for the Arabic exam said that once a student starts learning from a younger age, it is even easier to pick up. “I preferred taking Arabic over Tamil. The current pattern for state board Arabic exams is quite straightforward as well and it gives you the chance to score well,” said a student.

The headmaster of Al-Ameen School, S Sheikh Nabi, said that the school’s students want to learn the language mainly of their own interest and that demand has increased in recent years. “Now, we are having around 70 students in a class for Arabic. If other non-Muslim schools also include the language and hire faculty, I’m sure more students would take up the language as an option,” he said.

The teachers said that these days the language is highly useful for job opportunities in Gulf countries. “Many good opportunities are also available for those who want to pursue and study Arabic in higher studies. There is much demand for Arabic translators, including at United Nations,” added Hamza.

Title: Bank fraud: HC denies relief to staff
Content:
Madurai: The Madras high court dismissed the plea of a co-operative bank employee seeking to quash trial court proceedings against him for recommending loans to ineligible people who had already defrauded the bank by obtaining loans in 2014.

Justice G Jayachandran observed that the circular issued by the cooperative society does not prohibit from taking action against erring officials, as it is only suggestive in nature.

The judge observed that when dereliction of duty is not tainted with criminal intention, recovery proceedings alone is sufficient. “This is a clear case of fabrication of records and thereby, the petitioner and the other accused have caused loss to the society. The role of the petitioner in granting loan and tampering records has been spoken by the witnesses in their statements,” noted the judge.

The petitioner A Manivel was working as the circle supervisor of Trichy district central cooperative bank and his duty was to verify loan applications received by the primary agricultural cooperative society and forward the same to the district central cooperative bank. tnn

Title: Vans carrying Hindu outfit cadre blocked
Content:
Tirupur: Tension gripped Mangalam town on Sunday night after locals blocked the vehicles carrying Hindu outfit members, who were returning from a pro–CAA meeting held there.

The residents confronted the Hindu outfit members for organising the meeting in their locality. A posse of policemen had to be rushed to the spot to bring the situation under control.

“There was verbal duel between two groups. Nobody was attacked. Normalcy has been restored now,” a police officer told TOI.

According to police, more than 1,000 people from across Tirupur had participated in the pro-CAA meeting conducted by Hindu Makkal Kootamaipu at the Mangalam Four Road Junction on Sunday evening. The meeting concluded around 9.30pm and the participants started dispersing in vans. When the vehicles passed through a Muslim-populated area, as many as 100 people blocked the vehicles and staged a protest questioning the rationale behind organising the meeting in their locality at a time when they were opposing CAA.

Hindu outfit members also started arguing and staged a sit-in protest. As the situation became tense, a large number of police personnel were rushed to the place. The cops held talks with both the groups and got the vans move from the locality. Police also got the residents disperse from the place.

Title: Goa: Kalsotsav festivities conclude peacefully
Content:
The kalash procession was taken by Gad family with the assistance of the Parab community from Mahamaya temple

BICHOLIM: After the high court of Bombay at Goa gave a thumbs up, the Kalsotsav festivities of Maya Kelbai Devasthan in Mayem, Bicholim, were held peacefully under strong police bandobast on Saturday.

The kalash procession was taken by Gad family with the assistance of the Parab community from Mahamaya temple which thereafter proceeded to Maya Kelbai temple and then to Sateri temple. The festivities concluded after kalash entered into Maya kelbai temple late in the evening.

A team of around 80 police personnel was deployed to avoid untoward incidents. Bicholim mamlatdar Pravinjay Pandit , Bicholim PI Sanjay Dalvi and Valpoi PI Shivram Vaigankar were present at the site.

The festivities, scheduled to be held from February 28 to March 7, were suspended by deputy collector Jytotikumari anticipating violence between two rival groups with Parab Gaonkar on one side and Naik Gaonkar, Karbotkar Gaonkar, Gosavi Gaonkar and Gawas Gaonkar on the other. The Parab community had referred the matter to the high court.

Title: Pune: Engineers to devise software to help police track stolen vehicles
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Blacklisted and stolen vehicles, and even those sporting duplicate number plates, will soon run out of luck on the city’s roads.

Engineers from the Government Polytechnic College , Pune (GPP), are devising a new system that will harness the existing intelligent traffic management system (ITMS) to track down — and eventually catch — these vehicles.

The engineers said the software should be ready in six months and believe that it would greatly augment the capability of the police in solving crimes.

“We are planning to strengthen the software and hardware of the current traffic management system of the Pune traffic police. We are currently in the process of developing this software and in less than six months, it will be in place,” GPP principal Vitthal Bandal, who is working on this project along with an engineer from the College of Engineering , Pune, said.

Under the existing system, traffic violations such as signal jumping, not wearing seat belts, and helmetless riding, among others, are detected and challans are sent to the vehicle owners.

“We are working on the same system by providing additional technology that would help police solve crimes. Vehicles that are on the blacklist, those that are stolen or even those sporting the duplicate number plates — which is a serious offence — can be detected once we calibrate the current system with our technology,” Bandal further said.

The Pune police department welcomed the initiative by GPP.

“The technology is very good and once in place, it will certainly help the Pune police department in monitoring suspicious vehicles. The process of solving crimes will also become much faster,” additional commissioner of police Sanjay Shinde said.

Title: AMU students’ panel to provide legal aid to those booked for anti-CAA stir
Content:
Aligarh Muslim Universty

AGRA: Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) Students Coordination Committee on Sunday constituted a “legal helpdesk” at the varsity’s Bab-e-Syed to provide free legal aid to those who have been booked by the police while protesting against the contentious CAA across the city.

According to students, since many of the protesters were booked under false charges, there is a need to provide legal aid to them. The students’ committee was formed after the December 15 violence. It comprises lawyers and teachers, mainly to assist the ‘booked protesters’.

Talking to media, Imran Khan of the coordination committee said the “fascist” regime has plans to demonize their peaceful protests against CAA and also target Muslim activists.

“The government wants to criminalize our dissent. So, the committee has planned to constitute a legal helpdesk to fight the witch-hunt by this fascist regime, under the leadership of senior advocate Asad Hayat,” said Khan, adding that local advocate Ifraheem Chaudhary and Pradeep Kumar will also assist them. This desk will be functional at the protest site at Bab-e-Syed for three hours from 6 pm to 9 pm daily starting from today.

“The AMU coordination committee appeals to citizens of Aligarh to contact us if they feel there is any necessity of legal aid. This help will be selfless,” said Khan, adding that pamphlets in this regard will be distributed across the city.

According to committee members, “We, the people of India, have the right to put our counter ideas against government policies which harm our culture and ethos. It generally seems that government of India is targeting a community during the anti-CAA, NRC and NPR movement.”

Meanwhile, the students also appealed to the state government to release legal activist advocate Mohammad Shoaib of ‘Rihai Manch’. Shoaib was picked up by the police from his Lucknow home a day earlier.

Condemning Shoaib’s arrest, members of the coordination committee, said, “We stand in solidarity with him and appeal to the government that he must be released immediately and unconditionally.” Notably, Shoaib was arrested on December 19 and later granted bail. He was again arrested on March 7.

Title: Verna Accident: Three minor boys killed in four-wheeler accident at Verna
Content:
Representative Image

MARGAO: Three minor boys died in an accident involving a four-wheeler at the Verna plateau near the industrial estate on Sunday evening. Police gave the names of the deceased as Joshua Barreto, 15, Rowan Sequeira, 14, and Ethan Fernandes, 15.

While Sequeira is from Sanguem, the other two are from Curchorem, police said.

Police sources said that the accident occurred at around 4.30pm. While two of the minors died on the spot, the third succumbed to his injuries at Hospicio Hospital, Margao, sources said.

Police sources said that the three were inside the car when the accident occurred. Police said that the car was speeding and it veered out of control of the driver while manoeuvring the difficult terrain leading to the vehicle hitting the rocks, leaving the car a mangled wreck.

Following the accident confusion prevailed over which police station held jurisdiction over the location as it borders that of Verna and Maina Curtorim police stations, leading to considerable delay in registration of the accident.

The Maina Curtorim police are conducting further investigations.

Meanwhile, locals have complained of car drag races being held at the Verna plateau during weekends, and have urged the police to act.

Title: Custodial death: Plea to appoint competent official disposed
Content:
Madurai: Taking cognizance of the fact that the case was transferred to CB-CID, the Madras high court disposed a plea seeking to appoint competent officer to investigate the case in which a remand prisoner died inside Madurai Central Prison in 2016.

The superintendent of Madurai central prison stated that the case was transferred to CB-CID as per order dated December 24, 2019. Justice G Jayachandran observed that since the police have already taken an administrative decision to transfer the case to CB-CID, no further adjudication is required in this petition.

Thirukkammal had moved the high court in 2016 seeking a proper inquiry into the death of her husband M Senthil who died inside the prison. The petitioner suspected foul play in his death.

The superintendent of Madurai central prison, in his counter affidavit, stated that in a cell with S Senthil Kumar, another remand prisoner.

On February 23, 2016, the duty warden who heard screaming noticed M Senthil was lying unconscious with head injuries and S Senthil also sustained head injuries. After first aid was given to M Senthil, he was rushed to the government Rajaji hospital where he was declared brought dead.

Title: PAL-V looking at India to set up flying cars assembly line for Asia
Content: Flying cars are no longer a fairy tale. They are a reality now with the Netherlands based PAL-V International BV, which is engaged in the development of the world’s first commercial personal land air vehicle, gearing up to deliver flying cars to its customers and herald a new chapter in mobility. Carlo Maasbommel, VP international business development, PAL-V, talks to TOI about flying cars and the Dutch company’s plans for India.When does PAL-V plan to commercially launch flying cars globally?The product will be commercially launched in the first half of 2021 starting with Europe. As many as 90 pioneer limited edition units will be delivered, which include 45 for Europe, 25 for the US, and 20 for the rest of the world. We are also dealing with some potential clients in India. PAL-V is installed with Rotax engines, the most common engines used in light aircraft. All aviation freaks in the world know about this engine.When will India see flying cars in its skies?First, we will prepare a feasibility study to see what purposes the Indian government want the flying cars for. It could be used for disaster management, coast guard, flying doctors, police squad, or military use. Based on our feasibility study, we will present two machines for these applications with a special price tag. From there on, we are looking at setting up a supply chain and perhaps an assembly line in the near future.Is PAL-V looking at India for setting up an assembly line?The Netherlands and India have good relations. China wants us to come there. We are looking at setting up an assembly line in India for the Asian market. There is a lot of knowledge of and expertise in the aviation industry in India. That’s what we are looking for right now. It may become a reality in fewer than five years depending on the acceptance by the governments and the agreements we make with a variety of parties as well as the government here. This depends also on the value which will be offered by the Indian government. It doesn’t make sense to set up an assembly line in India if only 50-70 high networth individuals are going to buy our flying cars, which are currently being made at Raamsdonksveer in the Netherlands.How do you see Gujarat as a potential location for your assembly line?We are talking with the Gujarat government for a memorandum of understanding (MoU). The MoU has not been finalized yet. To be honest, I think, it will be a good state to start with. Gujarat has good ports and automotive industry.Are you also looking at sourcing parts from India?Yes, we are looking for supply of specific parts from India. I am surveying the country for potential vendors in automotive and aviation related industries. We are using our Dutch embassy and the Netherlands’ trade agencies located in India to contact the right parties.How big is the global market for flying cars?In 2018, Morgan Stanley wrote a report with 30 analysts. It says that the global market for flying cars is estimated to be US$ 1.6 to 2.9 trillion for the next 20 years. However, we believe the market is around US$ 50 billion.

Title: 261 government officers in ACB net with bribery charges last year
Content:
PUNE: The state anti-corruption bureau (ACB) had executed 184 “trap” cases and arrested 261 state government officers in bribery cases last year.

However, the traps “failed” in 38 instances, but during subsequent inquiries the ACB filed bribe demand cases and arrested the officers.

Rajesh Bansode, superintendent of police, ACB, said that none of the traps “failed” owing to the involvement of insiders.

“The 184 trap cases include 38 “failed” trap cases,” he said.

Citing reasons for failure of “trap” cases, Bansode said, “In majority of failed traps, the government officers became suspicious and refused to take bribes. At the same time, they carried out the work of the complainant.”

The traps also “failed” due to sudden transfer of government officers or they not being present on that day, he said.

A senior ACB officer said, “Sometimes, it has happened that the panch (witness) did not report on time and the officer, in question, had left the premises.”

“The ACB analyses the reasons for the failure of trap cases and tries to avert such incidents in future,” he said.

However, before trapping a government officer, the ACB takes due precautions, such as recording of calls, establishing long pendency of work of the victim, unnecessary delays and remarks passed by the government officer in executing the work, and others.

“If the case fits into any one of these categories and the demand is confirmed, a case is filed against the government officer,” Bansode said.

“If the officer demands money to execute government work, it confirms his/her involvement in bribery,” he said.

Bansode said that the ACB had collected evidences against government officers and filed bribe demand cases against them.

“Thus, despite failed traps, we have filed 38 incidents under demand cases and officers have been arrested in all the cases,” he said.

Title: Coimbatore: Burdened by son’s debt, couple kill themselves
Content:
Representative Image

COIMBATORE: Unable to repay the loans that their son had taken, a couple from Loganathapuram near Sundarapuram committed suicide by consuming a pesticide, which is locally known as cow dung powder, on Saturday.

Pointing out that their 24-year-old son Harihara Kumar had borrowed lakhs of rupees from many people, a police officer said the couple took the extreme step after moneylenders started to harass them by seeking to know the whereabouts of their son, who had been missing for the past couple of days.

The Podanur police identified the deceased as Vijayachandran, 57 and his wife Uma Maheswari, 49. According to a police officer, neighbours had seen the couple battling for their life and rushed them to the Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital, where doctors declared them brought dead. After the autopsy, the bodies were handed over to the family members.

Title: HC confirms acquittal of rly employee accused of theft
Content:
Madurai: The Madras high court confirmed the acquittal of a railway employee accused of stealing railway property from the Golden Rock Workshop in Trichy in 2000.

The prosecution had alleged that when the Railway Protection Force (RPF) officials of Golden Rock Workshop carried out an inspection, they found M Alaysius in possession of two railway brass control valves bearing railway marks under the seat of his bicycle on November 3, 2000. The materials were seized in the presence of RPF witnesses as no private citizens were present.

After a case was registered against Alaysius and a search was conducted at his house the next day, RPF officials seized 46 railway cylindrical roller bearing and various engineering and mechanical materials. Based on the statement given by Alaysius, a search was conducted at Anwar Hussain’s shop where several items were seized.

The Trichy JM II court in 2013 acquitted the both Alaysius and Anwar in the case. An appeal was filed by RPF in 2014 challenging the acquittal. Anwar died during pendency of the appeal.

Justice M Nirmal Kumar observed that no independent witnesses were examined and all the witnesses to the seizure are RPF personnel. The judge further observed that there was no distinct identification mark to prove that the valves seized belonged to the railways and whether all the materials seized were easily available in the open market.

The judge also observed that some of the witnesses in the seizure did not supported the case of the prosecution as they admit the articles were old. Therefore, the judge observed that the search and recovery is doubtful.

Title: Fire and rescue services dept opens children's museum
Content:
Coimbatore: In a first in the state, Tamil Nadu fire and rescue services department has set up a children’s museum on the premises of Coimbatore South Fire Station with various equipment used to douse the fire on display.

Director general of police (fire and rescue services) C Sylendra Babu inaugurated the museum established in a British-era building on State Bank of India Road near collectorate.

Sylendra Babu said a new model building would be constructed with an estimate of Rs 3.5 crore on the premises of South Fire Station. But we won’t disturb the trees for the construction work, he added.

“We have set up the museum at the British-era building which was opened in March 15, 1911. We have displayed firefighting equipment used in 1903 besides photographs of old and modern fire tenders,” he added.

Various types of suits used by firemen are displayed in the museum. Types of fire extinguishers, fire bell, three types of hose, portable pumps are also displayed.

The fire department is planning to screen animation videos about the department and its rescue work to schoolchildren.

The Coimbatore fire and rescue services department does not have snorkel.

When asked about it, Sylendra Babu replied that he would look into it.

According to sources from fire service stations, the department did not provide enough ropes to each fire service station. “A few weeks ago, a cow fell into a well near Thondamuthur. But the newly opened Thondamuthur fire service station did not have even a single rope. Immediately, two ropes were brought from the South Fire Service station and the cow was rescued. Most of the fire stations are having just two ropes, which is not enough. The department should give at least seven ropes to each station,” the source said.

When asked about the supply of ropes, joint director (fire and rescue services) S Vijayasekar said the department has enough ropes. Sylendra Babu said the department has got funds under the state disaster relief fund and enough equipment will be supplied to the fires stations.

Title: Biodiversity board to use GIS data to map wetlands
Content:
Panaji: The Goa State Biodiversity Board (GSBB) will seek access to information on the geographic information system ( GIS ) mapping of all water bodies in Goa currently being undertaken by the water resources department ( WRD ).

The board’s member secretary Pradip Sarmokadam said the biodiversity management committees (BMC), formed under the board in villages across the state, are in the process of identifying wetlands and water bodies in their jurisdictions.

He said the committees are also carrying out detailed mapping of the biodiversity supported by these wetlands and water bodies. The WRD data will help them in the process, he said.

This is the first time such mapping of the state’s water bodies is being undertaken. Except for rivers, the exact location of all other water bodies will be mapped during the exercise, including lakes, ponds, wells, nullahs, streams, springs and even reservoirs. With GIS mapping, WRD aims to enable online monitoring of any activity in and around a water body, thus making faster action possible in case of any violation.

Meanwhile, the Goa State Wetland Authority is in the final stages of notifying the century-old Bondvoll lake in Santa Cruz as Goa’s first official wetland. Sarmokadam said that work has already begun to get 35 other areas notified as wetlands.

The National Institute of Oceanography (NIO) has been appointed as an agency under the Goa State Wetland Authority to carry out ground study on the current status of wetlands in Goa.

Meanwhile, various committees are identifying water bodies and wetlands at their level and helping map their biodiversity, right from plants, to insects and bird life dependent on them. Once GSBB gets access to the GIS mapping data, it will help these committees collate data on their own and will make identifying wetlands easier and more accurate.

As per the wetland atlas prepared in 2011 by the space application centre in Ahmedabad, Goa has 555 wetlands.

Title: Coronavirus in Goa: As a precaution, churches in Goa keep stoups dry, use sanitisers
Content: PANAJI: Many Catholics across Goa who went for Sunday Mass noticed that the usual holy water stoups (fonts) at the entrance of the church were kept dry. As coronavirus spreads across the globe, churches and priests are doing their bit to keep it at bay, advising parishioners about safe practices during religious services.Although the state hasn’t reported anyone testing positive for coronavirus, and the archdiocese of Goa hasn’t issued any letter in this regard, priests are gearing up to combat any potential threat from the virus, given the thousands who attend Sunday Mass. Many churches across Goa saw their priests advise parishoners to receive Holy Communion in the hand rather than on the tongue, as is traditionally practiced.The priests’ move came after Archbishop of Bombay Oswald Cardinal Gracias issued a communication with suggested precautions regarding the virus. The letter, which was widely circulated on social media, was only addressed to institutions in Mumbai. However, owing to Gracias’ position as president of the Catholic Bishops’ Conference of India (CBCI), many priests outside Mumbai also decided to follow his advice.Even though the archdiocese of Goa hasn’t issued any communication yet, Se Cathedral, the seat of the Archbishop and the mother church of the archdiocese of Goa, kept its holy water fonts dry on Sunday. Parish priest Fr Alfred Vaz said the precaution was taken following a government circular.“We decided to keep the fonts dry as there are many foreigners who frequent the place considering it is a world heritage site,” he told TOI.At Porvorim’s Holy Family church, priests and ministers used sanitisers, and advised the faithful to receive Holy Communion in the hand. “We haven’t forced people to receive Holy Communion in the hand as we haven’t received any directions yet,” parish priest Fr Caetano Fernandes told TOI. “We merely kept both options open, and told people that it would be preferable to receive communion in the hand.”He said that his parish took these precautionary measures as the church usually attracts a lot of people. “There are also many doctors among the faithful who are open to the idea. We have been following the news and read Cardinal Gracias’ circular. Parishioners are ready to accept what’s good,” Fernandes said.Meanwhile, at Our Lady of Help church in Ribandar and Carmelite Monastery, Margao, holy water fonts were kept dry. In many churches, the virus also found mention in the prayers of the faithful. Attendees were also advised to greet each other with a namaste, instead of shaking hands. The shrine of Our Lady of Fatima at Don Bosco, Panaji, was among the first to follow Gracias’ letter, with its in-charge, Fr Loddy Pires, reading out the letter in full on Friday itself. On Sunday, many churches mentioned Gracias’ letter.Meanwhile, Gracias’ advice on the traditional veneration of the cross on Good Friday is also set to be followed in Goa. The superior at Carmelite Monastery, Fr Archibald Gonsalves, said that the traditional kissing of the cross will not be done this year. Gracias, in his letter, had recommended that a blessing with a raised cross be adequate, where those who desire could queue up only to make reverence with a bow and go back.At Don Bosco, Pires too announced that the tradition of kissing of the cross would not be followed at the shrine’s hugely-popular Good Friday service.The new norms are temporary, Gracias said, and will only be valid till Easter.

Title: Roads in Mela Anupanadi dug up, but not repaired
Content:
Madurai: The residents of Mela Anupanadi in the city find every day commute a challenge as most of the roads in the area are badly damaged, even as they have been repeatedly demanding corporation officials to relay roads. It has been years since new roads have been laid in the area.

Although the locality is in core area of the city, residents feel alienated as they find it difficult in getting basic amenities like road, drinking water and proper street lights. Be it the main or inner streets, all of them are in a shambles.

S Alagar, a resident of Nagammal Kovil Street, said that the street is unfit for commute and they have taken up the issue with the authorities concerned. Several months on, officials have not come forward to address it. “We are dependent on private trucks for drinking water and other household needs as we do not get adequate water supply from the corporation. Water level has receded in our borewells with the summer setting in. Water tanker drivers are not pleased to visit our area due to bad roads ,” he said.

Sewage problem is also a perennial issue in the area. Whenever it crops up, the problematic spot is dug up to provide a temporary solution. Many places have been dug to address sewage block, but they are not set right. “Roads were dug up at four places on a single road over the last few months, but they have not been repaired. We find it difficult to commute on it at night, as lighting is also poor. We want all bad roads to be relayed,” Babu, a resident said.

C Chelladurai, another resident, said that they feel alienated in every aspect as they have to travel long distances to avail basic services, like they have to approach Avaniyapuram station to report a crime, while Teppakulam and Keerathurai area stations are nearby.

When contacted, an official from Madurai corporation said that they were aware of the issues in the area and are already working on to address them.

Title: Foresters step up measures to prevent forest fire
Content:
Coimbatore: Forest department officials in Pollachi have appealed the public not to cook and smoke in the forest area as a pre-emptive measure to prevent forest fire, which they said were mainly man-made.

Pollachi forest range officer A Kasilingam said they have been issuing pamphlets to the people to spread awareness on man-made forest fire and how they could help prevent the same.

They have also urged the local people and tourists not to carry matchboxes or easily inflammable goods to the forest area. “They have been asked not to smoke and throw matchstick, cigarette or beedi butts inside the reserve forest. We have also advised the tourists not to stop their vehicle in the forest area and prepare food there,” the officer said.

He said the violators would be booked under the Tamil Nadu Forest Act, the Wildlife Protection Act and the Tamil Nadu Forest Conservation Act. “We have also urged the public to alert us if they notice fire in the forest. It will help us spring into action immediately to douse the fire and curb the extent of damages.”

Kasilingam and the field staff have distributed more than 500 pamphlets to the motorists at Aliyar and Sethumadai check posts on Sunday alone.

The forest range officer said they have set up fireline/firebreak for a stretch of 80km in the Pollachi forest range and deployed 12 temporary fire watchers to curb the incidence of forest fire in the range.

Title: Kochi’s youngsters don’t dream of owning a house
Content: KOCHI: Real estate is failing to catch the fancy of youngsters in the city. This generation is more keen on taking furnished properties on short lease rather than buying apartments or houses in the city. With the trend shifting from saving for the future to living in the present, the young are on the lookout for more freedom and excitement.“The aspirations of youngsters are different from those of the earlier generations. Those in the age group of 20-30 are generally not interested in buying assets and end up paying their hard-earned money on EMIs. They chose to spend on travel or gadgets rather than investing in property,” says Anuj Puri, chairman of Anarock Property Consultants.Interest rates for home loans currently range between 7.90% and 9.75%.It is possible to get well-furnished properties for lease or rent. It also does not force them to remain tied down to one place. Real-estate developers who study the change in attitude of buyers also say that interpersonal relationships between family members are also witnessing a transformation. Sharing of assets and debts during a spilt is confusing, and people do not wish to get themselves entangled in complicated division of assets and liabilities.“Though it is possible to buy a premium or luxury apartment with a bank loan, you end up paying a major part of the salary as EMI. There are really good and well-furnished apartments available for rent in the city and its suburbs. The rent does not come to half of what you pay as EMI. I do not have to worry about quitting a job or job cuts during times of financial crisis. There is ample financial liberty as the money is not locked in,” said Basant Madhavan, an employee with a multinational company. Moreover, he says that when he leaves the city he does not have to worry about upkeep of the property or its disposal. “Once I retire or decide to stop working I can always go back to my ancestral home,” he added.Najeeb Zakaria, managing director of Abad Builders, said that taking into account changes in the attitude of buyers, developers are keen to explore possibilities of providing co-living spaces. Rather than individuals, large companies or multinational corporations can lease spaces in specially designed co-living properties for their employees. “These are not serviced apartments or hostels. But, there are spaces where the individual housing needs of the residents will be met,” he said. Zakaria also said that the frameworks governing apartment owners’ associations and residents’ associations should change. “Society in general should adapt to the changing times,” he added.

Title: Weed bonfire on Holi today to keep away invasive plants from local flora
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A Weed Bonfire Festival will be organised on Monday evening at Savarkar Smarak to spread awareness about the threat of invasive plant species to local biodiversity on Holi.

Sachin Punekar, founder of biodiversity NGO Biospheres, said the event was in its fourth edition. “We have started an initiative called Weed Bonfire Green Movement. In Pune, this weed bonfire is symbolic and is aimed at addressing the biological invasion. Biological invasion is the biggest threat to biodiversity worldwide. It hinders ecological services and disrupts and destroys the cohesiveness of the ecosystem.”

As to why they chose Savarkar Smarak, he said it was because of its historical relevance. “Swatantraveer Savarkar and his associates had once burnt foreign clothes here to promote the Swadesi movement back then. We will hold the weed bonfire to eradicate invasive alien species and to promote our native biota at the same place.”

He said the basic rationale was to create awareness among the people. “Burning is not the only solution, we will hold workshops as well. We will try and create a dedicated policy to address this biological invasion. Through this particular campaign or movement we will try to promote the right kind of literacy particularly among bureaucrats and politicians.”

There are perennial weeds as well as seasonal weeds. Some thrive in the monsoon while some do so in winters or summers. “We are trying to address all kinds of invasive species including water weeds like the hyacinth as well as agriculture weeds,”he added.

Biospheres is organising the event along with the Pune forest division, the Pune Municipal Corporation ’s environment department and biodiversity management committee and NGOs. Mayor Murlidhar Mohol as well as state agriculture commissioner Suhas Diwase are expected to attend the event.

Title: Marathi actor stops to put out fire near Katraj tunnel in Pune
Content:
PUNE: Noted actor Sayaji Shinde and some others spent 90 minutes putting out a burgeoning forest fire just before Katraj tunnel on Sunday evening.

Shinde was on his way to the inauguration of a hotel and was accompanied by a few people. Their vehicle was driving from Pune towards Bopdeo Ghat, when they spotted the fire on the right side of the Katraj-Satara Road and stopped immediately to have a look.

“We decided to stop and have a quick look at the fire. As we went closer, we realized that it had just started, but was spreading quickly. So we cut some branches of trees nearby and started beating at the fire in a bid to stop it from spreading,” Shinde told TOI on Sunday.

“We identified the contact points and started beating at them with the branches to ensure it didn’t spread further.”

The area was hilly and there was a stiff breeze, which enabled the fire to spread fast.

Shinde and his team realized that they were getting delayed for their event, but persisted in trying to put out the fire as there were two or three jungles nearby. “At one point, we felt our efforts would go to waste, as the fire kept on spreading. It also posed a danger to all of us to an extent, but we persisted and, after 90 minutes of collective effort, we put it out,” he said.

Pictures and video of the entire incident went viral on social media by late Sunday evening. The actor is know for his concern towards the environment and recently undertook several initiatives for tree plantation and conservation across Maharashtra. In the past four years, the actor has planted over three lakh trees in nearly 20 different spots and has also started a non-government organization called Tree-Story Foundation.

Title: With Rs 2.4 crore in Yes Bank, Kolkata division of Iskcon to appeal to PM Narendra Modi
Content: KOLKATA: The Kolkata division of the International Society for Krishna Consciousness (Iskcon) has Rs 2.4 crore deposited in Yes Bank. The authorities have decided to write to both Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman after Holi, seeking their intervention.Officials of the accounts department of Iskcon have desperately been trying to convince the Camac Street branch of the bank to let the religious institution withdraw the money, but to no avail.After the Centre imposed restrictions on withdrawal of cash from Yes Bank, it came to light that around Rs 545 crore of Puri’s Jagannath Temple was stuck in the bank but Tirupati Temple had reportedly withdrawn Rs 13,000 crore from its account. Iskcon Kolkata, too, managed to withdraw a large part of their total deposits over the past one year, but could not take out the last fixed deposit of Rs 2.4 crore.Interest from this Rs 2.4 crore provides for the free meals that Iskcon Kolkata distributes among poor children in schools and other places. A total of 10,000 kids are fed by the institution, funded by this account. The balance was Rs 10 crore around this time last year, spread over two accounts. “The moment we heard talks about trouble brewing at Yes Bank, we decided to take steps before it got late. The accounts department started withdrawing money from the bank in phases. We had decided to withdraw everything but unfortunately, we had not been able to take out anything over the past one-and-a-half months,” said Radharaman Das, spokesperson for Kolkata Iskcon.The spiritual organisation fears this might affect its free-meal scheme for children as now, it has to borrow money from the temple funds to fill the gap. “This fixed deposit accounts for a lot of money, and we are at a loss how to factor in the amount. We will write to PM Modi and the Union finance minister immediately after Holi, requesting them to step in and ensure that we are allowed to withdraw the balance amount. Bank officials are continuously sending our accounts officials back, saying the money is safe and we should not worry about it. But we are anxious, looking at the current situation and we cannot compromise on the meal for the kids,” Das said.

Title: Only 7 colleges apply for new tech courses in Pune
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: After a national executive committee last September realised that engineering colleges must teach emerging trends, the All India Council for Technical Education decided to approve BTech in artificial intelligence and data science, from the upcoming academic year.

The council had then told state directorates of technical education to compile and send a list of interested institutes to them by January 31.The date was later extended to March 8.

Assistant director (technical) C T Kunjir said from Pune division, comprising Kolhapur, Satara, Sangli, Pune and Solapur districts, only seven of the 124 colleges had applied for the course till March 5.

“Colleges may not be aware and the course needs expert teachers in the field which may be a problem for many colleges,” he added.

Principals of prominent colleges said one of the reasons many have not applied is because they don't meet the 50% NBA accreditation criteria.

“At least 50% of the courses must be NBA accredited, which is not widespread among the engineering colleges,” said a principal.

A professor of an engineering college said, “At the graduate level, traditional courses make more sense. Students need to build fundamental knowledge of the subject. Emerging courses can be taught as an add-on credit course or as a PG diploma course. Many colleges offer such credit courses and hence the response to AICTE notification is not enthusiastic.”

Additional seats were not being granted for the new BTech programme, but seats have to be adjusted from the current courses which colleges may not find agreeable.

Anil Sahasrabudhe, chairman of the All India Council for Technical Education said, “The deadline was extended to March 8. The final decision on selecting colleges to have these courses will be taken on April 30.”

Title: Pune: Sanitary napkin machines must in all SPPU-affiliated institutes
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: All colleges and departments affiliated to the Savitribai Phule Pune University (SPPU) will have to install sanitary napkin dispensers and incinerators in women washrooms on an immediate basis.

As many as 800 colleges have been told to make these provisions from the available funds.

The varsity has notified the affiliated institutes and departments that the report of installation of these machines and their regular upkeep must be sent to the SPPU administration.

“The notification issued by the higher education department has mandated the installation of such machines in all the universities in the state. Accordingly, the colleges affiliated to SPPU would also have to follow the notification,” the SPPU’s Board of Students’ Welfare stated in the notification.

“Nearly 55 % of students are women in our college. We have installed both the sanitary napkin vending and disposal machines in our institute,” said professor Majusha Kulkarni of the Modern College of Arts, Science and Commerce.

“We are in the process of procuring sanitary vending machines. We shall meet the requirements as stated by the varsity,” associate professor at the Bharati Vidyapeeth Institute of Hotel Management and Catering Technology, Jyoti Peshwe, said.

“Our college had installed sanitary napkins incinerators in the women washrooms and hostels a few years ago,” associate professor Manisha Khaladkar of the College of Engineering.

Title: Rock pools that support unique ecosystems need conservation in Pune
Content:
A city-based group of scientists and researchers have taken up the study of temporary rock pool habitats that ... Read More

PUNE: A city-based group of scientists and researchers have taken up the study of temporary rock pool habitats that host a range of ecosystems in the tableland habitats of the Western Ghats .

Research group member Yugandhar Shinde , an assistant professor at the department of zoology, Modern College of Arts, Science and Commerce, said almost 97% water in the world is saline.

“The remaining 2% is under glaciers in the Arctic or the Antarctic. The 1% available as fresh water is from the rivers, ponds, pools and lakes. Of this 1%, about 0.35% water is in temporary habitats or pools which harbours 35% of freshwater diversity,” he said.

Such temporary habitats are not just available in the tropical regions with a lot of rain. “In some cases, it is there in colder climate. Melting snow forms small pools, particularly in grassland areas. In India, we generally look at rainwater pools. Not only animals, but plants are found only in these ephemeral aquatic habitats,” he added.

The flora on the Kas plateau is a kind of ephemeral habitat.

“We find some freshwater habitats, and we get some plants which are not terrestrial, but aquatic. Similarly, there are many animal communities in such habitats with very low nutrients,” he said.

Panchgani is another example of such habitats. “The substrata is mostly rock. The little amount of field or mud has poor nutrients. Fauna has adapted to oligotrophic habitats where nutrients are very low. These habitats harbour unique fauna and that ecosystem or ephemeral water body has a whole community, not just one or two animals. If the habitat is destroyed, you will lose a whole community and not just a single species,” he said.

Independent researcher Mihir Kulkarni said the pools are temporary and can hold water for a week to eight days. “In our ecosystems, we have pools that can hold water from 15 days to four or five months. This makes the habitat unique, when you compare it to other such systems in the world. Although, they are temporary, the duration of them being filled with water is quite different,” he said.

These pools harbour diverse groups of invertebrates.

“They will belong to four or five different groups. Commonly, you could find insect groups, crustaceans and other interesting groups like tardigrades which were released on the moon. All these animals have one thing in common specifically with crustaceans and tardigrades— they are desiccation resistant species. They can resist dry conditions for a considerable amount of time. This adaptation enables them to survive in the pools because they can’t fly away to other habitats like other insects,” he said.

Conserving the habitat would help conserve a particular species because most of them are very small. “If you look at all these different organisms, plants and invertebrates and so on, they are not found in other habitats even on comparable altitudes. It is important to conserve the habitat,” Kulkarni added.

Common threats include mining. “ In the Konkan region, tourism brings rubbish which can destroy the ecosystem. We don’t have a much information about the species which can reveal what we are losing out. Other concerns are climate change because if the rainfall pattern changes, and the animals don’t adapt well and will have to make adjustments to their life cycle. It can wipe out an entire ecosystem. So, habitats and landscapes must be conserved.”

Title: Burning of plastic irks Mugalli locals
Content:
The locals said that Sao Jose de Areal such garbage burning incidentsin the past too

MARGAO: Several incidents of burning of plastic by unidentified culprits off the Ramnagri main road at Mugalli in Sao Jose de Areal has left residents irked. They have urged the authorities to take immediate action.

“On Sunday morning I saw that a huge quantity of plastic had been set on fire. People in the vicinity were complaining of suffocation due to the smoke and the foul odour,” a resident, Tenny Fernandes , said.

The residents notified the sarpanch and called the Maina Curtorim police before dousing the fire.

Fernandes said in the past too he has brought the menace to the notice of authorities, but to no avail.

In fact, the residents recount a similar incident in the recent past where piles of garbage were set ablaze in pits in the same locality. The fire brigade had to be called in to douse the flames.

Title: Children of corporation employees felicitated
Content:
Madurai: Children of corporation employees, who have excelled in education and sports, were felicitated by Madurai corporation commissioner S Visakan in a function organized by the corporation employees association on Sunday.

A large number of employees of Madurai corporation took part in the function along with their family members. A dozen children who have made their mark in education and sports were shortlisted by the association members and were awarded cash prizes and mementoes.

The employees who had retired from service in the past year, were also felicitated. The funds collected by the association for the sake of the kin of corporation employees, who had died in the past one year, were distributed at the function.

In his address, the corporation commissioner thanked the employees for helping him run the administration effectively and urged the employees to keep striving to serve the society. Besides the corporation commissioner, city engineer S Arasu, Tamil Nadu State All Corporation Officers Associations Federation(TNACOAF) president S N Shanmugam, general secretary R Seetharaman, Madurai corporation chapter’s president K Muniyasamy and secretary Murugeswari also took part in the function.

Title: Kolkata: Police intensify vigil; 3,000 booked in pre-Holi drive
Content: KOLKATA: In the run-up to Holi, as many as 2,949 persons were booked for various offences on the roads — 1,917 for dangerous driving and 862 for disorderly conduct — during a police drive between 9pm on Saturday and 1am on Sunday at prominent intersections in the city. However, while stress was laid on helmetless driving, there was a sharp dip in drink-driving cases after a number of traffic guards stopped using breathalyzers to test the suspects. In a bid to prevent possible spread of the novel coronavirus through the breathalyzers, cops have gone back to taking a suspect to the police station and then a hospital for a confirmation of the offence.The change in the drink-driving test procedure did have an effect on the final prosecution figures of the city-wide block raid as only 33 drink driving cases were registered, a fifth of the number during the block raid conducted on the night of February 22. During the block raid conducted in the intervening night of November 30 and December 1 last year, the number of persons prosecuted for drink driving was 103. Traffic cops across the city said there has been no official order about stopping breathalyzer tests, but sources said an unofficial word has been passed down to officers to refrain from using a breathalyzers for the time being.During a drink-drive raid, motorists are randomly picked out and asked to blow through a pipe attached to the breathalyzer that measures the alcohol in his or her blood. But since last Thursday, the traffic guards have been informed to take those showing signs of intoxication to a police station and then to a government hospital for confirmation.“The process is time consuming, but it has been advised to be the norm from now on. We have been asked not to take any chance as coronavirus is extremely contagious and can spread through droplets after a cough or sneeze. Hence, we are trying to prevent exposure through this devices which are used by multiple persons,” said an officer. The officer, however, said the change in procedure did not mean that the crackdown on drunken drivers has come to a halt. “We have been speaking a lot with the suspects to understand if they are intoxicated. In case of any suspicion, we are taking the necessary steps,” the officer said.While the Jorabagan traffic guard topped the arrest list with eight drink-driving prosecutions, a number of traffic guards focussed more on other traffic violations. This led to the sharp decline in number.Of the 1,750 bikers who were prosecuted for offences, 1,116 were not wearing helmets and in 634 were on bikes with three riders each. The cops seized 12 vehicles during the raid. According to police, 134 others were prosecuted for rash driving and another 862 were booked for disorderly conduct.The officers even raided several hideouts of suspects and set up nakas across the city. The drive was supervised by senior officers, like divisional commissioners, assistant commissioners and officers in charge of various police stations and traffic departments.

Title: HM, BJP members held for ransacking tailor shop, locking up owner
Content:
Coimbatore: A Hindu Munnani ( HM ) functionary and a BJP worker were arrested on Sunday for attacking a tailor shop owner after he refused to down the shutters of his shop on Friday.

The Annur police identified the accused as K Tamilselvan, 24, of Pillaiyappampalayam near Annur, and 43-year-old D Sasikumar, of Kottampatti. While Tamilselvan is Annur south union vice-president of Hindu Munnani, Sasikuamr is a BJP member.

It is to be noted that the Hindu Munnani had called on the shops to down their shutters on March 6 to condemn the attack on its district secretary Anand. However, the protest was later postponed to March 7. Unaware of this, shopkeepers in Annur didn’t open their outlets on March 6.

A police officer said, “When Ananda Krishnan, a Thanthai Periyar Dravidar Kazhagam member, opened his tailor shop, a group of Hindu Munnani and other Hindu outfit members asked him to down the shutters. When he refused, they ransacked the shop and locked him inside.”

Ananda Krishnan lodged a complaint with the Annur police, who booked Tamilselvan and Sasikuamr under Sections 143 (punishment for unlawful assembly), 342 (punishment for wrongful confinement) and 506 (ii) (criminal intimidation) of the Indian Penal Code and arrested them on Sunday. The two were subsequently lodged in the Coimbatore Central Prison under the judicial custody.

Title: Petrol pumps come under pollution board scanner
Content: KOCHI: It is not just the new petrol pumps that would have to toe the line drawn by the pollution control board as part of making them comply with environment laws.While the fresh guidelines issued by central pollution control board (CPCB), including distance of 50m from residential areas/hospitals/schools, tank specifications and installation of vapour recovery units are directed at new pumps, existing units would have to comply with them sooner or later, Kerala state pollution control board (KSPCB) officials said.“There are a host of issues involving existing units. When it is time for renewal of their licences, we will have to consider all these aspects,” said KSPCB member secretary Sreekala S. A key worry for the board is the increasing cases of groundwater contamination. “Lot of neighbouring wells are facing issues because of contamination from petrol pump tanks and complaints are widespread,” Sreekala said.Kerala state petroleum traders’ association secretary R Sabarinath while welcoming the new guidelines said new norms if implemented properly would help address the issue of groundwater contamination.“I know a dealer who has been supplying potable water to houses nearby for the past two years because of groundwater contamination caused by faulty tanks. In Ernakulam district alone, dealers are supplying water to households in places like Muppathadam, Neriamangalam and Paravur because of issues related to groundwater contamination,” Sabarinath said. According to him, dealers are often not aware about the details when they acquire the dealership from oil marketing companies (OMCs).The national green tribunal had directed oil companies to install vapour recovery systems (VRS) in all petrol pumps as early as October 31, 2018, but this is yet to be implemented. A vapour recovery system helps collect petrol vapour released during unloading and refuelling back to the petrol tanker and underground storage tank.“To my knowledge such systems have not been introduced anywhere in Kerala,” he said, adding that loss due to vaporization is close to one percentage.

Title: Goa police loses its appeal before HC in ’06 Batlo case
Content:
Panaji: The Goa police recently lost its appeal in the high court of Bombay at Goa challenging the acquittal of Tariq Ahmad Batlo by a sessions court on charges of waging war against India.

The high court observed that the prosecution had relied on stock panch witnesses and had failed to examine any of the several independent witnesses present at the Margao railway station in March 2006 when Batlo, a Kashmiri, was arrested while allegedly alighting from the Mangala Express with explosives.

Following his arrest, Batlo had been charged under various sections of the Explosive Substances Act, the Arms Act and the Railways Act.

He had pleaded not guilty and had stated that he was not arrested at the Margao railway station on March 10, 2006 as alleged by the prosecution but near Grace Church, Margao, on March 3 that year by the CID police inspector.

Batlo had also stated that after he was illegally detained, it was made to appear that he had been apprehended at the Margao railway station.

He was later acquitted of all charges by a sessions judge, who had held that there was no evidence on record to suggest that Batlo had been travelling on Mangala Express and had been apprehended upon alighting from the train.

While the prosecution told the HC that Batlo was suspected to be involved in crimes by ‘terrorist organisation’ Tehreek-Ul-Mujahiddin, the court held that the dossier (issued by J&K of him being a member of the group) did not constitute evidence by itself.

“…Suspicion, however grave, can never be a substitute for legal proof in such matters,” observed the division bench comprising justices Mahesh Sonak and M S Jawalkar. “Evidence on record suggests that several persons were available at the railway station, including railways officials. Yet, in the present case, not only were stock panchas called, but these stock panchas were also sought to be passed off as independent witnesses during the course of trial,” the court held.

Batlo was defended by advocate J A Lobo, who was appointed under the legal aid scheme.

Title: 4 AIADMK workers plunge into sewage, narrow escape for Tamil Nadu minister
Content: MADURAI: Minister for co-operation Sellur K Raju and other AIADMK cadre were left red in the face when the flooring of an under-construction traffic island in Sellur gave way and four party workers plunged into the sewage below during an inspection on Sunday morning. It was a narrow escape for the minister who was just a couple of feet away. Officials said soil erosion caused by a leakage in the main sewer line passing under the island on Palam Station Road caused the cave-in.Apart from AIADMK workers, a large number of corporation officials were with the minister during the inspection of the spot where a statue is to come up.The party men who fell into the three-and-a-half-foot-deep hole were lifted to safety. Drenched in filth, they left the place in a hurry even as the minister began addressing the crowd.Corporation officials said the minister was scheduled to inaugurate a community hall built at a cost of Rs 25 lakh and anganwadi buildings constructed at a cost of Rs 17 lakh using his MLA fund. Since the island was on the way, the group decided to inspect the spot where a statue is to be erected under the swachh iconic places initiative.“It was a minor incident, and nobody was injured. It happened due to erosion of soil. There is a pipeline underneath the Island carrying sewage from Sellur to the Munthirithoppu pumping station. The leak was not noticed and it caused the incident,” a higher official from Madurai corporation said adding that they have already begun fixing it.Four traffic Islands - Thiruparankundram, Palanganatham, Sellur and Vilangudi - had been taken up for beautification under the swachh iconic places initiative at a total cost of Rs 60 lakh. While work on two other places is over, those at Sellur and Thiruparankudram have just begun. A peacock structure is coming up at Thiruparankudram, and a structure of kabaddi players is coming up in Sellur to honour the sport which is popular among the youth in Sellur.Structures representing the Thirumalai Nayak Mahal and the Meenakshi Amman Temple car have been erected at Palanganatham and Vilangudi. Corporation officials, including commissioner S Visakan and S Arasu, were present at the inspection.

Title: Thrikkakara police launch clean up drive as seized vehicles eat up space
Content: KOCHI: It may not be as vivid as an auto expo but Kochi police have managed to achieve nearly the same by assembling at least 279 vehicles from their collection of seized goods. At Thrikkakara police sub-division, sedans, suvS and high-end bikes which got tangled in legal troubles have now become ‘unclaimed articles’ and these will soon be auctioned, unless the actual owners turn up with a claim by the end of the month.These vehicles are parked on station premises and AR camps under the Thrikkakara police sub-division.As per the list compiled by the sub-division, there are vehicles from almost all popular brands. “There are vehicles which are abandoned for various reasons, mostly after using them for a crime. Police pick them up and keep them in custody. In other cases, there are vehicles which are seized while police nab someone who have smuggled contraband in them. Some vehicles get stuck with police after they are seized in accident cases,” said a police officer.Police officers took the decision to remove the vehicles after they started to occupy most of the space available on the police station campuses. “It is a waste of money to keep them lying around here. The vehicles — reusable or scrap — need to be auctioned off, if there is no one to claim them. The process itself takes a lot of effort from our personnel.
