We will remove these vehicles and clean up each and every police campus in the Thrikkakara sub-division,” said Thrikkakara ACP K M Jijimon.According to police, the department is in the initial stage of removing the vehicles as they are now in the process of compiling the number and type of the vehicles. “Now, we have taken the list of vehicles in the possession of each police station under the sub-division. The actual number may be at least 100 more than the primary list that we have prepared as there are vehicles which have turned into complete scrap. Some have even got buried under sand. The process of compiling the list of these vehicles is almost over now,” said an officer.Police, now, are in the process of sending individual intimations to the addresses of the owners to whom the vehicles are registered to. Actual owners will have to raise a claim for the vehicle before March 28, as the police have issued a 30-day public notice on February 27 asking owners to contact them if they have a claim. Unless, they turn up after getting the intimation, the vehicles would soon go under the hammer, police said.Also, officers at police stations said that it would be a relief to get rid of the vehicles. “There are vehicles which are in good condition though many have sustained damages,” said an officer with Panangad police.Some police stations like Ernakulam south station moved the vehicles to sites like the Kalamassery AR camp due to lack of space. Two weeks ago around 17 bikes which were already in a dilapidated state were gutted after fire from bushes near the camp spread to the vehicles.Auctioning procedure of the vehicles will take place as per the directions in Section 56 of the Kerala Police Act which specifies police action in respect of unclaimed articles. Meanwhile, excise department, Ernakulam, has already set a date for auctioning the 15 bikes, one car, one pick-up van and four autos in their possession. This auction would take place at Mamala Excise Range office at 11am on March 19. Public can contact nearest excise office to know the details about the vehicles.

Title: KYC Fraud in Kolkata: One more duped in KYC fraud, cops to meet telecom officials
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: Even after police arrested 29-year-old Adityabh Agarwal from Howrah, who acted as the nodal agent who helped gangs siphon off money from people’s bank accounts by tricking them into parting with their bank details on the pretext of updating their e-wallet KYCs, the racket seemed to thrive in the city. A senior citizen, Kaberi Ganguly, of Keshab Chandra Sen Street, received a call on March 2, when she was told to update her e-wallet KYC. As she was duped into divulging her debit card details, Rs 1.6 lakh was withdrawn from her account, police said.

Investigators have convened a meeting with telecom operators to seek their help. After siphoning off money from their targets, the gangs would disperse the funds at the earliest so that the money trail could not be tracked, police said. “They used an app to send requests to citizens to recharge their mobiles. The money they took for recharge were not paid to telecom companies. The accused sent the money to their own accounts and the money they had stolen were pushed into telecom firms,” said a senior investigator.

The officer said to track the stolen money, they would take telecom operators’ help. “We are creating a mechanism in which, we will get an alert when bulk requests are sent,” said an officer, adding stolen money was mostly funding the recharge industry.

Title: Mercury drops as summer begins
Content:
Panaji: While the peak of winter in December and even later part of it had witnessed warm nights, the mercury has remained largely below normal, bringing a chill on a few nights during the first week of summer .

The minimum temperature has hovered between 20 degrees and 22 degrees celsius during March, so far. At least on two occasions, the India meteorological department (IMD), Panaji, recorded a minimum temperature of 20.8C on Saturday and Thursday, nearly two degrees below normal.

The IMD had forecast a slight drop in night temperatures, triggered by western disturbances acting over north-west India, which result in rain and snow fall over Himalayan and adjoining regions.

“The circulations induced over western parts of India bring northerly wind from these cold regions,” Rahul M, scientist, IMD, Panaji, said. This drops minimum temperatures lower than the normal values over Goa.

A circulation over north Karnataka is likely to affect the behaviour of mercury, as the night temperatures will be below the normal range.

While the IMD had also recorded maximum temperatures of over 35C on seven days, making it one of the warmest in a decade, the day temperatures have been within the normal range in March, so far.

Title: Silapathikaram park to open in Duraisamy Nagar
Content:
Madurai: The work on the second Silapathikaram park (botanical garden) was inaugurated by minister for co-operatives Sellur K Raju in Duraisamy Nagar here on Sunday. The project aims to bring back trees that are mentioned in the Tamil epic Silapathikaram (A tale of two anklets) written by poet Elango Adigal and is the brainchild of SP N Manivannan.

Two years back, Manivannan, who takes interest in Sangam literature, initiated a drive to find if the trees mentioned in the epic still existed. The epic, said to have been written between the fifth and sixth century AD, has described in detail the fauna and flora at the time. The chapter in which the characters of the epic, Kovalan and Kannagi, come to Madurai speaks of a variety of trees and how they react at the arrival of the couple, through the eyes of the poet.

“The park created near the SP’s office two years ago is today a flourishing grove of trees and many enjoy it. It is also a learning experience as we were able to learn from him about these trees and took up the mission of planting these trees throughout Madurai,” said Pon Kumar, convener of Pasumai Nanbargal, an organisation working to improve the green cover in Madurai.

“The minister who planted the first tree, has assured us that this park would be designed and maintained with the help of the Madurai corporation,” said M Pushparaj, secretary Duraisamy Nagar Residents Welfare Association, adding that the park was being developed on a half-acre land in their residential complex. The engineering department of the corporation will lay out a walkway in the park, following which 35 saplings will be planted.

Title: Women weavers greeted by students on Women’s day
Content:
Madurai: Students of a school in Chinnalapatti, celebrated International Women’s Day, by honouring the female weavers in their town, known for its handloom sarees.

“Holistic education and compassion for fellow beings is what provide our students with,’’ said N Thilagam, headmistress of Cheran Vidayalaya Matric higher secondary school in Chinnalapatti. On Saturday, the students of the school accompanied by the teachers visited the female weavers at their workplace and offered them sweets and gifts.

Thilagam said that this was an effort to make the students realise the importance of women, and the amount of hard work they put in for their families. “These ladies are makers of beautifully designed sarees and a lot of effort goes into it. When they are appreciated, it makes them happy,’’ said Thilagam.

These women seldom receive any recognition for all their hard work in making these sarees, said another teacher. She said that the school has been recognising women in many fields for the past three years on Women’s day .Tenth standard students T S Rashmi, K Yogeswari and K Pooja said that even though they knew a thing or two about weaving, they were not aware that it was such a difficult task.

“We saw them dipping the cloth in boiling water and then hanging it to dry,’’ they said. The weavers said that they had heard about Women’s day but that this was for the first time, that they received sweets and gifts on the occasion.

Title: Leopard found dead near govt hospital
Content:
Udhagamandalam: A male leopard was found dead in Kotagiri town here on Sunday.

According to a forest official, the big cat was found dead inside a bush near the government hospital in Kotagiri, which is situated close to the reserve forest area. Both the forelimbs of the animal were found injured.

Postmortem operation was conducted as per the guidelines of National Tiger Conservation Authority in the presence of higher officials, a member of an NGO and local body representatives.

Preliminary autopsy report suggested that the animal might have sustained injuries during infighting, leaving it unable to hunt, said Guru Swamy Baddal, district forest officer, Nilgiris division.

Samples of vital parts of the animal were collected for lab test. Later, the carcass was burned in the forest area.

Title: Bidhannagar civic body to hold tax-collection camps
Content:
A Bidhannagar civic body official said the authorities had set itself a target to mop up Rs 100 crore from pro... Read More

KOLKATA: With Bidhannagar Municipal Corporation scheduled to go to the polls later this year, the civic body is taking extra efforts to collect property tax dues from the Rajarhat jurisdiction area that has run into several crores of rupees. Civic assessment department officials will from next week visit every ward and hold camps inside housing complexes in Rajarhat to collect property tax and sort out mutation-related problems.

A Bidhannagar civic body official said the authorities had set itself a target to mop up Rs 100 crore from property tax by October, before this civic body’s tenure completes. “Most people living in Rajarhat area wants to pay tax, but many of them are confused about how to calculate the amount. Our officials will visit every ward and hold camps in housing complexes in Baguiati, Kaikhali, Raghunathpur and other places, where residents can clear their confusion,” said an assessment department official of Bidhannagar municipal corporation. Sources said the central valuation board had been engaged to come up with a revised property tax structure for about 30 wards of Bidhannagar Municipal Corporation that fell in Rajarhat and areas adjacent to Salt Lake.

Civic officials pointed out that collection of the tax had been quite regular from residents of Salt Lake, but crores of rupees had been due from property owners living in the civic body’s Rajarhat jurisdiction. “When Bidhannagar Municipality was upgraded to a municipal corporation in 2015, a vast area on the two sides of VIP Road till airport, which previously fell under the erstwhile Rajarhat-Gopalpur municipality, was included in Bidhannagar. But there has been some problems in synchronising the area’s property tax collection with that of Salt Lake. This is largely due to disputes relating to issues, like building plan sanction and mutation, with complaints pouring in about several buildings being constructed illegally in the previous Rajarhat-Gopalpur municipality area,” a civic official said.

A Bidhannagar Municipality official said that the civic body had started collecting property tax from households in Rajarhat only since the past couple of years, after the authorities came up with a tax regimen for the belt. The tax amount collected on a quarterly basis had been very low and several years of dues had not been paid yet, the official said.

In Salt Lake, the civic body regularly sends tax bills to residents every quarter, based on the old tax structure of the pre-1995 rate. “A revised tax structure is required to increase revenues,” an official said.

Title: Ex-mantris, MLAs of NC, PDP & Cong form J&K party ‘to move on from 370 mourning’
Content:
SRINAAGR/NEW DELHI: Splinter groups from People’s Democratic Party (PDP), National Conference (NC) and Congress came together on Sunday to announce formation of a new political outfit, Apni Party , to provide an alternative to “family-owned” parties and move on, as some said, beyond “perpetually mourning” over abrogation of Article 370.

As reported by TOI on February 24, at least two dozen members of J&K Apni Party are ex-MLAs and former ministers of PDP, NC and Congress led by ex-finance minister of J&K and sacked PDP member Altaf Bukhari . The new formation draws its strength from scores of district-level functionaries across Kashmir drawn from the three main parties that governed the erstwhile state for several decades.

J&K’s special status was removed on August 5 last year and the state was turned into a Union Territory with a legislature. PDP chief Mehbooba Mufti and National Conference’s Farooq Abdullah and son Omar, all former CMs, were in detention since August 5 and have now been arrested under the stringent Public Safety Act.

Incarceration of the top leadership of PDP and NC is seen by many as the chief reason behind largescale defections in the two parties.

Congress called the new outfit an offshoot of BJP, intended to create “chaos and divisions” in J&K. “People have witnessed the offshoot of the saffron party in the political system of J&K and fully realise what is going on behind the curtains,” J&K Pradesh Congress Committee president G A Mir said in a statement.

NC and PDP described Apni Party as the “B-team of BJP” and said it was now becoming clear that detention of the top leadership of the two parties had nothing to do with law and order but was purely political.

“The way things are unfolding in J&K, it is pretty clear that the central government, in connivance with a few, are contriving to prop up yet another formation in J&K to serve its interests,” NC said. PDP state secretary Abdul Hameed Kousheen said while three former CMs were under detention, Bukhari and a few others were free to carry out their political activities.

Bukhari, appointed president of Apni Party, sidestepped criticism and blamed the leadership of PDP, Congress and NC for the developments. “We were waiting for the last seven months hoping that they will come out and raise issues and problems faced by the people. But as most leaders who were under detention have been released, they preferred to keep mum instead of raising those issues,” he said. He demanded that those in detention under PSA should be released.

Others who joined the new outfit include Usman Majid, a former minister and ex-MLA of Congress from Bandipora, PDP founding member Ghulam Hassan Mir , former PDP general secretary Dilawar Mir and former chief secretary and ex-NC MLC Vijay Bakaya among several former ministers and MLAs.

BJP's Kashmir unit welcomed the launch of Apni Party and said, “People were fed up with family politics in the Valley and now they want to see a vibrant change.” The party said it would work with the new outfit “for the development of the region”.

Title: Adopt zero-tolerance towards sexual harassment cases in schools: Experts
Content:
Coimbatore: Shocked by the sudden rise in sexual assault cases in government schools in the district, psychologists and child counsellors are calling for more awareness and counselling sessions for teachers.In the last two months, three such cases were reported one as recent as Saturday.

A 42-year-old blind teacher at a government school was arrested by the Perur all women police on Saturday under the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act, 2012 for sexually harassing a 12-year-old blind student. In February, a government school teacher in Annur was arrested for sexually harassing a 12-year-old girl student. The headmaster of a panchayat union primary school in Negamam was also arrested in February for sexually harassing girl students.

Psychologists cited surveys to show that the state fared badly in tackling the issue. S Arul Vadivu, a psychologist with the school education department, said they have been talking to teachers about sexual harassment cases and its consequences during training sessions. “There has to be district-level counselling sessions for teachers in the beginning of the academic year,” she said.

Along with male teachers, their spouses should be given counselling, said G P Godhanavalli, student and family counsellor. “Their marital problems could also be a reason for the issue. That should also be dealt with,” she said. “Counselling sessions should be offered to both teachers and students in government, corporation and private schools. Such incidents happen regardless of the type of school but in some instances, they don’t get reported.”

Personal accountability is lacking in the school education department, said Saras Bhaskar, a counselling psychologist. “A teacher accused of sexual harassment is just transferred to another place. Rather, the school education department should adopt a zero-tolerance policy and make teachers sign an agreement during recruitment that in case of such an accusation, they would be dismissed and also blacklisted,” she said.

“Awareness sessions would help, but unless there are strict policies regarding sexual harassment and also penalty on school authorities for non-implementation, there wouldn’t be a real impact,” Bhaskar said. “There should also be provisions to strictly deal with false complaints,” added Bhaskar.

Title: Underground parking proposed near old Aatish Market in Jaipur
Content:
JAIPUR: To decongest the Walled City area, an underground parking has been proposed near the old Aatish market. The project will accommodate 400 vehicles, including 250 cars. According to officials, the multi-crore project will be constructed and funded by Jaipur Smart City Limited (JSCL) and executed by the Jaipur Municipal Corporation (JMC). An official at JMC said, “The detailed project report (DPR) of the parking has been prepared. The estimated cost for construction is Rs 15 crore. The project will be completed in two years, once commissioned.”

The technical bid for the project will be opened on April 16. “The decision to construct the parking was taken nearly five months ago. Following which DPR was prepared,” an official said.

As parking has become a perennial problem in the Walled City areas, civic agencies are trying to make the area vehicle-free. A senior official said, the Ramniwas Bagh underground parking extension, however, might not be included in the Smart City projects list.

An official at UDH said, “The JSCL has proposed to develop parking spaces near the Walled City. For this, Rs 90 crore has been proposed. It was requested to include Ramniwas Bagh parking and involve JDA for construction. However, the proposal was turned down,” the official said.

The JDA is planning to extend underground parking at Ramniwas Bagh to resolve the issue of vehicular congestion in Walled City.

As per the proposal, approximately 700 vehicles can be parked after extending the existing parking. An official source said, “The underground parking is proposed to be constructed on a strip of land situated between the existing parking and Mahila Chikitsalaya. Its length and width would be 584 metre by 26 metre. Once constructed, the parking space can house 1,615 vehicles. The estimated cost of the project is Rs 153 crore, if the JDA got the financial support, the project would have been completed without hindrance,” the official said.

Title: Rajasthan government mulls regulating unauthorised budget hotels
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: To fill the coffers of the cash-strapped state government, the urban development and housing (UDH) department is mulling a proposal to regulate unauthorised budget hotels operational in the residential areas of the city.

The long-pending demand of the hoteliers was put forward by the state UDH department in a meeting called by the chief minister’s advisor to boost revenue. The department had given a presentation to regulate these unauthorised budget hotels.

A senior official at the town planning wing said, “As Rajasthan is a tourist state and these hotels are a major source of economic activity, the department will formulate a policy to regulate these units. Mandatory provisions of fire safety and policy will be incorporated in the policy.”

Over the years, these hotels have illegally flourished near the bus stand area, railway station and many residential areas of the city. The state is eyeing to earn Rs 1,000 crore revenue after regulating these budget hotels. As per the department officials, there are over 2,000 budget hotels operational in the state, including 525 in the state capital alone.

Many fear the state government might get stumped as high court has banned commercial activity in residential areas and directed the state government to adhere to the masterplan. However, the UDH department official said, “The government can always regulate these establishments after bringing the policy. The policy will be framed following the high court directions.”

Sources said the department might also bring in policy to regulate nearly 450 hospitals in the state capital and coaching institutes to earn revenue.

Other than this, the UDH is also contemplating to impose impact fee on illegal buildings to discourage the rampant practice in cities. After the decision was taken in the building bylaws expert committee, the department is preparing a draft proposal. Once the concept is introduced, owners of commercial properties that violate the building bylaws will have to pay penalty every year. But for residential properties, a one-time impact fee will be imposed.

An official said, “The proposal has been given approval by the expert committee. The rates will be fixed after receiving a nod from the UDH minister.”

Title: Uday express’ all-woman crew goes full steam ahead
Content:
Coimbatore: Operated by an all-woman crew, the journey on Coimbatore-Bengaluru Uday express turned out to be a special one on the International Women’s Day on Sunday.

In a warm gesture to celebrate the untiring spirit of women employees, the Salem division of Southern Railway got the entire operations of the Uday express, from the loco pilot, to guards to ticker examiners, executed by women.

It was a pleasant surprise for the passengers of the train 22666 when they realized that it had an all-woman crew. The train left from Coimbatore railway junction around 5.40am.

While H Nimmy and B J Sindhu took the mantle of loco pilots, S MAreena was the guard, and P R Savithri, Dhanya, Mythili, Helen Mary and Nandhini were the travelling ticket inspectors and examiners.

Even as the crew were receiving appreciations from the passengers, a battery of Southern Railway officials was waiting at the Salem junction to honour them. When the train reached Salem Junction by 8am, officials led by additional divisional manager A Annadurai, senior commercial manager E Harikrishnan and senior divisional finance manager Uma Maheswari received the crew and gave them sweets. Passengers also joined the officials to appreciate the crew.

Title: Women’s Day celebrated by AIADMK
Content:
Madurai: Hundreds of women participated in the Women’s Day celebration organized by the Jayalalithaa Peravai in Madurai on Sunday. Minister for revenue, disaster management and IT, R B Udayakumar, who inaugurated the meeting said that the event was organized to thank chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami and deputy chief minister O Panneerselvam for declaring the birth anniversary of late chief minister J Jayalalithaa, as state girl child protection day.

Women who participated in the meeting showcased their skills. Welfare measures were also distributed to the beneficiaries by the minister. Meanwhile, street corner meetings were held in many places to celebrate the birth anniversary of Jayalalithaa. Gifts and sweets were distributed by the members of the AIADMK to the residents of Karumbalai on Sunday. Similarly, events were held in many parts of the city. Games including bullock cart races were organized by the AIADMK.TNN

Title: Telangana budget: Healthcare gets over Rs 6k crore, govt focus on basti dawakhanas
Content: HYDERABAD: The state government , in its budget for 2020-21, allocated Rs 6,186 crore towards healthcare . It announced that another 232 basti dawakhanas will be coming up in the city. This, in addition to the 118 currently in operation, according to finance minister T Harish Rao “The government will establish more basti dawakhanas in areas where SCs, STs, minorities and people from underprivileged backgrounds reside,” the minister said. There will be two basti dawakhanas for every division according to the minister. Speaking about the KCR kit, Harish Rao said that institutional deliveries had increased by 22%.“The government has provided 40 dialysis centres, 20 intensive care units in government hospitals. In addition, 305 standardised labour rooms and 200 Ammavodi vehicles have been provided,” the minister said. He also announced the government will soon initiate an action plan on the lines of Kanti Velugu for treatment of ear, nose, throat and dental ailments.The minster said that the government is doing all it can to prevent the spread of Coronavirus in the state. “As per experts’ opinion, there is no scope for survival of the virus in the summer heat. With summer already here, there is no need for panic. Even then, the government has taken all preventive measures. I request people to not believe in any rumours,” Harish Rao said.

Title: All-women crew operates train
Content:
at the helm: Loco pilot T J Gerothy (right) and assistant loco pilot Vidya Das inside the Venad Express at Ern... Read More

Kochi: A train operated by all-women crew conducted service from Ernakulam Junction railway station to Shoranur on the International Women’s Day on Sunday. Venad Express (16302), which conducted service at 10.20am, was operated by women crew starting loco pilot to RPF personnel.

The train was run by T J Gerothy, a loco pilot with 22 years of experience in Indian railways. She was assisted by Vidya Das, assistant loco pilot, in the cabin. “I worked as assistant loco pilot for around 10 years before getting promoted as loco pilot. Currently I am running passenger train and occasionally operate mail and express trains. I am happy to be part of this initiative on Women’s Day,” said Gerothy, who is from Varapuzha.

The chief ticket examiner was P B Geethakumari, who has 32 years of experience as TTE. “Though I have been in the field for the past 32 years, being part of an all-women crew in Venad Express is a surprise for me,” she said, while waiting to board the train.

Venad Express operated with all-women crew on trial basis on the same stretch on Friday. “Normally, there would be an assistant to help me during duty. Today there is no one to assist me. This is my first experience,” said AC technician Sunitha.

The crew was received at Ernakulam Junction and were honoured at a function attended by deputy commissioner of police, Kochi City, G Poonguzhali, assistant collector M S Madhavikutti, and GST intelligence deputy director Gayathri P G, who flagged off the train.

Besides the all-women crew, the station master, senior passenger guard, traffic staff and signal staff at Ernakulam Junction station were women. An exclusive all-women batch performed the mechanical duties like shunting, rolling in /rolling out examination and other works at the station.

Title: Dhatwada locals want bandhara demolished
Content:
Ponda: Dhatwada-Usgao locals are firm on their demand that the bandhara erected at Dhatwada be demolished. This may reduce the chances to get Mhadei water for augmentation of Khandepar river at Opa , sources said.

Villagers on Wednesday had agreed to allow the water resources department (WRD) to lay a pipeline under the river bed of Dhaushirem-Khandepar nullah, provided the department demolish the bandhara. The bandhara is built inside the nullah.

But, the WRD said that it cannot demolish it now as the bandhara is filled with water. “If we have to release the water, we have to remove plates of the Opa barrage which is impossible at this stage,” WRD executive engineer Arun Naik said.

At a joint meeting between WRD officials and Dhatwada-Usgao locals under the banner of Dhatwada Usgao Citizens Forum held before Ponda deputy collector and sub-divisional officer Kedar Naik, locals demanded that the bandhara be demolished.

The department has already laid an underground pipeline covering 2.5km of the 3km-long nullah bed. Work on just 500m is pending.

Title: Portrait of an artist as a technophile
Content:
Austin Konchira at his art exhibition at Durbar Hall Art Gallery

KOCHI: We live in an age when a wave of neo-luddism, philosophy of technological opposition, riding the growing fears of automation, is sweeping across the world .

But Austin Konchira will have none of it. The aesthetic experience of machines in the works of Austin is a vision cobbled together by disembowelled nuts and bolts, sockets and fulcrums in a state of perpetual motion. His canvases reveal a kinetics of chaos that can immerse you in a world where desire meets death. The metallic music that emanates from his art is that of the industrial junkyard and the factory assembly line: thrum and rumble, drone and scrunch.

For many modernists, fear of technology and horrors of the modern age that gave us two world wars and ideologies like fascism were traumatic. For Konchira too, it was a similar experience. His earlier works had hellish landscapes and deformed human beings crying out in pain.

Konchira says machines and discarded mechanical objects began to appear in his paintings as far as 20 years ago. “When I used to do surrealistic works I used machine forms to fill the space. They were supportive elements to the main theme. Recently I began to think why not use them as the main theme,” he said.

“Men invented machines but they had a growth of its own. I believe that a modern man cannot fulfil his desires without machines. Many criticize them but there is no escape from them,” says Konchira, who taught history for 20 years in various colleges across the state. “In Indian art scene, you cannot see an artist who praise machines, they were all against it,” he said.

“But it’s true that some aspects of machines are hideous like the aircrafts in the world war,” says Konchira, who holds a postgraduate degree in history from University College, Thiruvananthapuram. “I am worried when we misuse technology and machines,” he said.

A dropout from the College of Fine Arts in Thiruvananthapuram, Konchira calls himself a self-taught artist.

“I always consider my art as a performance to heal my existence. It is a long journey to reach some unknown destination and I know that one can never reach there till his life is spent,” writes Konchira in a note introducing his work. A seeker, Konchira’s art has traversed several styles from naturalism to romanticism and surrealism and abstraction. A journey he continues to undertake in search of new images, forms and colours.

An art exhibition by Konchira is on at the Durbar Hall Art Gallery. The exhibition will conclude on Wednesday.

Title: Allocation for public debt repayment down in Telangana
Content:
Telangana finance minister T Harish Rao presenting budget in the state legislative assembly on Sunday. Chief m... Read More

HYDERABAD: The state government has reduced allocation for public debt repayment compared to last year. Finance minister T Harish Rao on Sunday announced that Rs 4,701 crore have been earmarked for this purpose in the 2020-21 budget compared to last year. The figure was Rs 6,411 crore and Rs 4,558 crore in the years 2019-20 and 2018-19 respectively.

Public debt repayment is the measure how government instils confidence in lenders. The state government also announced that the tax devolution from Centre to the state is expected to be lower in 2019-20 by Rs 3,731 crore as compared with the budget estimates.

Following the economic slowdown, the growth of the state’s own revenues in 2019-20 (till the end of February) is estimated to be at 6.3%, much below the growth of 16.1% achieved in 2018-19.

The finance minister also said that it is also expected that due to the recommendations of the 15th Finance Commission , there will be a reduction in the share of Telangana in central tax devolution from 2.437% to 2.133% resulting in reduction of tax devolution by an amount of Rs 2,384 crore in 2020-21.

Title: On two-wheelers, they make a statement on Women’s Day
Content:
Madurai: Around 150 women on 70 two-wheelers rode through Madurai city to spread the message of women empowerment and gender justice on International Women’s Day on Sunday.

The two-wheeler rally organised by Terapanth Mahila Mandal, Madurai, is part of the ‘WOW – Women On Wheels’ initiative. The rallies were held across India in more than 400 centres in an attempt to enter the Limca Book of Records. The rally was flagged off at the Terapanth Bhavan on Manjanakara Street by the chief guest, Dr Usha Kim of Aravind Eye Hospitals, who addressed the gathering of enthusiastic young women.

“Women are the real architects of society. They are the nourishing power of the universe which make the world alive and colourful,” she said.

The rally made its way across the city to Teppakulam and back to the Bhavan for a distance of more than 7 km. The rally which saw all the participants wear helmets, aimed to spread the message of women empowerment, necessity of wearing helmets and awareness about gender justice.

“This is for the first time that such a big rally is being conducted. It was great to see the huge turnout from the public, all of them dressed colourfully in orange and white,” said Nayna Parokh, President, Terapanth Mahila Mandal, Madurai.

During the event, Kumkum Agarwal was awarded Prerna Samman for her work in women empowerment. President of Terapanth Sabha, Om Prakash Kothari and President of Terapanth Yukak Parishad, Dhiraj Parokh also addressed the rally.

Title: Telangana's per capita income growing faster than India’s
Content:
Telangana finance minister T Harish Rao along with home minister Mahbood Ali and chief minister K Chandrasheka... Read More

HYDERABAD: Telangana ’s per capita income (PCI) which grew to Rs 2,28,216 has outpaced the national average of Rs 1,35,000.

“The progress of our state can be seen in the fact that Telangana’s (growth in) per capita income is Rs 93,166 higher than of the country,” finance minister T Harish Rao said while presenting the state budget on Sunday.

While the national average per capita income grew at 6.3% for 2019-20, Telangana’s growth stood at 11.6% for the same period.

The Socio-Economic Outlook 2020 released by state government showed that Telangana’s PCI in 2018-19 was Rs 2,04,488 while India’s was Rs 1,26,521 for the same period.

While district-wise growth in PCI was not given, the 2018-19 numbers showed that 23 districts in Telangana had outpaced the national average. As per the data, Rangareddy district had the highest PCI at Rs 5,78,978 while Hyderabad had a per capita income of Rs 3,57,287.

In terms of Gross District Domestic Product (GDDP), calculated on the same lines as Gross State Domestic Product (GSDP), both Rangareddy and Hyderabad had stand-out showings for 2018-19 with GDDPs of Rs 1,73,143 crore and 1,67,231 crore respectively.

The PCI growth rate of the state since 2013-14 has consistently been higher than the country’s. For 2013-14, the growth rate for state and country over the previous year was recorded at 11.5% and 11% respectively. The PCI growth rate of Telangana was higher in 2015-16 too at 13.5% over the previous year while the country had a growth rate of 10.6% in the same period.

Title: Four set ablaze over gang rivalry in Bikaner, two critical
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: Two people were critically burnt and two others injured when their vehicle was set ablaze by around six attackers in Bikaner’s Nokha area on Sunday evening. The crime took place barely 150m from the police station and is suspected to be the fallout of a gang rivalry.

“The four victims were sitting in their vehicle and having tea when around 4.30pm, the attackers poured petrol on the vehicle and set it afire. Two passengers suffered more than 70% burns and are under treatment at a Bikaner hospital. The other two got away with minor burn injuries,” Bikaner SP Pradeep Mohan Sharma said. Sources said the critically burnt are unlikely to survive as their injuries are very grave.

“The victims and accused were members of rival gangs and both groups had a long criminal history. Around six months ago, the victims had attacked the accused. Sunday’s attack was apparently an act of revenge. A case of attempt to murder has been registered against the accused. We are investigating the matter and looking for them,” SP Sharma said.

Even as cops claimed the accused are yet to be arrested, sources said around six people have been detained in connection with the crime and their vehicle seized. The attack took place in a lane parallel to the Nokha police station while a Community Liaison Group meeting was being held there.

Title: Man shot at in Jhotwara, accused flee
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: A man was shot in his shoulder by two persons in Jhotwara police station area on Sunday evening and was admitted to SMS Hospital .

The victim identified as Pradeep Yadav is a history-sheeter of Jhotwara police station and was shot in his shoulder by the accused near his house in Sahajpura. Jhotwara ACP Bajrang Singh said, “The victim is a known history-sheeter and before incident he was talking to the accused. The conversation suddenly turned into an argrument and the accused fired at him. The accused are also known criminals.”

Yadav is undergoing treatment at the hospital and is out of danger. Cops are looking for the absconding accused who are yet to be arrested.

Police reached the hospital and recorded Yadav’s statement in which he named the accused as Himanshu and Bunty. tnn

Title: Hope rises as MSME units get more orders
Content:
Coimbatore: With the financial year coming to an end, micro, small and medium enterprises (MSMEs) in the district are receiving more orders.

This could be due to the necessity of industries to achieve the year-end target, representatives of MSME associations said. They hope to tide over the slump of the previous fiscal if the trend continues for the next quarters.

Job orders in sectors such as textile machines and pumpsets have seen an increase, said C Sivakumar of the Coimbatore Tirupur District Micro and Cottage Entrepreneurs Association (Cotma). “While it is not as much as we used to get earlier, it is better compared to the last year,” he said. “There is a 60% increase in the orders compared to the last year.”

District president of the Tamil Nadu Association of Cottage and Tiny Enterprises (TACT) J James agreed. “Compared to almost no orders in the beginning of this year, over the last one week, there has been 40% increase in orders. While usually orders for pump jobwork begin in December, this year, it has started to pick up,” he said.

Industrialists hope that the trend will sustain post April, which would mean that they will have a favourable year. “Units have started to get orders. But, we suspect it to be due to the year-end targets. We have to wait for two more months to get a clear picture. Only after April we can say whether the upward trend would sustain,” said state vice-president of Laghu Udyog Bharati S Surulivel.

While some reports said that due to the coronavirus impact on the Chinese industry, Indian engineering industry stands to gain, a section of industrialists were sceptical. “We cannot deliver for prices as competitive as China,” said Surulivel.

Title: Avoid panic-buying sanitisers in bulk: City pharmacists
Content:
Madurai: With the first COVID-19 case reported in Tamil Nadu at Chennai on Saturday, public and health officials are on alert across the state for possible spread of infection.

In light of the COVID-19 breakout in India, many pharmacies and departmental stores in the city said that the sale of hand sanitizers and hand wash solutions has shown a distinctive rise during the past month. Pharmacists are now urging the public to not panic-buy such items in bulk which could lead to a shortage.

The most effective way to prevent the spread of any viral infection, including COVID-19, is practising hand hygiene and cough etiquette. “It was surprising for us because hardly 10% of people in the city buy sanitizers and hand wash solutions. But, during the past month, there has been an increase in sales. Cheaper brands are getting sold out quickly and many individuals are even buying it in bulk as well,” said a pharmacist from Kamarajar Salai. The pharmacist added that they have had to get more orders for sanitizers from different brands to keep up.

“Certainly there has been an increase in sales and we found some people buying even 500 ml containers which were mostly left unsold before. There is no threat of shortage yet but definitely demand has increased,” said a salesperson at a departmental store in Anna Nagar. Apart from sanitizers, pharmacists said that retail sales of masks had shown a marginal increase too.

“It is better to be safe than sorry. We had not paid much attention to getting sanitizers before but it would be foolish now to ignore precautions. We have young children at home too,” said Shanti A, resident of KK Nagar.

Meanwhile, the Tamil Nadu Chemists and Druggists Association general secretary, KK Selvan urged the public to remain vigilant but not buy sanitizers or masks in bulk. “Manufacturers are unable to match the orders required, as there is a sudden demand and it is not possible to import too. So, the public should exercise good judgment and take precautions as and when necessary instead of stocking up. Irresponsibly buying it in bulk can cause a shortage and those who really need it will suffer,” he said.

Title: Loan waiver: TRS junks DBT, will hand over cheques
Content:
Finance minister T Harish Rao announced that local MLAs will distribute the cheques to the eligible farmers.

HYDERABAD: The TRS government, which had promised a farmer friendly approach, made major announcements regarding the loan waiver scheme. Instead of distributing the loan waiver amount through direct benefit transfer (DBT), the government will now distribute cheques to the farmers. All outstanding loans up to Rs 25,000 will be waived off in a stretch with the release of Rs 1,198 crore.

Finance minister T Harish Rao announced that local MLAs will distribute the cheques to the eligible farmers. This shows that the TRS regime is keen on reaping political benefits by making direct contact with the farmers, unlike the DBT. A total of 5,83,916 farmers have outstanding loans below Rs 25,000. It is estimated that the state would need Rs 24,738 crore for this scheme as against Rs 16,124 crore when it implemented it in the first cycle between 2015 and 2018.

The state has allocated Rs 6,225 crore this year for the scheme. Rao later said that all outstanding loans of above Rs 25,000 to Rs 1 lakh will be waived in four instalments. It may be noted that the allotment for loan waiver last year was Rs 6,000 crore, but did not spend single rupee on the scheme.

Title: Aurangabad: GMCH’s building being turned into virus management centre
Content:
AURANGABAD: In preparation for possible coronavirus cases in the city, the Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH) has emptied its cardiovascular and thoracic surgery (CVTS) building for the setting up of a coronavirus management centre.

Over the past week, the government health authorities and private hospital administrations had held several meetings. In a meeting called by the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) on Wednesday, mayor Nandkumar Ghodele, municipal health officer Nita Padalkar, deputy director of health services Swapnil Lale, district civil surgeon Sundar Kulkarni, head of GMCH’s medicine department Meenakshi Bhattacharya, World Health Organisation’s consultant doctor Shaikh Mujeeb and Indian Medical Association ’s Kuldeepsing Raul and Satyanarayan participated.

It was decided that the responsibility of preliminary screening and diagnosis of Covid-19 lies with the district civil hospital, while training and tertiary care management is the GMCH’s responsibility.

The GMCH has, subsequently, dedicated its two-floor CVTS building for setting up of a coronavirus tertiary care management centre. According to GMCH medical superintendent Suresh Harbade, “The guidelines state that there should be an isolated compartment for each patient with oxygen support. We are raising compartments for isolation of each bed.”

The GMCH has maintained that no suspected or positive coronavirus patient has been identified in Aurangabad so far. However, the centre is being developed in case an emergency arises, the hospital said.

The cath lab at the CVTS building went out of function around 2 years ago. Since then, the hospital had stopped performing heart-related surgeries and diagnostic procedures. Harbade said the staff of the CVTS building will be equipped to manage the coronavirus cases. “The GMCH has started the training of its doctors, nurses and class IV staff for the management of Covid-19. If municipal or district health authorities approach us, we can train their staff too,” he said.

The hospital has called for masks (N-95) from the district public health department and the Directorate for Medical Education and Research (DMER). The hospital will be using its HIV personal protective equipment (PPE) for coronavirus management.

Title: Ministers take stock of hailstorm-hit districts, assure compensation
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR/JAISALMER: Ministers in charge of the hailstorm-affected districts took stock of the crop damage on Sunday and said that every affected farmer will be compensated adequately based on the girdawari (crop assessment) report. They also directed the officials not to deprive any farmer of crop-damage assessment.

B D Kalla, minister in charge of Jaisalmer and Barmer districts, directed the officials that a special girdawari report for areas with more than 33% damage must be submitted by March 16 so that relief can be provided. Kalla also said that farmers who suffered more than 33% damage will be provided compensation through Pradhan Mantri Fasal Bima Yojana and those farmers who are not covered under it will be provided assistance from the Natural Disaster Fund.

Chief minister Ashok Gehlot had instructed them to assess the damage in 18 of 33 districts in the state.

“The state government is standing by farmers. Compensation will be given to affected farmers. Assessment is being conducted by officials in all affected districts,” said agriculture minister Lalchand Kataria, who visited the affected areas in Jaipur. Minister in charge of Jaipur, Shanti Dhariwal, after taking stock of crop losses in the villages of Sirsi region in Jaipur said wheat crop has been badly damaged due to hailstorm in the district and vegetables have been destroyed completely in some places. “The complete assessment of the damage caused by hailstorm can be established only after the completion of girdawari report. So far, girdawari has been done in 90% of the affected areas. Not a single farmer should be deprived of crop damage assessment by the officials,” he said.

“In Jaipur, crop damage has been between 50 and 70%. In some cases, the damage is 100% (cash crop including vegetables and tomatoes),” he added.

Pratap Singh Khachariyawas, Bundi in charge, also instructed the officials to submit the girdawari ssoon. Govind Singh Dotasra , minister in charge of Ganganagar also echoed similar sentiments after assessing the damage.

Title: Goa: Soon, activity-based learning at DSE schools
Content: PANAJI: The Diocesan Society of Education (DSE) is preparing to introduce more activity-based learning at the primary school level in its institutes, assistant secretary of DSE, Fr Arnaldo Pinto said recently.Fr Pinto said that activity-based learning can help in laying a strong foundation at the pre-primary and primary school level, after he unveiled an activity workbook for pre-primary school children. He said that the DSE was in the process of similarly preparing activity-based learning material for the primary school students as well.The core premise of activity-based learning is that learning should be based on doing hands-on experiments and activities.The idea of activity-based learning is rooted in the common notion that children are active learners rather than passive recipients of information. If the child is provided the opportunity to explore on their own and provided an optimum learning environment, then the learning becomes joyful and long-lasting.Sr Olivia Oliveira, who is a specialist in kindergarten education and under whose guidance the workbook for pre-primary students was prepared, said that the workbook contains activities which help the child to develop and keep them steady in their writing skills.The book will help children solve and learn even more difficult cognitive tasks. It will aid in “creating a natural period of thinking through various activities”, she said.The workbooks have already been implemented in Santa Cruz Pre Primary School , school manager Fr. Ricardo Pinheiro said, stating that the teachers and parents too had helped introducing the activity-based teaching-learning process in the school.The school headmaster Russell Coutinho said that the parents had cooperated well in programmes as per the workbook where their active participation was required with their children.

Title: Bird flu in Tamil Nadu: Poultry farmers stare at another blow
Content: COIMBATORE: Even as poultry farmers in Namakkal, Coimbatore and Tirupur are struggling to cope with the drop in sales due to Covid-19 scare, they are staring at yet another business challenge in the wake of avian flu outbreak in Kerala.For now, the drop in sales was only due to Covid-19 scare and the bird flu outbreak in Kozhikode has no impact whatsoever in the multi-million poultry sector of Namakkal. Poultry farmers say they have been dealt a severe blow because of the coronavirus scare and seek the government to take measures to prevent fear mongering before sales could drop further because of avian flu.“If the government does not take any action to create awareness that chicken is not a health threat, poultry farmers will be in deep trouble. We have no choice but to let chicks out from farms,’’ said Vangili Subramanian, president of Tamil Nadu Egg Marketing Society and a pioneer in poultry sector in Namakkal.Namakkal has hundreds of poultry farms which on any given day have 20 crore chicks. These are exported to various countries besides catering to domestic supply across the country. Kerala is a key buyer.Subramanian said there was no way bird flu could spread from Kerala to farms in Tamil Nadu. “But the fear can affect consumption,’’ he said. While Namakkal poultry farmers can fall back on other markets, those in Coimbatore and Tirupur say they would be severely affected if fear of avian flu spreads. “There are close to 5,000 farms in Coimbatore and Tirupur concentrated in places like Dharapuram, Udumalpet, Madathukulam and Annur. More than 80% of our chicken is sent to Kerala,’’ president of Coimbatore district broiler merchants association M Kandasamy said.He said 20 lakh to 30 lakh kg of chicken was sent to Kerala every week. Reiterating the view of Subramaniam, Kandasamy also said that the farms here would not be affected by bird flu outbreak in Kerala. But if the consumers stop buying because of the scare, then they will be hit hard. “The farm gate price of chicken has dropped to Rs 25 per kg where as our input cost itself is Rs 70 per kg,’’ he said.

Title: BJP challenges BSP MLAs joining Congress, calls it unconstitutional
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: Rajasthan BJP has challenged the BSP MLAs joining Congress while submitting a petition before assembly speaker CP Joshi in the assembly. BJP objected to the joining by calling it unconstitutional and demanded disqualification of the BSP MLAs.

The petition reads, “It is the party which has to take a call on the merger or forming an alliance, not its MLAs.” BJP MLA Madan Dilawar had told the speaker that the way the MLAs joined Congress calls for an inquiry. “This has violated the electoral system of the country. I urge the speaker to investigate the matter legally and find out the motives behind joining,” said Dilawar, who handed over the petation along with some BJP MLAS. Reacting to the move, Joshi said, “I have received a formal petition from the BJP, law will take its own course.” Six BSP MLAs - Rajendra Singh Gudha , Jogendra Singh Awana, Wajib Ali, Lakhan Singh Meena , Sandeep Yadav and Deepchand - had joined the ruling Congress in September 2019.

The mnove was scripted by chief minister Ashok Gehlot after several rounds of negotiations with the MLAs while keeping the BSP chief Mayawati in the dark. BJP has been raising objection since the MLAs joined Congress. Sources said that if BJP failed to get a proper response from the speaker, they will take the matter to the court. tnn

Title: Tamil Nadu: DMK in no hurry to choose new general secretary
Content:
K Anbazhagan

CHENNAI: Following the demise of K Anbazhagan , who was the DMK’s general secretary for 43 years, the party has to now choose a successor to the post. But the DMK may not be in a hurry to choose its next general secretary, multiple sources in the DMK said.

Anbazhagan became the party’s general secretary in 1977, after V R Nedunchezhiyan, who was holding that post, resigned. Since then, M Karunanidhi and Anbazhagan have remained the only contenders for the posts of president and general secretary in the DMK’s intra party elections.

As the senior-most leader, DMK treasurer S Durai Murugan may be the natural choice. With organisational polls now under way and the formal election of DMK president and general secretary being the last step in the process, it is likely to take time, pointed out senior leaders.

After the death of Karunanidhi, M K Stalin was chosen as the president by the party’s general council. Despite Anbazhagan’s failing health due to age-related complications, Stalin had decided that the latter will remain the general secretary until his end.

“Actually, there is no hurry for choosing a new general secretary. As per our party bylaws, in the absence of the general secretary, the party president can discharge all the duties,” DMK Rajya Sabha MP and party spokesman T K S Elangovan told TOI. At the DMK’s last general council meeting held in November, 2019, the council vested Stalin with additional discretionary powers.

“Further, the general secretary is an elected post. Members of the party’s general council will elect a person for the post. For that, a meeting of the party’s general council has to be convened,” Elangovan added.

Besides the week long mourning period, the DMK’s organisational elections too have already begun. The process has now been suspended for a week due to Anbazhagan’s death.

“What has begun is only the party’s preliminary election process, which will end in April. Elections to the posts of party president and general secretary will take place only towards the end and that may happen only after the assembly elections,” said DMK Rajya Sabha MP R S Bharathi.

While the assembly election is more than a year away, anything could happen in politics. “It is the prerogative of the party president and the person that he chooses will become the general secretary. As such, there would not be much competition,” said a DMK source.

“In the past, it was the party’s treasurers, who went on to become the general secretaries, including in the case of Anbazhagan. Hence, the party’s present treasurer Durai Murugan may be the obvious choice, as and when it happens,” DMK sources said. When that happens, the DMK may have to choose a new treasurer too.

Title: Old Goa ruins to echo with sacred music from bygone days
Content:
Over 70 artists from across the globe will perform at the annual festival

PANAJI: The ruins of the Church of St Augustine will resonate with uplifting strains of timeless music from March 13 to 15, when the fifth edition of the Ketevan sacred music festival will host musicians from several countries at the monument in Old Goa.

The relics of St Ketevan were brought from the Middle East to the UNESCO world heritage site, and were found buried there for almost 400 years. Inspired by this Queen of Georgia, the festival combines unique music traditions from different eras, with a line-up featuring over 70 artists from Argentina, Spain, UK, France, Georgia, Australia, Japan, Russia, Vietnam, Portugal, Switzerland, besides India.

The highlights of the annual fetsival include the World Premiere of the Cantata a Vox Clamantis In Deserto,composed by the festival’s resident composer, Dr Santiago Lusardi Girelli, as well as a performance by 22 Vietnamese artists celebrating the Th Mẫu - Worship of Mother Goddess of Three Realms.

The festival this year will be opened by octogenarian Indian jazz master Braz Gonsalves, with the Goa University Choir.

On day two, the ruins will come alive with the sounds of the ancient kingdom of Al-Andalus and the fiesty colours of the flamenco soul. Passes are available at Furtados in Panaji and Margao.

Title: Drones may soon monitor Tamil Nadu jails
Content:
Representative Image

CHENNAI: Soon, the campuses of central prisons in Tamil Nadu would be under close scrutiny as unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) will help step up surveillance. Officials say this would be the first time that prisons in the country would be using drones for surveillance.

There are nine central prisons for men and four special prisons for women, with more than 13,000 remanded and convicted prisoners. While three of the prisons in Vellore, Trichy and Coimbatore are spread over 100 acres, the remaining are spread over 20 to 45 acres. With shortage of manpower, it is a daunting task to keep a close watch on convicts, particularly those locked up in high-risk cells. This has prompted the prison department to step up surveillance by installing jammers to X-ray machines, checking smuggling of contrabands and ensuring that convicts don’t get access to cellphones.

TN had announced in the Budget session that Rs 21.85 lakh would be allocated for procuring drones to monitor prisons effectively. “In the first phase, the department plans to procure nine drones, each at a cost of Rs 2.25 lakh,” said an official, seeking anonymity.

While the department has invited tenders to procure the UAVs, senior officials have sought the assistance of the police department’s technical wing to purchase drones that suit the prison department’s need. “We will procure UAVs with specifications similar to those of the police department,” he added. The closed-circuit television cameras in the prisons have become defunct. In such a scenario, it would be a daunting task to keep a close watch over the prison campus and act immediately in situations like a riot.

The drones would be used to prevent smuggling of contraband into the prison.

Title: Aurangabad: Harsul waste management project in limbo
Content:
Representative image

AURANGABAD: The civic body did not have any discussion with the agency, which was shortlisted for the Harsul waste management plant tender, on whether the bidder is ready to accept the modified terms of the tender set by the standing committee on February 13.

The tender for the installation, operation and maintenance of the plant to treat 150 tonnes of waste per day (TPD) worth Rs 16.76 crore was placed before the standing committee. On February 13, committee chairperson Jaishri Kulkarni , gave a ruling that the tender cannot be approved in full. Kulkarni said that the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation could only procure the machines required from the agency, but the operation and maintenance of the plant has to be done by the AMC . The committee approved Rs 4.57 crore of the total tender cost.

In September 2019, the committee questioning the efficiency of the agency, asked the AMC to carry out the re-tendering process. However, Shiv Sena brought the tender before the committee again in January asking it to reconsider the old tender. According to deputy mayor Rajendra Janjal , who is also a standing committee member, re-tendering would increase the costs of the project by at least 10 to 15%.

Title: Stop all NPR work in the state: Uttam urges KCR
Content:
Hyderabad: Telangana Congress president and Nalgonda MP N Uttam Kumar Reddy in a letter to chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao on Sunday said the state should take a clue from the Kerala government and issue a government order (GO) to government officials to stop all activities related to National Population Register (NPR).

“While we welcome a resolution in Telangana assembly against NPR, NRC and CAA , this alone is not enough to stop the NPR work in the state. Clear-cut directions in the form of a GO should be given to the officials to stop all NPR-related work as has been done by few other states,” the letter said.

He also attached a copy of the GO issued by the Government of Kerala which read: “Considering the apprehensions among the general public that the conduct of NPR-related activities lead to NRC, the state government must order a stay on all the activities related to the updation of NPR in the state forthwith.”

Uttam said that the Congress will lend full support to the resolution against CAA, NPR and NRC in the Telangana assembly. “A GO staying NPR work will send a strong message that Telangana, home to a diverse population, stands firmly opposed to the communal agenda of the BJP-led central government,” he said.

Stating that the NPR is the first step towards implementing a nation-wide NRC, he said that data from the NPR would be used to instill fear against targeted sections of society. “The problem is not necessarily with the NPR itself but the blatant communal intentions of the BJP that is implementing it,” he said.

He said that it is important for the state government to take a documented and definitive stand against CAA, NPR and NRC. “We believe that a resolution to be passed in the state assembly is a step in the right direction, but not an adequate response to the threat of communalisation,” Uttam said.

Title: Telangana budget: From Rs 1k crore last year, 2-bhk project funds hiked to Rs 11.9k cr
Content:
Telangana chief minister K Chandrashekar Rao

HYDERABAD: After having drawn severe criticism for not releasing adequate funds to the two-bed room housing project for the homeless poor in the past six years, chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao-led TRS government has allocated Rs 11,917 crore to the housing department in the budget for 2020-2021 fiscal.

The government had allocated a meagre Rs 1,005 crore in 2019-20 budget for the project.

With this huge allocation in 2020-21 budget, the good news for homeless poor is that their six-year long wait and dream of becoming owners of “dignified housing” in the form of 2-bhk units — an election promise made by chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao in 2014 poll campaign — has shown signs of materialising.

Over one lakh houses in and around GHMC area alone are likely to be completed before elections to the civic body. Polls to GHMC are likely to be held by year end or early 2021.

Currently, construction on majority of the total sanctioned 2.72 lakh 2-bhk housing units is nearing completion in the state. Contractors had stopped work at several places over non-payment of bills. The project requires over Rs 9,000 crore to be completed.

CM KCR had dropped indications of TRS government being committed to fulfil its poll promise of providing “2-bhk dignified housing” to the homeless poor in the state assembly on Saturday itself.

Stating that the TRS government promises only those things, which it can fulfil and that 2-BHK project was one among them, KCR had said the party has been delivering every promise made by it to the people of Telangana in its election manifesto. “The 2020-2021 budgetary allocations will make this amply clear even in case of 2-BHK project,” he said in the assembly on Saturday, while replying to Congress members allegations on TRS-government’s failure to complete the much-delayed housing project.

The KCR-led TRS government has decided to fulfil its promise made in 2018 assembly elections manifesto of giving Rs 5 lakh each one lakh eligible families owning lands to construct 2-bhk houses.

This promise was made by TRS as the government was finding it difficult to get suitable land to expand the beneficiary list for 2-BHK housing project.

Those who have own lands but do not have pucca houses and are eligible for 2-BHK units, will be given Rs 5 lakh each in 2020-21 financial year.

Title: Telangana budget: Roads & highways given a raw deal
Content:
Picture for representational purpose only.

HYDERABAD: Only Rs 750 crore have been allocated for development as well as maintenance of highways in Telangana .

There was no mention of budgetary allocation to take up works on regional ring road, which is estimated to cost over Rs 13,000 crore. Though Rs 550 crore were allocated for completion of integrated collectorate complexes, district police offices and police command control centres, a raw deal has been meted out to the roads and buildings department.

The R&B now needs to obtain loans to not only take up development of highways but also for maintenance as the allocation is meagre. The government has allocated Rs 1,000 crore to TSRTC in the budget. Though the accumulated losses of TSRTC are over 5,000 crore, this allocated Rs1,000 crore will provide partial relief to the RTC.

The chief minister has also promised cargo business from government departments to TSRTC to raise its revenue. In all, the transport, roads and buildings department got an allocation of Rs 3,494 crore, of which over Rs 1,000 crore would go towards salaries alone. The development and expansion of national highways, state and district roads is all set to slow down in Telangana in the current financial year due to lack of financial support.

Title: Jaipur: 1 arrested for growing poppy
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: Jaipur Rural police on Sunday arrested one person in Jamwa Ramgarh for growing ‘ poppy ’ ( papaver somniferum ) and seized 73,642 plants of the same. The accused was growing opium in the middle of his wheat field for the past couple of years.

The accused, 40-year-old Bansi Lal, was growing poppy in two areas of his field. “We received information that the accused was illegally growing poppy and constituted a team to nab him. A 29-member team raided his field and found that poppy plants were being grown at two spots. During questioning, the accused confessed that he had been growing poppy for over two years,” a police official said.

According to officials, the accused admitted that he was addicted to doda-post and had planned on selling the poppy at a high price in the market. The seized poppy plants weighed 610kg.

Title: Pune: Stand-up comics tickle the funny bone while ghazals serenade many
Content:
PUNE: It was a full house on Sunday at the Amstrad Times Celebrate Pune festival with sounds of laughter, hooting and whistles buzzing around the arena.

The women of the Bharatiya Digital Party, aka ‘Bhadipa’, engaged the crowd completely on the second day of the festival.

The Balgandharva Rangmandir was bustling with a predominantly young audience, majority of whom were fans of the many acts and actors, especially the irrepressible “Bhadipachi Aai” (Renuka Daftardar) and the plain-speaking Savita Prabhune, alias “Kadam Kaku”.

However, the young brigade of women stand-up comics Sayali, Trupti, Madhura, Savani and Neha were not too far behind in garnering applause. They were contemporary, uninhabited, and unapologetic. They enjoyed interacting with the audience and were quick on the repartee. But the show-stoppers were indeed “Bhadipachi Aai” and “Kadam Kaku”.

The festival is powered by Phoenix Marketcity , co-sponsored by Sankla Buildcoon and the Pune Municipal Corporation is a partner.

The music launch of actor-director Mahesh Manjrekar’s film, ‘Pangharun’, added flavour to the festivities later in the evening. The entire team of the movie was in attendance. Popular poet-lyricist Vaibhav Joshi presented “Chandane Tuze Maze”. He was accompanied by singers Hrishikesh Ranade and Anjali Marathe.

Earlier on Saturday night, noted vocalist Rahul Deshpande ’s ‘Shayarana’, that premiered at the Times Celebrate Pune festival, took the ghazal aficionados on a delightful journey that continued well past midnight.

He was joined by the talented actor-vocalist Priyanka Barve. Barve enthralled the audience with solo performances of songs ‘Aata Jagayache Ase’, ‘Malawun Taak Deep’, ‘Salonasa Sajan Hai’ and more. She joined Deshpande for a few duets.

“This entire event is all about give and take. You will get as much from me as you give. Leave all your baggage outside and tell yourself that you are only going to be happy tonight,” Deshpande told the audience as he started humming Nasir Kazmi’s “Aaj Dekha Hai Tuze Bahut Der Ke Baad”.

Deshpande’s expertise in this beautiful form left the audience marvelling the delicate power and translucence of his voice. “After completing SSC, I spent almost 12 years learning from ghazal expert Sureshchandra Nadkarni who introduced me to ghazals sung by different singers. Ghazal is all but a form of Bhaavsangeet and my grandfather Vasantrao Deshpande was a connoisseur,” he said adding, “In classical music, the ‘sur’ comes first and the words follow. In bhaavsangeet, however, words come first and the ‘sur’ follows and enriches it. The focus changes and one needs to work on the diction as well.”

The audience was left spellbound as numerous ghazals of renowned poets like Faiz Ahmad Faiz, Ahmad Faraz, Nasir Kazmi and Suresh Bhat were performed. Deshpande also presented a ghazal by Vaibhav Joshi, which is to be a part of his grandfather’s upcoming biopic, “Mee Vasantrao”.

The programme reached its pinnacle with the rendition of “Ranjish Hi Sahi … Dil Hi Dukhane Keliye Aa’ by Deshpande and Barve. Happy with the response of the gathered mass, Deshpande said it was difficult to get an audience for a ‘ghazal-only’ programme. He thanked The Times of India for providing him with a platform.

Aaditya Oak, who accompanied Deshpande on the harmonium, also compèred the event. His wit and repartee had the audience in splits, making Deshpande comment that Oak — though a resident of Thane — was as good as a Punekar. Shayarana would not have been what it was without Anay Gadgil on keyboard, Yashwant Vaishnav on tabla and master Sanjay Das on guitar.

Title: Mercury takes upward swing in Rajasthan
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: After a spell of hailstorm and rain, weather on Sunday was dry while mercury took an upward swing across the state. However, there is not going to be any rainfall on Holi when weather would continue to be dry.

Gradual rise in the temperature was witnessed across the state. No rainfall was reported in any part of the state. People in Jaipur witnessed a chilly Sunday morning as a minimum temperature of 14.4°C was recorded in the city. In the afternoon a bright sunny day was witnessed in and around Jaipur while a maximum temperature of 25.5°C was recorded.

Jaipur Met office said that there is no forecast of rainfall for Monday and Tuesday during the festival of colours – Holi. However, a few places are likely to get mild showers on Wednesday and Thursday.

Bikaner remained coldest in the state where a minimum temperature of 12.2°C was recorded. It was followed by Jaisalmer where a minimum temperature of 12.5°C was recorded, Churu 13, Sriganganagar 13.7, Udaipur 14, Ajmer 14.3 and a minimum temperature of 15.2°C was recorded in Jodhpur.

In its forecast Jaipur Met office said that weather would mainly remain dry in the next 48 hours and thereafter mild rainfall is likely on Wednesday.

Title: BRABU, NOU get new VCs
Content:
Patna: Profesor Hanuman Prasad Pandey will be the vice-chancellor of B R A Bihar University (BRABU), Muzaffarpur while Professor H N Prasad of Banaras Hindu University has been made the VC of Nalanda Open University (NOU), Patna.

Governor-cum-chancellor Phagu Chauhan on Sunday made the appointments. Vibhuti Narain Singh has been appointed pro-VC of Magadh University, Bodh Gaya. All these appointments have been made for a period of three years from the date they join their posts.

These posts were lying vacant for the past several months and the search committees constituted by the chancellor had submitted the panels of selected candidates to him more than one and a half months back. But the appointments materialized only on Sunday when the CM called on the governor at Raj Bhavan.

The chancellor’s secretariat has advertised the posts of VCs of Patna University, KSD Sanskrit University and B N Mandal University. The posts of pro-VCs in as many as eight universities, namely, Patna, Tilka Manjhi Bhagalpur, BRABU, L N Mithila, KSDSU, Maulana Mazharul Haq Arabic and Persian, B N Mandal and J P universities have also been advertised. The last date for online submission of applications for these posts is April 10, according to Raj Bhavan sources.

Title: Elephant with open wounds rescued, sent to rehab
Content:
Chennai: A 55-year-old cow elephant Jameela with deep open wounds on both sides of its hips was rescued by wildlife officials from Pottalpudhur in Tenkasi district on Sunday and sent to the forest department’s elephant rehabilitation centre in Trichy. Its owner continued to hire the elephant out for functions despite the wounds, which showed no signs of medicare, according to animal welfare activists.

The action by the wildlife authorities was triggered by a complaint sent to them by A S Ramesh, an animal lover, who is a software consultant in Chennai. He told the TOI that he first noticed Jameela’s condition when he visited Pottalpudhur for a function at which she was paraded.

“On both sides of the hips there were deep wounds that had been left open. There was no indication that any ointment had been applied to the wounds. The open wounds posed a grave danger to the very survival of the animal, which was being forced to attend functions in many parts of the state,” he said.

Animal welfare activist Antony Rubin too said veterinary care was totally absent and the animal continued to participate in functions with the open wounds.

Another animal welfare activist, R Raghu, said the animal had been suffering the wounds for more than a decade and that the forest department had rescued the elephant on several occasions, only to release it to the owner’s care in a few days. He said the wounds were the result of making the elephant lie down on cement floors. “Elephants develop small sores when they lie on cement floors. These sores develop into deep wounds when left untreated,” he said. Raghu said the owner had failed to provide any medication to heal the elephant.

Ramesh said only a couple of days ago he sent a letter to the TN chief wildlife warden, S Yuvaraj, who asked the Tirunelveli district forest officer to rescue the animal. On Thursday, a team of vets inspected the elephant and, on Friday, the district captive elephant welfare committee recommended that Jameela should be immediately shifted to the rehabilitation centre. On Sunday, the elephant was transported in a truck to the centre.

Tirunelveli district forest officer N Senthil Kumar, who supervised the shifting operation of Jameela, told TOI that a specially designed truck had been brought from Coimbatore to transport the elephant, which is the fifth to taken to the Trichy centre. First, three elephants belonging to the Kanchi temple, which were under the custody of a private centre at Marakkanam was shifted to Trichy following a Madras High Court order. Subsequently, Gomathi, a cow elephant belonging to Tharumapura Adheena Mutt, was sent there for rehabilitation. Jameela is the fifth inmate of the Trichy centre.
